fields.headline: Fiesta night for Chelsea
fields.standfirst:
Barcelona ripped apart by eight-minute blast from Zola and Flo
Zola 30; Flo 34, 38 | Figo 64
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: On one of the finest nights in the club's history, Chelsea proved beyond doubt that they can live with the very best in Europe. They scored three goals in eight minutes just before half-time to consign Barcelona to their first defeat in this season's competition.
fields.body:
On one of the finest nights in the club's history, Chelsea proved beyond doubt that they can live with the very best in Europe. They scored three goals in eight minutes just before half-time to consign Barcelona to their first defeat in this season's competition.

Although the Spanish take an away goal into the second leg, Gianluca Vialli's gallant team go to the Nou Camp with an outstanding chance of reaching the semi-finals.

Barcelona had begun the game with a confidence befitting a side on a run of nine wins in a row. And it took them only 14 minutes to cause the panic in the Chelsea defence which many pundits had predicted before kick-off. But a couple of crucial saves by Ed de Goey kept the Spanish at bay and by half-time Barcelona had seen the swank knocked out of their aristocratic stride.

A packed Stamford Bridge mixed disbelief with joy as the giant video screens flashed up a fantasy scoreline of 3-0. West London pinched itself and so did Barcelona.

Chelsea's first-half dominance was created by two factors. First their growing tenacity in the tackle, denying the Spanish team's legion of ball-players time to even start their party tricks.

The second ingredient in Chelsea's ascendancy was of Barcelona's own making. Their team are built for attack, with a three-man forward line firing the bullets. But the natural consequence of their urge to get forward is that they leave holes at the back. And Chelsea fully exploited the space.

First, though, the Premiership side were required to undergo an early test of their defensive character as Barcelona three times came close to scoring.

On 14 minutes Luis Figo, an early handful for Celestine Babayaro down the right, fed Rivaldo, whose shot was acrobatically saved by De Goey diving to his left.

A minute later the Dutch goalkeeper denied Garcia Gabri at the near post and then Emerson Thome, replacing the suspended Frank Leboeuf, brilliantly cleared Figo's cross as Patrick Kluivert dashed in.

On the half-hour Luis Figo was yellow carded for handball on the edge of the Barcelona area and Gianfranco Zola shaped to take the free-kick. He practises these every day on the training ground and the hours put in paid off as he bent a pearler over the wall and inside Ruud Hesp's right-hand post.

If Chelsea could not believe they were ahead, the sense of disbelief was doubled four minutes later as the former Barcelona player Albert Ferrer won the ball on the right and fed it down the line to Zola, whose cross was side-footed home by Tore Andre Flo.

Again the speed of the movement had caught Barcelona unawares, and the trick was repeated four minutes later. A hopeful ball hooked over the top by Didier Deschamps caught the Spanish back line flatfooted and Flo ran on to the ball before executing a delightful lob from 19 yards over the advancing Hesp.

Chelsea made the early running in the second half as the indefatigable Zola wriggled his way characteristically into the Barcelona area before going down under a challenge by Frank de Boer. But instead of winning a penalty, the referee rewarded the little Italian with a yellow card for diving.

Barcelona's attacks were unusually ragged, but on 64 minutes everything suddenly came together. A great through-ball split the Chelsea defence and found Rivaldo unmarked on the left. The world player of the year fired in a first-time cross and from close range Luis Figo nipped in front of Marcel Desailly to tuck the ball past De Goey. Barcelona had bagged a precious away goal.

 Valencia, beaten 3-0 by Barcelona in the Spanish league on Sunday, made amends last night by crushing Lazio 5-2 in the first leg of the other quarter-final.

Chelsea (4-4-2): De Goey; Ferrer, Thome, Desailly, Babayaro; Petrescu (Di Matteo, 72min), Deschamps, Morris, Wise; Zola, Flo (Sutton, 88).

Barcelona (4-3-3): Hesp; Puyol (Litmanen, h-t), Abelardo, F de Boer, Bogarde; Gabri, Xavi, Cocu; Figo, Kluivert (Dani, 72), Rivaldo.

Referee: M Merk (Germany).

webTitle: Vieira sees light as Lens come to town

fields.headline: Vieira sees light as Lens come to town
fields.trailText: Given that Lens are the visitors, Patrick Vieira can assume there will be no anti-French provocation tonight. Not that garlic jibes would bother him much these days. It sounded yesterday as if the midfielder could be kicked and abused and still spit only on the ground.
fields.body:
Given that Lens are the visitors, Patrick Vieira can assume there will be no anti-French provocation tonight. Not that garlic jibes would bother him much these days. It sounded yesterday as if the midfielder could be kicked and abused and still spit only on the ground.

Since his appalling behaviour at Upton Park in October, which earned him a six-match suspension and £45,000 fine, Vieira has looked a calmer, more effective player. Another four bookings confirm he is no Mary Poppins but his new patience, allied to the old spirit, could be vital against a defensive Lens. Much good ought to come out of his bad.

"He doesn't overreact any more," said Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger. "I've not seen one overreaction from him, even when sometimes you could understand. He has improved tremendously in his behaviour without losing his aggression. It's tremendous how he has done that.

"Before he was a bit more sensitive to things. He's convinced today he has to keep his concentration on the game and not be influenced by anything else. His concentration is better, his maturity is better and he goes into the game with a different target."

One of Vieira's targets is to change the way he is viewed by the public. He says it saddens him that people think first of his reputation rather than his football. But even after the incident at West Ham the 23-year-old was never tempted to leave. "That was a bad moment," he said, "but I didn't think I had to go back to France or to another country. I'm very happy here. I didn't want to change everything for a stupid thing like that.

"The manager talked to me about life in general and that's really helped me to calm down and improve my football."

So, had spitting at Neil Ruddock and swearing at a policeman proved a blessing in disguise? "He shouldn't have done that but he deserves a lot of respect for his reaction," Wenger said. "He accepted the punishment with dignity. He didn't come out and say it's not justified; he didn't cry. He said, 'I made a mistake and I will show I can change.' And that's what he has done."

Arsenal start clear favourites this evening, though they will miss the pace of the suspended Thierry Henry up front. A stormy 1-0 defeat by Lens at Wembley in last season's Champions League is a reminder not to relax against a much-changed, improving side who are 11th in the league but have knocked out Atletico Madrid and Celta Vigo.

Arsenal (4-4-2, probable): Seaman; Dixon, Luzhny, Keown, Silvinho; Parlour, Vieira, Petit, Overmars; Kanu, Bergkamp.

webTitle: Posh to square it with the Swans

fields.headline: Posh to square it with the Swans
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with the contact at the Old Trafford treatment table, offers his tips ahead of the weekend's action
fields.trailText: The Premiership card is a bit thin on the ground this weekend, but conditions look perfect for a big accumulator spread throughout the divisions. While most of the country looks towards Europe and Aintree, sneak in through the back door - starting at the Vetch Field, and Swansea's clash with Peterborough.
fields.body:
The Premiership card is a bit thin on the ground this weekend, but conditions look perfect for a big accumulator spread throughout the divisions. While most of the country looks towards Europe and Aintree, sneak in through the back door - starting at the Vetch Field, and Swansea's clash with Peterborough.

Posh are unbeaten in their last five visits to the Vetch and, despite going down 3-2 to the Swans at London Road near the start of the year, they should be backed to force the stalemate on Saturday. Posh drew 3-3 at home to Rochdale last week, but would have won in the dying minutes had Jason Lee not fluffed his penalty.

Swansea similarly shared the points with Brighton, but had enough chances to win the game and greeted the final whistle with disappointment rather than relief. Both teams have found victory elusive of late and this table-top cruncher looks unlikely to change that picture.

True enough, Peterborough's injury crisis looks bleak - Howard Forinton did his ankle in training and first team regulars Mark Tyler, Dean Hooper, Tony Shields and Francis Green are all still out of contention. However, the Swans have never looked more than mildly threatening up front all season (their success rests on a rock solid defence) and the visitors have enough in reserve to keep their hosts at bay. Expect a tight game.

In the Second Division Luton look good value at 2-1 with Hills to win away at Scunthorpe. The Irons went down 4-1 at Kenilworth Road earlier in the season and things could hardly look more desperate for them at the moment. The Hatters, on the other hand, will saunter into the clash on the back of a stirring 3-2 comeback victory over Colchester - Matthew Taylor's spectacular winner sealed it with less than ten minutes remaining. At the same time Scunthorpe were getting stuffed by Bury. The visitors should take this - unless complacency intervenes.

Ipswich have won 14 out of 16 matches at home to Port Vale and should be regarded as banker material in the First Division, even though they only managed a draw at struggling West Brom mid-week. Manchester City's recent successes should shake the home side into a winning frame of mind.

Up at the bottom of the top flight, Southampton can pick up three points at Bradford, who have lost their last two at home. The 11-5 at Hills looks especially generous. Glenn Hoddle's men created loads of chances in defeat against a massively improved Sunderland last week and can defeat a side whose shock win over Arsenal a month ago now looks like a flash in the pan.

Last Saturday Newcastle beat the Bantams without breaking sweat or ever looking too convincing. The Saints are, admittedly, awaiting the results of a scan on keeper Paul Jones's hamstring but that setback will be offset by Jamie Lawrence's absence for Bradford.

Everton have lost only one of their last five at Leicester and the clubs' last three Premiership meetings in the Midlands have produced two wins for the visitors. Evidently, Filbert Street will hold no fear for the Toffees on Saturday, especially now that Stan Collymore is out for the rest of the season after breaking his leg. Walter Smith can capitalise.

Finally, Derby's surprise defeat of Martin O'Neill's men last weekend should tee up an easy win against Watford at Vicarage Road. Fear of the drop is all the motivation the Rams will need.

For inclusion in your accumulators

Swansea v Peterborough - draw
Scunthorpe v Luton - away win
Ipswich v Port Vale - home win
Bradford v Southampton - away win
Leicester v Everton - away win
Watford v Derby - away win

fields.headline: Galatasaray crave Turkish delight
fields.standfirst: Europe is the main focus for Istanbul's top side despite their cash crisis
fields.trailText: Europe is the main focus for Istanbul's top side despite their cash crisis.
fields.body:
Leeds United have gained some fans here. Passionate supporters of Galatasaray's arch-rivals Fenerbahce have displayed banners during their last couple of games urging the Premiership side to thrash the old enemy from the other side of Istanbul.

They will be in a tiny minority tonight, though. Football is a consuming passion for many Turks and most are hoping that Galatasaray will become the first Turkish side to reach a European final. In a country of more than 60m desperate for football success, it has become an issue of national pride.

"If they beat Leeds," said Halil Ozer, who follows the team for the daily Milliyet, "most of Turkey will be singing in the streets for the next three days."

"It means everything to them," said Galatasaray's veteran Romanian midfielder Gheorghe Hagi. "The fans here go absolutely crazy."

When Galatasaray reached this stage, telegrams of congratulation poured in from politicians and business leaders. Small cafes and bars planning to show the Leeds game on cable TV expect long queues and standing room only tonight.

At the Ali Sami Yen stadium the club's fanatical support will give Leeds a hot reception, but at Galatasaray's training ground this week there was only an air of quiet confidence.

Their coach Fatih Terim, who led the national side to Euro 96 in England, said it was time for Turkish club football to take a big step forward.

"Coaches always want too much," he said with a grin, "but if we can win this game we will be very close to the final."

Galatasaray have dominated the domestic game here this season. They are six points clear at the top of the First Division and overwhelming favourites to win the Turkish Cup. But, like Leeds, they have stumbled in their past two matches, losing at home to Fenerbahce and managing only a goalless draw against lowly Erzurumspor.

But Europe has been the stage for their most dramatic exploits. In the past Turkish teams have suffered from an inferiority complex when they faced clubs from the major European leagues. But no longer. Victories over Milan, Borussia Dortmund and Real Mallorca have convinced Galatasaray they need fear no one.

Their most embarrassing defeat, though, was against English opposition when they lost 5-0 at home to Chelsea in the first phase of the Champions League. "That was a one-off," said Terim, wincing at the memory. "The Chelsea result will have no effect on the way we approach the Leeds game."

A quick glance at the team sheet shows the potential Galatasaray have, if they can protect a sometimes suspect defence. Many of Turkey's best players, such as the striker Hakan Sukur, are joined by some well known foreigners: Hagi, his compatriot Gheorghe Popescu, the former Tottenham player, and Brazil's World Cup goalkeeper Claudio Taffarel.

Success has come at a price, though, and Galatasaray are reported to be millions of pounds in debt. Terim is among those considering his future if the finances are not sorted out soon, but for the moment the focus is on Europe.

At 35, Hagi is slower than he used to be but he is still capable of conjuring spectacular goals. He has a feel for the big occasion and may produce something special tonight.

"We know it will be a difficult game against Leeds," he said this week. "But we have to win. For ourselves and for the fans. This is our moment."

webTitle: Anelka back in the Real world

fields.headline: Anelka back in the Real world
fields.trailText: Nicolas Anelka resumed full training with Real Madrid yesterday after serving 22 days of a 45-day suspension for missing three days of training.
fields.body:
Nicolas Anelka resumed full training with Real Madrid yesterday after serving 22 days of a 45-day suspension for missing three days of training.

The 21-year-old Frenchman, whose suspension was lifted after a public apology, said he "didn't know" if he had made peace with his team-mates or when he would be selected to play again, but hoped to feature in the second leg of the Champions League quarter-final against Manchester United at Old Trafford the week after next.

"He was received as normal like any other day and like any other player," said Real's defender Ivan Helguera.

Germany's head coach Erich Ribbeck, recently criticised by the Bayern Munich player Jens Jeremies, insisted yesterday that he knew exactly what he was doing.

"I'm not an idiot," he claimed. "I'm being described as somebody who does not know what he wants. I know exactly what I want and that is to put together the best possible team."

Carlos Roa, Argentina's World Cup goalkeeper who retired last year saying that the world was going to end in January, has reviewed the situation globally and decided it is safe to come out of retirement and return to Real Mallorca's first team.

fields.headline: City of London Sinfonia
fields.standfirst:
City of London Sinfonia/ Richard Hickox
***
Barbican Hall, London
fields.trailText: Celebrating Aaron Copland's centenary in tandem with playing works by Stravinsky makes perfect sense. Of all the ingredients that went into the making of the American's style, that of Stravinsky's neoclassicism was easily the most persistent.
fields.body:
Celebrating Aaron Copland's centenary in tandem with playing works by Stravinsky makes perfect sense. Of all the ingredients that went into the making of the American's style, that of Stravinsky's neoclassicism was easily the most persistent.

The central panel of Richard Hickox's series with the City of London Sinfonia brought the two composers together. Copland's ballet Appalachian Spring is a masterpiece, and if he had written nothing else of significance, we would celebrating his centenary for the sake of that miraculous score alone.

The two Stravinsky works - the concerto Dumbarton Oaks and Danses Concertantes - are more or less contemporary with Appalachian Spring, but this music of the late 30s and early 40s needs to be presented with real punch and flair if it isn't to come across as a caricature of sewing-machine neo-baroque. Danses Concertantes in particular needs more characterful wind playing and more adroit strings than Hickox generated here.

The Copland was a little surer. Pamela Helen Stephen sang five of the Old American Songs in their orchestral garb, and Michael Collins stamped his personality on the Clarinet Concerto, with suave suggestiveness in the Satie-esque opening movement and pyrotechnic brilliance in the second, though the question of whether the work really hangs together was never satisfactorily answered. Appalachian Spring came as the abridged concert version, which was fine, but in an unsatisfactory hybrid orchestration, which was not. Everything was unwieldy, and what should have danced and sung was flattened.

The two Stravinsky works - the concerto Dumbarton Oaks and Danses Concertantes - are more or less contemporary with Appalachian Spring, but this music of the late 30s and early 40s needs to be presented with real punch and flair if it isn't to come across as a caricature of sewing-machine neo-baroque. Danses Concertantes in particular needs more characterful wind playing and more adroit strings than Hickox generated here. The Copland was a little surer. Pamela Helen Stephen sang five of the Old American Songs in their orchestral garb, and Michael Collins stamped his personality on the Clarinet Concerto, with suave suggestiveness in the Satie-esque opening movement and pyrotechnic brilliance in the second, though the question of whether the work really hangs together was never satisfactorily answered. Appalachian Spring came as the abridged concert version, which was fine, but in an unsatisfactory hybrid orchestration, which was not. Everything was unwieldy, and what should have danced and sung was flattened.

fields.headline: Unsexy symbol
fields.standfirst:
Puff Daddy
NEC, Birmingham
*
At Manchester Arena (0161-930 8000) tonight and Wembley Arena (0181-902 0902) tomorrow and Saturday. This review appeared in some editions yesterday
fields.trailText: There is an interesting irony about the scenes on the perimeter of the NEC in the build-up to the first date of Puff Daddy's UK tour: everywhere you look, young women seem to be unhappy.
fields.body:
There is an interesting irony about the scenes on the perimeter of the NEC in the build-up to the first date of Puff Daddy's UK tour: everywhere you look, young women seem to be unhappy. Teenagers travel in packs of four, three squabbling baseball-capped male suitors to one unimpressed female. Elsewhere, a girl speaks into her mobile phone, warning her boyfriend that it's the last time he cheats on her. Surely Puff Daddy, an artist marketed as a love god and renowned for putting women above all his other worldly desires (vintage cars, white fur, diamonds), would not be happy to witness this.

You arrive at Puff Daddy's show anticipating monumental sexual chemistry. In the event, it is only really there in the shrill, electrifying moments (some five minutes) when the stage is lit up but Puff Daddy is not actually on it. Upon arrival, he attempts to sustain the atmosphere by throwing around ultra-loud gunpowder and nostalgia-exploiting samples. Not only does Puff Daddy get his second-hand material from the most unimaginative sources (the blockbuster single I'll Be Missing You ripped the chorus from Every Breath You Take); most of his actual rapping merely consists of reworking the chorus to a well-known song (Shaft, We Will Rock You). This, clearly, is what a New York subway graffiti artist was referring to when he wrote that Puff Daddy killed hip-hop.

Puff Daddy has assured his fans that his recent personal problems will not affect his live performance, but how could they, when he reveals so little of himself on stage? If the booming sound system failed and he ran out of gunpowder, he would probably be wandering around like a lost puppy. His input is pathetically small, and his presence disappointingly innocuous. Most of the boyfriends in the crowd would make better sex symbols.

The girls just about managed to keep screaming, but all you could see in their eyes was Puff Daddy's empty greed reflected back, nothing you could compare to the burning desire of female Beatlemaniacs and Osmonds fans. You can't help wondering if they know that all they are applauding is big, dumb power that does not know quite what to do with itself.

fields.headline: Banks' mega-merger is off
fields.standfirst:
Dresdner accuses Deutsche of breaking spirit of deal over Kleinwort Benson

Dresdner Bank
fields.trailText: Plans to create the world's biggest bank collapsed abruptly yesterday, lifting the threat of heavy job losses in the City.
fields.body:
Plans to create the world's biggest bank collapsed abruptly yesterday, lifting the threat of heavy job losses in the City.

Germany's Dresdner Bank angrily called off its proposed £20bn merger with Deutsche Bank, blaming the latter's insistence that the Dresdner Kleinwort Benson investment bank should be sold off - whole or in parts - for its decision to halt the negotiations.

There was considerable relief that the deal, which had promised very substantial jobs losses at Kleinwort - more than 2,000 on some estimates - had been scrapped. But there was concern about the residual uncertainty over the investment bank's future.

"The number of people in negotiations to go elsewhere is enormous which means you cannot put this in a box and say nothing has happened," said one insider. There have already been a number of high profile departures - a team of seven to Salomon Smith Barney - while TJ Lim, its co-head of global markets, resigned this week.

Under the terms of the original deal, Kleinwort was to have been integrated into the merged bank but Deutsche subsequently sought to have the business sold off. Yesterday there were reports that it would accept integration only if Kleinwort bore the brunt of the job cuts.

According to Dresdner: "Deutsche Bank refused to integrate Dresdner Kleinwort Benson in a balanced way in accordance with the wording and the spirit of the agreed terms. The behaviour of Deutsche Bank resulted in a loss of confidence in the planned merger."

Dresdner last night pledged that it would keep the investment bank. "Just as there was no intention to sell it over the last four weeks, there is no intention to sell it now," said Gerd Häusler, the chairman of the investment bank's managing board.

Deutsche's chief executive, Rolf Breuer, said his board regretted Dresdner's decision to call off the merger but said its opposition to the sale of all or part of Kleinwort "called the logic of the deal into question".

This is the second time efforts to bring the two German banks together have failed. Last year talks about merging their retail businesses collapsed.

Scrapping the merger is bound to raise speculation that Dresdner will have to seek another partner. The Bavaria-based HypoVereinsbank, Germany's second largest bank, is likely to be favourite for the role, though independently minded Commerzbank - number four in Germany - may also be seen as a possible Dresdner partner. There are also suggestions that one or more of the US banks could be interested now that the merger has been called off.

One big loser from the collapse of the talks will be Munich insurer Allianz. It is a big shareholder in both banks and was widely regarded as the driving force behind the merger proposal. It would have acquired a large stake in the two banks' combined retail banking operations as well as Deutsche's highly regarded DWS fund management business.

When trading in the shares of all three companies, which had been suspended yesterday pending the announcement of the merger's collapse, resumed shares in the two banks rose 3% but those of Allianz fell more than 10%.

Analysts were divided over the impact of the failure of the talks. Some argued that it meant Germany had missed a chance to restructure its banking sector but others said the deal was doomed because of the difficulties of delivering the savings promised.

webTitle: 'Lots of investors should be counting their lucky stars for being unable to trade'

fields.headline: 'Lots of investors should be counting their lucky stars for being unable to trade'
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: For online stock market punters it was a long wait for the power to be switched on yesterday, so the time was spent swapping conspiracy theories and jokes on the dozens of internet bulletin boards which operate as a rumour mill for private investors.
fields.body:
For online stock market punters it was a long wait for the power to be switched on yesterday, so the time was spent swapping conspiracy theories and jokes on the dozens of internet bulletin boards which operate as a rumour mill for private investors.

Far from being disgruntled about their end-of-tax-year plans being thrown into chaos, many investors were relieved that the market had closed for most of the day following Tuesday's dot.com movements, when share prices gyrated wildly and fears spread that the so-called internet bubble might be about to burst.

"At least with the market closed I wasn't losing any money," said Rob Yates, one of the investors contributing to the iii (Interactive Investor International) website yesterday.

Alex Banks, a 21-year-old tech stocks investor, said: "The shutdown was a blessing in disguise and lots of investors should be counting their lucky stars. It gave everyone the ability to stand back and take the time to rationally analyse the situation. I think lots of investors are actually better-off having been unable to trade for most of the day."

Mr Banks, a student at Cardiff University who trades about twice a week, added: "Tomorrow is another day and the institutions will be buying back in, due to the new financial year. With luck this will turn people's losses into small gains."

Another investor, a trainee solicitor, said he had never been more relieved to hear the market couldn't open "considering my appalling performance yesterday [Tuesday]. At least with the market closed I can't make the wrong trades."

There were various conspiracy theories as to the cause of the computer glitch, with one iii chatroom contributor claiming hackers had broken into the computer on Tuesday night.

Another, "Henry the Investor", joked that the fiasco suggested that "maybe tech stocks are a good investment after all," because the Stock Exchange was clearly in need of some expert technical assistance.

While many were making light of the collapse, Jason Hollands at the investment broker Best Investment said the shutdown would nevertheless have caused problems for many.

"Investors wanting to crystallise capital gains in order to make use of their 1999/2000 tax allowances have been caught out by the technical problems. This is doubly embarrassing for the London Stock Exchange after the announcement of further merger talks with Frankfurt and comes at a very sensitive time for investors who were expecting London tech stocks to follow yesterday's volatility in Nasdaq."

fields.headline: Firmly rooted in the City
fields.standfirst:
BT
British Airways
Dresdner Bank
fields.trailText: Although its roots can be traced back more than 200 years, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson itself is still several months short of its fifth birthday. It was formed in the summer of 1995, when Dresdner Bank joined the rush of mainland European banks flocking to the Square Mile flourishing their chequebooks.
fields.body:
Although its roots can be traced back more than 200 years, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson itself is still several months short of its fifth birthday. It was formed in the summer of 1995, when Dresdner Bank joined the rush of mainland European banks flocking to the Square Mile flourishing their chequebooks.

Dresdner paid £1bn for Kleinwort Benson, one of the best known City names.

Kleinwort Benson was a well established bank, although only formed in 1961 when Kleinwort,Sons & Co merged with Robert Benson, Lonsdale to form Kleinwort Benson Lonsdale , later to become known as the Kleinwort Benson group.

During the 1980s Kleinwort Benson, along with a number of City merchant banks, was closely involved the government's privatisation programme, advising on the BA , BT and British Gas floats.

The merger with Dresdner's investment banking business turned Kleinwort Benson into a full service bank, but the UK arm retained a strong reputation in corporate finance.

One suggestion was that if the bank had been dismembered the corporate finance side was the area of the business most likely to be kept.

The merger of Dresdner and Kleinwort Benson did not proceed entirely smoothly. In 1997 the chairman of Kleinwort Benson, Simon Robertson , resigned amid differences over integrating the Frankfurt and London operations. The investment bank employs 7,500, just fewer than half of them in London.

webTitle: C&N unfazed by Thomson bid rejection

fields.headline: C&N unfazed by Thomson bid rejection
fields.trailText: German travel group C&N Touristic yesterday piled more pressure on Britain's beleaguered Thomson Travel, signalling that it would pursue a hostile takeover despite having its initial bid rejected out of hand.
fields.body:
German travel group C&N Touristic yesterday piled more pressure on Britain's beleaguered Thomson Travel, signalling that it would pursue a hostile takeover despite having its initial bid rejected out of hand.

On Tuesday Thomson, Britain's biggest travel operator, said no to C&N's £1.3bn offer labelling it "wholly inadequate" and ruling out future talks with what is Germany's second largest travel firm.

But C&N said yesterday it was confident of victory.

The German media, scenting a rematch of the Vodafone-Mannesmann merger battle, has also entered the war of words. The country's leading tabloid, Bild, has scarcely been able to conceal its delight at such an apparently swift reversal of fortune, and is predicting a C&N victory.

"In England they're already worrying about Germans flying them on their holidays and giving them the bad seats. Sorry, Britain, we've won the towel war," it crowed.

C&N, a 50:50 joint venture between Lufthansa and retailer Karstadt Quelle, has yet to raise its bid price but investors expect an improved offer within a few days. On Tuesday it raised its stake in Thomson to 4.8%, sparking a rally in the travel group's depressed shares which surged by more than 30% after languishing at around 92p all year.

If its bid succeeds C&N will become Europe's top travel operator, unseating arch-rival Preussag AG and gaining a strong foothold in the UK market. It would be the biggest British travel agent by revenue and the second largest in both Germany and Scandinavia.

Thomson's pre-tax profits to December 31 1999 slumped by 38% to £77m, against £124.4m in 1998.

webTitle: 'Madness' to raise rates as output and house prices dip

fields.headline: 'Madness' to raise rates as output and house prices dip
fields.trailText: The Bank of England came under mounting pressure to save Britain's struggling manufacturers from a fifth interest-rate increase in eight months as fresh evidence showed factory output falling, house prices falling and high-street spending failing to meet retailers' expectations.
fields.body:
The Bank of England came under mounting pressure to save Britain's struggling manufacturers from a fifth interest-rate increase in eight months as fresh evidence showed factory output falling, house prices falling and high-street spending failing to meet retailers' expectations.

Although separate data showed activity in the service sector at its highest for almost three years, trade unions and employers urged the Bank's monetary policy committee not to inflict further pain on exporters by lifting rates from their current level of 6% today.

Peter Booth, the national organiser for manufacturing at the T&G union said the strength of the pound had been a key factor in the loss of 400,000 manufacturing jobs over the past 12 months, while Kate Barker, the chief economist at the CBI said there was strong evidence that industry was failing to cope with the high exchange rate.

The former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke said in an interview with the Guardian that the Bank would be "mad" to raise rates, adding that the least the MPC could do would be to leave rates on hold. "They have already raised rates quite a lot and sterling is now becoming a serious medium-term problem."

Mr Clarke accused both the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the governor of the Bank, Eddie George, of not knowing what to do about sterling's persistently high levels which are dramatically hurting exports and the balance of payments.

"There is a threat hanging over Dagenham where Ford are at least set to cut production, a threat to Honda at Swindon as well as the crisis at Longbridge. But this is only the visible tip of a big iceberg," said Mr Clarke.

Official government figures released yesterday showed that manufacturing output fell by 0.2% in February, the third consecutive fall.

Factory production in the three months to February was down by 0.5% on the previous quarter, with some analysts saying that the pre-millennium boost in output was a false dawn.

The CBI said retail sales volumes were higher last month than a year ago, but that shops and stores had been disappointed by the level of activity. Some 44% of retailers said sales were higher than in March 1999, while 21% said they were lower. The gap of 23 percentage points was well down on the 47-point gap in February.

Meanwhile, the Halifax - Britain's biggest mortgage lender - said house prices fell by 0.4% in March. The second monthly fall brought the annual rate of increase down from 15% to 13.5%. An earlier survey by the Nationwide said prices were rising more rapidly than at any time for nine years, but the Halifax said the market was starting to cool.

City analysts believe that today's decision is too close to call, with the problems of manufacturing offset by strong growth in the sheltered service sector.

The Chartered Institute of Purchasing & Supply said yesterday that business activity in services had expanded for 13 months, with growth accelerating last month.

Employment had also picked up, as did prices, the CIPS added.

webTitle: Interest rates: the Bank postpones the inevitable

fields.headline: Interest rates: the Bank postpones the inevitable
fields.standfirst:
Guardian economics reporter Charlotte Denny on the reasons behind the bank's decision to keep interest rate the same

Money Unlimited special report
fields.trailText: Thursday, 12.45pm: Guardian economics reporter Charlotte Denny on the reasons behind the bank's decision to keep interest rate the same
fields.body:
Of all their recent decisions on interest rates, this was probably the one which kept the members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee tossing and turning in their beds last night. Which ever way they jumped - upping rates to keep inflation under control as is their mandate from the government, or keeping rates on hold to ease some of the pressure on sterling - they were bound to be come under fire.

The Bank has decided - as widely expected - to keep interest rates on stable at 6%. But they will face criticism today for bowing to industry concern about the pound's strength rather than keeping their eye on their main target: the gathering speed of the economy which some analysts fear will spark renewed price pressures.

The numbers suggest the Bank has won its battle against inflation. The underlying measure of how fast retail prices are growing has been below the Bank's 2.5% target for nearly a year. Britain now has the lowest inflation rate in the European Union - a remarkable achievement given the UK's history of period of rampant price acceleration.

But many economists believe that after recovering from last year's stagnation, the economy is now growing unsustainably fast and that price pressures are bound to re-emerge.

Having raised rates four times since last September the Bank has been dismayed to see that there have been few signs of a slowdown. The economy grew by 3% between the last quarter of 1998 and the same point in 1999.

Most people would see that as a cause for celebration. But economics is not called the dismal science for nothing. For the nine members of the monetary policy committee, that's a sign that demand is outstripping the economy's capacity to supply goods and services.

Luckily for the Bank, the extraordinary rise of sterling against other world currencies has kept price pressures in the domestic economy under control - so far. The pound's strength has made imported goods and raw materials cheaper. But while consumers benefit from lower prices on the high street, manufacturers feel the pinch. It is harder for them to sell their goods overseas because they are more expensive, while at home they face competition from cheap foreign products.

This month, the Bank appears to have gone for a wait-and-see approach. Since it last met, a month ago, the pound has remained at its record levels against the euro, while there are some signs in forward looking indicators that some of the fizz may be going out of the economy. House prices, blamed for fuelling a consumer spending spree in the South East, have fallen for the past two months. However, the MPC may be simply postponing the inevitable higher interest rates. Next month they publish their quarterly assessment of the prospects for inflation. If Threadneedle Street's number crunchers believe price pressures are rising, so too will the cost of borrowing.

But many economists believe that after recovering from last year's stagnation, the economy is now growing unsustainably fast and that price pressures are bound to re-emerge. Having raised rates four times since last September the Bank has been dismayed to see that there have been few signs of a slowdown. The economy grew by 3% between the last quarter of 1998 and the same point in 1999. Most people would see that as a cause for celebration. But economics is not called the dismal science for nothing. For the nine members of the monetary policy committee, that's a sign that demand is outstripping the economy's capacity to supply goods and services. Luckily for the Bank, the extraordinary rise of sterling against other world currencies has kept price pressures in the domestic economy under control - so far. The pound's strength has made imported goods and raw materials cheaper. But while consumers benefit from lower prices on the high street, manufacturers feel the pinch. It is harder for them to sell their goods overseas because they are more expensive, while at home they face competition from cheap foreign products. This month, the Bank appears to have gone for a wait-and-see approach. Since it last met, a month ago, the pound has remained at its record levels against the euro, while there are some signs in forward looking indicators that some of the fizz may be going out of the economy. House prices, blamed for fuelling a consumer spending spree in the South East, have fallen for the past two months. However, the MPC may be simply postponing the inevitable higher interest rates. Next month they publish their quarterly assessment of the prospects for inflation. If Threadneedle Street's number crunchers believe price pressures are rising, so too will the cost of borrowing.

fields.headline: Power and minimalism
fields.standfirst:
Danilo Perez
Dean Street Pizza Express, London
****
Until Saturday. Box office: 0171-439 8722
fields.trailText: Despite his flamboyant character, the young Panamanian pianist Danilo Perez has been happy to share the limelight with jazz giants such as Dizzy Gillespie and Roy Haynes. For these leaders, Perez has often played a supportive rhythmic and harmonic role.
fields.body:
Despite his flamboyant character, the young Panamanian pianist Danilo Perez has been happy to share the limelight with jazz giants such as Dizzy Gillespie and Roy Haynes. For these leaders, Perez has often played a supportive rhythmic and harmonic role. But he is unleashing his full formidable talent at Pizza Express this week. He is aided by the eloquent young bassist Carlos Henriquez (whose long sonorities and flamenco-like strumming sometimes recall Charlie Haden) and the tireless and resourceful drummer Antonio Sanchez.

Adapting to Perez's fondness for frequent tempo changes (also a habit of Chick Corea's, and one that can lose its fascination in large doses), Sanchez's playing is a fascinating mixture of power and minimalism. He stitched together a rich rhythmic tapestry out of fragments of many drum techniques. Straightahead cymbal beats were delivered only in glimpses, flickering tom-tom accents surfaced and van ished, short bursts of Latin hand-drumming suddenly turned to furious polyrhythmic thrashes. Sanchez wound up Perez's third tune on Tuesday with just such a dazzling display, and threw in a simultaneous hi-hat and pedal- powered cowbell counter-rhythm for good measure. The tension between Sanchez's drumming and the pianist's swerves toward and away from the beat was at the centre of the band's appeal.

Perez's trio played a single unbroken set, which enabled the music to take on a coherent shape, its textures characteristically uniting Panamanian influences and the jazz mainstream. Folksy accordion-like music played on a blown mini-keyboard gave way to fast Latin rumbles, with Perez's long, bold bar-jumping lines imparting freshness to these familiar idioms. This time, the pianist's frequent tributes to Thelonious Monk were represented by Think of One. Perez hid the theme for a long time, then slipped it in and out of an exclamatory Latin groove, ending with an explosive three-way collective blast.

The intensity gave way to a piano tone-poem devoted to Panama. This would have been exquisite as mimicry of birdcalls and street dances, but turned instead into You Don't Know What Love Is. But this is a fine, cooperative band, giving everything it knows.

fields.headline: Computers halt the City
fields.trailText: City regulators last night launched an investigation into the running of the London stock exchange after the stock market was paralysed by its worst ever computer system failure.
fields.body:
City regulators last night launched an investigation into the running of the London stock exchange after the stock market was paralysed by its worst ever computer system failure.

On a day when thousands of private investors were flooding into the market to carry out trades ahead of last night's midnight tax deadline for the financial year end, business in the City was delayed by almost eight hours.

A problem, blamed on "corrupt data," led to the supply of all share price and company news being cut off first thing in the morning, and was only rectified late in the afternoon. This led to an emergency extension of share trading hours to 8pm as stockbrokers struggled to catch up with the backlog of trades.

The Financial Services Authority, the watchdog charged with overseeing City markets, issued a rebuke, stating that any necessary changes to computer and back-up systems would have to be made immediately. The watchdog added that lessons would be "learned rapidly and made public."

While the exchange's chief executive, Gavin Casey, issued a public apology, tempers were heated in the Square Mile yesterday as traders found themselves locked out of the market as share prices around the world are threatening to crash.

The past few days have seen unprecedented volatility in the world's markets as fears have grown that the boom in internet and technology-related companies is coming to a premature end. The popularity of dot.com companies and the growth of online share dealing, has turned hundreds of thousands of British investors into amateur speculators.

fields.headline: Warning, boys at play
fields.standfirst:
Cressida
Albery Theatre, London
****
Until June 10. Box office: 0171-369 1740. This review appeared in some editions yesterday
fields.trailText: Three years ago the Old Vic staged an excellent play by April de Angelis, Playhouse Creatures, about the first generation of Restoration actresses. Now Nicholas Wright has written an equally enjoyable play, set in the 1630s, about the boy players they supplanted.
fields.body:
Three years ago the Old Vic staged an excellent play by April de Angelis, Playhouse Creatures, about the first generation of Restoration actresses. Now Nicholas Wright has written an equally enjoyable play, set in the 1630s, about the boy players they supplanted. If de Angelis's pioneer actresses were the victims of aristocratic patrons, Wright's cross-dressing boys are no less at the mercy of backstage politics.

Part of the charm of Wright's play lies in its glowing, detailed, unsentimental account of London's Caroline theatre. He focuses on John Shank, who runs a school of boy players and is a mixture of trainer, talent scout and thespian Fagin. But Shank, once a bit of a boy star himself, is now a ruined Titan massively in debt. Forced to trade in his props and costumes, he is trying to sell off his latest apprentice, Stephen Hammerton. Though the boy is a hopeless case, Shank hopes to turn him into a passable Cressida. By increasing the boy's market value, Shank becomes aware of his own lost talent as a tutor.

Wright vividly depicts the grubby heartlessness of Caroline theatre: boy actors were as much commodities as today's soccer stars, had a short theatrical life and were often abandoned by their families. Yet, while painting a graphic historical picture, Wright also draws parallels between Caroline and contemporary theatre. Managers vie for talent, people worry over whether scenery is stifling imagination and theatre folk combine camaraderie and competitiveness while harking back to a golden age.

Theatre itself becomes a metaphor for human transience. But there is an exuberant pathos to Wright's play that is perfectly matched by Michael Gambon's John Shank. The great moment in his performance comes when he tries to teach his protege how to play Cressida. Suddenly Gambon's shambling ursine lope is replaced by a skipping gait and his whole being lightens as he tries to transmit his stored-up knowledge: it is a classic bit of acting based on the ecstasy of memory.

Gambon is marvellously supported by Michael Legge as Stephen and Malcolm Sinclair as a predatory artistic patron. Nicholas Hytner's Almeida Company production also combines the historical past and the metaphorical present exactly like Wright's play.

webTitle: As Barclays closes 172 branches, the boss stands to collect a £30m bonus

fields.headline: As Barclays closes 172 branches, the boss stands to collect a £30m bonus
fields.trailText: Barclays was embroiled in fresh controversy last night with the revelation that its chief executive stands to earn £30m in bonus payments.
fields.body:
Barclays was embroiled in fresh controversy last night with the revelation that its chief executive stands to earn £30m in bonus payments.

The disclosure of Matthew Barrett's performance pay package is certain to add to the outcry against the bank, which plans to axe 172 of its branches tomorrow.

The proposals have triggered unprecedented calls for a boycott of the bank by the environment minister, Chris Mullin.

Barclays admits that its shareholders have already attacked the bank's complex share options bonus scheme for senior managers.

And Pirc, a pensions and investment research company which advises fund managers on how to invest £250bn every year, intends to tell its clients to oppose the new bonus payment plan when they are asked for their approval at the bank's annual general meeting later this month.

Details of Barclays new bonus scheme were sent out to its shareholders last week.

Mr Barrett, whose annual income already exceeds £6m, joined Barclays as chief executive just seven months ago.

According to an analysis by Meis, an executive compensation company which conducts research for the National Association of Pension Funds, the terms of the complicated new bonus scheme means that top managers could receive options on shares worth up to 36 times their basic salary each year if they meet all the performance criteria.

This suggests that Mr Barrett, who is on a basic salary of £850,000, could be awarded options which would be worth £30.5m if Barclays meets its own targets.

Last night Barclays insisted that the complex terms of a new long-term incentive scheme for senior executives were being "misrepresented".

Peter Hawker, director of compensation and benefits at the bank, admitted that the intricacy of the plan had prompted questions from leading shareholders, but insisted that Barclays had no plans to rewrite the six page "incentive share option plan".

Alan MacDougall, managing director of Pirc, said that while he had yet to receive any comments on its recommendation from the bank, parts of the plan did not meet industry standards and in some instances were "insufficiently" stretching for top managers.

The scheme, which was sent to the bank's shareholders last week, has prompted the Association of British Insurers, the industry lobby group, to raise questions with Barclays about its structure.

Michael McKersie, manager of investment affairs at the ABI, while not endorsing the 36 times calculation, said: "Various points will need to be clarified to reach a full conclusion about the cost of the scheme.

"The potential awards appear high by UK standards and shareholders will want to ensure that the targets are genuinely demanding."

The terms of the reward scheme are complicated but allow for top executives to be awarded options worth a maximum of twice their salary and bonus. These are then allocated in two potential ways - one based on the "economic profit" of the group, the other on the way its shares relate to a peer group of 12.

While long-term performance schemes are common among major firms, and recommended by industry watchdogs, Barclays is also proposing to introduce a new way of valuing the options granted to executives - a system most commonly used in the US.

Mr Hawker disputed the calculations on a number of grounds, and insisted that it was impossible to value of the options because it would not be possible to know what the bank's share price would be worth in three years time, when the payouts would be calculated.

Salary experts say that the complicated new pay scheme, which Mr Barrett said earlier this year would see a "higher risk of no pay out", resembled pay deals which are more common in north America, the pay of senior managers is increasingly linked to the performance of the company.

fields.headline: Meltdown at the stock exchange
fields.standfirst: Market chief's future bleak as systems failure halts trading for eight hours on what was likely to be busiest day
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange came to an embarrassing and hugely expensive halt yesterday as a computer breakdown meant City traders were unable to deal for almost eight hours. On the last day of the financial year, problems with "corrupt data" stranded tens of thousands of investors on what was expected to be one of the busiest trading sessions of all time.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange came to an embarrassing and hugely expensive halt yesterday as a computer breakdown meant City traders were unable to deal for almost eight hours. On the last day of the financial year, problems with "corrupt data" stranded tens of thousands of investors on what was expected to be one of the busiest trading sessions of all time.

Gavin Casey, its chief executive, was forced to issue a grovelling apology, but his future looked bleak last night.

The financial services authority which regulates the City issued a withering statement saying the breakdown was a "serious matter that requires a prompt and thorough response", and stockbrokers throughout the Square Mile poured scorn on the stock market authorities.

"It is a bloody disgrace," one broker declared. "When we have come close [to a breakdown] in the past those responsible have behaved like gentlemen and fallen on their swords. But then in the City perhaps we don't have many gentlemen anymore."

It was almost 4pm by the time the exchange's computer systems were patched up sufficiently to allow trading to resume. The market's usual trading session was immediately extended from 4.30 to 6.30. Later, as it emerged that stockbrokers and investors were still queuing up to execute thousands of trades, the dealing period was extended again to 8pm in an attempt to clear the backlog.

Frustration and anger was compounded by the fact that hordes of private client investors, who have flocked to the stock market over recent months to speculate on dot.com companies and other technology-related shares, were unable to use their final chance to execute trades for tax purposes as the financial year came to a close. The exchange's computer systems failed just as share prices around the world were gyrating and investment pundits were predicting that the internet share boom may have come to a premature end.

On Tuesday, technology-related shares in the US, as measured by the Nasdaq index, fell by 13% at one stage. There were similar falls in London before yesterday's sudden freeze, which left many investors unable to realise large gains built up over the last few months.

Officially, the year-end deadline for tax purposes came to an end at midnight last night, but urgent discussions were under way about whether shares trades transacted late into the evening yesterday would still count.

"We very much regret the disruption that market users have experienced during the course of the day," Mr Casey said. "As a result of today's breakdown, extensive work is being undertaken not only to ensure that the immediate problem has been resolved satisfactorily, but to take whatever additional steps are required to ensure that the system is robust and reliable for the future."

Such paralysis has never been witnessed before in the London market, the closest example being October 16 1987, when the hurricane resulted in so few City workers getting to their desks that the exchange shut early. The following week, the stock market suffered its biggest fall in living memory - Black Monday.

Yesterday's system failure could not have come at a worse time for the exchange. It is facing a new and potentially terminal threat from rival purely-electronic exchanges, such as an organisation called Tradepoint in the UK and the Nasdaq market in the US, which is planning to launch a pan-European stock exchange, allowing investors to avoid using national bourses across the continent.

It has also emerged that previous talks between the London market and its counterpart in Frankfurt, Deutsche Borse, about an alliance have developed into full-blown merger discussions as the two institutions seek to protect their business from rivals. The apparent weakness in London's computerised trading system has led to speculation that the German market authorities will take a lead in establishing this new Anglo-German market - a move that could undermine London's status as Europe's pre-eminent financial centre.

For ordinary investors, the damage was more immediate. Private client stockbrokers were swamped with orders but were unable to execute many of these, even after trading formally got under way late in the afternoon. There were accusations that market makers - the City firms who act as wholesalers in share transactions - were refusing to pick up their telephones to complete orders. Traders were also unable to trust share prices appearing on their screens, adding to the chaos.

"Everyone is losing money. Clients are dealing blind, taking the wrong prices for stock. City firms are sitting on trading positions which they are unable to unwind. The recriminations are going to go on for weeks," one frustrated broker said.

webTitle: Gates offered fast-track to supreme court

fields.headline: Gates offered fast-track to supreme court
fields.standfirst:
Judge to announce Microsoft penalty within 60 days

Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft and the US government yesterday agreed to wrap up the landmark anti-monopolies case.
fields.body:
Microsoft and the US government yesterday agreed to wrap up the landmark anti-monopolies case.

Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson wants to conclude the trial by ruling within 60 days on an appropriate punishment for Microsoft's illegal behaviour. He called for a "genuine fast track" after ruling that Microsoft had broken US anti-trust laws.

Lawyers for Microsoft and the US justice department met yesterday with the judge to discuss penalties the company could face.

This could mean that the outcome could be announced as soon as June. This "fast track" approach - which the justice department has agreed to - could include the unusual step of any appeal going straight to the supreme court, bypassing one stage of the appeals process, with a final decision by the end of the year.

Judge Jackson told both sides: "My objective is to get this thing before an appellate tribunal quickly."

The judgment against Microsoft for bundling its internet browser with its dominant Windows software contradicts an earlier appeals court ruling.

Companies such as Sun Microsystems and hundreds of individuals are also keen to see a swift conclusion to a case that could form the basis of their own lawsuits against Microsoft.

Yesterday's meeting between the company, the justice department and representatives of the 19 US states that brought the complaint was their second in two days. Legal expects said yesterday that the judge's desire for a speedy resolution of this phase of the trial suggests that he is unlikely to call for the break-up of Microsoft.

Bill Kovacic, a professor at George Washington University Law School, said: "If you're going to ask for restructuring of the company, you don't want to do that on the run."

The judge is understood to have asked both sides to make their final proposals in the settlement talks a starting point for discussions over remedies.

These proposals were understood to have been based on remedies that fell short of a break-up.

Talks broke down when the sides could not agree on an adequate alternative, Microsoft blaming the states.

Kevin O'Connor for the state of Wisconsin, said: "We're going to work very closely with the department of justice to the extent we can to try to get on the same page in remedies."

 Bill Gates, the Microsoft founder, was one of several high-profile guests at a White House conference held yesterday to discuss how new technology is transforming the economy. He was expected to meet senior politicians in a renewed lobbying effort.

Bill Kovacic, a professor at George Washington University Law School, said: "If you're going to ask for restructuring of the company, you don't want to do that on the run." The judge is understood to have asked both sides to make their final proposals in the settlement talks a starting point for discussions over remedies. These proposals were understood to have been based on remedies that fell short of a break-up. Talks broke down when the sides could not agree on an adequate alternative, Microsoft blaming the states. Kevin O'Connor for the state of Wisconsin, said: "We're going to work very closely with the department of justice to the extent we can to try to get on the same page in remedies."  Bill Gates, the Microsoft founder, was one of several high-profile guests at a White House conference held yesterday to discuss how new technology is transforming the economy. He was expected to meet senior politicians in a renewed lobbying effort.

fields.headline: Byers backs new Rover buy-out
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: An alternative buy-out of the crisis-hit Rover car group is understood to have won government backing and will be formally presented to its troubled parent company BMW in Munich by the end of the week.
fields.body:
An alternative buy-out of the crisis-hit Rover car group is understood to have won government backing and will be formally presented to its troubled parent company BMW in Munich by the end of the week.

According to top level industry sources involved in putting together a complex new financial package, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, has been quietly supporting the creation of a consortium committed to mass car production at Rover's troubled Longbridge plant near Birmingham, to be headed by the former chief executive of the Rover group, John Towers.

The rescue operation - initially codenamed Project Phoenix and consisting of a consortium of venture capitalists, a series of wealthy Rover dealerships, and trade unions - will be presented as an alternative to the offer from the Alchemy venture fund, which plans to shed thousands of jobs and concentrate on sports cars. Crucially, it is understood that the consortium will also boast a string of direct government financial guarantees.

Last night the Department of Trade and Industry said: "[The] government made it clear from the outset that if there has to be a new owner for Rover, we would prefer it to be one committed to high-volume car manufacturing.

"The government will consider appropriate assistance to achieve this objective."

As well as Mr Towers, the team is believed to involve the Midlands Rover dealership mogul John Edwards. Mr Towers - who resigned as Rover chief executive in April 1996, two years after it was bought by BMW - is known to Mr Byers socially and professionally.

Should the consortium win Rover, it would be the latest extraordinary twist in the month-long struggle to save the firm that began when BMW admitted defeat in its efforts to turn around the group. Alchemy was BMW's original choice to take the chronic loss-maker off its hands, and made it clear thousands of jobs would need to be axed from Rover, with particular emphasis on the near 9,000-strong workforce at Longbridge.

Alchemy said it intended to cut the number of jobs at Rover's Longbridge plant to about 4,500. A total of 50,000 people could be affected in the Midlands if the sale goes through.

Mr Byers made it clear he would welcome an alternative to Alchemy's plan to turn Rover into MG Cars and concentrate on supplying niche markets.

In the wake of Alchemy's appearance, the millionaire Midlands businessman John Hemmings, a Liberal Democrat member of Birmingham city council, went public with plans for a counterbid. The computing entrepreneur, who at the time appealed for backing for his own fledgling bid, might also join the new syndicate.

Any government guarantee for a new Rover consortium would need to be cleared with the European commission in Brussels.

Mr Towers joined Rover in 1988 and, despite not having been consulted by its former parent company British Aerospace about the sale to BMW, spent the years 1994-96 consolidating the company under its new owner.

When he quit his £300,000 a year job as group chief executive the last link with the pre-BMW Rover group was cut.

Earlier yesterday Mr Byers faced further calls for his resignation after he insisted to the trade and industry select committee that he had had no hint from BMW of plans to sell off Rover, despite being warned last month that the company had considered cutting thousands of jobs at Longbridge.

As the argument spilled over into prime minister's question time the unions at Rover added a twist by releasing a memorandum from the German car manufacturer assuring Longbridge workers of its "total committment", just weeks before it decided to sell the factory.

webTitle: Bank of England leaves rates unchanged

fields.headline: Bank of England leaves rates unchanged
fields.standfirst: Comment: how the bank is postponing the inevitable
fields.trailText: British manufacturers and unions today heaved a sigh of relief as the Bank of England left interest rates unchanged after four increases in eight months.
fields.body:
British manufacturers and unions today heaved a sigh of relief as the Bank of England left interest rates unchanged after four increases in eight months.

Rates were left at 6% amid evidence of a cooling off in the economy. Fresh evidence has showed factory output falling, house prices falling and high-street spending failing to meet retailers' expectations.

Although separate data showed activity in the service sector at its highest rate for almost three years, trade unions and employers had urged the bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) not to inflict further pain on exporters by tightening credit.

John Monks, the Trades Union Congress (TUC) general secretary, said prior to the announcement: "A decision to raise interest rates would be a complete misreading of the economic situation. It could tip even more of our vital manufacturing sector over the brink. Even more jobs would go under the cosh of the overvalued pound."

Mr Monks argued that inflation remained on target and that pay settlements were responsible. "The chancellor maintained a tight fiscal stance in the budget," Mr Monks said. "To increase rates in reaction to the government's decision to start rebuilding the NHS over five years would be ridiculous, and reflect City prejudice, not economic reality."

Unions say the strength of the pound has been a key factor in the loss of 400,000 manufacturing jobs over the past 12 months, and the Confederation of British Industry believes there is strong evidence that industry is failing to cope with the strong pound.

In an interview with the Guardian, the former chancellor Kenneth Clarke asserted that the bank would be "mad" to raise rates, adding that the least its monetary policy committee could do was to leave rates alone. "They have already raised rates quite a lot and sterling is now becoming a serious medium-term problem."

Mr Clarke accused both the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the bank's governor, Eddie George, of lacking a strategy to deal with sterling's persistently high levels which are damaging Britain's exports and the balance of payments.

"There is a threat hanging over Dagenham where Ford are at least set to cut production, a threat to Honda at Swindon as well as the [Rover] crisis at Longbridge. But this is only the visible tip of a big iceberg," Mr Clarke added.

webTitle: Murdoch and Packer quit mobile licence auction

fields.headline: Murdoch and Packer quit mobile licence auction
fields.trailText: Australian telecoms company One.Tel, backed by media moguls Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer, quit the government's auction of third generation mobile telephone licences yesterday as the total bids hit £12.5bn.
fields.body:
Australian telecoms company One.Tel, backed by media moguls Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer, quit the government's auction of third generation mobile telephone licences yesterday as the total bids hit £12.5bn.

One.Tel admitted that despite the deep pockets of its shareholders, neither of the media conglomerates were prepared to pay more than £2.5bn for one of the five licences available.

One.Tel, which has 1m UK customers, still intends to offer a third generation mobile service by buying capacity from a winning company.

Don Millard, One.Tel's wireless strategy director, said: "One.Tel is not prepared to buy a licence at any cost. One.Tel, together with its financial advisers, is of the opinion that the business plan does not support a licence price in excess of £2.5bn.

"At these levels, the company believes it will create greater shareholder value by spending its UK funds acquiring and servicing customers."

One.Tel was the fifth contender to drop out of the auction this week after Eircom, Nomura-backed Epsilon, Global Crossing's Crescent Wireless and SpectrumCo, which counted Finland's Sonera and the Virgin Group among its shareholders.

That leaves eight bidders to battle it out for the licences in the next few weeks.

BT put in the highest offer yesterday for licence B at £2.84bn. Analysts now expect that licence, which offers the most capacity to existing operators, to fetch at least £3bn as it is fought over by Vodafone and BT.

NTL Mobile, which is supported by France Telecom, offered £2.6bn for licence A, which has been reserved for a new entrant.

Spain's Telefonica offered £2.42bn for licence C, while Canada's TIW bid £2.34bn for licence D and the Vodafone-owned Orange group offered £2.33bn for licence E.

The new generation of mobile telephones will be available from 2002.

fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Exchange Holdings
Aspect Online
fields.trailText: Exchange Holdings, the online financial information company, has broadened its investment in Germany with the £31m acquisition of Aspect Online.
fields.body:
Exchange Holdings, the online financial information company, has broadened its investment in Germany with the £31m acquisition of Aspect Online.

The cash and stock deal gives Exchange an additional 600,000 users from Aspect, an internet financial services group that provides insurance products and online banking and broking advice.

Exchange also announced a joint venture with Germany's Rheinhyp last month to develop an online mortgage site named Extrahype.

The initial offer for Aspect online comprises £4.7m in cash and the issue of 11m Exchange shares at 235.2p.

The British group has also agreed to stump up a further 1.62m shares if its stock price stays below 205p on April 4 this year.

Another chunk of shares valued at £27m would be issued over the next two years if certain revenue and cost-savings targets are met.

Paul Lindsey, chief executive of Exchange, said: "We are continuing to drive our strategy towards becoming a leading international electronic financial distribution company operating in the business to business and business to consumer market."

Exchange made its first move into Europe in February with the acquisition of Fondex, a Scandinavian online retail investment fund, and it has since moved into Spain through joint ventures.

webTitle: China makes key concession to power of the web

fields.headline: China makes key concession to power of the web
fields.standfirst:
Mr Wu what can you do? Ministry connives with business to clear obstacles it created

E-finance: special report
Sina
ChinaByte
fields.trailText: China has finally allowed mainland internet companies to seek an overseas listing in what is seen as a crucial concession to the power of the web. The popular internet portal Sina.com has already filed an application for Nasdaq listing and others are expected to follow soon.
fields.body:
China has finally allowed mainland internet companies to seek an overseas listing in what is seen as a crucial concession to the power of the web. The popular internet portal Sina.com has already filed an application for Nasdaq listing and others are expected to follow soon.

Chinese sites have been angry at the raft of government restrictions placed on them and complained loudly that they were losing ground to Hong Kong-based portals such as Tom.com which have floated with dramatic success recently.

Beijing's Ministry of Information Industry (MII) had imposed a strict ban on allowing foreign ownership of mainland sites, but is now conniving with business leaders to allow a backdoor device to get around the very obstacle it created.

Sina.com has set up a foreign-based firm as its listing vehicle which technically will not have ownership relations with the mainland provider. But it will be linked via a minority holding to another company which operates the mainland site.

"If Chinese internet companies plan to list abroad they must first peel off any China-based online content-related busi nesses and assets," MII chief Wu Jichuan said last week.

The statement was seen by the industry as a green light from Mr Wu, who had previously made a series of negative pronouncements on listing prospects. The second ranking portal Netease.com is also seeking a Nasdaq listing. It claims that its listing company is an overseas registered internet firm while its China operation simply develops software and provides support services.

Other companies, including the third ranking Sohu-com and the popular "lifestyle portal" Zhaodaola, are scrambling to list on Nasdaq. Industry experts say there may only be room for a few Asian companies on Nasdaq. Beijing observers say that Chinese internet regulations are now incoherent with nominally foreign-owned dot.coms being created while foreign participation in domestic internet business is still restricted.

Mr Wu has admitted that Chinese controls will have to be relaxed further as soon as Beijing joins the World Trade Organisation. The Beijing leadership has been torn for months between tightening controls and relaxing restrictions so that China can build a competitive information industry.

The balance shifted at last month's National People's Congress - China's annual parliament - when delegates complained of too many restrictions. China's president Jiang Zemin told provincial leaders that they should appreciate the "momentous significance" of internet technology. He was said to be anxious that China should not lag behind.

Seeking to convince diehard Communist Party cadres, he argued that they had stayed in so far by remaining "in the vanguard" of modern production techniques - and should continue to do so "by learning internet technology".

In another significant shift, China has relaxed tough rules on internet privacy which would have banned foreign-designed encryption software from being used in imported operating systems. Industry sources also say that new checks on websites announced in January to ensure that they do not carry "state secrets" are being ignored.

Mr Wu said last week that he expects the information industry to maintain an annual growth rate of 20% in the next decade - nearly three times current GDP growth.

Beijing appears to have been simultaneously impressed and alarmed by the rapid increase of China's internet population. The total number of users was 8.9m last December - compared to 2.1m in December 1998 - according to the government-run China Internet Network Information Centre (CINNC).

Some estimates suggest the total will more than double again to 20m by the end of the year.

Strict controls are maintained to ensure that Chinese websites only carry officially approved news and do not offer links to foreign wire agencies or newspapers. But these can usually be accessed directly or via a Hong Kong portal.

Funds are needed to expand into e-commerce which has become the latest "web fever" in China this year. However, finance specialists warn that the Chinese banking system is not yet able to support any online payment system.

Sina.com was ranked first in China's most popular websites by the CINNC survey. The second and third placed websites are Netease.com and Sohu-com.

But ChinaByte, which is run jointly by Rupert Murdoch's NewsCorp and the Communist Party's People's Daily newspaper, has now dropped to 50th in the list.

webTitle: Robert McCrum's top 10 books of the twentieth century

fields.headline: Robert McCrum's top 10 books of the twentieth century
fields.trailText: Robert McCrum is The Observer's literary editor and the author of, among other books, My Year Off
fields.body:
Robert McCrum is The Observer's literary editor and the author of, among other books, My Year Off.
Buy My Year Off at Amazon.co.uk

1. A La Recherche Du Temps Perdu by Marcel Proust
Proust redefined the terms of fiction with this great novel, a profound and often very witty 12-volume masterpiece whose influence continues to pervade the body politic of imaginative prose.

2. Ulysses by James Joyce
In the world of English language literature, this book casts a long shadow. Much of the last century's fiction would be impossible without it.

3. The Man Without Qualities by Robert Musil
Seen by some as the A La Recherche DuTemps Perdu of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, this is a meditation on the plight of thelittle man lost in a great machine. One of Europe's unquestioned 20th-centurymasterpieces.

4. The Trial by Franz Kafka
For many readers, this is the novel that captures the spirit of the age most comprehensively. The term Kakfaesque is one that seems appropriate to much of the century's history.

5. Murphy by Samuel Beckett
Beckett's fiction, which preceded his plays, shares many of their qualities and has proved immensely influential with many subsequent writers - even Roddy Doyle.

6. One Hundred Years of Solitude by Gabriel Garcia Marquez
The original novel of Magical Realism, this has sponsored generations of imitators.

7. The Good Soldier by Ford Madox Ford
The haunting masterpiece of Edwardian England.

8. The Tin Drum by Gunter Grass
Grass was recently awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature, and probably won it for this provocative assault on the poisoned legacy of the Third Reich.

9. A Bend In The River by VS Naipaul
To my way of thinking, Naipaul is the greatest living writer of English prose, and this is his masterpiece, though some would nominate A House For Mr Biswas.

10. Nostromo by Josef Conrad
Conrad now looks and reads like a Victorian, but this - one of his finest - was actually published in 1904.

Top 10 US/English books of the last century

1. Sword of Honour Trilogy by Evelyn Waugh
2. On the Road by Jack Kerouac
3. USA by John Dos Passos
4. The Code of the Woosters by PG Wodehouse
5. Stories by Ernest Hemingway
6. All The King's Men by Robert Penn Warren
7. The End of the Affair by Graham Greene
8. Midnight's Children by Salman Rushdie
9. New York Trilogy by Paul Auster
10. Song of Solomon by Toni Morison
