fields.headline: Inquiry as Leeds buy stake in Oldham
fields.standfirst: Premiership club exploits loophole to widen youth academy net
fields.trailText: Leeds United are facing a Football League inquiry after announcing an unauthorised link-up with Oldham Athletic that exposes a loophole in the rules governing the signing of schoolboy players.
fields.body:
Leeds United are facing a Football League inquiry after announcing an unauthorised link-up with Oldham Athletic that exposes a loophole in the rules governing the signing of schoolboy players.

A subsidiary of Leeds Sporting plc, owner of the Premiership side, has bought a 9.9% stake in the Second Division club for an undisclosed sum with a view to doing the same with other lower-league clubs.

As part of the agreement Leeds will jointly fund the development of a youth academy in the Lancashire town for an initial five-year period. This would enable them to entice youngsters from under the noses of clubs such as Manchester United and Liverpool who were previously unavailable because of a rule barring clubs from recruiting under-16s who live more than 90 minutes' travelling time away.

Having attracted them to the Oldham camp, Leeds would be in a stronger position to sign them at 16.

However, the deal prompted immediate concern from the Football League. "The regulations specifically state that clubs cannot hold or deal in the shares of another club without our prior written consent," said its spokesman John Nagle. "We have not given our consent and, if necessary, we have the power to prevent this from happening. All clubs must abide by our rules and we cannot make exceptions.

"This is the first of its type and the obvious concern is that it is going against our regulations. The whole issue will need to be examined and we shall be contacting both Leeds and Oldham."

The league will also seek clarification that Leeds are not seeking to have any input into the management of Oldham and their stake is purely for investment purposes.

Last night the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale insisted the club had abided by the rules. He said he had personally made contact with the Football Association to clarify the position last Thursday.

"Liverpool have been doing it at Crewe for years and Manchester United have unofficial tie-ups with clubs all around the world. Of course we're looking to get something out of it. We're not a registered charity and, if young players come through who are good enough, we will want to sign them," he said. "It allows us to extend the range to 90 minutes from Oldham and will take us into Lancashire, Merseyside and north Wales.

"At the same time this will be of great benefit to Oldham and they will be able to attract more young players by using our name. Premiership clubs are often accused of being greedy and self-centred but, if this was stopped from going through, the only people who would lose out are Oldham.

"We could set up a centre of excellence right on their doorstep and take players from there. Is that what the Football League really want?"

The Leeds midfielder Stephen McPhail, 20, is expected shortly to sign a new 5-year contract.

webTitle: Ferdinand frustrated by Harry's hapless Hammers

fields.headline: Ferdinand frustrated by Harry's hapless Hammers
fields.trailText: Rio Ferdinand has warned West Ham United he will leave unless they start to fulfil their potential.
fields.body:
Rio Ferdinand has warned West Ham United he will leave unless they start to fulfil their potential.

The 22-year-old's ultimatum follows Saturday's 7-1 thrashing by Manchester United and shows how frustrated the England defender is becoming with West Ham's failure to win any silverware and their habit of selling their better players.

"If the club wants to go forward, selling players can't happen," said Ferdinand. "If it does, I'm off."

Despite recently signing a long-term extension to his contract, the former trainee said he will move abroad if West Ham do not become a successful club. "We had a really good chance of winning something this season," he said. "Next year we've got to do it.

"We've been promising to for three or four years, but we've under-achieved. It's no good bringing through all these young players if we don't win something.

"I've made no secret of the fact that I'd like to play abroad one day to experience life in another country. I need to learn my trade here first and for the moment I'm happy at West Ham," he added. "They've made me what I am and it would be nice to pay them back by winning some silverware."

 Football Association officials are demanding an explanation from the Tottenham manager George Graham of his comments about Alan Wiley, the referee in Monday night's Premiership match against Middlesbrough at White Hart Lane which Spurs lost 3-2.

Graham said: "All three officials started nervously and deteriorated into incompetence. It is the referee's first season in the Premier League, but we don't want him learning at our expense. At least he was consistent: he was bad all night."

According to Ghent, Spurs have inquired about their Norwegian striker Ole Martin Aarst, the top scorer in Belgium with 24 goals in 29 games.

webTitle: Everton look to break new ground

fields.headline: Everton look to break new ground
fields.trailText: The possibility of Goodison Park being bulldozed has been resurrected by Everton despite Bill Kenwright's recent take-over of the club.
fields.body:
The possibility of Goodison Park being bulldozed has been resurrected by Everton despite Bill Kenwright's recent take-over of the club.

Although Kenwright, the vice-chairman, has championed the cause of those who would prefer to see Everton's current home upgraded, he will shortly order a feasibility study to explore the financial and geographic practicalities of relocating one of the English game's oldest clubs.

Though the possibility of Goodison being improved and enlarged to accommodate a maximum capacity of around 45,000 still exists, there is a groundswell of opinion on the board that a new stadium should be built before the start of the 2002-2003 season.

If it is decided to abandon Goodison after 108 years, the likelihood is that Everton would seek permission to build a 50,000-seat arena on the outskirts of Liverpool, possibly beside the East Lancashire Road on a vacant site in the city's Gilmoss district.

Everton believe they would need £25m-£30m to construct a home which could well be modelled on Sunderland's Stadium of Light.

The Football League is seeking a chief executive following the departure of John McKeown by mutual agreement yesterday, less than four months after he took up the post on December 23. A statement by the league's board said: "Both parties have recognised that things have not worked out and it is better to part now on an amicable basis."

webTitle: Net growth will make red giants even more terrifying

fields.headline: Net growth will make red giants even more terrifying
fields.trailText: If you are tired of hearing about the astounding wealth and power of Man Utd, football analyst William Davies has some bad news.
fields.body:
There is one recurring story on these rear pages that is guaranteed to double-glaze the eyes and induce an instant yawn fest: it is that Manchester United are a jolly big club and are going to get even bigger and make even more millions for that nice Martin Edwards.

You too, eh?

When it was announced, recently that the club was now worth over £1bn I could almost feel the little Zs coming out of my mouth as I headed for terminal Bo Peep with a facility that the men from Mogadon could only envy.

If you, too, would feel less than bereaved if United took one gobble too many and exploded in the fine fashion of Mr Creosote in Monty Python's Meaning of Life, you should avoid William Davies.

Davies is one of a growing band of brothers. He is a football analyst. He, too, thinks United will get bigger and bigger but what he has to say is so mind-boggling, so vast in its meaning and significance, that the little Zs have been stopped in their tracks.

Davies, from the stockbroker Capel-Cure Sharp, has worked out that United have only to embrace the fashionable world of dot.com and they will be worth another £300m a year. At this rate Roy Keane will be banging on about a pay rise and Sir Alex Ferguson will be asking for another contract.

Davies says: "One of the most interesting things about the proposed new television document is that everyone is getting very excited about the internet, because of its global audience.

"The clubs are now all talking about platform independence, which is the ability of fans to watch their team's games wherever they want.

"In the short term the internet isn't going to happen, but it will come. I've made a simple calculation and I reckon United could have around £300m a year coming from the website in five or six years.

"United, I read, have 6m fans in the UK and 20m throughout the world. Assume they show 25 games at £3.50 a time on the website to 3m people worldwide, and say another 25 games as highlights at £1.50 a time to 1m viewers. Plus another chunk from what they receive for allowing matches to be shown on other sites. If you do that you start to get these large figures very quickly."

You are probably still trying to get your head round Monday's news that the Premiership's chairmen have cleared the way for a pay-per-view TV deal that could bring in another £2bn for the clubs.

United are already pushing to broadcast more football, live and highlights, on their own television channel MUTV, which would attract more subscribers and advertising revenue.

They are also hoping to exploit the new technology of WAP (wireless application protocol), which would allow them to show match action on mobile phones.

But, according to Davies, the real money will be in the internet. "This is five years down the line. I think United will post some very good profits and the value of the club will continue to increase. But players' salaries are going to go ever higher. This will not be that big a problem for United but it could pose difficulties for other clubs."

The money, and shift of talent, could also make it more difficult for players such as Rivaldo to reject United's approaches. Barcelona's European footballer of the year, who plays against Chelsea tonight, is reportedly staying put. He says that the Spanish Liga provides the best in the world.

If that is true, it may not be for much longer. Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier is not alone in attributing the recent success of English clubs in Europe to the influx of foreign talent. And the Premiership is likely to appear attractive to overseas players for at least as long as English clubs - and not only United - remain light years ahead of their European rivals in realising big money from merchandise and TV.

The thought of the likes of Rivaldo and the French master Zinedine Zidane lining up in the Premiership is mouth-watering. But, if all Premiership teams end up as polyglot as Chelsea, it might be time to think again.

And, if Manchester's jolly red giant grows any bigger than it already is, life will become difficult to bear.

fields.headline: Rangers relax in comfort zone
fields.trailText: Rangers 3 - 0 Dundee United
fields.body:
Rangers played their 100th match under Dick Advocaat last night but the manager took a long time to get into the party mood. He growled in his dugout as the champions found Dundee United more troublesome than expected.

Eventually he could relax as goals from Jorg Albertz, Billy Dodds and Rod Wallace in an 11-minute period in the second half took them to a comfortable win and stopped a lot of criticism which was being voiced all around the ground by fans who expect simply the best every time.

The problem with these kind of games is that Ibrox tends to be about as sedate as the local bowling club on the day of the ladies finals. It leaves the players to motivate themselves, not an easy task in a league where the clubs meet each other four times every season.

The Rangers supporters are also notoriously hard on their own players if things are not going to plan. Their target was Wallace, who may have scored a fair tally of 17 goals this season but who has indisputably missed many more. It hardly helped his cause when, after only two minutes, he volleyed a two-yard rebound over the bar after the goalkeeper Andy Combe had parried Andrei Kanchelskis's shot.

But Wallace was not the only culprit. In the first half Kanchelskis himself contrived to fail to convert an Arthur Numan cross from about 18 inches and a Dodds shot was somehow trapped on the line by Jason De Vos.

Advocaat introduced Neil McCann for Tugay after the interval to give himself some more width and that helped to make Rangers become more positive.

They needed a spell of pressure to make their work count and they produced it around the hour. In the 62nd minute Claudio Reyna broke down the left wing at the end of a series of attacks and with the United defence under pressure crossed to Albertz. His first header was blocked but it came back nicely to him and this time he nodded high into the roof of the net.

With their worries over, Rangers took some real control and five minutes later Dodds skipped through the middle of the United defence to add a second goal. Wallace put Rangers out of reach four minutes later.

fields.headline: Jackson settles red rose joust
fields.trailText: Wigan 0 - 1 Preston
fields.byline: Oliver Kay at the JJB Stadium
fields.body:
If a truly enthralling and crisply competitive match was what you were looking for last night, you should have headed to Wigan. This clash between the top two sides in the division attracted 15,593 spectators, Wigan's record for a league match, and only the most hard-nosed of locals will deny they were suitably entertained.

Preston roused themselves still further in a bid to abandon their sleeping giant label once and for all. Unbeaten in their previous six matches, they moved clear at the summit courtesy of Michael Jackson's first-half goal. Only rarely, in the closing minutes of each half, did that lead look in danger.

Four consecutive victories had made Wigan favourites for the runners-up spot behind their visitors, and thousands of Lancastrians ensured the game kicked off against the backdrop of incessant noise. It was augmented by a thunderous opening as tackles flew in at knee height.

After 17 minutes of attrition, the deadlock was broken when Rob Edwards' right-wing corner was inadequately cleared and Jackson hooked the ball beyond the reach of Roy Carroll in the Wigan goal.

Preston threatened to run riot as Bjarki Gunlaugsson curled a speculative shot over the crossbar before Ian Anderson was denied by Carroll after an incisive pass by Mark Rankine.

Wigan, looking surprisingly nervous for a team that won the corresponding fixture 4-1 earlier in the season, did not test Tepi Moilanen until first-half stoppage time when the Finn saved well from Simon Haworth and Arjan De Zeeuw.

The second half saw more of the same, Wigan playing at a pace which proved more problematic for them than for the opposition, while the referee Uriah Rennie's bewildering decisions ensured that a Yorkshireman made a contribution to what had been billed as a strictly Red Rose affair.

webTitle: Holland saves a point for Ipswich

fields.headline: Holland saves a point for Ipswich
fields.trailText: WBA 1 - 1 Ipswich
fields.body:
Ipswich Town had to rely on Matt Holland's uncanny ability to score goals away from home to rescue a point against relegation-threatened West Bromwich Albion at the Hawthorns last night.

Holland's strike took his season's tally to nine, seven of which have come away, but Albion will be happy to have won a point which moves them clear of the relegation zone.

With five players making their home debut, Albion's line-up had an unfamiliar look. A quartet of the newcomers formed a new-look rearguard, the other, Bob Taylor, played up front.

It was Taylor who had the less eventful first half as Ipswich, needing to win 2-0 to move into second place, looked hell-bent on achieving it. All of which suggested a familiar outcome - Albion failing to beat the Suffolk side for the 25th time in succession.

Albion's defence were in obdurate mood and behind them goalkeeper Brian Jensen was in commanding form.

After a diving save to keep out a long-range effort from Jim Magilton in the ninth minute he produced an even better one midway through the half to tip over a snap shot from David Johnson.

Johnson was a constant menace, but should have done better with Mick Stockwell's perfectly flighted cross six minutes before the interval. Instead, the tiny striker headed straight at Jensen.

It proved a costly miss two minutes before the interval when Hughes put Albion in front; his 16th goal of the season was also Albion's first shot on target.

Hughes, who collided with the Ipswich keeper Richard Wright, did not come out for the second half. With Ipswich predictably laying siege to the Albion defence to salvage a point, he wouldn't have seen much of the ball anyway.

The visitors failed to capitalise on that pressure in the 58th minute when Johnson, set up by Jamie Scowcroft's knockdown, took the ball round Jensen but fired wide. Ten minutes, though, Holland collected a Jamie Clapham through-ball and placed his shot past Jensen to equalise.

fields.headline: Charlton struggle to draw
fields.trailText: Port Vale 2 - 2 Charlton
fields.body:
Andy Hunt, whose goals have done much to put Charlton within touching distance of the Premiership, spared them an untimely embarrassment last night against a side seemingly bound for the Second Division.

Hunt's 23rd goal of the season was the final word in a thrilling match during which Vale twice held the lead. If these clubs' encounter over an unpaid £600 parking bill in court next week is as entertaining, it might be worth reserving a seat.

Charlton's apparent fallibility against the First Division strugglers threatened to be their undoing again only two victories short of reclaiming the Premiership place they lost last May. Three weeks ago they went down 1-0 to last-placed Swindon at the Valley, their only defeat in 18 games, and here they threatened to repeat the exercise against Vale.

Dean Kiely's hopes of a club record-breaking 20 clean sheets in a season were ruined by a striker Vale picked up for nothing.

Kiely would have beaten Nicky Johns's 19-year-old record had he kept Vale out. But he was beaten late in the first half by a brilliant strike from Ville Viljanen, the player Vale signed on a free transfer from the Gothenburg club Vastra Frolunda in February, after 39 minutes.

The Finnish international swivelled to hook home a right-foot shot from 25 yards, his fourth goal in six games, and enhance his prospects of a permanent move to England.

Charlton had only themselves to blame for finding themselves in arrears. They squandered a superb chance to take the lead midway through the first half, when Graham Stuart's first-time through-ball beat the home defence through sheer speed of thought and sent Paul Kitson clear. The on-loan striker should have scored but delayed his shot too long before firing weakly at Kevin Pilkington.

Charlton should have gone further behind just past the hour when Viljanen missed a chance far easier than the one he accepted, blazing over from 15 yards after being put through by David Healy.

Hunt's 23rd goal of the season was the final word in a thrilling match during which Vale twice held the lead. If these clubs' encounter over an unpaid £600 parking bill in court next week is as entertaining, it might be worth reserving a seat. Charlton's apparent fallibility against the First Division strugglers threatened to be their undoing again only two victories short of reclaiming the Premiership place they lost last May. Three weeks ago they went down 1-0 to last-placed Swindon at the Valley, their only defeat in 18 games, and here they threatened to repeat the exercise against Vale. Kiely would have beaten Nicky Johns's 19-year-old record had he kept Vale out. fields.headline: Chelsea face the ultimate test
fields.standfirst: Barcelona will show how far the revolution in SW6 has really come
fields.trailText: Where has the Chelsea revolution left the club? Tonight they enter a crucial five days in their season and face the ultimate progress report against a club that ooze intimidation and class.
fields.body:
It is five years since Glenn Hoddle began a cultural revolution at Chelsea by signing a player known around the world and not just around the World's End pub.

Ruud Gullit's arrival began a process of internationalisation at Stamford Bridge which recently saw the club's Italian manager field a side of 11 foreigners.

But the Chelsea revolution is not just about collecting different-coloured passports. It is mainly about lifting the club's horizons, about becoming a power in the land and on the continent.

So where has this transformation left them? How good are they? Tonight Chelsea face the ultimate progress report.

Barcelona are, according to many observers, simply the best team in Europe. The statistics are impressive: unbeaten in the Champions League this season, top scorers with 36 goals in 12 games, victorious in their last nine matches in all competitions. Barca ooze intimidation.

It was enough to move Gianluca Vialli on to the defensive yesterday as he piled on the flattery before tonight's collision. "Nobody would be too surprised if we lost over the two legs," he said.

"Barcelona have the best strikers in the world," he added. "Louis van Gaal is the best manager in the world along with Sir Alex Ferguson and Marcello Lippi."

When everything clicks for Barcelona's Dutch-dominated team, as in their 4-2 home win against Porto in a group match, they are in a different league from anything Chelsea have yet produced.

Despite all the big-match European experience contained within their multinational squad, Chelsea have always needed a helping hand to live with the very best.

When every player in blue is truly focused and when the opposition is slightly off colour, Vialli's side have pulled off away draws against Lazio and Milan. But, as Lazio reminded everyone in the return at Stamford Bridge last month, when a team of quality attacks Chelsea with touch and imagination, the Premiership side struggle, gaps open up in defence and the coolest of players are left scrambling to recover position and dignity.

"We will need to be on top of our game and hopefully they will not be." Vialli knows the reality.

With a three-pronged forward line of Luis Figo, Patrick Kluivert and the world player of the year Rivaldo, now recovered from injury, it is expecting a lot for all of them to be off colour at the same time.

As ever, the flow of the game will largely be determined by who dominates midfield, where the battle-hardened Dennis Wise and Pep Guardiola come face to face. It will be little consolation to Chelsea that Barcelona are missing the injured Luis Enrique and Ronald de Boer from midfield because that will only expose the depth of Barcelona's squad.

With Celestine Babayaro finally cleared by the Nigerians to play in this tie, Chelsea's main defensive question will be whether Emerson Thome, likely to replace the suspended Frank Leboeuf, can repeat his encouraging Premiership form at this higher level.

It all adds up to a crucial five days in Chelsea's season. On Sunday they meet Newcastle in the FA Cup semi-final. By then everyone will know whether that progress report reads more encouragingly than "must do better".

Possible teams: Chelsea (4-4-2): De Goey; Ferrer, Desailly, Thome, Babayaro; Petrescu, Deschamps, Wise, Poyet; Zola, Flo.

Barcelona (4-3-3): Hesp; Reiziger, Abelardo, F de Boer, Bogarde; Gabri, Guardiola, Cocu; Figo, Kluivert, Rivaldo.

fields.headline: Bosnich passes Spanish inquisition
fields.standfirst:
United can be content with a job well done against inspired Real Madrid
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Mark Bosnich led Manchester United's resistance here last night as Real Madrid tried all they knew in the opening leg of this quarter-final to give themselves an advantage to take to Old Trafford in a fortnight's time.
fields.body:
Mark Bosnich led Manchester United's resistance here last night as Real Madrid tried all they knew in the opening leg of this quarter-final to give themselves an advantage to take to Old Trafford in a fortnight's time.

The United goalkeeper thwarted Real's best scoring efforts as Jaap Stam and the defence steadily wore down an attack which increasingly looked to Steve McManaman for its inspiration.

Gento, a voice from Real's golden age in the 50s, had declared himself confident that in Europe the present side could succeed performing "like 11 Di Stefanos". United were grateful that their opponents could no longer come up with one Alfredo.

Nevertheless the holders knew that if Real's form, which has flickered all season like a faulty gas ring, did burst into full flame they would be hard pressed to keep them at bay.

So United's patient, possessive approach, with no immediate scoring ambition, was understandable. Real, on the other hand, knew they had to up the tempo and disturb the normal calm of Stam and Henning Berg, and in this they succeeded almost from the outset.

Quick combinations accompanied by instinctive runs into space saw Raul, Fernando Morientes, McManaman and Savio prise a number of openings to arouse the passions of a stadium well populated but far from full.

Berg's well-timed tackle thwarted Raul's attempt to dribble through a thicket of defenders, a cross-shot from Michel Salgado, although it was not going in, was still pushed away by Bosnich and, when McManaman met Savio's dipping cross with a diving header, the United goalkeeper touched the ball over the crossbar.

So long as their centre-backs held firm and Roy Keane and Paul Scholes retained a measure of parity in midfield, Manchester United could feel confident about surviving Real's initial attacking burst. And, when United did move forward in any sort of numbers, they soon created chances of their own.

The first two, midway through the half, fell to Andy Cole in the space of two minutes. One, from Ryan Giggs's cross after Salgado had slipped, was wafted over the bar. The other, a low shot from 20 yards, was easily saved by the 18-year-old Iker Casillas.

Thus an open game promised goals at either end, although by the half-hour the excellence of the goalkeepers had left this promise unfulfilled.

After 23 minutes, for example, McManaman and Savio combined to set up Morientes for a point-blank shot which Bosnich kept out with a stretching left hand. Three minutes later David Beckham, taking corners amid a hail of missiles from the crowd, saw one nodded on by Stam at the near post but then headed over by Cole from four yards.

As the rain returned, making the surface slippery and testing defenders on the turn, Giggs began to open up the left flank for United while Beckham frequently moved to the middle to increase his range.

Yet at half-time Real were entitled to feel more frustrated at having failed to score, after creating the more clear-cut chances. Just past the half-hour McManaman, ever eager to run at defenders, sent Raul clear only for the advancing Bosnich to smother the ball before the Real striker could get in a proper shot.

As the half ended Casillas failed to hold a long, low drive from Scholes and Dwight Yorke pounced on the rebound to put the ball into the net. But he was adjudged to have been marginally offside.

United's prime task of keeping Real out remained a priority, however, and Bosnich was equal to the low free-kick which Roberto Carlos drove through the United wall in the 47th minute. Now Real's movements in and around the United area began to lose their earlier precision, and a touch of Nicolas Anelka's pace would have served them well at that point.

With Giggs rather than Beckham now moving to the middle, Manchester United found opportunites to catch Real on the break the more their opponents pressed forward. In the 64th minute Keane released the Welshman into a thinly defended Real half only for Aitor Karanka to be shown a yellow card for bringing Giggs down at the edge of the area.

Real's momentum was flagging, no doubt about that, but United were never going to abandon their tightly organised gameplan.

Real Madrid (4-3-1-2): Casillas; Salgado, Ivan Campo, Karanke, Roberto Carlos; McManaman, Helguera, Redondo, Savio; Morientes (Ognjenovic, 86), Raul.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Bosnich; G Neville, Berg, Stam, Irwin (Silvestre, 87); Beckham, Keane, Scholes (Butt, 81), Giggs; Cole,Yorke (Sheringham, 76).

Referee : G Veissiere (France).

webTitle: Smaller clubs 'duped' into signing away collective broadcast rights

fields.headline: Smaller clubs 'duped' into signing away collective broadcast rights
fields.trailText: Leading Premiership clubs were accused yesterday of railroading through two of the most revolutionary aspects of a future television deal, the right to broadcast their matches on their own club channels and on the internet.
fields.body:
Leading Premiership clubs were accused yesterday of railroading through two of the most revolutionary aspects of a future television deal, the right to broadcast their matches on their own club channels and on the internet.

The Guardian has learned that no vote was taken on these two aspects of the deal by the 20 Premiership chairmen who met on Monday to discuss a tender document for the next television deal, due to begin at the start of the 2001-02 season.

Smaller Premiership clubs, who do not stand to profit from owning their own rights, are angry and claim they were not given a chance to discuss fully the implications of club channel and internet rights or vote on them.

During the meeting in central London heated discussions about introducing 40 pay-per-view games each season were followed by a vote, but small clubs claim there was no such procedure over club channels and the internet. They claim that the issue of individual rights was raised only late in the afternoon almost as an afterthought.

A source close to Monday's talks said: "Surprisingly, the issue of clubs owning rights to their matches was not even discussed. It was not presented to us as a serious proposal; it was just added on at the end of a busy day. We were never really made fully aware of the implications of these two aspects of the deal.

"The right to show your own games is clearly the most revolutionary part of this deal. It's good news for the larger clubs: what was previously a pooled right is now owned by the individual club. This will increase the gap between the haves and the have-nots. Many of us came away from Monday's meeting feeling that we'd been duped."

The Premier League insists that all 20 member clubs had ample opportunity to raise concerns about any of the seven packages.

Its spokesman Mike Lee said: "The proposals from the chief executive [Richard Scudamore] were a result of extensive consultation and there was ample opportunity to comment, ask questions or amend. The mood of the meeting was clearly to go forward on the basis proposed with some changes agreed through discussion."

Equal time was given to the discussion of each of the seven packages, officials claim.

Initially, the pay-per-view package was rejected because it failed to reach the required two-thirds majority. One club chairman left Monday's meeting before voting took place but 11 voted in favour of pay-per-view, six against and two abstained.

Under the initial proposals the broadcaster winning the bid would have had the right to show a team a maximum of eight times and could refuse to show others.

Many of the smaller clubs felt that this would devalue the main live games package, in which 66 games are to be shown during the season, and that they would also miss out on pay-per-view revenue.

The package was eventually amended so that all Premiership teams would have to be featured at least once and a maximum of six times. The final vote had 16 in favour.

A presentation of the tender document took place on Monday morning led by the Premier League's competition lawyer and Scudamore. In the afternoon, most of the discussion was taken up by pay-per-view.

Clubs were not told how much money the new deal could generate but some estimates put it at £2bn. All agreed that it should be a three-year deal and there was also unanimous agreement on other aspects, such as the decision to have two highlights packages, on Saturday and Sunday night.

According to the source: "There's a lot more optimism that there will be a lot more money to share around the smaller clubs. But the gap in income is set to widen now that clubs also own rights to their matches. It's a natural result of the approach adopted by the Premier League."

webTitle: Leeds soccer fan killed in riot

fields.headline: Leeds soccer fan killed in riot
fields.trailText: 10.05pm: Breaking news A Leeds United fan was killed in rioting in Istanbul tonight ahead of Thursday's Uefa Cup semi-final clash between Galatasaray and Leeds.
fields.body:
A Leeds United fan was killed in rioting in Istanbul, Turkey tonight, the Foreign Office has announced.

The supporter died in clashes between rival fans ahead of Thursday's Uefa Cup semi-final clash between Galatasaray and Leeds. Five or six other Leeds fans were injured in the riot.

According to the Turkish television station A-TV, a second Leeds United fan was seriously injured and TV pictures showed the aftermath of the clash, with English fans lying in pools of blood in Takim Square in the centre of Istanbul.

One man was being given the kiss of life by a policeman in the middle of the road while another Leeds fan was lifted by police into a police car to be taken to hospital.

While police tried the clear the area, there were angry scenes, with Turks standing outside restaurants and hotels shouting at the Leeds fans.

fields.headline: Prevent not cure
fields.standfirst: Jeremy Porteous on a report that stresses the value of early intervention
fields.trailText: Jeremy Porteous on a report that stresses the value of early intervention
fields.body:
The widely accepted belief that community care resources should be targeted on people in greatest need was challenged today with the launch of a report which claims that investing money early in people's career of need prevents future cycle leading to hospital admission or residential care.

The report is the result of a research study commissioned by Anchor Trust, which provides housing care and support for older people, and funded by a Housing Corporation grant. It looked at how appropriate housing and housing-related services can reduce the demand for more costly services and promote older people's well-being. And it found that where people with high levels of disability and frailty, including wheelchair users, use low-level services, such as timely advice and access to home improvements, they were able to live comfortably and independently in their own homes.

While support services have traditionally responded to need as health or social care-led, the report points out that housing must play a central role for prevention to be effective.

What often hampers progress, in the opinion of people interviewed in the study, is inadequate information on what is available. Those who got what they needed usually did so through word of mouth or were already "in the system". Jargon put people off. "Make it as simple as ABC if you really want us to take part," said one tenant. Lack of co ordination between agencies, variability in provision and stereotyping of older people also caused difficulties.

While pockets of good practice exist at local level, these are not being replicated regionally. And, perhaps not surprisingly, what does work well happens on an ad hoc basis, with no coherent strategies.

However, John Belcher, chief executive of Anchor Trust, is optimistic that change is beginning to happen. "The prevention movement is one whose time has come," he says. "Interest in prevention strategies has been growing at all levels, from government departments to front line social housing and care staff."

The report concludes that, to bring about prevention, housing must be fundamental to any strategy for improving the lives of older people. Recommendations made for achieving this goal are:

* the development of a national framework for prevention incorporating the housing dimension;

* the Housing Corporation making prevention a key component of its current policy review;

* local government taking a strategic view of the need for prevention services in their area and investment decisions;

* the Preventive Task Group ensuring that prevention permeates debate in a way similar to social exclusion.

 Jeremy Porteus is corporate strategy manager of Anchor Trust. Preventive Approaches In Housing: An Exploration Of Good Practice is published (price £15) by Anchor Trust (contact Louise Wood on 01865 854093). For further information contact: Marie Mulligan on 0207 759 9107 or Jeremy Porteus on 0207 759 9106.

And it found that where people with high levels of disability and frailty, including wheelchair users, use low-level services, such as timely advice and access to home improvements, they were able to live comfortably and independently in their own homes. While support services have traditionally responded to need as health or social care-led, the report points out that housing must play a central role for prevention to be effective. What often hampers progress, in the opinion of people interviewed in the study, is inadequate information on what is available. Those who got what they needed usually did so through word of mouth or were already "in the system". Jargon put people off. "Make it as simple as ABC if you really want us to take part," said one tenant. Lack of co ordination between agencies, variability in provision and stereotyping of older people also caused difficulties. While pockets of good practice exist at local level, these are not being replicated regionally. And, perhaps not surprisingly, what does work well happens on an ad hoc basis, with no coherent strategies. However, John Belcher, chief executive of Anchor Trust, is optimistic that change is beginning to happen. "The prevention movement is one whose time has come," he says. "Interest in prevention strategies has been growing at all levels, from government departments to front line social housing and care staff." The report concludes that, to bring about prevention, housing must be fundamental to any strategy for improving the lives of older people. Recommendations made for achieving this goal are: * the development of a national framework for prevention incorporating the housing dimension; * the Housing Corporation making prevention a key component of its current policy review; * local government taking a strategic view of the need for prevention services in their area and investment decisions; * the Preventive Task Group ensuring that prevention permeates debate in a way similar to social exclusion.  Jeremy Porteus is corporate strategy manager of Anchor Trust. Preventive Approaches In Housing: An Exploration Of Good Practice is published (price £15) by Anchor Trust (contact Louise Wood on 01865 854093). fields.headline: Paying the price
fields.standfirst: Chris Holmes wants to see a change in attitudes to rented homes, starting with scrapping the term 'social housing' because it is so stigmatised
fields.trailText: Chris Holmes wants to see a change in attitudes to rented homes, starting with scrapping the term 'social housing' because it is so stigmatised
fields.body:
While the government set out its vision for the future in its long-awaited housing policy green paper, published yesterday, we must not lose sight of the need to plan communities.

The green paper vision is ambitious. At the heart of the green paper is the aim of ensuring that everyone has the opportunity of a living in a decent home. It emphasises the need to reform the current crisis-driven legislation and to create policies and practice which seek to prevent homelessness arising in the first place. There are important proposals to extend the help given to vulnerable people leaving institutions and an outline of changes to make the homebuying process easier. The paper has a lot to say about choice, flexibility and inclusive communities. But, to give substance to these words, we need to jettison old thinking about housing - and with it some old language.

It is time to break down the divisive attitudes to housing tenure - the ingrained belief that owning your own home is intrinsically better than renting, and that rented "social housing" is the tenure of the last resort for those who have no other choice.

The term social housing should be abandoned. It is an artificial and increasingly stigmatised label. In its place we need to create new and more flexible forms of housing where people can choose between different tenure of equal status.

Polls shows that 90% of people would like to own their homes, but a significant minority cannot afford to do this. Some owners face serious problems as a result of taking on commitments they cannot sustain, while many single people in their 20s prefer the flexibility of renting.

Public subsidy should be available to people in all tenures, but only to assist those who cannot afford the full market cost of adequate housing.

For home owners, this help could include grants to lower income households - especially older people -to improve their property and mortgage benefit to home owners facing unexpected difficulties.

Rented homes could be made up of "private" and "not-for-profit" lettings - homes let by local councils, housing associations, housing co-operatives and local housing companies. Not-for-profit landlords would provide homes at subsidised rents for low income tenants and at-cost rents for those in work who can afford it.

A Mori poll last year found that two-thirds of people believe that local authority and housing association homes should be available to anyone who prefers to rent their home.

A new form of cost-rent tenancy will encourage this, but without giving public subsidy to people who do not need it.

More radically, not-for-profit landlords should have the freedom to decide the kind of homes they let. This will mean selling properties - for full or part ownership - on monolithic estates of rented housing. And, using the proceeds from sales, buying homes to rent in areas that are mostly privately owned.

Recent research by the Demos thinktank has shown the crucial link between the housing market and choice of schools. House prices are pushed upwards as better-off parents buy homes near to successful state schools.

A properly integrated social policy would set targets for the balance of incomes and tenure for schools' catchment areas. Current market forces are leading to greater segregation, and social action is essential to develop more inclusive communities.

We also need a new approach to the way homes are let by not-for-profit landlords. Most landlords give very little choice to people over where they live; the very name - "allocating" tenancies - reflects a deeply ingrained paternalism. The aim must be to offer people seeking somewhere to rent as much choice as possible, while giving priority to those in greatest need.

The internet could transform the process of letting rented homes, making it possible for people seeking accommodation - from any landlord anywhere in the country - to find out what is available.

The success of this radical new approach depends on an increase in investment in affordable homes. A major research project carried out for Shelter has shown a substantial shortfall in the investment needed to provide affordable homes for people on lower incomes.

Next month, Shelter will publish the final report from a three-year research project. It will set the scale of unmet need, how it can more effectively be met, and how much it will cost. Our proposals include linking private finance with public subsidy to provide homes at affordable rents; making better use of planning powers to secure more affordable homes and ensuring that both investment and public spending are targeted to where they are most needed.

But they also require an increase in public spending on housing. As the price of achieving the goal of a decent home for everybody, increasing choice, strengthening cohesive communities and raising achievements in schools, it is surely a price worth paying.

 Chris Holmes is director of Shelter.

webTitle: New hope for housing - but it's not going to come cost free

fields.headline: New hope for housing - but it's not going to come cost free
fields.standfirst: Yesterday's housing green paper was not quite as revolutionary as leaks suggested. Yet a revolution is under way. A score of local authorities have applied to transfer 300,000 homes this year - six times the number transferred in the last six years. Housing managers, reluctantly recognising that there is no prospect of either local or central government raising the funds to meet the £20bn backlog in repairs and maintenance, have come to accept transfers as a way of raising capital.
fields.trailText: Yesterday's housing green paper was not quite as revolutionary as leaks suggested. Yet a revolution is under way. A score of local authorities have applied to transfer 300,000 homes this year - six times the number transferred in the last six years. Housing managers, reluctantly recognising that there is no prospect of either local or central government raising the funds to meet the £20bn backlog in repairs and maintenance, have come to accept transfers as a way of raising capital.
fields.body:
It was being billed as the day which would mark the end of 100 years of council housing. Yesterday's housing green paper was not quite as revolutionary as leaks suggested. Council housing will not be hived off to housing associations or arms-length, non-profit local housing companies within 10 years. Ministers aim to restrict housing transfers to 200,000 a year. That would eliminate England's 3m council homes within 15 years; but even this is unlikely. It does not take into account the growing proportion of tenant ballots (over 10%) rejecting such proposals, the opposition of Labour council chairmen, or the non viability of transferring seriously dilapidated estates with huge debts. Yet a revolution is under way. A score of local authorities have applied to transfer 300,000 homes this year - six times the number transferred in the last six years. Housing managers, reluctantly recognising that there is no prospect of either local or central government raising the funds to meet the £20bn backlog in repairs and maintenance, have come to accept transfers as a way of raising capital.

There was a lot to welcome yesterday: first official recognition of a £20bn backlog; a public commitment to renovate this dilapidated stock within 10 years; a new duty to provide children leaving care, and young offenders leaving penal institutes, with a home; a rent review with the aim of providing comparable rents for comparable accommodation, which opens the way to housing benefit reform; new help for key workers - nurses, teachers, fire officers - to purchase homes in high cost housing areas; and more regulation of unscrupulous landlords. There is something here for everyone. It is the most comprehensive review of housing policy for a generation.

Yet many questions remain. The three different rent options require careful analysis. There are many broad brush proposals where more detail is needed. There are no new building targets. Stock transfers are in danger of simply switching supply from one kind of monopoly to another rather than ensuring that managers become closer to tenants. Most important of all is funding. A new duty to house the young homeless is commendable but it will mean finding new cash. Government subsidies will still be needed. We will have to wait for the July comprehensive spending review to judge just how seriously Labour remains committed to social housing.

webTitle: Holy ghost, Hair gel, and Hamburgers

fields.headline: Holy ghost, Hair gel, and Hamburgers
fields.trailText: NEWCASTLE'S SORRY BOARD
fields.body:
NEWCASTLE'S SORRY BOARD

They've openly mocked their fans for buying over-priced merchandise, tried to force a non-league team to give up home advantage in the FA Cup, forced loyal season ticket holders out of their seats to make room for freeloading business clients and subsequently taken them on in the courts, and called women from their region "dogs". But don't you understand? The board of Newcastle United are simply good souls seeking redemption. That's why outgoing chairman Freddie Fletcher has been to confession.

"Issues relating to boardroom changes have adversely impacted on our relations with the City," began Fletcher simply, in the first religious act to be held on the front page of a statement to shareholders. "The disruption relating to the stadium and indeed our own handling of this has severely tested our relationship with our fans," he continued, now ready to repent for his sins.

"Undoubtedly mistakes have been made in how we handled the communications of these issues," he went on, pleading to be given penance, "and for this the board apologises unreservedly to all concerned." You are absolved, my son! And so, having been credited by the Fiver with a couple of Hail Mary Poppins, Freddie toddled off to find the free wafers and wine.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER'S PATENTED EXPONENTIAL TALENT-AND-AGE BIRTHDAY CURVE

Happy birthday to John Hartson (27), Richard Gough (38) and Sir Tom Finney (78). Just watch that graph shoot off the page.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

LEEDS CHALLENGE LEAGUE'S LEEDS CHALLENGE

Yesterday the Fiver reported Leeds' ambitious attempts to extend the definition of a '90-minute journey from Leeds' to include the whole of the north-west of England and north Wales. And all this without inventing a very fast rocket car. In fact all they had to do was invest in Oldham Athletic and, thanks to a loophole in FA rules, the cream of the nation's footballing youth was theirs. Or so they thought.

"The whole issue will need to be examined and we will be contacting Leeds and Oldham," said Football League spokesman John Nagle last night, fighting back for the rights of the small club. "The League's board are set to meet in the next 10-12 days and the matter will be discussed then," he went on. "We have not given our consent and if necessary have the power to prevent it happening." Which gave the League the upper hand in any argument. Or so they thought.

"If this was stopped from going through the only people who would lose out would be Oldham," retorted busy Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale this afternoon at the same time as launching a new Leeds hair gel and releasing a white paper on European competition policy. "We could set up a centre of excellence right on their doorstep instead," he continued. "Is that what the Football League really wants?" Probably not, and it wouldn't help the parking problem outside Boundary Park either.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I don't think there is any point dwelling on it. I missed a good chance, but I'm not going to go home and top myself over it" - Who mentioned topping yourself? Andy Cole after heading over from 1.11 inches last night.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MALTEASEY DOES IT

The Fiver knows more than most about the majestic Mediterranean isle of Malta - it's the home of the Malteser, the birthplace of Napoleon, and a lovely place for a holiday (Paphos is particularly nice this time of year, apparently). But we've never heard about the country lacking a sense of humour of Graham-esque proportions. Not until now, anyway.

Earlier today, cuddly multinational McDonald's were forced to apologise to Maltese footballers for poking fun at their ability in a TV ad (not unreasonably, considering the Malts have never reached a major championship). A Dutch commercial showed actors dressed as the Maltese national team taking part in a McDonald's competition for Euro 2000 tickets. It has been assumed by Dutch comic analysts that the punchline was: this is the only way Malta could ever make it to the finals.

The advert caused such a storm of protest that the global giant (McDonald's, not Malta) was forced to back down. "It is never our intention to offend anyone. We have apologised by letter to the Maltese Football Association," said a spokeswoman for McDonalds Netherlands. She didn't, however, explain why they eat chips with mayonnaise.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Middlesbrough's Christian Ziege has denied he will be joining Liverpool for £8m this summer. Recent reports suggested that Ziege could be set to follow fellow German international Dietmar Hamann from the North East to Merseyside, but he said today: "It's not true that I want to leave to go to Liverpool or anywhere else, I'm happy at Middlesbrough."

Gianluca Vialli has been tipped to move for three Internazionale players this summer. £10m striker Nicola Ventola, club captain Javier Zanetti (also valued at £10m) and £7m-rated goalkeeper Sebastien Frey are his mooted targets.

Rio Ferdinand, who this morning expressed his dissatisfaction at West Ham's failure to challenge for trophies, is wanted by AC Milan and is likely to be approached by the club this summer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Norwich have appointed Bryan Hamilton as manager on a permanent basis. Hamilton had been acting as caretaker boss since the resignation of Bruce Rioch last month. "I can use the remaining games of the season to start to build for the next campaign... the Board and I are ambitious," said the 54-year-old former Northern Ireland manager.

Lazio's Argentinian midfielder Juan Sebastian Veron is under investigation by Italian justice officials regarding his Italian citizenship which allows him to play for the Rome club as an EU player.

Blackburn are to provide free travel to their match at Grimsby on April 22 for around 1,000 fans. The club will lay on up to 20 coaches. "The gesture is a mark of appreciation aimed at those who regularly travel the length and breadth of the country to support the team," said chief executive John Williams.

Nicolas Anelka resumed full training with Real Madrid today after serving 22 days of a 45-day suspension for missing three days of training.

Gheorghe Hagi has been offered the assistant manager post with Romania and could take up the role after Euro 2000.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Live (7.30pm)
The best efforts of the talented ITV technicians go to waste as their coverage of Chelsea v Barcelona is ruined by some amateur presenter with an shoddy moustache.

The Big Match (11.30pm)
Hallelujah for Gabby and Barry, bringing time-honoured professionalism back to ITV Sport.

Sky Sports 1: Cup Heroes (5.55pm, 1.25am SS2, 4.15am)
A profile of David Davies.

Futbol Mundial (1.45am)
It sounds like football... it looks like football...

ONsport 1: Valencia v Lazio - Live (7.30pm)
Good luck to Lazio - it's always nice to see a team from the less successful nations battle through to the latter stages of a European tournament.

Chelsea v Barcelona (9.55pm)
Good luck to Barcelona - it's always nice to see a team from the less successful nations battle through to the latter stages of a European tournament.

Don't Mention the Score (11.45pm)
So you don't want us to mention that Kaisersalutern lost to a late Stuttgart winner? Righty-ho.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)
7. Alan Green's Great! "This is appalling. If Leeds were playing in my back garden I'd close the curtains." David Maton remembers the ruler of the radio's nod to Bill Shankly. Send your offering to the.boss@theguardian.com.

David Mellor (10pm)
Arguments with ridiculous gaps.

talkSPORT: The Two Macs - McCaffrey and MacInally (1pm)
Given that ***'** ** *** ******! isn't on tonight, McCaff's Message Board has been temporarily shifted to his contribution to audio hell. "Tom. Please buy a pint of milk before you come home tonight. Thanks from Luna." Can you email the.boss@theguardian.com to tell us whether he remembered?

Big Cup Quarter Finals (7pm)
We won't be able to concentrate on this - did he take some milk home or not?

fields.headline: Watchdog may inquire into peerage awards
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: April 5 2000: The committee on standards in public life may investigate the growing controversy over "cash for coronets" as major party donors are awarded peerages in the half-reformed Lords, the committee's chairman, Lord Neill, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The committee on standards in public life may investigate the growing controversy over "cash for coronets" as major party donors are awarded peerages in the half-reformed Lords, the committee's chairman, Lord Neill, warned yesterday.

"There certainly should not be payment for honours, that is implicit in what we have said in earlier reports," he said in the wake of last week's row over 33 newly appointed peers.

But he also warned against witchhunts - "the danger of creating a whirl of animosity" between parties.

Lord Neill, who announced that he will step down from the post in the autumn after completing his three-year term, spoke at a press conference to launch the watchdog committee's next investigation, into the possibility of extending the full rigours of the MPs' register of interests to members of the House of Lords.

In the wake of the controversy over Tory treasurer, Michael Ashcroft's appointment to the Lords last week - and Tory counter-claims that major Labour donors have also won peerages - Lord Neill said "there's an argument for having it on the agenda as one of the possible topics the committee could look at one day. I don't think it is within the remit of what we are doing now".

The latest inquiry follows a series started under Lord Nolan's chairmanship in response to growing alarm about sleaze and declining standards in public life. Unlike MPs, now paid nearly £50,000 a year plus expenses, peers are not paid.

Instead they get expenses, including up to £81.50 for overnight accommodation in London, £36 a day for subsistence and £35 a day for secretarial help.

webTitle: How the famous five were chosen

fields.headline: How the famous five were chosen
fields.trailText: The selection of Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Year has always been the perquisite of the Almanack's editor of the day. Perhaps he gets a little help from his friends. But the process has always been rather secretive, even mystical, and the choice personal, sometimes downright eccentric.
fields.body:
The selection of Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Year has always been the perquisite of the Almanack's editor of the day. Perhaps he gets a little help from his friends. But the process has always been rather secretive, even mystical, and the choice personal, sometimes downright eccentric.

The system works and, over the years, has come up with more interesting and less predictable names than a committee might have done. But once the decision was taken for Wisden to choose Five Cricketers of the 20th Century, it seemed inadequate. There was a precedent. When the centenary Almanack was published in 1963, Sir Neville Cardus was asked to name "Six [not, interestingly, five] Giants of the Wisden Century." He went for Sydney Barnes, Sir Donald Bradman, W. G. Grace, Sir Jack Hobbs, Tom Richardson and Victor Trumper.

But the cricketing 20th century was a much more global one than Wisden's first century. No list to cover the years 1900 to 1999 could reasonably include only white males: four Englishman and two Australians. And no one person's perception could properly cover the entire sweep of the game as it is now played. So it seemed right that, for the age of democracy, the choice should be made differently.

To reflect the pattern of cricket history, we established an electorate of 100, from all nine Test-playing countries but weighted to reflect each country's role in international cricket over the century, judged - very roughly - on the number of Tests played. So there were 28 English voters, 20 from Australia and so on down the line to just one from Zimbabwe.

The electorate comprised 97 men and three women (the doyenne of English women's cricket, Netta Rheinberg, the Pakistani journalist Fareshteh Gati and the Barbadian commentator Donna Symmonds). They were a mixture of cricketers, journalists (indeed many count as both), historians or even just expert observers of the game like Sir Carlisle Burton of Barbados. More than half had played Test cricket; all of them had watched copious amounts of it. There were many people whose broad knowledge and expertise would have added further lustre but who could not be squeezed in; to all of them my apologies.

Those who were asked faced a task that was essentially impossible. The major problem with this exercise is, of course, that no one watched all the cricket of the century. Some, however, came close, led by E. W. Swanton, whose first-hand knowledge of all cricket since the First World War was unsurpassable. We were fortunate that he was able to take part before he died in January 2000. We were also privileged to have three electors who played Test matches before the Second World War: Norman Gordon, Alf Gover and Lindsay Weir. It would be wrong, though, to have had this decision entirely filtered through the perhaps rheumy eyes of age. The current generation of cricketers, not all of whom have much feel for the game's history, was represented by the Australian captain Steve Waugh, who does.

To avoid embarrassment, it was decided not to ask any of the most obvious candidates for the accolade to be voters themselves, even though this meant losing, most obviously, the unparalleled judgment of Sir Donald Bradman. Even so, there was some overlap, and half a dozen of those asked to cast votes also received them. No one voted for himself, though there was one near-miss, which we will come to.

During the World Cup and just afterwards, the 100 voters were asked "to set aside any bias towards your own country and your own era, and name the five whose excellence at cricket during the 20th century you think has made the greatest contribution to the game".

They were told not to put the players in any order of merit, just to name the five, and given only two pieces of advice. One was a general point that has always driven the selection of Cricketers of the Year. "Excellence can be interpreted broadly," we said. "It is legitimate to take into account leadership qualities, personality, character and impact on the public." The second was more specific: "Please don't vote for W. G. Grace. We consider him a Cricketer of the 19th Century." They were given the option of explaining their choices if they wanted; some of the most telling remarks are quoted below.

There were no problems with the guidelines. A few (mostly journalists, of course) had problems with the deadlines. The terror on my part was that there might be a tie for fifth place, forcing us to find some kind of tiebreak mechanism. But it was not a problem: the final verdict was unexpectedly decisive, and there was a substantial gap between fifth and sixth.

It was not, of course, as great as the gap between second and third. The endorsement of Bradman was every bit as ringing as expected (I did wonder if someone, somewhere, might be contrarian, but no one dared). Steve Waugh summed up the consensus as eloquently as anyone: "Sir Donald really speaks for himself." "Only one Don," said Alan Davidson. No one can doubt, no one does doubt, that here was the greatest cricketer of the 20th century.

But Sir Garfield Sobers was not far behind. He was on 90 of the 100 ballot papers and those who left him out must have wrestled with their consciences first. "If there's been a better all-rounder," as Dickie Bird put it, "I'd love to have seen him play." Thus the overwhelming majority of those who voted felt, frustratingly, that they did not really have five votes but three - because the top two were certainties.

Indeed, many felt the same applied to Sir Jack Hobbs. But here there was a complication. Most people wanted to include someone to represent the pinnacle of English batsmanship, and there were alternatives. Walter Hammond's statistics are overwhelming. Then consider "impact on the public"; on that basis it is hard to argue against Denis Compton. And what about Sir Leonard? Many exceptional judges did not vote for Hobbs. John Woodcock chose Compton "for enchantment". Swanton made the case for Frank Woolley: "He scored more runs than anyone bar Hobbs and scored at around 50 an hour, giving more pleasure and for longer than any other English cricketer." And he took 2,000 wickets and 1,000 catches.

Enough, however, opted for Hobbs's quiet but devastating impact on the game. "He challenged the key assumption that no professional could bat as well as a thoroughbred amateur," said Gideon Haigh, editor of Wisden Australia. And he was, as our long-standing Sri Lankan correspondent Gerry Vaidyasekera put it, "a batsman with a charming smile and a kind heart".

Perhaps the biggest surprise is the identity of the player in fourth place. There were people among our hundred frightened to make a judgment on players they had not seen, which might have given present-day players an advantage. With perfect knowledge, maybe there would have been more votes for some of the early players, for Barnes, say, or Victor Trumper. But there are always former players who scorn the moderns, and perhaps an equal number of ballot papers reflected this factor. In any case, the votes for Shane Warne came from across the globe and across the generations. If anyone doubts his status, listen to Crawford White, 88 last year and the former cricket correspondent of the Daily Express, who watched both Warne and Bill O'Reilly. "O'Reilly didn't rip the ball through like Warne does," said White. "And I don't think he caught the imagination quite as much as this lad."

The fifth selection turned out to be a third specialist batsman, Viv Richards, "a master of both versions of the game," in the words of the Pakistani journalist Omar Kureishi. No one better epitomises the ferocious nature of cricket in the 1970s and 1980s - except perhaps Dennis Lillee. No specialist fast bowler made the final cut, arguably the one flaw in our selection. But Lillee was by far the nearest, with a particularly high poll from those who saw him at closest quarters - "To me, the greatest fast bowler in history," said Dickie Bird - as well as votes from such luminaries as Sir Everton Weekes and Peter Pollock.

Others preferred Harold Larwood or Ray Lindwall ("the greatest quickie of all in pace, control and movement" - Tom Graveney). In the end, Lillee was not even outright sixth, but finished equal with Sir Frank Worrell, whose position perhaps bore testament to the concept of interpreting excellence broadly, and the near-reverence in which he is still held as a leader whose impact resounded far beyond cricket. "A great man," said Richie Benaud, his most worthy opponent, putting Worrell in his five.

Some voters - quite legitimately - used at least one of their picks to include their personal heroes. Fred Trueman chose Wilfred Rhodes; one South African sheet anchor, Russell Endean, voted for another, Bruce Mitchell; Bob Taylor struck a blow for wicket-keepers, not easy to do in a list of just five, by choosing Godfrey Evans.

Others honoured their contemporaries. Vic Marks had the chance to name two of his Somerset team-mates - Richards and Ian Botham - and took it, though he resisted including Peter Denning, Peter Roebuck and Colin Dredge as well. Peter van der Merwe, the former South African captain, picked out Colin Bland: "He revolutionised the attitude to fielding, and set a standard not yet equalled." Alf Gover named Maurice Tate. Brian Close went for Trueman.

But there were also some touching, and unexpected, tributes across the generations. The great New Zealand batsman John Reid voted for Malcolm Marshall, before Marshall's tragically early death: "He seems to have had everything: pace, movement, accuracy, and the right attitude, which is hard to say of some other fast bowlers." Ian Chappell, that bonny fighter for cricketers' rights, went for Barnes: "Statistically a great bowler and stamped his character on the game by demanding that he always be paid his worth." Jonathan Agnew went for A. P. Freeman: "His statistics blow my mind whenever I read them."

One member of the panel, however, went very close to home indeed. Walter Hadlee confronted the issue squarely as he cast his ballot for his son, Sir Richard. "This has to be embarrassing for me," he wrote. "But there's a job to be done. I will cite the bare facts." And he did: 431 Test wickets and the transformation of New Zealand's Test record. "I consider him to be marginally ahead of Dennis Lillee," he concluded. And a dozen other people - all unrelated - came to a similar conclusion.

Not one of our hundred voted for all the final five. Yet I don't believe anyone will argue that we have got it terribly wrong. At least one of the five played in every decade of the century. We have two Australians, two West Indians and an Englishman, which seems geographically right (though one suspects an Asian or three will be up there for the 21st century). A total of 49 players received at least one vote. And the difficulty of the choice can be gauged by the quality of some of those who failed to get on the scoresheet at all: Keith Miller (who received many mentions in despatches), Barry Richards, Greg Chappell, Gooch, Laker, Lara, Hanif, C. B. Fry...

It was enormous fun just counting the votes; I think almost everyone enjoyed the exquisite torment of making a decision. If there is a sadness, it is only that none of us can expect to be around to have a second bite in 2100. But I hope our successors will make the attempt, and (with more video to guide them) will have just as many great cricketers from whom to choose.

In choosing and contacting the electorate, I was given special help by Mike Coward, Colin Bryden, Tony Cozier, R. Mohan, Qamar Ahmed and Don Cameron. To these, and everyone else who took part, I would like to express my gratitude.

Matthew Engel is editor of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack

webTitle: £1bn waste scandal as green tax flops

fields.headline: £1bn waste scandal as green tax flops
fields.trailText: Britain's first £1bn green tax, which aimed to make the polluter pay and give hundreds of millions of pounds to save the environment, has been dominated and distorted by the waste operators, a joint Guardian and Channel Four investigation reveals today.
fields.body:
Britain's first £1bn green tax, which aimed to make the polluter pay and give hundreds of millions of pounds to save the environment, has been dominated and distorted by the waste operators, a joint Guardian and Channel Four investigation reveals today.

The tax, introduced in 1996 by the Tory environment secretary John Gummer, was meant to extend conservation, develop research into recycling, and curb excessive rubbish dumping in the countryside. But it has led to further destruction of the countryside, allegations of fraud and misappropriation of money, and hijacking of some environment trusts by the waste industry.

Lax regulations, weak penalties and lack of resources to enforce the law have allowed the industry to ride roughshod over the tax.

The landfill tax was supposed to make it very expensive to dump contaminated waste. The £7-a-tonne tax, subsequently increased to £11 a tonne by Gordon Brown, was meant to ensure businesses would look to alternatives.

Instead the joint investigation has discovered that from Cornwall to Northumberland millions of tonnes of waste is being illegally dumped to avoid the tax. Inquiries reveal that 30 golf courses in Britain have been used for dumping a range of waste from asbestos and household rubbish to arsenic. In one city, contaminated waste has been dumped next to a shopping centre.

The environment agency, which is meant to inspect such sites, said last night: "We haven't got the resources to do it."

The new landfill regulations also allowed waste firms to avoid paying 20% of the tax if they gave that money to independent environmental trusts to tackle conservation, community projects and recycling, provided they did not make commercial gains from the deal. Waste firms could also set up their own environmental bodies provided they were run independently.

A regulator called Entrust - a private company - was appointed by customs and excise to supervise this money, which now totals more than £250m, to aid the environment. But the Guardian has found that the regulatory body includes senior waste industry staff and consultants and supervises a flawed initiative. There is evidence that not all the money has been used or allocated to the satisfaction of environmental groups.

fields.headline: Compost success fertilises botanic garden
fields.trailText: There is one place in Britain where the government's green tax is working as it should do - providing a huge increase in recycling along with investment in worthwhile environmental projects. That place is the Isle of Wight.
fields.body:
There is one place in Britain where the government's green tax is working as it should do - providing a huge increase in recycling along with investment in worthwhile environmental projects. That place is the Isle of Wight.

Desperately short of land to create dumps, and needing to dispose of 138,000 tonnes a year of rubbish, the island's county council has been forced to take drastic action.

It has a £40m deal under which 41% of domestic rubbish is being recycled -compared to an average 7.8% in the rest of Britain.

Island Waste, a subsidiary of Biffa, the waste company arm of Severn Trent Water, has re-equipped the council's dustcarts to separate kitchen waste, and is rebuilding an "energy from waste" power station (which will supply the national grid) so it can be fuelled by waste pellets processed at a refuse collection plant next door, one that also removes and recycles aluminium cans.

The most striking investment is £2.2m to build the UK's largest composting plant, a Canadian made machine that turns waste into compost within 14 days and can process 15,000 tonnes a year -more than can be used on the island at the moment.

The plant is responsible for a boom in organic farming. This year one of the island's biggest tomato growers intends to use the compost to grow his entire crop. The council also sells compost to gardeners and puts the rest on its parks and gardens.

This month the council closed one of its landfill sites, and within 15 to 20 years landfill will stop altogether. Any material that cannot be recycled will then have to be shipped to the mainland - making it very expensive.

Bruce Gilmore, general manager of Island Waste, is predicting that by next year more than 50% of rubbish will be recycled. "We shall be expanding our doorstep collection, which already covers newspapers, to include three types of glass and possibly textiles," he promised. The company is also trying to change attitudes to recycling by talking to schools and by targeting pensioners, the group most resistant to change.

Unlike some other schemes, distribution of landfill tax credits is given to a national body, the Royal Society for Nature Conservation, that has no connection with the waste industry. The main beneficiary on the Isle of Wight will be Ventnor botanic garden, which will get a visitors centre paid for by £600,000 from landfill tax and £830,000 from the Millennium Commission.

Another beneficiary will be the red squirrel, which will get new tree corridors.

The one flaw is that the firm monitoring Biffa's success in re-cycling is funded by landfill tax credits from the scheme - and, because of the way the landfill regulations are drawn up, the credits originally come from Biffa; but there is no other way to fund monitoring of the scheme.

What a waste

The UK produces 27m tonnes of municipal waste each year

2.2m tonnes of newsprint are recycled every year

Every day approximately 80m food cartons and drinks cans end up in landfill

Over 9m disposable nappies are used in Britain every day, for 4% of waste

Last year 20m plastic bottles were recycled in the UK

There are 22,000 bottle banks in the UK; 27% of all glass waste is recycled
