webTitle: Queen warned Wilson of civil list cash shortfall

fields.headline: Queen warned Wilson of civil list cash shortfall
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The then prime minister, Harold Wilson, and senior civil servants grappled for months with the problem of funding the monarchy after the Queen warned that she was running short of cash, newly-released documents disclose.
fields.body:
The then prime minister, Harold Wilson, and senior civil servants grappled for months with the problem of funding the monarchy after the Queen warned that she was running short of cash, newly-released documents disclose.

The Queen wanted more money from taxpayers in the late 1960s because the sum of cash she received from the government to cover official royal expenses had not been increased since she had come to the throne in 1953.

The civil list stood at £475,000 a year at 1952 prices and was found to be insufficient by 1970. But Mr Wilson, a devoted royalist, and Roy Jenkins, the chancellor of the exchequer, were reluctant to grant an increase before that date as they wanted to avoid a rumpus before the general election.

Mr Jenkins suggested that the Queen could dip into her private fortune to meet any shortfall until the next batch of funding from the public coffers was agreed, according to documents in the public record office.

Alternatively, "perhaps the royal family's bankers could be asked to help with a loan", he pointed out in a minute to Mr Wilson in May, 1968.

Mr Jenkins noted that some members of the royal family were "finding it increasingly difficult to manage" on their allowances.

Mr Wilson was worried that courtiers from the royal household would be subjected to "hostile" questioning from a select committee of MPs, especially since his government was straining to control the rise in people's wages and the cost of goods in the shops through a prices and incomes policy.

At a secret meeting with Mr Jenkins in July 1968, Mr Wilson said: "The palace would probably recognise that it was desirable, in the interests of avoiding controversy, that nothing should be done about a new civil list during the lifetime of this parliament."

He was concerned that a furore about the royal finances would be stirred up in 1969 when Prince Charles became the Prince of Wales. By doing so, he would be able to live off the whole of the profits which accrued from his estate, the Duchy of the Cornwall, instead of receiving payments from the civil list.

Mr Wilson warned: "It was likely that, when the prince came of age in November 1969, public attention would be drawn to the very large sum he would be receiving from the revenues of the Duchy of Cornwall."

The "problem" of the money given to the other members of the royal family was also discussed at this meeting between Mr Wilson and Mr Jenkins, but the minutes are censored until 2049.

Mr Wilson wanted the opposition parties to agree to delay resolving the question of royal finances until after the next general election.

But the then Tory leader Edward Heath was unwilling to cooperate.

webTitle: Money pours into the road to nowhere

fields.headline: Money pours into the road to nowhere
fields.standfirst: The country lane suddenly widens. Lorries bound for a landfill site roar past. This is an 'experimental road' paid for by the green tax
fields.trailText: Amid the undulating green of the Ayrshire countryside lies a road. A bendy little single-track road of the sort you find hidden among hedgerows across Britain. But then, at a point precisely the middle of nowhere, the road becomes something entirely different.
fields.body:
Amid the undulating green of the Ayrshire countryside lies a road. A bendy little single-track road of the sort you find hidden among hedgerows across Britain. But then, at a point precisely the middle of nowhere, the road becomes something entirely different.

It is no longer content to wind narrowly through the farmland: it has pretensions to greater things.

For the lost motorist it is instantly perplexing. The single-track road suddenly widens; where once there were potholes it is smooth; where once there was nothing road markings appear; for 700 metres the road is level and straight.

Then it stops, as suddenly as it appeared. And again it becomes the same slightly shabby old road, heading to nowhere in particular. There is no one around to ask about the road. In the nearest hamlets the locals say they know nothing about it - but on the rare occasions they have passed they have found it a little strange, too.

What the locals do not know is they are looking at an environmental project funded by a green tax that would otherwise have gone to the Treasury through customs and excise.

The scheme is funded by Canford Environmental - an environmental body registered in Companies House as a general commercial company. The money for the road has been approved by Entrust, the regulatory body in charge of funnelling money donated by landfill companies.

Officially the road has been described as a national research project which uses different types of recycled and reclaimed aggregate. But the use of recycled aggregates is hardly new.

There is another advantage to building this road. A sign alongside it gives a clue. It reads: "Barkip landfill. Waste management and recycling. Opened Monday to Sunday 0700-1900. Operated by William Tracey Ltd."

William Tracey Ltd describes itself as the largest independent waste management company in Scotland. Where the widened road ends is what the firm calls its "fully engineered, modern landfill site".

So here we have a company using money that could have gone to the Treasury to build a new access road for its lorries to speed along what was a narrow country lane to tip waste in the countryside. Under the rules of the green tax this is completely permissible.

A visit found the road busy but only with lorries trundling in and out of the site. A monitoring survey found 104 lorry movements every day - with hardly another car or farm vehicle in sight.

There is a reason why this section of road was chosen for the development. The literature for the experimental road scheme revealed it. The road had been damaged by excessive lorry movements to and from the Barkip site.

Mike Charles, senior waste campaigner for Friends of the Earth, says the Ayrshire example is depressingly familiar: "The only demonstration this road shows is the folly of allowing landfill operators to spend money on the environment."

Entrust sees things differently. "If it is an experimental road there might be a need to monitor carefully every lorry movement on the surface - so what better than virtually a private road where you can check the effect of every vehicle," a spokesman said.

The scheme is not the only one to be approved by Canford Environmental. The company also operates at the other end of the UK, in Dorset. Here it is planning to build a huge new sports facility for the residents of Poole and Bournemouth. The plans include full-size football pitches, two junior pitches, two mini pitches, a cricket pitch and a jogging track.

The scheme qualifies for green tax funding because it is improving the environment near a landfill site. But is not only sports enthusiasts who will benefit - a land registry search found that much of the site is owned by a firm called WH White and an associate company. And who is on the board of Canford but directors of WH White. And what does WH White do? It is the landfill operator that is putting money into the centre.

There are 10 directors of Canford Environmental. One director is Michael Tracey, director of William Tracey Ltd; another is David Telford, managing director of the Factor Ten Company - a company set up to supervise the develop ment of the Ayrshire road. The company secretary, Richard Watts, is company secretary of WH White. Two other directors, William Riddle and Jonathan Fryett, are also directors of WH White. Two others, Richard Harding and Martin Ross, are directors of companies associated with WH White. Another is the general manager of Canford Environmental. This leaves two people independent of the two landfill operators: a solicitor and a university professor.

So the net result is this - Canford has funded one road that benefits one waste disposal company that holds a directorship, and plans to provide a sports centre that will benefit a further two companies that between them have five directors on the Canford board.

Environmental bodies are expected to stay at arm's length from the landfill operators. The companies' directors do not dominate the board. But schemes such as these have led some to shake their heads. Mike Charles of Friends of the Earth says: "This shows you cannot trust the landfill operators to spend millions of pounds of money to help the environment."

Canford disagrees. Its general manager, Adrian Gunner, yesterday defended both the road and the sports centre: "I am very excited about the road; I believe it is the first genuine national research project outside a transport laboratory. Because the landfill operator knows the tonnage of every vehicle we can really work out how effective the materials are. I don't see it as a benefit to William Tracey because they would have to drive along it."

On the sports centre he said: "This landfill tax provision is to provide full-size soccer pitches, which everybody knows you cannot make a lot of money out of, so I don't see how the WH White directors will benefit financially out of it.

"They intend to leave the management of them to Poole and Bournemouth councils. It will be wonderful for the community. The rest of the project, which is profit-making, is not being funded from landfill tax."

webTitle: Wall Street slumps while London seizes up

fields.headline: Wall Street slumps while London seizes up
fields.trailText: Just 24 hours after Wall Street experienced its most volatile session in history, initial gains were soon wiped out by further slumps, while in London the market was paralysed for almost eight hours thanks to a technical glitch.
fields.body:
Just 24 hours after Wall Street experienced its most volatile session in history, initial gains were soon wiped out by further slumps, while in London the market was paralysed for almost eight hours thanks to a technical glitch.

Shares opened slightly higher in New York in nervous trading, but early gains soon faded with the Dow Jones industrial average declining 17.06 to 11,147.78, erasing a 53-point gain. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1.08 to 1493.65, and the Nasdaq index, home to many high-tech companies, lost 1.45 to 4147.44, after being up 50.

Today's opening followed a shaky Tuesday, when the Nasdaq and Dow each plummeted more than 500 points. A semblance of calm returned at the end of yesterday's trading as buyers returned in search of bargains, and most stocks ended the chaotic session with only moderate losses. Goldman Sachs' influential analyst Abby Cohen provided some footing for the US markets as she reiterated her confidence in the outlook for the US market. The "new/old economy" divide continued to dominate trading, with "new economy" stocks were back in favour as investors took heart from Nasdaq's dramatic recovery overnight.

In London, trading on one of the most important days of the financial year finally kicked off at 3.30pm, just an hour before the market was due to close, after the Stock Exchange was paralysed by a computer glitch from 8am. The Stock Exchange announced it was extending trading until 6.30pm to help make up for the failure which hit the markets on one of the busiest days for private investors - the last day of the tax year. At 3.58 pm, the FTSE 100 index was trading 111.7 points lower at 6,310.4, its low of the day so far. Volume was 120m shares in 21,879 transactions.

The inability to trade this morning left brokers frustrated and angry, particularly after the wild swings in New York overnight and sharp falls on the European bourses in trading today. Those most affected by today's breakdown - the second on the exchange in less than a week, and the worst in its history - were the retail investors, who are particularly active at the end of the tax year.

Today's problem was caused by a fault in the electronic feed that sends prices from the Exchange to dealers screens. Mark Dampier, of stockbrokers Hargreaves Lansdown, said: "It's been a very bad advertisement for the City of London. This is not going to make us look good on the world stage."

Yesterday's ructions on Wall Street spilled on to European markets as Frankfurt, Milan and Paris all tumbled. In afternoon trading Frankfurt was down 2.82%, Milan was off 2.70% and Paris was down 2.83%

fields.headline: Tesco rejects internet float
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Tesco, the supermarket group, yesterday dampened speculation that it was planning to float off its internet retailing arm TescoDirect from the rest of its operation.
fields.body:
Tesco, the supermarket group, yesterday dampened speculation that it was planning to float off its internet retailing arm TescoDirect from the rest of its operation.

Its shares had been buoyed on Monday by growing expectations that it would announce at its results meeting next Tuesday an intention to create a new stock market listing.

But chief executive Terry Leahy yesterday said e-commerce was at the heart of retailing and could not be separated from Tesco's core business. He told the annual meeting of the British Chambers of Commerce: "Every company has a long queue of banks outside their door suggesting they should go out and float their businesses. You have to decide whether your businesses on the internet are an interesting sidelines or whether they are the future of your company."

But he did not comment on predictions that he would split off TescoDirect and build up a separate management team to help it expand.

Tesco has stolen a march on competitors by building up its online grocery operation by using its existing stores to source deliveries. Others have been building depots especially to service Net orders.

But Tesco management is frustrated about the low stock market valuation of the company which makes it difficult to expand as fast as it would like.

Tesco shares closed up 4p at 219.5p.
fields.bodyText: Tesco, the supermarket group, yesterday dampened speculation that it was planning to float off its internet retailing arm TescoDirect from the rest of its operation. Its shares had been buoyed on Monday by growing expectations that it would announce at its results meeting next Tuesday an intention to create a new stock market listing. But chief executive Terry Leahy yesterday said e-commerce was at the heart of retailing and could not be separated from Tesco's core business. He told the annual meeting of the British Chambers of Commerce: "Every company has a long queue of banks outside their door suggesting they should go out and float their businesses. You have to decide whether your businesses on the internet are an interesting sidelines or whether they are the future of your company." But he did not comment on predictions that he would split off TescoDirect and build up a separate management team to help it expand. Tesco has stolen a march on competitors by building up its online grocery operation by using its existing stores to source deliveries. Others have been building depots especially to service Net orders. But Tesco management is frustrated about the low stock market valuation of the company which makes it difficult to expand as fast as it would like. Tesco shares closed up 4p at 219.5p.

fields.headline: Hands-free mobiles safe, say makers
fields.trailText: Mobile phone makers moved yesterday to quash claims that hands-free headsets trebled the amount of radiation beamed into the brains of users, accusing the Consumers' Association of using misleading tests.
fields.body:
Mobile phone makers moved yesterday to quash claims that hands-free headsets trebled the amount of radiation beamed into the brains of users, accusing the Consumers' Association of using misleading tests.

The association, which published the claim in its magazine Which?, acknowledged it had used a different test from the standard one demanded by the safety regulators, but said it stood by its findings that headsets and phone radiation shields offered no protection.

For the manufacturers, a spokesman for the Federation of the Electronics Industry said: "Tests made by FEI members and also at an independent laboratory have without exception shown that the absorption levels produced when using a headset are significantly less than those produced without a headset.

"All mobile phones on the market meet all relevant safety standards and recommendations, with or without an approved headset."

About 24m Britons now use mobiles, including 300,000 schoolchildren. Which? claimed that headsets, far from reducing microwave radiation produced by mobile phones - the reason many consumers bought them - channel three times as much radiation to the head, because the headset wires act as an aerial.

The magazine's editor, Graeme Jacobs, also urged people thinking of buying radiation shields: "Don't waste your money."

The association's research contradicts a study carried out last year by the National Physical Laboratory. The research found that shields cut radiation by 80%, while headsets reduce it by 98%.

The NPL, like phone manufacturers, used a test called specific absorption rate. An artificial human head, filled with a number of fluids which mimic the consistency of the brain and fitted with temperature sensors, measures the rise in temperature caused by using a mobile.

The Consumers' Association also used an artificial head, filled with a single type of brain-like material. But it did not measure increase in temperature, only the microwaves.

George McPherson, managing director of Philips Consumer Communications UK, said: "No conclusions on the health effects of the use of mobile phones with or without headsets can be drawn on the basis of the tests performed at the request of Which? magazine.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst:
The Question: Leah Brown believes the British start school too young, and is taking the government to the European Court of Human Rights over her child's education. When should a child start formal learning?
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Question: Leah Brown believes the British start school too young, and is taking the government to the European Court of Human Rights over her child's education. When should a child start formal learning?
fields.body:
Margaret Hodge
Education and employment minister
What matters is not where a child is, but the quality of the experience they enjoy. That's why we are introducing a foundation stage, the Early Learning Goals, a unified regulation and inspection regime working to national standards and a training programme for all practitioners. It's not about formal learning too soon. Like others in Europe, we want to encourage aptitudes that support a child's development - listening, speaking, concentrating, persisting and enjoying learning. That's what a child experiences in a nursery, a pre-school or a reception class.
Verdict: Four or five.

Christopher Clouder
Chief executive at the Steiner Waldorf Schools Fellowship
We believe young children have the right to experience childhood fully, and we're very worried by the current vogue for pressuring very young children into formal learning. Until the age of six a child educated on Steiner Waldorf principles would learn through play, which we believe is the natural way. We try to encourage a sense of wonder, to stimulate imaginations - we don't want any child to feel a failure. Social skills are also crucial at this stage, and can be forgotten about if the emphasis is on learning. Our children do just as well - they're not held back in any way.
Verdict: Six.

John Coe
National Association for Primary Education
It's not until the term after a child's fifth birthday that parents have a statutory responsibility to educate their children, but in practice many children start school at four. Even at five, many are simply too young to be in formal school - our European neighbours tend to start them at six or seven and there's evidence that it works well. Some children, especially summer-born boys, may be disadvantaged by our system. What's crucial at this young age is the right sort of learning. At present, too many children are being pitched into formal learning and it can set them back.
Verdict: Six.

Margaret Lochrie
Chief executive of the Pre-School Learning Alliance
Children need to be at least five, maybe six before they start formal school, but that's not the start of their learning. What happens at nursery is crucial - they learn about social behaviour, develop essential skills such as holding a pencil, learn concepts like big and small which are important pre-maths skills, learn about shapes and to enjoy stories. Nurseries are about play-based learning, but the skills are fundamental, and should never be dismissed. Probably one of the most crucial elements of nursery education is to enthuse the child about learning.
Verdict: Five or six.

Caroline Sharp
National Foundation for Educational Research
What matters is, first, the individual child and, second, the curriculum and environment on offer. Some four-year-olds are ready for formal education; others find "big school" difficult. There's no evidence that starting formal education early gives children an advantage later on. A possible disadvantage is that some could be discouraged by having too much asked of them too soon. In some countries, such as the US, there is more flexibility in the system, with room for negotiation between family and school over what would work best for a particular child.
Verdict: Depends on child.

Jane Chitnis
Mother of three children
My daughter Asmita was only just four when she started school, and it did seem too young. Where we live - Wandsworth in London - there's no provision for children who are young in the school year to start later than September, because the school doesn't get its funding if a child defers entry. It was hard on Asmita - she was still sleeping in the afternoons and she'd often fall asleep during story time. When she came home she used to say, "It goes on too long." I felt sad that she was being forced into a formal set-up so early in her life - she'd have been happier just playing.
Verdict: At least five.

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: Last year, after watching footage of a shooting in a California kindergarten, Donna Rees-Thomases applied for a permit to march on the mall in Washington DC on May 14 2000 - US Mother's Day. The idea was to mobilise American mothers against lax gun laws. With just one answering machine in New Jersey and two grandmothers taking messages, the Million Mom March was born. Today Rees-Thomases has offices in Washington DC and branches all over the US, powered solely by volunteer mothers.
fields.body:
Last year, after watching footage of a shooting in a California kindergarten, Donna Rees-Thomases applied for a permit to march on the mall in Washington DC on May 14 2000 - US Mother's Day. The idea was to mobilise American mothers against lax gun laws. With just one answering machine in New Jersey and two grandmothers taking messages, the Million Mom March was born. Today Rees-Thomases has offices in Washington DC and branches all over the US, powered solely by volunteer mothers.

"We are going to put Congress on notice that commonsense gun policy is the will of the people," she says.

Every day in the US 12 children die from gunshot wounds, often the result of loaded guns in the home or firearms bought at trade shows or on the black market. Guns purchased at gun shows, which Rees-Thomases calls "Tupperware parties for criminals", do require no registration.

Now, one month before an estimated quarter of a million mothers, fathers and grandparents descend on Washington, another mothers' protest group, the Armed Informed Mothers of America (Aim), have announced their plans to sabotage the march on the grounds that "we won't stand for having our right to defend our families ripped away".

But Million Mom Marchers are unperturbed. They insist that Aim's pro-gun message will be drowned out by the sheer numbers finally taking a stand on gun violence.

fields.headline: 'Mum, I've been raped'
fields.standfirst: When  Sarah Collender's 16-year-old daughter, Emma, was assaulted, the whole family felt the repercussions.
fields.trailText: When Sarah Collender's 16-year-old daughter, Emma, was assaulted, the whole family felt the repercussions.
fields.body:
When friends complain about their teenage daughters' behaviour, I am gripped with crippling nostalgia for those days of loud music, interminable phonecalls and arguing about whether pierced belly buttons are "common". It wasn't an easy time, but it was normal. And my daughter was a perfectly normal 16-year-old - until one night three years ago, when a stranger followed her off a bus, dragged her down an alley and raped her.

Through some misunderstanding, I had thought she was staying at her boyfriend's that night, so I'd gone to bed, not even expecting her home. I will never forget opening my eyes to see her standing over me, crying and shivering, her hand on my shoulder to wake me gently as she whispered: "Mum, I've been raped." As I woke my husband, Emma's stepfather, and my son, to tell them what had happened, we began to realise that life would never be the same again for Emma, or indeed for any of us.

What happened to my daughter devastated our family - it also affected close friends and even colleagues. I remember particularly the reactions of the men. On the morning after it happened, my husband took my son, then 13 and stunned into an angry yet slightly bewildered silence, to a football match while we dealt with the immediate post-rape formalities. His eyes still fill with tears as he remembers sitting next to my son at the match with everyone around them cheering and singing, not knowing what to say or do, and trying not to let my son see that he was crying.

My sister's husband raged. He wanted to know exactly what was being done to catch the rapist and had clear ideas on what should be done with him (and to him) if and when he was caught. My male boss and colleagues wept and then they too talked of revenge, death and castration. They were no more angry or distressed than the women, but they felt ashamed to be male, and guilty on behalf of mankind.

They didn't know how to approach my daughter, or even how to be in the same room with her. Would she trust them, or would she now always fear men? They didn't know how they should be around her and were too uncomfortable and embarrassed to ask.

Perhaps the most difficult family member to tell was my mother. The relationship between a grandparent and grandchild is an uncomplicated one, where each seeks to protect the other from the harshness of life, where a teenager or young adult can slip back into childhood and where granny can spoil them rotten without worrying about the consequences. How the hell do you tell a grandma that her granddaughter has been raped?

I told her carefully, starting with: "She's okay, but..." She wasn't okay, of course, but what I meant was that she was alive and she hadn't been mutilated or beaten to a pulp. My mother went quiet at the other end of the telephone. Perhaps she was steadying herself or grabbing a chair in case she fainted, as my sister nearly did when she heard. I asked her if she was all right, but I don't remember what else we said to each other, just that we'd talk later.

When we did talk, it was both as mother and daughter and as one mother to another. My mum, aware that the worst thing that can happen to a mother is for something dreadful to happen to her child, was torn between her pain at what had happened to Emma and her pain at what was happening to me as Emma's mother.

She said, bizarrely it seemed at first, that in some odd way, she would have found it easier to cope with if it had me who had been raped. That way, she would have only had to deal with the one terrible thing. As it was, she had to cope not only with the awfulness of what her granddaughter had been through, but also the agony that I, in many ways still her baby, was suffering as a mother whose child has been raped.

The memory of my own reaction is somewhat hazy. I did not, as you might expect, scour the streets in search of the beast who had violated my daughter and turned our lives upside down. Nor did I even give much thought to revenge or punishment. Whether they caught him or not seemed irrelevant; the fact was that she had been raped and nothing could change that. I was angry, of course, but it was a subdued anger I was totally incapable of expressing.

Although my reactions seemed less obvious than those of the rest of the family, they stemmed from the same basic responses. We are always horrified by rape, but when it is your child, the horror is indescribable, and the feelings of revulsion, inadequacy and guilt that you were not there to protect her are magnified to such an extent that you wonder how you can continue to breathe.

Three years on, we seem a normal family and we have adapted to the changes, but some things will never be the same. My two little nieces, too young at the time to know what was happening, will, I fear, be allowed less freedom than they may otherwise have enjoyed. I often wonder if, when and what we will tell them about what happened to their cousin.

My daughter, who instinctively understood the awkwardness of male friends and relatives, worked hard at reassuring them that she felt relaxed in the company of men she knew and trusted. She still, however, finds it difficult to trust men she didn't know before the rape. Although mature for her age, she was catapulted into a world of which her contemporaries had no experience. She suffered an inevitable period of sleeplessness, panic attacks and depression and then - her attacker having been caught after committing another rape - she had to deal with the trial, which involved a harrowing three days in the witness box and a vicious and degrading cross-examination.

Fortunately, and unusually (only a tiny proportion of rape cases result in conviction), the rapist received a life sentence. In raping my daughter, he stole a large and important part of her life. She was no longer able to join in with teenage chatter, and although she went to parties and school get-togethers a couple of times, what did she have in common with her mates?

She now has a baby girl of her own. It is unlikely that she would have become a mother at the age of 19 had her life not been brutally yanked off course at 16. But, in having her child, she has ultimately regained control over her own body. She fears that she'll be the sort of mother who will never let her child out of her sight, half-joking to me after the birth: "Would 35 be too soon to let her out on her own?"

The biggest change in our family is awareness. Having been forced to confront rape and the issues surrounding it, we are all better informed. We know, for example, how difficult it is to bring a rape case to court, much less get a conviction. We know that when the majority of defendants are acquitted, it does not mean that the majority of women are lying, rather than that the current system makes rape extremely difficult to prove beyond reasonable doubt.

We also know that the cross-examination of rape victims is often described as a "third rape" (the second being the invasive and painful medical examination). With so many women seeing their attackers go free after all this, is it any wonder that rape is so under-reported?

Only after rape has touched your life do you begin to realise its prevalence, and until we accept the magnitude of the problem, it will continue to go unreported because women rightly assume that society will not believe them.

The recent estimate of a quarter of a million woman suffering rape or other sexual assaults, most of them by someone known to them, is shocking, and we don't want to believe it. But I do not, for one moment, doubt it. Rape happens to all sorts of women (and men), devastating them and their families. And while this situation exists, an increasing number of rapists are learning that they can get away with it - again, and again, and again.

 The author's name has been changed for legal reasons.

webTitle: Just wait till your father gets home

fields.headline: Just wait till your father gets home
fields.standfirst: The Conways left their 13-year-old for two hours. When they got back, the house was trashed. When are kids old enough to know better, asks  Maggie Brown.
fields.trailText: The Conways left their 13-year-old for two hours. When they got back, the house was trashed. When are kids old enough to know better?
fields.body:
Is there a parent in the land who didn't involuntarily shudder on hearing the tale of Richard and Elaine Conway? They left their 13-year-old son Adam alone for the first time, only to return to find the place trashed in less than two hours. It wasn't that Adam had encouraged the rampage; far from it. He had been overwhelmed. The Conways found him wandering haplessly around vomit-streaked walls and beer-soaked beds, with a can of carpet cleaner in his hand. A mob of around 80 teenagers had heard of the parent-free house in St Ives, Cambridgeshire, and, armed with all the usual teenage stimulants, and cocky because there were no bouncers to stand in their way, barged in and ran riot.

I immediately thought of the one and only teenage party I'd organised when my eldest of four children, a daughter, was 14. It was three years ago, but it is etched on my memory. Although the ground floor had been cleared, an antique chair stowed away on a landing was discovered, broken, and its legs used as mock guitars. Drunk schoolboys streamed out of the french window, filled the garden bushes with empty lager cans and smuggled-in vodka bottles, and were sick. Other seemingly well-brought up kids smashed the Christmas tree decorations on the floor and danced the pieces into the wood. All the while we had remained, tactfully invisible, not intending to show our faces, in an upstairs bedroom. (The person who became most furious, and blew the whistle, was our three-year-old son, who was woken by the smashing glass, rushed downstairs, and shouted at the big boys to leave his tree alone.)

But did the Conways bring it on themselves? Should a boy of 13 be left alone, or with a friend of similar age for company, while parents indulge in a night out? The Conways, in the event, didn't blame their son: he had been unable to get the invading boys out. But he is in that difficult early-teens category, a grey area. It is an age when asserting independence matters, and when parents also start to want some payback, to reclaim their free time again.

It is perfectly natural for the interests of parents and teenagers to start diverging dramatically: it is part of growing up and separating, culminating in the all too frequent stroppy refusal to join family events, or take family holidays. What are parents supposed to do? Certainly I've noticed a trend for parents of sixth-form children to take term-time breaks alone, leaving only fairly rudimentary supervision in place.

Suzie Hayman, agony aunt of Woman's Own, professional counsellor and author of You Just Don't Listen - a parents guide to communi cating with children - says: "I'm a great believer in teenagers being given responsibility. They rise to it. But the more you talk to them, rehearse situations that might arise, the better. For example, what might happen if friends come round."

Thirteen, she says, is too young to be left alone for long, but she advises there should be a sliding scale, taking into account the maturity of the child. This requires individual judgment. "Some 16-year-olds are very mature. Others are not. There is no hard and fast rule. To leave a 13-year-old overnight alone is foolish."

The point, she adds, is that a teenager may like having friends round, but not if it means having their place trashed. "After all, it's their home, too. So you have to role-play with them, imagine what could happen." But her attitude hardens for ages below that.

"It is terribly dangerous to leave smaller children alone. The task of being a young child is being curious. You can't punish a child for that. The lesson is that being a parent is just bloody hard work."

Michele Elliott, director of Kidscape, says in her book Ways to be a Good Parent that there is no law in England stating a specific age for when you can leave children alone, but you can be prosecuted if you do so and they subsequently come to harm (in Scotland it is against the law to leave children alone under 12). And yet, as she says, even though experts say small children shouldn't be left alone, how often have you had to slip across the road to buy milk, post a letter?

"Most parents have found themselves in this position for one reason or another and, fortunately, nothing untoward has happened. I talked with a group of five-year-olds in one school and found 15 out of 20 had been home alone at least once in their lives," says Elliott.

These figures are borne out by a study presented to the Society for the Research on Adolescence this week in Michigan, which showed that, in America at least, "latchkey kids" as young as five were spending more than 45 minutes a day at home alone because of parents working.

Valerie Howarth, chief executive of Childline, says it would scare her to death to leave a five-year-old alone. "No parent should leave their children unless they are absolutely sure they will be properly cared for."

But it happens. And until there are a range of really practical, affordable options, such as after-school clubs that stay open long enough, it's hard to see it stopping. Elliott's advice for older children is to establish a set of practical ground rules, fire drills, emergency numbers, what do to in case of obscene phone calls and intruders. And surely, parents also should take into account children's fears and needs.

Childline had 270 calls from children left alone last year. Some children had been abandoned for days. Others, very young, rang at night, alone and frightened. One girl, aged 14, rang because her mother used her non-stop as a carer for her baby sister. Children as they enter their teens are proud to be given an increasing amount of independence. And younger children relish and probably need time on their own, in a bedroom, or garden, to simply "muck around" rather than supervised play. But equally, they do not enjoy feeling abandoned or being really left alone.

Childhood fears stalk even apparently well-adjusted children. One of my daughters, when she was seven, rang 999 because she thought she had been left alone. In fact I was simply at the bottom of the garden. But then I wondered if it stemmed back to a genuine muddle, a year earlier, when rushing out to pick up her sister from a friend, we suddenly realised we had forgotten her, playing quietly in her bedroom on the third floor. And we had switched the burglar alarm on! Yes, it had gone off by the time we hared back. Yes, the police were outside, talking to her as she peered panic-stricken through a top floor window. fields.headline: Secrets and lies
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: The diary of a part-time father.
fields.body:
My wife Angie and I speak often by phone: she from work or in transit, me from our sweet-and-sour home. We speak face to face as well, but cannot always do so about what worries us most. That's because what worries us most is the emotional condition of Gloria, Jed and Billy; and it particularly worries us while they're under our roof when, of course, such matters cannot be discussed except in furtive whispers.

So after the part-time threesome have been hustled off to school and half-sister Estelle is ensconced with her childminder, Angie and I get gabbing.

Frequently, we ponder standard questions. Is Billy apparently so sublimely unworried about living in two homes because he's in a potentially disastrous state of denial or because he is, well, sublimely unworried the way six-year-olds are? Is his older brother Jed just as withdrawn when he is at his "other house", or does he save up being withdrawn - and suspicious, disapproving and generally infuriating - for when he is with Angie and me?

Given the state of sullen non-communication between us and that pair of cooing egomaniacs - Hello Dilys darling ex! Hello Chris the Pillock, pseudo-dad and supernerd! - who run things at the "other house", there is no hope of sharing insights into such matters. (Why let little things like the welfare of children spoil a good feud?)

Which brings us to Gloria. Just turned 12, she is our only source of specific information about the chemistries and carry-ons that go on at Chez Pillock. But she is also scrupulous about never taking sides. This, I have read, is common among children who become part of two families at once. It also brings out in Gloria a prickly rectitude that so reminds me of her mother that I can't resist the urge to misbehave. Such was the case when she let slip to me that Chris was going to the USA.

"Oh really? What for?"

"A Manly Men convention."

She stiffened, realising immediately she'd given something away. It was getting late, and she'd dropped her guard. I should have let it be. But I couldn't help persisting.

"Interesting! And what goes on at those?"

"I don't know, Joe. And please don't ask me about it any more."

Being very firm now. Just like Dilys has told her to be when I ask awkward questions. A Manly Men convention! Couldn't wait to share that one with Angie. But I had a serious question first.

"Gloria. I've been wondering. Would your mum and Chris like to have children of their own?"

It wasn't just the question that was risky. It was the nomenclature, too: I put up with being called "Joe" instead of "Dad", even though it's not something I asked for, but Chris remains "Chris" and Dilys remains "your mum" when I speak of them to the children. Please also note the formulation "children of their own". My little way of telling Gloria she's my daughter, not Chris's. Blood distinction matters. And there are limits to what I'll live with for the sake of peace.

Gloria let this sink in. Then: "I don't know that either," she replied, avoiding my eyes. Hmmm. Maybe. Angie would find out. I stole up to our bedroom, but she was already asleep. So I saved my exciting news for a phonecall the next morning.

"Joe," she answered, "I'm on the bus, and standing. Can't it wait?"

"Not today. Chris is going to a Manly Men convention."

"You're joking."

"I would never joke about a thing like that. I reckon he's got tadpole trouble."

"Pardon?"

"Can't get the little chaps to swim upstream."

"What are you talking about?"

"Could be under-production. If his name was Rover they'd have to close him down."

This was speculation. There could, of course, be many reasons why Dilys and Chris have produced no children together. But if Chris was having problems with his sperm, it would explain a lot about him: Manly Men conventions, for example. It also conjured up disturbing images. Chris scouring the high street for baggy boxer shorts. Chris lying on his back, his scrotum stacked with bags of frozen peas. Reflecting on such indignity, I almost felt sorry for him. Almost.

fields.headline: Markets swoon after Microsoft ruling
fields.trailText: European markets fell sharply this morning following some of the most volatile trading ever experienced by Wall Street. Technology shares were the hardest hit, falling more than 3% by late morning in a broad retreat in which other sectors saw losses ranging from 1 to 3.3%.
fields.body:
European markets fell sharply this morning following some of the most volatile trading ever experienced by Wall Street. Technology shares were the hardest hit, falling more than 3% by late morning in a broad retreat in which other sectors saw losses ranging from 1 to 3.3%.

Frankfurt, Paris and Milan took the biggest hits as their main indices fell more than 3% each. London was spared market turmoil because of computer problems at the FTSE. "There's no panic yet, but people are getting very, very cautious," one trader said.

Asian markets largely weathered the storm which erupted in the US overnight, with only Hong Kong suffering a sharp sell-off. Markets had opened in fear that gyrations in the technology-laden Nasdaq, which plunged over 13% before closing down 1.77%, would spark a wave of investor selling in hi-tech shares across the region.

In the event, it was mainly Hong Kong's technology, media and telecommunications companies which bore the brunt of the selling. In the broader market, the Hang Seng index closed 3.4% or 574.49 points down at 16,318.44 - its lowest level in six weeks.

In today's market ructions in Europe, heavy individual losers included Nokia, which fell 7.6% to 192.2 euros, and Dutch telecom stock KPN, which shed 5.5% to 94.5 euros. Europe's sell-off came after the Nasdaq and the Dow Jones index suffered one of their most volatile days ever on Tuesday. Panic selling carved more than 13% out of the Nasdaq and 4.5% out of the Dow in frantic trading.

Both indices later recovered as cash moved back into manufacturing, pharmaceuticals and some top computer names. The Nasdaq and the Dow closed down 1.77% and 0.5% respectively. Traders said European sentiment was being further undermined by uncertainty about how American markets would perform later today. Early indications were that both key US indices would extend yesterday's losses as S&P and Nasdaq futures traded lower.

Traders said direction could be determined by first quarter results from Internet portal Yahoo!, which routinely reports strong quarterly sales and profits. Before the recent slide in technology stocks, Yahoo! symbolised the almost unlimited potential of the entire technology sector. But following this week's sell-off of technology shares, analysts said Yahoo!'s results could be a potential cause for further selling in other stocks.

"Should Yahoo! miss any numbers or deliver another negative shot to the market, that could thwart any comeback [in internet stocks]," said Bob Walberg, an analyst at Briefing.com in Chicago.

The immediate trigger for US volatility was the court ruling that Microsoft had broken US anti-trust law by attempting to monopolise the internet browser market. Judge Thomas Jackson has not yet decided what action to take against Microsoft, but plans a new round of hearings to decide on "remedies".

fields.headline: Wise Woolf
fields.standfirst: Despite the sound sense of the riots inquiry, a serious question remains: why do we put up with anachronisms such as Dartmoor?
fields.trailText: Despite the sound sense of the riots inquiry, a serious question remains: why do we put up with anachronisms such as Dartmoor?
fields.body:
One of the first things the Woolf inquiry team did was to visit the sites of the worst disturbances. Strangeways, the largest prison in the land, was a scene of utter devastation, yet even then it was possible to imagine that the building would be used again. Strangeways is an ideal city site and its design is excellent for its purpose. The building needed upgrading: the damage provided an opportunity to start afresh.

By contrast, Pucklechurch remand centre, outside Bristol, a prison with which I was very familiar by dint of 10 years' membership of its board of visitors, was a burnt-out ruin over which I shed not a tear. It had been a shabby 1950s building, in which no noble aspirations or any real organisational effort had ever been invested, and it never re-opened. Its former young prisoners, held in enforced idleness by a thoroughly alienated staff, dispersed for ever.

Elsewhere, the damage was more limited and the prospects for the future more complex. The prisons at Cardiff, Bristol and Glen Parva in Leicestershire, all had obvious roles. But I knew that the penal anachronism on Dartmoor would be the acid test for the success of our efforts. The prison service had many years earlier attempted to close Dartmoor and had mothballed parts of it. Its interior should have become a tourist attraction in the 1960s. But. although totally unsuitable for its contemporary purpose, Dartmoor will continue to be used until we tackle overall prison numbers.

Ten months after those initial visits, the Woolf report was published. It grew out of a remarkable series of public consultation exercises, during the course of which much common ground emerged. The report was almost universally welcomed. There seemed a real likelihood that Woolf's key recommendations would be implemented and that prison overcrowding might cease. At a Woolf seminar the then director general, Chris Train, said an end to overcrowding was the "indispensable precondition of sustained and universal improvement in prison conditions". The prison population had fallen and stabilised below 45,000.

The 1991 Criminal Justice Act, premised on more parsimonious use of imprisonment, was introduced. In 1993, prison capacity and the prison population were in equilibrium for the first time for several decades. Yet Woolf's proposal that no establishment be permitted to hold more than 3% above its certificated number, unless the minister laid an authorising certificate before both houses of parliament, was rejected. In the face of tabloid criticisms, Ken Clarke, the then home secretary, lost his nerve over the 1991 act and reversed key parts of it.

His successor, Michael Howard, resorted, unashamedly, to the populist ticket and pronounced what all his advisers in the Home Office knew to be a serious distortion of the truth: "prison works".

The judges and magistrates sentenced accordingly. The proportion of defendants sentenced to imprisonment in the crown court had, by 1998, increased from 44% to 61%, and in the magistrates courts from 5% to 12%. Sentences also got longer. The prison population soared to its present level of 65,000. The latest Home Office projections - which need not come to pass - anticipate there being anything between 70,400 and 80,300 prisoners in 2007.

Woolf's proposals for "community prisons" and "prisoner compacts" were knocked sideways by the disastrous escapes from Whitemoor and Parkhurst in 1994 and 1995. The resulting Woodcock and Learmont reports may have been intellectually bereft and their proposed super-maximum security prisons and revised prisoner security system will not now be implemented. Nevertheless, sufficient of their recommendations were adopted, greatly increasing the "depth" of imprisonment - more security, greater surveillance, fewer opportunities for prisoners to go out. Whereas Woolf saw "security," "control" and "justice" as complementary and symbiotic components of acceptable prison regimes, Learmont made no reference to "justice" and saw "care" and "custody" as conflicting. Giving them their due weight caused "confusion"; custody was the "primary purpose". Whereas Woolf entertained prisoners' rights - "legitimate expectations" which, if breached, "could provide an application for judicial review" - there was instead the introduction of an incentives and earned privileges scheme. The independent evaluation of this scheme found that it was introduced inconsistently, failed to improve prisoner behaviour and did not enhance prisoners' perceptions of staff fairness.

Yet despite these dismal developments, the Woolf agenda remains alive because prison personnel go on dusting off the report. They do so because the Woolf analysis is based on some fundamental truths.

First, the vast majority of prisoners are in prison briefly - months rather than years. It therefore makes sense for most prisons to be organised according to local catchment areas so that the same agencies with whom prisoners dealt prior to their incarceration, and with whom they will have to deal again on release, are involved in the delivery of prison services. Further, if prisoners' often tenuous contacts with their families are not nurtured, the prospect of them leading law-abiding lives is diminished. Community prisons make sense. Eliminating prisoners' opportunities to exercise responsibility -through home leave, and so on - does not.

Second, if prisoners leave prison with a sense of injustice, or if they have been held idle in degrading conditions, then their commitment to the values allegedly underpinning the criminal justice system will not be enhanced, and the whole criminal justice exercise founders. Woolf put the final nail in the coffin of slopping-out and, in report after report, the chief inspector of prisons continues to expose the unfairness and barren futility of some prison regimes - particularly for young prisoners. His recent report on Portland is a case in point.

Prisons are generally in better shape than 10 years ago - less overcrowded, better managed, more orderly, providing more active regimes. But there remains a long way to go, and the government's welcome emphasis on offence-focused programmes for prisoners has unfortunately resuscitated a dangerous myth: that prisons provide a good environment within which to make people better.

They do not - which is why Dartmoor lives on and there is no talk of closing it.

 Rod Morgan, who was an assessor to Lord Woolf, is professor of criminal justice and director of the centre for criminal justice at the University of Bristol.

Ten months after those initial visits, the Woolf report was published. It grew out of a remarkable series of public consultation exercises, during the course of which much common ground emerged. The report was almost universally welcomed. There seemed a real likelihood that Woolf's key recommendations would be implemented and that prison overcrowding might cease. At a Woolf seminar the then director general, Chris Train, said an end to overcrowding was the "indispensable precondition of sustained and universal improvement in prison conditions". The prison population had fallen and stabilised below 45,000. The 1991 Criminal Justice Act, premised on more parsimonious use of imprisonment, was introduced. In 1993, prison capacity and the prison population were in equilibrium for the first time for several decades. Yet Woolf's proposal that no establishment be permitted to hold more than 3% above its certificated number, unless the minister laid an authorising certificate before both houses of parliament, was rejected. In the face of tabloid criticisms, Ken Clarke, the then home secretary, lost his nerve over the 1991 act and reversed key parts of it. His successor, Michael Howard, resorted, unashamedly, to the populist ticket and pronounced what all his advisers in the Home Office knew to be a serious distortion of the truth: "prison works". The judges and magistrates sentenced accordingly. The proportion of defendants sentenced to imprisonment in the crown court had, by 1998, increased from 44% to 61%, and in the magistrates courts from 5% to 12%. Sentences also got longer. The prison population soared to its present level of 65,000. The latest Home Office projections - which need not come to pass - anticipate there being anything between 70,400 and 80,300 prisoners in 2007. Woolf's proposals for "community prisons" and "prisoner compacts" were knocked sideways by the disastrous escapes from Whitemoor and Parkhurst in 1994 and 1995. The resulting Woodcock and Learmont reports may have been intellectually bereft and their proposed super-maximum security prisons and revised prisoner security system will not now be implemented. Nevertheless, sufficient of their recommendations were adopted, greatly increasing the "depth" of imprisonment - more security, greater surveillance, fewer opportunities for prisoners to go out. Whereas Woolf saw "security," "control" and "justice" as complementary and symbiotic components of acceptable prison regimes, Learmont made no reference to "justice" and saw "care" and "custody" as conflicting. Giving them their due weight caused "confusion"; custody was the "primary purpose". Whereas Woolf entertained prisoners' rights - "legitimate expectations" which, if breached, "could provide an application for judicial review" - there was instead the introduction of an incentives and earned privileges scheme. The independent evaluation of this scheme found that it was introduced inconsistently, failed to improve prisoner behaviour and did not enhance prisoners' perceptions of staff fairness. Yet despite these dismal developments, the Woolf agenda remains alive because prison personnel go on dusting off the report. They do so because the Woolf analysis is based on some fundamental truths. First, the vast majority of prisoners are in prison briefly - months rather than years. It therefore makes sense for most prisons to be organised according to local catchment areas so that the same agencies with whom prisoners dealt prior to their incarceration, and with whom they will have to deal again on release, are involved in the delivery of prison services. Further, if prisoners' often tenuous contacts with their families are not nurtured, the prospect of them leading law-abiding lives is diminished. Community prisons make sense. Eliminating prisoners' opportunities to exercise responsibility -through home leave, and so on - does not. Second, if prisoners leave prison with a sense of injustice, or if they have been held idle in degrading conditions, then their commitment to the values allegedly underpinning the criminal justice system will not be enhanced, and the whole criminal justice exercise founders. Woolf put the final nail in the coffin of slopping-out and, in report after report, the chief inspector of prisons continues to expose the unfairness and barren futility of some prison regimes - particularly for young prisoners. His recent report on Portland is a case in point. Prisons are generally in better shape than 10 years ago - less overcrowded, better managed, more orderly, providing more active regimes. But there remains a long way to go, and the government's welcome emphasis on offence-focused programmes for prisoners has unfortunately resuscitated a dangerous myth: that prisons provide a good environment within which to make people better. They do not - which is why Dartmoor lives on and there is no talk of closing it.  Rod Morgan, who was an assessor to Lord Woolf, is professor of criminal justice and director of the centre for criminal justice at the University of Bristol.

fields.headline: When wishes come true
fields.standfirst: David Brindle on the launch of this year's competition to honour outstanding work by voluntary groups in the social welfare sector
fields.trailText: David Brindle on the launch of this year's competition to honour outstanding work by voluntary groups in the social welfare sector
fields.body:
With more than 100 new charities registered each week, it's ever harder to stand out from the crowd. But five voluntary groups will be able to do just that by winning this year's Guardian Charity Award, launched today.

The winners, to be announced in the autumn, will each receive £5,000. Just as important, though, is the prestige that comes with the award and the undoubted confidence boost for staff, volunteers and supporters.

"It's been brilliant, absolutely wonderful," says Pauline Collishaw, head of fundraising at Friends for Young Deaf People (FYD), one of last year's winners. "It's given us the kudos to go forward, showing that we have been recognised for our work. The full benefits are still to be reaped."

The award, now in its eighth year, aims to showcase excellence among small to medium sized charities in the social welfare sector.

Supported until last year by the Jerwood Foundation, it is being backed this time by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, the sector's leading research and policy development institute.

Entries are invited from charities registered for at least two years, with annual income of between £5,000 and £1m. They must be able to demonstrate outstanding practice and achievement and have a clear vision of future progress, including plans for the use of any prize money.

In addition to the award, one of the winners is chosen to feature in the Guardian's Christmas appeal. Last year, FYD was selected and the charity is receiving some £30,000 extra as a result - all of which will be ploughed into its work with young people struggling to cope with deafness and the educational, social and economic exclusion that it all too often means. Many leave school with a reading age of just eight.

Collishaw says the charity's main current project is to set up a network of family co-ordinators able to work with families from the moment they learn they have a deaf child. Nine in 10 deaf babies are born to hearing parents, very often traumatised by the news. The scheme has proved its worth in pilot form and is to be established permanently at a three-year cost of £460,000 - all of which, it is hoped, will be met by grant funding.

Having the Guardian award has been a real boon in securing such funds. And the publicity last October, and again at Christmas, has triggered other media interest in FYD and the issues it tackles. "It's all been enormously helpful," says Collishaw.

Last year's other winners reflect the broad range of the award: the Belfast Community Circus School teaches circus skills to young people - and even some adults - as a way of helping heal a fractured city; Winston's Wish works with children who have suffered the loss of a parent, hitherto in Gloucestershire but now spread ing further afield; the Gaia Trust promotes sustainable living in picturesque but impoverished Cornwall; and Community Service Volunteers' Retired and Senior Volunteer Programme (RSVP) harnesses the talents and energy of some 6,000 older people across the country in voluntary activities ranging from gardening to counselling.

Previous winners of the award have included prison charities, arts groups and even a self-build housing organisation.

More than 1,000 charities have entered for the award since the scheme started in 1993. Over the years, several winners have been making a second or even third bid for success, so repeat entries are encouraged - especially if a project has moved on, achieved more concrete results, or perhaps taken a partly or wholly different direction.

Closing date for entries is June 16. The winners, who will be honoured at a reception in London in October, will be chosen by a judging panel chaired by Simon Armson, chief executive of the Samaritans, and including also Naomi Eisenstadt, chief executive of Sure Start, Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, Catherine Graham-Harrison, a Rowntree trustee, and Malcolm Dean, assistant editor of the Guardian.

 Entry forms are available at Charityfair or by writing to Gerry O'Connor, the Guardian Charity Award 2000, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER (tel: 020-7713 4971).

fields.headline: Strange legacy
fields.standfirst: Two people died and 200 were injured in the Strangeway riots of 1990. But, says Brendan Friel, governor of the jail at the time, they led to a radical improvement of the service.
fields.trailText: Two people died and 200 were injured in the Strangeway riots of 1990. But, says Brendan Friel, governor of the jail at the time, they led to a radical improvement of the service.
fields.body:
The Strangeways riot of 1990 was the most serious prison disturbance in England and Wales in the 20th century. But long before the riot, Strangeways had acquired a high media profile. In 1979, Rex Bloomstein produced a remarkable series of BBC TV documentaries on the Manchester prison, exposing for the first time an overcrowded Victorian prison to the British public. The year before the riot, Bloomstein returned to Strangeways because the series was to be repeated. We discussed the possibility of a further programme, but funding was not forthcoming. Otherwise, the cameras might have been inside - as well as outside - the prison on April 1, 1990.

Three days before the riot, which was to last 25 days, the chief inspector of prisons published a favourable report on Strangeways. We had been the first large prison to embrace the major staff changes, known as "Fresh Start", in 1987. Activities for prisoners had impr oved dramatically and conditions, while still grim, were considerably better than they had been.

The magnitude and ferocity of the riot came as a great shock to most staff; the majority of prisoners, too, were numbed by what had happened. Trauma affected everyone in the prison community and many beyond. The most despicable part of the riot was the rioters' savage beating of a group of prisoners awaiting trial for alleged sexual offences. Only the great bravery of members of my staff - and the co-operation with them of some prisoners - prevented fatalities within Strangeways on that dreadful day.

Realising the possibility that there had been deaths among prisoners, staff asked the ambulance service whether body-bags were available. This was a sensible precaution, but it changed the course of events. Word reached reporters that there had been deaths, and the media focused in on "bodies in Strangeways" - to the detriment of other issues. On April 2, two national tabloids claimed there were 11 and 12 dead; the Manchester Evening News led one edition with the headline "20 Dead".

The effect on politicians and on prison headquarters was unfortunate. Instead of concentrating on ending the disturbance quickly, London HQ appeared quite distracted with handling the media clamour for confirmation or denial about the number of bodies. The disturbance was not quickly brought under control as I was refused permission to forcibly intervene. Predictably, copycat riots soon broke out across the service.

While enormous damage and trauma was caused by the Strangeways and related riots, they triggered a process that led to wholesale improvement within the prison service. In an inspired appointment, the government selected Lord Justice Woolf to head an inquiry. This resulted in probably the most important document about the prison service to be published last century.

The recommendations from the Woolf report resulted in dramatic action to improve the service. The rapid installation of integral sanitation hugely improved standards of decency and hygiene in cells. The need to share cells, however, still leaves an unsatisfactory situation: compelling prisoners to use a toilet in front of a fellow prisoner is hardly a standard to be proud of at the start of the 21st century. Prisoners also benefited from measures to improve justice in prisons - the most important being the introduction of a prison ombudsman.

Organisational changes also resulted from the Woolf recommendations. Governors now have more discretion to manage their prisons. Prison officers have improved roles - although the delivery of this improvement varies considerably across the service.

Perhaps the most radical recommendation aimed to reduce the scourge of overcrowding. A new prison rule would require the responsible minister to report overcrowding to parliament. That proved to be a step too far for politicians and no action has been taken.

Two setbacks to the Woolf reforms have occurred. The upward trend of the prison population, evident since the second world war, continued unabated. There are now 65,000 people in custody. Home Office projections forecast that the population will reach between 66,000 and 74,000 by 2007. So England and Wales are likely to continue at the top of the league table of European countries for imprisoning citizens.

The second setback was the serious escapades in 1994 and 1995, which led to the Woodcock and Learmont reports into prison security. The resultant substantial increase in prison security diverted resources away from positive rehabilitative programmes for prisoners. The emphasis on security, coupled with a very tight budget, also led to regime restrictions and slowed down the pace of reform.

Looking back, the overall effect of the Strangeways riot - while immensely painful and damaging at the time - has been beneficial.

Strangeways itself has been modernised and rebuilt. Instead of the 1,750 prisoners I was compelled to detain 10 years ago, the present governor has fewer than 1,300 prisoners, and facilities for them are vastly improved compared to those available when I was governor. Prisoners can be kept better occupied and can lead their lives in custody in reasonable conditions.

The Strangeways riots shocked the prison service into a programme of reform which has greatly improved the entire system.

But one critical underlying problem remains. How many prisoners should we be locking up? Does our country really want to emulate the US, with an ever-increasing population? Is there not a better way to deal with many of our offenders?

 Brendan O'Friel was governor of Strangeways prison from September 1986 to September 1990. He is a trustee of the Prison Reform Trust.

fields.headline: Testing times
fields.trailText: A debate that is rapidly polarising opinion in the disability movement will take centre stage at a Guardian sponsored event in Newcastle next week, when doctors, academics and disability rights activists join the public to discuss how advancements in genetics will affect people with disabilities.
fields.body:
A debate that is rapidly polarising opinion in the disability movement will take centre stage at a Guardian sponsored event in Newcastle next week, when doctors, academics and disability rights activists join the public to discuss how advancements in genetics will affect people with disabilities.

Reproductive Choices and Disability Rights is part of a three-day event that aims to tackle mounting concern over the new genetics and the eugenic overtones of scientists' plans for genetic screening, says Tom Shakespeare, a disability and genetics specialist at Newcastle University.

The spectre of sterilisation pro grammes carried out in the 20s and 30s in Britain, the US and Germany looms large when genetic tests are discussed. At the heart of the debate is what value society places on the lives of people with disabilities.

At the moment during pregnancy doctors can assess whether a foetus is at high risk of developing a number of conditions - the most well-known test is that for Down's syndrome. Increasing understanding of the human genome and of the part genes play in a range of diseases means genetic testing for a wider range of disorders could be available in the near future.

Some fear that routine use of genetic testing would dramatically increase the number of women choosing to terminate a pregnancy rather than risk giving birth to a child with a serious impairment. Critics say a rush for genetic testing could be seen as a push to rid society of people with disabilities.

The disability movement is struggling to reconcile support for a woman's right to terminate a pregnancy, on the grounds that the baby may suffer an impairment, with support for the rights of people with disabilities, says Shakespeare.

Most people within the movement are not against genetic screening but they are worried about the implications, he says. People with disabilities can understand why someone might want to terminate a pregnancy if the foetus has a serious degenerative illness with a very short life expectancy, but many would be unhappy about a termination for something like a cleft palate.

"I don't think all doctors are Nazis and are setting out to eliminate disabled people through screening," Shakespeare says. "But there are serious problems with current policies. Abortion [on the grounds of an impairment] is a significant step and shouldn't be taken lightly."

But very often doctors do not have enough information to put the case for continuing with the pregnancy, says Bill Albert, chair of the British Council of Disabled People's international committee. He says doctors are well-versed in the medical side of a disability but know very little about living with an impairment.

Shakespeare says more work is needed to ensure that women have all the information they need to give informed consent to tests and that they aren't bullied into ending the pregnancy.

Activists also argue that people with disabilities could face widespread discrimination in employment and financial services unless they are fully involved in debates on the future of genetics.

Feelings run high when it comes to misuse of genetic information. In a recent survey carried out by the disability organisation Radar, nine out of 10 respondents thought it should be illegal for employers and insurance companies to have access to the results of genetics tests. They feared that, in the wrong hands, they could be used to refuse people insurance.

No doubt this will be one of the issues discussed by the Human Genetics Commission, set up to advise the government. The commission is in the process of drawing up a work programme that will look at the ethical implications of storing genetic information and testing foetuses during pregnancy. As a member of the commission, Albert intends to ensure disabled people's views are heard.

Agnes Fletcher, parliamentary officer for Radar, will be speaking at the conference. She believes that, within the next 10 years, there will be legislation to address the discrimination on the grounds of genetic make-up. Meanwhile, "discussion can only bring us closer together," she says. "We need to reach a consensus in order to create a campaign agenda."

"The issues are so emotive and difficult that people need guidance through the 'moral maze'," says Shakespeare. He hopes the conference will produce a report to help " men and women make the decisions that are right for them".

 Reproductive Choices and Disability Rights, will be held at Disability North on April 11, the Dene Centre, Castle Farm Road, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne NE3 1PH (tel: 0191 284 0480; Text phone 0191 285 7261). The symposium is from April 10-12.

fields.headline: Union blues
fields.standfirst: Simon Fairlie on why the NFU is losing its grassroots support to environmental groups
fields.trailText: Simon Fairlie on why the NFU is losing its grassroots support to environmental groups
fields.body:
Two years ago, Dave Mugeridge, an agricultural contractor in Wiltshire, cancelled his National Farmers' Union subscription and went elsewhere for his business insurance. In his view, Britain's small farmers were being betrayed by the union which was once described as "the most effective, well-organised lobby in Britain". The purpose of Dave's gesture was "to make a small hole in a big dam".

Last week, the cracks in the dam appeared to be widening. On Thursday, Dave was outside the gates of Downing Street, together with a collection of farmers, ranging from tractor drivers in casual workclothes to portly gents in tweeds. Inside No 10, the NFU, in a bid to acquire an extra £200,000 of emergency cash, was presenting its "contract with society" to Tony Blair's farming summit, to which the Country Landowners Association and representatives of the food and processing industries had been invited, while certain other groups were conspicuously left out.

The protesting farmers had taken time off from work because they felt their views were not being represented at the summit. Of the dozen I talked to, only one, the tweediest of them all, expressed confidence in the NFU. The others variously described the union that claimed to represent them as "disappointing", "failing to challenge the supermarkets and processors", "crap", "unprintable", "representing the rich boys" and "in reality, the East Anglia Grain Growers Association".

Meanwhile, in a nearby hall, similar grievances were being aired more formally at an alternative farming summit organised by the newly-formed Small and Family Farms Alliance. Speakers included representatives from Young Farmers, Friends of the Earth, the Council for the Protection of Rural England, the Royal Society for the Pro- tection of Birds, the World Wildlife Fund, the Women's Institute and The Land Is Ours. They were united in the view that the government was consulting a narrow base of interests in the face of a crisis that will have severe repercussions upon the rural economy and landscape.

In private, the consensus between the protesting farmers and the environmental and social campaigners extends a good deal further. Both groups recognise that the government's commitments to global free trade, to a "market-oriented and competitive" farming industry, and to providing cheap food at world prices, point to one conclusion. The UK's "inefficient" and "uncompetitive" family farms will be sacrificed to an agricultural industry which one supermarket-owned farming consortium predicts will soon consist of a mere 10,000 agribusiness farms employing only a third of the present workforce.

The cabinet office, however, rejects this option because it would "employ more people, whether this was efficient or not".

The EU similarly allows subsidies to be reduced on larger wealthier farms but maintained on smaller marginal farms. The cabinet office again advises against this because it will "inhibit restructuring . . . farms may be less inclined to grow through acquisition if the benefits of scale are offset by a reduction in the marginal rate of subsidy".
