fields.headline: Secret service
fields.standfirst: Alison Clarke finds more questions than answers as she tries to represent the public
fields.trailText: Alison Clarke finds more questions than answers as she tries to represent the public
fields.body:
Primary care groups have somehow turned into one of the government's best-kept secrets. Well, have you ever heard of PCGs? As the lay representative on the Middlesbrough and Eston board, it is my job to do something about that, by ensuring that at least some of our 195,000 residents find out who we are and what we do.

The idea behind PCGs, set up last April in yet another restructuring of the NHS, is to make the service more responsive to local need at primary care level. Hence the requirement to have a lay person on the board, along with local GPs, nurses and social services representatives. Overall, the board has one main function - to decide what services are needed to improve the health of its local residents. Simple as that may sound, it is far from straightforward, as I have discovered over the past year and a half.

It didn't take me long to realise that there was a problem with resources. Although the Middlesbrough and Eston PCG has an annual budget in excess of £100m, the bulk of the money automatically goes on buying routine services (hip replacements, coronary artery by-pass grafts and the like) as well as covering the £20m prescribing budget. In other words, existing demands make it difficult for the PCG to start to shift priorities in the direction of, say, health promotion or complementary therapies.

M ore recently, I found out more about the way that money is devolved to the PCG. Believe it or not, instead of getting all its money at the beginning of the financial year, a certain amount goes direct to the local hospitals the PCG contracts with.

The reason, apparently, is to cover the costs of inflation faced by the acute sector. This happens, mark you, before the PCG has even decided what its priorities are for that year. It's a bit like going to the local greengrocer and only having enough left over to buy one banana from the bunch, because someone else has already handed your money over to cover the greengrocer's inflationary costs in getting those bananas (whether you wanted them or not).

By this stage, I was six months into the job and still grappling with the intricacies of NHS finances and its structures. I had done very little in the way of consultation with local people. I now needed to think about how the board was going to find out what local people wanted in terms of health care. But that in itself is an expensive business and begs a number of difficult questions. For instance, what should the PCG ask its local residents? Whom should it ask and how many? How does it ask them? Through questionnaires? Or a representative sample of the public? Or a citizens' jury? Or a selected group of people on a talk-back panel? And how often? Finally, and crucially, how should the PCG weigh up conflicting public demands, given that 195,000 people are unlikely to agree on one set of priorities?

To make matters even more complicated, I have also realised recently that the PCG cannot consult in a vacuum. In other words, people need information on which to base their decisions. For instance, there is no point asking people for their views about, say, a change in service, without giving them the relevant information. The trouble is that the only people likely to be interested are those who already make use of it. And the chances are that they will oppose it.

What I have learnt over the past year and a half is that the general public is not much interested in the provision of health care services at all, whether at a local or national level. That is, until they use them, either as consumers or carers.

The paradox, of course, is that as interested parties, they will probably have an agenda that is not in the overall interests of other consumers in the area.

Public involvement is, clearly, a laudable aim, but whatever the problems, PCGs have to face up to their obligations. And fast. Middlesbrough and Eston PCG, for one, has put its money where its mouth is and has just appointed a full-time community involvement manager to help us do exactly that.

fields.headline: Urban horror story
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's action teams have uncovered widespread deprivation. Now he must producea joined  up strategy, reports Peter Hetherington
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's action teams have uncovered widespread deprivation. Now he must producea joined up strategy, reports Peter Hetherington
fields.body:
Britain has not been short of urban regeneration initiatives for the past 20 years or so. Billions have been spent, particularly under a Tory government, transforming docklands and riversides, creating flashy business parks, building office blocks and hotels - in short, making city centres look nicer.

The idea was that the wealth from these publicly-funded enterprises would somehow trickle down to the poorest in society, improving cities as a whole. It didn't. Coming to power almost three years ago, Labour recognised that bricks and mortar alone could not solve deep-seated problems. It launched the social exclusion unit, led by a young Treasury cum Downing Street high flyer, Moira Wallace, to work out how the marginalised in society - often ghettoised on run-down estates - could be brought up to the norm.

As Tony Blair lamented 18 months ago, when unveiling its preliminary neighbourhood renewal strategy, urban problems - from decaying housing, unemployment, street crime, nightmare neighbours, abandoned banks and shops - had become so acute that . . . "over the last two decades, the gap between these 'worst estates' and the rest of the country has grown . . . it has left us with a situation no civilised society should tolerate . . . it shames us as a nation."

On a reborn council estate in Hackney, rescued from the brink by tenants in partnership with the local council, the prime minister started an initiative designed to cut across government departments and present neighbourhoods with co-ordinated programmes - some task, when the performance and innovation unit at the cabinet office reported barely two months ago that "there are too many government initiatives causing confusion, not enough co-ordination, and too much time spent on negotiating the system, rather than delivering." So there's some ground to make up.

On that Hackney estate, alongside councillors and com munity leaders, Tony Blair launched an £800m New Deal for Communities programme, with pilot schemes in 17 "pathfinder" districts. Crucially, he also set in train 18 cross-cutting policy action teams (Pats) to report on problems in a variety of areas - from job and skill shortages, to business revival, housing abandonment and anti-social behaviour.

Next week, a full-blown national strategy of neighbourhood renewal, based on reports from those action teams, will be launched by Tony Blair. There will be much talk of cross-cutting initiatives, new programmes - probably an extension of New Deal - and even, perhaps, a new (or re-branded) minister to push things forward. More money - lots of it - is being sought from July's three-year comprehensive spending review, which will kick-in next year.

Research for the Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions has already identified 1,370 estates which can be classified as "run-down"; the English house condition survey has actually identified at least 3,000 poor neighbourhoods. But the exclusion unit has pointed to 44 local authority districts with the highest concentrations of deprivation in England.

They have nearly two thirds more unemployment than average, a level of underage pregnancy and lone parenting one-and-a-half-times the norm, mortality rates 30% higher than average and up to three times the level of poor housing. Throw in a quarter of adults with poor literacy and numeracy, poor exam results among teenagers and high levels of income support all round, and you construct an urban horror story. Our run-down neighbourhoods are now among the poorest in the western world.

While the 18 policy action team reports, most of which have now been completed, make sober reading, they do point a way forward. The scale of unpopular, or blighted, housing - 377,000 coun cil houses (11% of the national stock) and a further 90,000 housing association properties (8%) - is identified for the first time. Recommendation: think of alternative uses (students, nurses?).

Anti-social behaviour, not surprisingly, is on the increase, with reports to police of disorder offences up by 20% in the two years up to 1998 alone. But then, it is fuelled by "wider problems of social exclusion and deprivation . . . poverty, unemployment, family breakdown." Suggestion: crime and disorder partnerships, promote prevention, improve street lighting, etc.

Jobs, business, skills, are also covered. While some of the findings might appear self-evident, reminding decision makers "of a lack of networks linking people without jobs to the employers with jobs to fill" is no bad thing; that education and training for adults is often "physically remote" and that public sector education and training somehow misses the disadvantaged.

Crucially, there is no national strategy or framework for providing support to enterprise in deprived communities, with services seen as inaccessible or unapproachable. Marooned on estates with few of the facilities most of us take for granted, the poor have simply withdrawn (or been forced to withdraw): over 2m use no financial service. With no car, and with public transport expensive, they can't take advantage of cut-price shopping. While the number of superstores has almost trebled in 10 years to well over 1,100, the number of independent stores has dropped by 40%.

In short, the scale of deprivation in England has never been subjected to such rigorous analysis. Whether it can be tackled by an administration committed to joining up initiatives - while, ironically, still presiding over a complex array of disjointed programmes - remains to be seen. And whether regional economies, particularly in the more depressed north, can be tilted to address the marginalised and the "have nots" is another question altogether.

fields.headline: Quality streets
fields.standfirst: As Londoners choke on the cost of pollution and gridlock, leading contenders in the race to become mayor offer their solutions
fields.trailText: As Londoners choke on the cost of pollution and gridlock, leading contenders in the race to become mayor offer their solutions
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone

London's future must be clean and green. The environment is not an optional extra to be added on to other policies as and when time and resources allow. London's economic future, as well as the quality of life of every Londoner, depends on the capital leading the way as a sustainable world city. As mayor, I will ensure that the environment is placed at the heart of London's government. I will:

 Ensure comprehensive environmental monitoring of all strategies that the mayor is required to produce by adopting a "quality of life" index for London, adapted to the city's specific needs. The index would include measurements on crime, health, air and water quality, road traffic levels, access to green space, and re-use of polluted and derelict land.

 Establish a sustainable development unit inside the mayor's office, and a sustainable development committee for the assembly, advised by key academic, business and voluntary sector experts.

 Aim to reduce road traffic by 15% by 2010, encourage greater use of public transport and make the streets safer for cyclists and pedestrians.

 Draw up a biodiversity action plan to give full protection to London's wildlife sites, and intervene to help save Rainham Marshes from ugly and destructive development plans.

 Designate the Thames a specially protected Blue Ribbon zone.

 Set a target to recycle 25% of all household waste by 2005 and ensure that the Greater London assembly sets an example to the rest of the public sector and business by making a commitment to buy recycled goods.

 Aim to create 10,000 jobs in new green businesses by 2005.

 Make sure London plays its part in meeting climate change targets, in particular the government's target of cutting carbon dioxide emissions by one-fifth from their 1990 level by 2010.

 Protect and enhance London's green spaces so that it is possible to walk across London north to south and east to west on green corridors.

Frank Dobson

By improving public transport, getting the planning framework right and regenerating deprived areas we can enhance the environment and meet the economic and social needs of Londoners - that is practical sustainable development.

Defending the green belt and promoting the recycling of land through conversion or rebuilding on brownfield sites will be my aim. But the biggest environmental challenge is how to tackle the rise in vehicle use. Congestion charging could be a significant aid to reducing car use, but only if people have a viable alternative.

I will invest £8bn in public transport. I want to extend tube (Crossrail and the East London line), rail and tram routes. I will encourage bus use through free fares for under-18s, speedier journeys by better bus lane enforcement and smartcard technology. I will make transport safer so that people feel comfortable using buses, tubes and trains in the evenings. I will restrict lorry movements in peak hours. I will promote cycling and walking. But regenerating our city will also help to reduce journeys.

One of the biggest environmental issues facing London is regeneration. The drift to the suburbs adds significantly to car use. The greatest pressure on London's green belt comes from Londoners moving to the edges of the city. Only by addressing crime and economic prospects can we reverse the decline of the inner city, which is such a threat to our environment. I will make tackling crime my number one priority and will work with business to create an extra 100,000 jobs in London and use the £1bn regeneration budget to ensure that Londoners from deprived parts of the city have a chance of filling those vacancies.

We can only have a greener city if we address crime and unemployment as well as the environment.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
These are exciting times for the citizens of Stratford-upon-Avon. No sooner have they learned that their beloved red-brick Royal Shakespeare theatre is to be replaced by a gleaming steel and glass construction than news arrives that they have been chosen to play a leading role in Tony Blair's campaign to modernise local government.

They owe the opportunity to Ian Prosser, the chief executive for Stratford, who has persuaded the Home Office to allow his district to be the first to pilot a new electronic voting system. Voters in local elections this May will still have to trek along to their usual polling stations in libraries, church halls and community centres, but when they arrive they'll no longer be pointed towards a voting paper and a stubby pencil, but to a screen and a set of buttons.

It's hardly the cutting edge of information technology but local government officials in Stratford sound genuinely excited by its implications. No longer will they have to print out thousands of ballot papers, or worry about recounts, or engage in endless arguments about whether the messy blob beside a candidate's name is a cross or an exclamation mark. An electronic "x" is unambiguous. There's also the boost to local pride from being able to announce the results for a large rural district at shortly after 10pm rather than 1am.

Time and money are not the only considerations. Stratford already has a relatively high turnout for local elections, but Prosser wants to discover whether the novelty value of electronic voting will ensure an even larger turnout among young people, for whom a pencil on a string must seem as anachronistic as a wind-up gramophone.

If all goes well at Stratford then the next stage is to abolish polling booths altogether and further increase turnout by allowing voters to make their electronic choices nearer to home in banks, post offices and supermarkets.

But the cynics are already gathering. Is it really the inconvenience of travelling to a polling booth that accounts for local election apathy? Or have voters realised that their choice is increasingly insignificant now that all the important decisions about such key matters as housing and education are made by central government?

 Laurie Taylor visits Stratford-upon-Avon in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed: The Larger Map at 4 pm today.

No sooner have they learned that their beloved red-brick Royal Shakespeare theatre is to be replaced by a gleaming steel and glass construction than news arrives that they have been chosen to play a leading role in Tony Blair's campaign to modernise local government. They owe the opportunity to Ian Prosser, the chief executive for Stratford, who has persuaded the Home Office to allow his district to be the first to pilot a new electronic voting system. Voters in local elections this May will still have to trek along to their usual polling stations in libraries, church halls and community centres, but when they arrive they'll no longer be pointed towards a voting paper and a stubby pencil, but to a screen and a set of buttons. It's hardly the cutting edge of information technology but local government officials in Stratford sound genuinely excited by its implications. No longer will they have to print out thousands of ballot papers, or worry about recounts, or engage in endless arguments about whether the messy blob beside a candidate's name is a cross or an exclamation mark. An electronic "x" is unambiguous. There's also the boost to local pride from being able to announce the results for a large rural district at shortly after 10pm rather than 1am. Time and money are not the only considerations. Stratford already has a relatively high turnout for local elections, but Prosser wants to discover whether the novelty value of electronic voting will ensure an even larger turnout among young people, for whom a pencil on a string must seem as anachronistic as a wind-up gramophone. If all goes well at Stratford then the next stage is to abolish polling booths altogether and further increase turnout by allowing voters to make their electronic choices nearer to home in banks, post offices and supermarkets. But the cynics are already gathering. Is it really the inconvenience of travelling to a polling booth that accounts for local election apathy? Or have voters realised that their choice is increasingly insignificant now that all the important decisions about such key matters as housing and education are made by central government?  Laurie Taylor visits Stratford-upon-Avon in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed: The Larger Map at 4 pm today.

fields.headline: No longer a soft touch
fields.standfirst: Schools now have clear targets for fundraising - like their own accounts
fields.trailText: Schools now have clear targets for fundraising - like their own accounts
fields.body:
Young people are giving less to charity, so it's said, yet new research estimates that schoolchildren raise some £30m a year for good causes. This has been achieved in the face of serious financial pressures for many schools, who have taken time out from raising cash for their own funds to support both national and local charities.

But according to the report, due to be published early next month, some charities are "bombarding" schools with requests for cash instead of engaging them in a partnership in which both sides can benefit.

The authors of the report, School Fundraising In England, who will be highlighting some of their survey results at Charityfair tomorrow, are calling on charities to rethink their approach to schools.

Anne Mountfield, former assistant director of the directory for social change, believes too many fundraisers view schools as easy pickings. She says: "In our survey, many heads complained that their school would give to a charity, hear nothing from them for a year and then suddenly they'd be back asking for more cash.

"Charities need to guard against treating schools as just another milch cow. The attitude seems to be, 'Let's see how much we can get out of them.' But we detected warning signs suggesting that that sort of approach is becoming counterproductive."

One headteacher among the 1,000-plus who took part in the survey says: "Charities seem to think schools are bottomless pits of money which they can continually ask to raise cash." Another says: "Primary schools are bombarded with requests from charities, but we are here to educate children, not to ply them with competition entries."

Mountfield says schools want to be involved in charity events that are either fun or have some educational benefit. "If they have neither, then forget it," she says. "Fun events have their place, because though you don't have to care about the poor to have a bath in baked beans, engaging in that sort of stunt can help raise awareness."

On the educational side, schools reported that they were keen to tie in charity initiatives with the national curriculum.

"But the message came across loud and clear that the days when a fundraiser can leave a pile of envelopes and a few stickers and expect kids to fill them have long since gone," Mountfield says. "The heads from whom we heard told us their pupils are just not interested this sort of 'collection box' approach."

The survey highlighted an increasing tendency among schools to consult children on what charity they wanted to support. But it also found that raising money from schools is getting harder.

Mountfield says: "Many of those who replied to our questionnaire reported that they were only prepared to engage in joint fundraising. They'll stage a charity fun day, but they want half the proceeds. That's a trend the charities need to watch as it could put the public off giving."

A number of the schools who responded were under financial pressure. One school had a budget shortfall of £110,000 - though it still managed to raise £10,000 for charity. But headteachers warned that they found getting involved in charity work highly time consuming.

"There was a definite sense that we could be approaching the limit of effort schools are prepared to put in," Mountfield says. "What charities need to do is focus their efforts on ensuring that schools get something out of the partnership. And it's important they get this right, because school fundraising is not just about raising cash for the appeal of the day. We're talking about nurturing the charity supporters of tomorow."

 The report School Fundraising In England is available (price £9.95) from the Directory of Social Change (tel 020-7209 5151).

fields.headline: River of tears
fields.standfirst: Why is Aids an epidemic? Edward Hooper spent years looking for the source, and his book has sparked controversy over claims of human error in the vaccination programmes
fields.trailText: Why is Aids an epidemic? Edward Hooper spent years looking for the source, and his book has sparked controversy over claims of human error in the vaccination programmes
fields.body:
In June 1981, two unusual events occurred in very different parts of the world. In Los Angeles, five gay men fell sick with rare symptoms suggestive of immunological problems, which prompted two local doctors to write a paper for the Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report. Meanwhile, in Mugana, northern Tanzania, a German missionary doctor saw five women from the Ugandan border region, all suffering from untreatable anaerobic ulcers of the groin and anus. Some new pathogen was abroad, and these doctors were among the first to recognise that fact.

Before long, the beast was named. By 1983, the condition of immune collapse had swept through gay communities in the western world, and was given the acronym Aids. Meanwhile, in Africa, the condition spread almost as rapidly among men, women and children. Tanzanian villagers christened the newly-arrived disease "Juliana" and Ugandans named it "Slim". By 1985, it was realised that the US and African outbreaks were caused by the same pathogen. In both cases, it seems, this pathogen, HIV, had been planted in fertile seed-beds (the gay bath-houses of Los Angeles; the smuggling zone around Lake Victoria) and had prospered. But this begged a further question: where had the new virus sprung from?

The classic view about emerging viruses is that there is an unprecedented interaction between humans and their environment (traveller visits bat cave, logging company opens up virgin rain forest), which triggers a zoonosis - a human disease caused by crossover of an animal pathogen. This scenario seems to work well for killer diseases like Ebola, Marburg and Lassa Fever, and has considerably boosted funds to American virology labs. But does it apply equally well to HIV?

The disciples of "natural transfer", such as the microbiologist Beatrice Hahn, from the University of Alabama, and geneticist Paul Sharp, from the University of Nottingham, believe it does. They propose that a hunter or bushmeat- seller who had skinned or butchered a chimpanzee somewhere in west-central Africa became infected with a simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV), and that this gave birth to the HIV variant (HIV-1 Group M) which has now infected more than 50 million persons worldwide, causing 16 million deaths from Aids.

Two other outbreaks of HIV-1 infection (Groups O and N) have been recognised in the 1990s, and these, they say, arose in the same way. When asked why there have apparently been no Aids outbreaks before the late 20th century, they reply that perhaps there have been, but that it took road-building, urbanisation, and new sexual freedoms following independence, to allow the viruses to break free from sequestered African environments and begin their awful spread.

This theory of west-central African origin was presented in February 1999, with Hahn adding that a reduction in the chimpanzee bushmeat trade would lessen the chances of future Aids outbreaks. She further claimed (misleadingly) that the local subspecies of chimp was in danger of extinction, which might prevent the development of an effective vaccine. It was a sexy package and it grabbed headlines.

However, there were some problems with the theory. First, in the slave trade up to the 1860s, more than 10m Africans from the western seaboard were transported to the Americas. Their viruses and retroviruses came too, but apparently no SIVs or HIVs. Furthermore, there were huge internal population movements in Africa - caused by colonial labour recruitment for plantations, mines and the construction of roads and railways - in the early 20th century, while millions of Africans fought in the two world wars. Yet there was not one visible outbreak of Aids.

Second, although the two minor HIV-1 variants, Group O and Group N, have a clear epidemiological hearth in west-central Africa, the pandemic variant, Group M, does not. There is no evidence of Group M being present there before 1981.

There is, meanwhile, another HIV, HIV-2, which appears to have descended from the SIV of the sooty mangabey, and which has a hearth in West Africa, especially the tiny state of Guinea-Bissau.

The American virologist, Preston Marx, carried out extensive research on sooty mangabey SIV and HIV-2 infections in West Africa and he reached a startling conclusion: that sooty mangabey SIV acquired by hunters or bushmeat sellers resulted in non-pathogenic infections that were hardly, if at all, transmissible; "dead-end infections", in short. Natural transfer, he decided, was not by itself enough to cause Aids.

Marx felt that an extra factor was needed to turn such viruses into epidemic forms, and he proposed needles - either those reused in poorly-equipped "country clinics" or those inadequately sterilised during mass vaccination programmes. What Marx was proposing was a natural transfer from sooty mangabeys, followed by an iatrogenic (physician-caused) amplification of the virus in humans.

So, could the needles hypothesis apply in west-central Africa also, and explain the outbreaks of HIV-1-related Aids?

The natural transfer school thought it could. In February this year, one of Hahn's colleagues, Bette Korber, addressed a press conference about her research on the dating of the pandemic. She had used a "super-computer" to compare many different Group M viral sequences, and proposed that the date of the "last common ancestor" was 1930, plus or minus 20 years. Most reporters interpreted this as a chimp hunter getting infected in west-central Africa in 1930, and Korber did not disavow them.

When other scientists looked for mass vaccination campaigns in the area, they came up with inoculations against smallpox, yaws, sleeping sickness and yellow fever, starting as long ago as the late 19th century and continuing right through to the present day.

I believe, however, that this actually weighs against the natural transfer theory, for despite claiming mechanisms for crossover and amplification, Hahn and Korber still cannot provide evidence of Group M infection in west-central Africa before 1981. However, there is considerable evidence further east, in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Rwanda and Burundi, where M-infected blood is seen from the late 1950s onwards, and Group M-related Aids from the early 1970s.

Hahn and Sharp argue that a chimp hunter from west-central Africa could have travelled here soon after getting infected, and sparked the Group M pandemic. The problem is there are approximately 12 subtypes of Group M, which appear to have emerged in the 1950s. Just how did the itinerant hunter start all these?

The answer, I believe, is that he did not. I propose a different origin for HIV-1 Group M, pertaining to Chat, an experimental oral polio vaccine (OPV) which, I believe, was prepared in the kidney cells of chimpanzees, nearly 400 of which were sacrificed between 1956 and 1958 at Lindi camp, a vaccine research facility in the then Belgian Congo (now the DRC).

The primate cells used to produce Chat were never documented at the time and have never since been revealed. But between 1957 and 1960, Chat vaccine was fed to over a million Africans in the Congo, Rwanda and Burundi - and 64% of all the earliest (retrospectively recognised) Aids cases in Africa, through 1980, come from the same places where Chat was fed. So do 82% of the earliest HIV-1 Group M infections, again through 1980. I have documented 28 Chat campaigns in these former Belgian colonies, and the introduction of different chimp SIV variants in different vaccination venues may provide the explanation for the very different Group M subtypes.

It is only 200 miles from the Ruzizi valley, where the biggest mass trial of Chat was staged in 1958, to northern Tanzania, where the Tanzanian army camped for three months in 1978 before driving Idi Amin from Uganda, and where the first cluster of African Aids cases was seen in 1980. And the only other place where experimental variants of Chat were tested was on babies born at Clinton, a women's prison in New Jersey, which lies just 50 miles from where the first plausible HIV-1 infection in the US was identified.

My own position has changed somewhat since my book, The River, was published. I now believe that both methods of transfer (natural and iatrogenic, cut hunter and contaminated vaccine) may work. Scientists are now finding "sputtering forms" of HIV-1 in the Cameroon, variants which are not related to any of the known subtypes and which look suspiciously like those dead-end HIV-2 infections. Increasingly it seems that natural transfers of SIVs from sooty mangabeys and chimps may occasionally take in humans, but that they neither spread easily, nor readily cause Aids.

But for an Aids epidemic or pandemic to occur, I believe what is needed is a mass exposure, as through a vaccination campaign. Perhaps SIVs stand a better chance of infecting humans when prepared in cell culture, and are then introduced by an "unnatural" route. Or perhaps it is simply a question of numbers - and only 1 in 10,000 (or 100,000) human exposures to SIV results in a productive infection.

My bet is that even those smaller outbreaks of HIV-1 Group O and HIV-2 may have been sparked by experimental vaccine trials. In the late 50s', French polio vaccines, prepared in cells from African primates, were tested in the French colonies of west Africa and west-central Africa. The preferred primates were Guinea baboons which, records reveal, were frequently gang-caged with other monkeys, including sooty mangabeys.

However, scores of chimps were also present in the manufacturing labs for vaccine safety testing, and it may be their kidneys (undamaged by this testing) were later incorporated into the French vaccines - just as I believe happened with the Lindi chimps and Chat vaccine.

 Edward Hooper is the author of The River: A Journey Back to the Source of HIV and Aids (Allen Lane/Penguin Press). © Edward Hooper 2000

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Firefighters who rushed to rescue a pony in the New Forest, Hampshire, after a passer-by reported that it had sunk in mud, discovered a Shetland pony happily grazing on dry ground.
fields.body:
Short answer: Firefighters who rushed to rescue a pony in the New Forest, Hampshire, after a passer-by reported that it had sunk in mud, discovered a Shetland pony happily grazing on dry ground.

Butting in: Women working at an animal sanctuary near Bawtry, South Yorkshire, are being harassed by an over-amorous billy-goat.

Spotlight: A pink bulb that shows up acne is to be installed in a street light to deter youths who hang around at night behind a village store at Stretton, Staffordshire.

Sole survivor: Archaeologists have unearthed a 500-year-old shoe on a site next to a footwear shop in Southampton.

Dead cool: Robbie Williams's hit record Angels has come top in the Co-op's latest "Pearly Greats" survey of the songs most frequently requested for funeral services.

Restricted entry: The National Trust has had to apply for permission to install a cat-flap in the door of a shed at a listed manor house near Broadway, Gloucestershire.

Off the leash: The owners of a border collie that has won six Kennel Club obedience competitions spent five days searching for it after it ran away from their home in Therfield Heath, Hertfordshire.

Top of the poops: A rap song titled Scoop the Poop is being performed at schools in Coventry to teach youngsters of the dangers of not cleaning up after their dogs.

Stamp duty: Four benefits cheques for a total of 7p were sent to a woman in Annan, Dumfriesshire, costing £1.04 in postage.

Currying favour: A woman from Uckfield, Sussex, has started cooking curry twice a week to feed a badger after it polished off the remains of an Indian takeaway left in her garden.

Pipe down! Inmates at a youth offenders institution near Falkirk have complained about a warder practising the bagpipes during his lunch breaks.

Suit you, sir! A man in Hackney, east London, got a job as security manager of a supermarket chain after a job agency worker lent him the suit, shirt and shoes he was wearing when the client was called for an immediate interview.

Inched out: A boy's seventh birthday party was ruined when one of his friends was refused entry to the play area at a McDonald's restaurant in Llanelli, south Wales, on the grounds that he was an inch too tall.

fields.headline: Bethlehem revisited
fields.standfirst: Nigel Turner warns that the rights of people detained in hospital are at risk
fields.trailText: Nigel Turner warns that the rights of people detained in hospital are at risk
fields.body:
To many, the government's green paper proposals on the reform of the Mental Health Act appear to be a fait accompli . Their basic premise - that public safety overrides individual rights - appears to be outside the scope of the consultation, which ends on Friday. Concentration on administrative detail has hidden a fundamental erosion in safeguards for the people detained. Few of them have committed any crime, yet they are subject to what would otherwise be deemed false imprisonment and assault. An example of this erosion of safeguards is the abolition of the Mental Health Act managers.

Under the current 1983 act, people detained in hospital can ask for their detention to be reviewed by the managers of the hospital. These are lay people, essentially volunteers, and are appointed by the NHS trust to represent its board - which is ultimately responsible for the deprivation of liberty which being sectioned entails. Such a review usually takes the form of an appeal hearing, at which the patient (sometimes through an advocate or solicitor) puts their case for the section to end, and the psychiatrist and other professionals argue why it should not. The managers can end the section, except where a court or the Home Office has imposed restrictions, and thus enable the person to leave hospital. It is a power used sparingly, but it is used - much to the chagrin of psychiatrists, who are not used to their clinical judgment being challenged by members of the public.

In addition, the managers' review system has been accused of time-wasting duplication, because detained patients can also appeal to the more formal (and much slower) mental health review tribunal (MHRT).

In the green paper, the power to detain is vested in a new type of tribunal only, and this sidesteps any appeal to the trust's managers. The new tribunal may have a minority of lay members, but essentially statutory mental health care is being further formalised and excessively professionalised.

Managers - ordinary citizens - are seen as a risky inconvenience, although there is no evidence that managers make any more mistakes than psychiatrists or the MHRT in discharge decisions. NHS trusts have devoted increasing resources to recruiting, inducting and training managers. A unique resource which has taken years to build up - thousands of volunteers with an intimate knowledge of mental health - will be scrapped.

The system of managers' hearings is the Robin Hood of statutory mental health care. It robs professionals of time, but it redistributes it to the patient. Often matters get discussed at a managers' hearing which have not been fully aired in ward rounds, where time is rationed. Managers' hearings can even have a therapeutic role, in that when a patient is not discharged, they can sometimes come to a better understanding of why they are detained and, having had their case heard, a greater acceptance of the necessity of detention.

The green paper's emphasis is on managing public anxiety - often unfounded - regarding the risk of violence, and not about human rights and the civil liberties of people with mental health problems. There is no discussion about the number of people who will be subjected to compulsion who ought not to be.

Professionals are encouraged to err on the side of caution, in an obsessive attempt to capture everyone who might possibly pose a risk to themselves or others. People with mental health problems are not significantly more violent than the population as a whole: if we really want to reduce the amount of threatening behaviour and violence we would do better to lock up every young man leaving a pub after 10pm.

Dramatic intervention is sometimes needed to deliver proper treatment when the person cannot make a rational decision on the matter. However, after decades of abuse in Victorian mental institutions, we are in danger of 21st-century complacency that powers of compulsion - in hospital or in the community - will not be misused.

 Nigel Turner has been a Mental Health Act manager for over 15 years; he chairs the Lambeth committee in the South London and Maudsley NHS trust. He is chief executive of Ealing Consortium, which provides supported housing and community care services.

fields.headline: An equal struggle
fields.standfirst: From the dangers of institutional racism to arguments about the sector cuddling up to government - there's no shortage of matters to debate, reports Janet Snell
fields.trailText: From the dangers of institutional racism to arguments about the sector cuddling up to government - there's no shortage of matters to debate, reports Janet Snell
fields.body:
The ninth annual Charityfair, supported by the Guardian, kicked off yesterday with Home Office minister Paul Boateng spelling out the government's vision of the future role for voluntary organisations and extolling the virtue of partnership with government. How far that partnership should go looks set to emerge as a key theme at what has become one of the biggest events in the charity calendar, with around 10,000 people expected to attend during the four days it runs.

Boateng is on record calling for the voluntary sector to do more to address the question of diversity - a theme seized on by Daniel Silverstone, director of London Borough Grants. Silverstone believes the voluntary sector is lagging behind in responding to the recommendations on tackling institutional racism made by the Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence. "I don't feel that the sector has really grasped the issue of diversity," he explains. "If health or local government had acted this slowly people would say it's a scandal. Other sectors have engaged in a fundamental reconsideration of the way they work."

He points out that new research by London Borough Grants suggests that tackling the diversity question needs to be more co-ordin ated and integrated. "Addressing this should not just be left to the black and minority ethnic voluntary sector," he says. "The whole sector needs to take all this on board. Our research highlights the view that though some of the larger organisations have equal opportunity procedures, they have become rather passive about the whole thing."

Silverstone wants to see more directors, trustees, senior managers, policy makers and volunteers from ethnic minority backgrounds. "I think it's fair to say voluntary organisations are yet to take up this challenge," he says. "Just pick any large major charity and look at how many black trustees they have. Often it's the case that they recruit people but they don't support them once they're in. The culture of the organisation doesn't change and so they lose black and ethnic minority recruits. "

Mike Eastwood, director of the Directory of Social Change, which organises Charityfair, agrees that the voluntary sector can suffer from complacency when it comes to institutional racism.

"I think there's a rather circular argument along the lines of 'there's no racism in the voluntary sector because the voluntary sector is not racist'. Because these organisations are more involved at the cutting edge of minority issues, there's a sense that they are less likely to be institutionally racist - which, of course, is not necessarily the case."

Jeremy Crook, director of the Black Training and Enterprise Group, will speak tomorrow on the future role of the black voluntary sector. He agrees that the voluntary sector as a whole needs to be more proactive in addressing race and involving ethnic minorities in what they do. "The government has taken a lead by setting targets for the recruitment of black and minority individuals and I believe this idea should be adopted by the voluntary sector," he says.

Crook accepts that the black voluntary sector itself has a lot of work to do. "The Home Office has put money into the infrastructure of black voluntary groups, and what we are hoping is that this will lead to more engagement with the mainstream voluntary sector," he says, adding that black charities tend to feel isolated from mainstream networks. "Often local contracts are very bureaucratic and many of the smaller groups feel excluded from taking part in the process. Black organisations need to get to grips with business planning, then go out and seize the opportunities on offer."

He believes that until now the whole subject of diversity has been consigned to the margins of debate. "But I think that's changing and we're starting to see signs of willingness among the mainstream sector to look at race issues, though only because the Home Office has made it a priority," he says.

Crook welcomes government moves towards making grants available for mainstream organisations on condition that they have a black voluntary sector partner. "It's good to see funding being used that way."

On the issue of funding, tomorrow Charityfair sees the publication of the third UK Voluntary Sector Almanac, which charts trends in charity income. The almanac is published by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, whose director, Stuart Etherington, will launch the new publication and highlight the challenges it raises.

Etherington is encouraged by the chancellor's budget announcement of tax incentives to prompt more people to give to charity. "Thanks to these proposals we are going to see a real simplification of the tax system, which will mean that giving to charity in Britain will be easier than practically anywhere else in the world," he says.

But he is urging charities to play their part in alerting the public to the full implication of the changes. "The money won't just come rolling in," he warns. "Voluntary organisations have got to get out there and tell people how the new system works."

Another Charityfair speaker, Lord Sheppard, former Bishop of Liverpool, believes voluntary bodies need to take a tougher stance in fighting their corner. "Partnership is definitely one of today's buzz words, but voluntary bodies need to be wary," he cautions. "For example, when they take on contracts with local authorities they need to be robust. And with initiatives like City Challenge and the single regeneration budget, though there's usually a place at the table for the voluntary movement, the question is whether it has the muscle to punch its weight."

Mike Eastwood agrees. He believes charities are "drifting along" in a dangerous way. "If charities continue the current emphasis on service provision at the expense of other roles such as campaigning, the public will become disaffected and donations will tail off even further," he says.

He will be presenting figures to Charityfair showing that, for some major organisations, the proportion of voluntary income has halved while the amount from fees and service income has doubled. "We are moving further and further away from our voluntary roots," he warns. "At this rate, we'll soon be just another arm of social services."

 Charityfair 2000 started yesterday and continues today, tomorrow and until 2pm Friday at the Business Design Centre in Islington, north London. Admission to the exhibition is £3 (£2 concessions) and is free on Friday. Events cost £10 upwards. Further details: 020-7288 6127/8.

webTitle: New hope for housing - but it's not going to come cost free

fields.headline: New hope for housing - but it's not going to come cost free
fields.standfirst: More about house prices
fields.trailText: Yesterday's housing green paper was not quite as revolutionary as leaks suggested. Yet a revolution is under way. A score of local authorities have applied to transfer 300,000 homes this year - six times the number transferred in the last six years. Housing managers, reluctantly recognising that there is no prospect of either local or central government raising the funds to meet the £20bn backlog in repairs and maintenance, have come to accept transfers as a way of raising capital.
fields.body:
It was being billed as the day which would mark the end of 100 years of council housing. Yesterday's housing green paper was not quite as revolutionary as leaks suggested. Council housing will not be hived off to housing associations or arms-length, non-profit local housing companies within 10 years. Ministers aim to restrict housing transfers to 200,000 a year. That would eliminate England's 3m council homes within 15 years; but even this is unlikely. It does not take into account the growing proportion of tenant ballots (over 10%) rejecting such proposals, the opposition of Labour council chairmen, or the non viability of transferring seriously dilapidated estates with huge debts. Yet a revolution is under way. A score of local authorities have applied to transfer 300,000 homes this year - six times the number transferred in the last six years. Housing managers, reluctantly recognising that there is no prospect of either local or central government raising the funds to meet the £20bn backlog in repairs and maintenance, have come to accept transfers as a way of raising capital.

There was a lot to welcome yesterday: first official recognition of a £20bn backlog; a public commitment to renovate this dilapidated stock within 10 years; a new duty to provide children leaving care, and young offenders leaving penal institutes, with a home; a rent review with the aim of providing comparable rents for comparable accommodation, which opens the way to housing benefit reform; new help for key workers - nurses, teachers, fire officers - to purchase homes in high cost housing areas; and more regulation of unscrupulous landlords. There is something here for everyone. It is the most comprehensive review of housing policy for a generation.

Yet many questions remain. The three different rent options require careful analysis. There are many broad brush proposals where more detail is needed. There are no new building targets. Stock transfers are in danger of simply switching supply from one kind of monopoly to another rather than ensuring that managers become closer to tenants. Most important of all is funding. A new duty to house the young homeless is commendable but it will mean finding new cash. Government subsidies will still be needed. We will have to wait for the July comprehensive spending review to judge just how seriously Labour remains committed to social housing.

webTitle: The famous five - and the not-so-famous links

fields.headline: The famous five - and the not-so-famous links
fields.standfirst: Steven Lynch examines whether the Five Cricketers of the Century had anything in common
fields.trailText: • Jack Hobbs was the only fielder to run out Don Bradman in Tests - at Adelaide in 1928-29. Hobbs was fielding at cover, and his return was quick enough to send Bradman packing for 58 after an ill-judged call from striker Bert Oldfield
fields.body:
 Jack Hobbs was the only fielder to run out Don Bradman in Tests - at Adelaide in 1928-29. Hobbs was fielding at cover, and his return was quick enough to send Bradman packing for 58 after an ill-judged call from striker Bert Oldfield

 Don Bradman fielded through Jack Hobbs's 142 at Melbourne in the final match of that 1928-29 series, when Hobbs became the oldest man to score a Test century (46 years 82 days)

 Jack Hobbs is the only player to score more than 1000 Test runs on an overseas ground, with 1178 at Melbourne. Don Bradman , with 963 at Headingley (at an average of 192.60) runs him close

 Don Bradman (99.94), Garry Sobers (57.78), Jack Hobbs (56.94) and Viv Richards (50.23) all averaged over 50 in Tests

 Don Bradman and Shane Warne have both been the subject of biographies written by the same man - Australian journalist Roland Perry

 Don Bradman rated Garry Sobers's 254 for a World XI against Australia at Melbourne in 1971-72 as the best innings he had ever seen on Australian soil, and later narrated a film about the innings

 Garry Sobers was the first player to complete a Test "triple" of 1000 runs, 100 wickets and 100 catches (Ian Botham was the second). Viv Richards is the only player to achieve this in one-day internationals

 Garry Sobers and Viv Richards never played in the same West Indies team - but it was close. Sobers won the last of his 93 Test caps early in 1974, and Richards made his debut later that year, in West Indies' next Test. Both were selected for the first World Cup, in 1975, but Sobers had to pull out with a knee injury

 Don Bradman ranked Shane Warne alongside Bill O'Reilly as the best two spinners he had seen, in a 1995 interview. "Warne challenges the world's best batsmen like no-one else," observed The Don

 Viv Richards and Shane Warne were due to cross swords during Australia's 1993 tour of England, when Richards was playing for Glamorgan - but he didn't play in the match. They will both be on the same field this summer: they have each agreed to play in a memorial match for Malcolm Marshall in London on July 27 (details from Andrew White, 01189 323600)

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. If you have any cricketing queries, send Steven a question to asksteven@theguardian.com for his popular Thursday column.

fields.headline: Sir Donald Bradman
fields.standfirst: From a special tribute by John Woodcock in Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000
fields.trailText: Sir Donald George Bradman was, without any question, the greatest phenomenon in the history of cricket, indeed in the history of all ball games. To start with, he had a deep and undying love of cricket, as well, of course, as exceptional natural ability. It was always said he could have become a champion at squash or tennis or golf or billiards, had he preferred them to cricket. The fact that, as a boy, he sharpened his reflexes and developed his strokes by hitting a golf ball with a cricket stump as it rebounded off a water tank attests to his eye, fleetness of foot and, even when young, his rare powers of concentration.
fields.body:
Sir Donald George Bradman was, without any question, the greatest phenomenon in the history of cricket, indeed in the history of all ball games. To start with, he had a deep and undying love of cricket, as well, of course, as exceptional natural ability. It was always said he could have become a champion at squash or tennis or golf or billiards, had he preferred them to cricket. The fact that, as a boy, he sharpened his reflexes and developed his strokes by hitting a golf ball with a cricket stump as it rebounded off a water tank attests to his eye, fleetness of foot and, even when young, his rare powers of concentration.

Bradman himself was of the opinion that there were other batsmen, contemporaries of his, who had the talent to be just as prolific as he was but lacked the concentration. Stan McCabe, who needed a particular challenge to bring the best out of him, was no doubt one of them. "I wish I could bat like that," Bradman's assessment of McCabe's 232 in the Trent Bridge Test of 1938, must stand with W.G.'s "Give me Arthur [Shrewsbury]", when asked to name the best batsman he had played with, as the grandest tribute ever paid by one great cricketer to another.

So, with the concentration and the commitment and the calculation and the certainty that were synonymous with Bradman, went a less obvious but no less telling humility. He sought privacy and attracted adulation.

fields.headline: The return of Waqar Younis (again)
fields.trailText: The Burewala Express is rolling again. Waqar Younis, the man most responsible for Pakistan's conveyor belt of Shoaibs, Shabbirs, and Shahids, produced a vintage spell at Sharjah last week to clinch the Coca-Cola Cup.
fields.body:
The Burewala Express is rolling again. Waqar Younis, the man most responsible for Pakistan's conveyor belt of Shoaibs, Shabbirs, and Shahids, produced a vintage spell at Sharjah last week to clinch the Coca-Cola Cup.

There are several reasons why this victory is significant. Firstly, Pakistan ended their abysmal run against South Africa with two resounding victories. Secondly, Moin Khan and Javed Miandad showed that salvation is possible, despite the Pakistan Cricket Board's compulsive disorder of inept policy-making. The latest suggestion from those bright sparks at HQ is that Tony Greig should oversee everything from picking the national coach to building floodlights. Forgive me, but you cannot be serious, can you? Greig has repeatedly demonstrated that he as much loyalty to his adopted home as a cuckoo, and has certainly never struck me as having the best interests of Pakistan at heart. In fact, there is plenty of evidence to the contrary. As lunatic solutions go, this rivals the board's recent hair-brained plan to hire Dickie Bird to straighten out Shoaib Akhtar's action. Luckily that never happened; Greig shouldn't either.

Thirdly, Waqar was resurrected Ð again. In danger of an embarrassing crawl to 300 wickets in both Tests and one-day internationals, Waqar is now streaking across the line. He should reach the double landmark in the West Indies, only the second to do so after Wasim Akram. His career has been blighted by injury (back, toe, elbow) and a damaging feud with Wasim that he claims left him marginalised. Now that Wasim has lost the captaincy, however, Waqar has no more excuses. He doesn't need them. There may not be many years left in his body, but WaqarÕs hunger for success remains, driven significantly by his rivalry with Wasim. Admittedly, he has lost the speed of old (with Shoaib pounding the ground Pakistan don't need it anyway) but Waqar is once more an essential selection. Artistry, though, has supplanted ferocity.

Shades and a pose, a pose and shades. Not quite Midnight's Children, but Waqar and Wasim had much in common in the beginning: style, speed, and attitude. But they drifted apart, divided by an invisible barrier. "Selectors kept selecting me and he kept pushing me out. He was unfair to me and the game of cricket," accused Waqar after Pakistan's pre-Christmas Australian misadventure. Certainly, one of the reasons for Wasim's downfall was that he became too powerful and dominant in Pakistan's strategy; a fatal association when results went against him.

Wasim nearly finished off Waqar's career, but the South Africans can blame the ICC's little-lamented technical committee on illegal deliveries for his resurrection. He was not in Pakistan's squad for last year's Tests against Australia, but Shabbir Ahmed's ban allowed him back in. Then, despite some glimpses of his old form in the Test series he was dropped for the one-dayers. Again the illegal-deliveries panel intervened. Shoaib was banned, and Waqar was recalled despite his public outburst against Wasim.

On this day of picking the best, spare a thought for Waqar Younis. Assessing greatness is a complicated task. Objective measures (like career records and averages) rarely tell the full story; subjective conclusions depend heavily on the sample of people being questioned. No method is perfect, and asking the best to pick the best is as good as any. A decade ago Waqar was on course to break every international bowling-record by a mile. The question was: would his body hold out? It didn't.

But what made Waqar so special? It was partly his smoothly accelerating run-up and explosive action, culminating in a viciously fast delivery swinging toe-wards. It was partly his accuracy and willingness to bowl a full length that bucked the trend of fast bowlers pitching short. But it was mostly his phenomenal strike-rate. If wicket-taking bowlers win matches, then Waqar was the ultimate fast-bowling machine. In his pomp his strike-rate was under 40 (a wicket every six or seven overs). Even now his Test-match strike-rate is 41.4. Of all bowlers who have taken over 175 wickets in Test cricket, his strike-rate remains the best. SF Barnes is second with 41.6 and the next best is Allan Donald on 45.6; only five bowlers are under 50. Waqar also leads the field in one-day internationals with a strike-rate of 30.4.

"I am a magician with the ball," he says, shades and a pose never far away. Waqar, the greatest? He has a case. After all, Wasim has claims to being the best leftie.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the Bulletin of the World Health Organisation. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

webTitle: The mouse roars against net thieves

fields.headline: The mouse roars against net thieves
fields.trailText: Michael Eisner, the head of Disney, has warned that internet piracy of Hollywood films could make the net a "wonderful delivery system with nothing to deliver". Using alluring images from Disney's upcoming Dinosaur, Mr Eisner attacked "internet thieves and pirates" for attempting to steal intellectual properties - including films and copyrighted images - through the web.
fields.body:
Michael Eisner, the head of Disney, has warned that internet piracy of Hollywood films could make the net a "wonderful delivery system with nothing to deliver". Using alluring images from Disney's upcoming Dinosaur, Mr Eisner attacked "internet thieves and pirates" for attempting to steal intellectual properties - including films and copyrighted images - through the web.

With a series of animated pictures, Mr Eisner explained the painstaking four-year process Disney animators went through on Dinosaur and how the entire DVD could conceivably be downloaded onto a single disc by anyone over the net. "This film represents the flesh and bones - or in this, scales and bones - of that highfalutin' legalistic term, intellectual property," he told the Big Picture conference for industry insiders in New York in his keynote address.

"And it's all put in jeopardy by an old-fashioned everyday term - piracy Theft is theft, whether it is enabled by a handgun or a computer keyboard," Mr Eisner said. He had no truck with the assertion that material should be free and available to all and took on net guru Esther Dyson, who has spoken out against traditional copyright protection on the web.

"I must say I find this assertion interesting, since at the bottom of Ms Dyson's newsletter, one can clearly read that it is copyrighted and as her subscribers can attest, her newsletter is most certainly not free."

Mr Eisner laid out a five-point plan to combat internet piracy, beginning with an alliance with the government aimed at defending the right to keep owned intellectual property from being stolen. Second, he wanted to make sure efforts to control the net would be international. "The issues involving it cannot be viewed with a myopic American eye," he said.

fields.headline: Sir Vivian Richards
fields.standfirst: From a special tribute by Vic Marks in Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000
fields.trailText: Sir Isaac Alexander Vivian Richards (he was knighted by the Antiguan Government in 1999) separated himself from his rivals by his ability to perform at his peak on the grand occasion. He adored Lord's in a way that is peculiar to overseas players, who first pictured the ground while listening to crackling radios in the old colonies. He played in eight Lord's finals, five for Somerset and three for West Indies, and failed - by normal standards - only once. Even that day, the inaugural World Cup final against Australia in 1975, his fielding altered the course of the match. "When I was batting at Lord's," he said, "I wanted to make sure that no one else was going to come in. It was my stage."
fields.body:
Sir Isaac Alexander Vivian Richards (he was knighted by the Antiguan Government in 1999) separated himself from his rivals by his ability to perform at his peak on the grand occasion. He adored Lord's in a way that is peculiar to overseas players, who first pictured the ground while listening to crackling radios in the old colonies. He played in eight Lord's finals, five for Somerset and three for West Indies, and failed - by normal standards - only once. Even that day, the inaugural World Cup final against Australia in 1975, his fielding altered the course of the match. "When I was batting at Lord's," he said, "I wanted to make sure that no one else was going to come in. It was my stage."

When it really mattered, he might proceed a little more cautiously at the start of his innings; he would sweat even more profusely, and then he would set about tinkering with fate as only the great players can. Take two innings at another of his favourite spots, the Recreation Ground at St John's, Antigua. West Indies played their first Test there in 1981 - mostly thanks to the prominence Richards himself had given the island. He willed himself to a hundred, edgy by his standards. Five years later, against England again, his mission was to entertain those who had seen him grow up. One hundred came from 56 balls, the swiftest Test century recorded. Sixes disappeared down the high street. Richards could destroy both clinically and ferociously, provided he had a cause to play for. He usually did.

Teams West Indies, Combined Islands, Leeward Islands, Somerset, Queensland, Glamorgan

Test career

Bowling O 861.4 M 203 Runs 1964 W 32 Avge 61.37 BB 2-17

fields.headline: Shane Warne
fields.standfirst: From a special tribute by Greg Baum in Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000
fields.trailText: There are three elements to Shane Warne's greatness - skill, novelty and drama - and all were manifest in the one great delivery that made his name, at Old Trafford in 1993.
fields.body:
There are three elements to Shane Warne's greatness - skill, novelty and drama - and all were manifest in the one great delivery that made his name, at Old Trafford in 1993.

The delivery was exceptionally skilful. It began its flight innocently so as to lull Mike Gatting, drifted to leg, pitched in the batsman's blind spot, then rounded on him fiercely and bent back off stump. It was at once pinpoint in its accuracy and prodigious in its spin, qualities that had always been thought to be irreconcilable. Later that summer, John Woodcock would write that it was doubtful if there had ever been a bowler who could aim the ball as precisely and turn it as far as Warne. This is a sentiment that has echoed down the seasons.

The delivery was something different. West Indies and their battery of pace bowlers had set the agenda for 20 years; spin, particularly wrist-spin, had become nearly defunct, but suddenly here it was again in more irresistible form than ever before.

Most of all, the Gatting ball was not just early in his spell, but his very first delivery - in the match, in the series, in Ashes cricket. That gave the ball a sense of theatre, and Warne a name for showmanship, that has grown at each new threshold of his startling career, and at its peak made him nearly mystical. In the modern era, only Ian Botham could compare.

Greg Baum writes on cricket for The Age, Melbourne

fields.headline: Sir Jack Hobbs
fields.standfirst: From a special tribute by Matthew Engel in Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000
fields.trailText: Jack Hobbs scored more runs than anyone else in the history of first-class cricket: 61,237. He scored more centuries than anyone else, 197. Most astonishingly from a modern perspective, the last 98 came after his 40th birthday. However, his career batting average is 50.65, which does not even put him in Wisden's top fifty.
fields.body:
Jack Hobbs scored more runs than anyone else in the history of first-class cricket: 61,237. He scored more centuries than anyone else, 197. Most astonishingly from a modern perspective, the last 98 came after his 40th birthday. However, his career batting average is 50.65, which does not even put him in Wisden's top fifty.

Only 16 of those hundreds were double-hundreds. One says "only" with trepidation, because just four men have surpassed that. But the figure does not remotely compare with Bradman's 37 or Walter Hammond's 36. Hobbs was not primarily interested in scoring runs for their own sake. For much of his career he would go in at the top of a strong Surrey batting order on good Oval pitches. His job was to get the innings started. He would frequently be out for a-hundred-and-few, and was content enough himself with 60 or 70, though he liked to please his friends who took such things more seriously. But there were other times, when wickets had fallen and the ball was flying: "That was the time you had to earn your living," he said.

More than that, it was when he earned his undying reputation, his knighthood and his place as a Cricketer of the Century. He was never as dominant as Bradman; he never wanted to be. But his contemporaries were in awe of his ability to play supremely and at whim, whatever the conditions.

Hobbs set the standard for 20th-century batsmanship. As he attained his peak in the years before the First World War, he switched the emphasis away from gentlemanly Victorian off-side play to a more pragmatic approach, with an emphasis on the businesslike pull, plus an acute judgment of length, footwork and, where necessary, pad play to counter the googly bowlers of his youth. He was not an artist, like some of his predecessors, nor yet a scientist, like some of the moderns; he was perhaps the supreme craftsman.

Teams England, Surrey

Test career

Bowling O 62.4 M 15 Runs 165 W 1 Avge 165.00 BB 1-19

fields.headline: Sir Garfield Sobers
fields.standfirst: From a special tribute by Ian Wooldridge in Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000
fields.trailText: In February 1975, already celebrated as a face on Barbadian postage stamps, Sir Garfield St Aubrun Sobers was knighted by the Queen at the Barbados Garrison Racecourse, barely a mile down the road from where he was born in Walcott Avenue. It was not quite the ultimate accolade. In 1988, Sir Donald Bradman conferred on Sobers the title of the greatest all-round cricketer he had ever seen. Bradman's judgment in these matters is regarded as Holy Writ.
fields.body:
In February 1975, already celebrated as a face on Barbadian postage stamps, Sir Garfield St Aubrun Sobers was knighted by the Queen at the Barbados Garrison Racecourse, barely a mile down the road from where he was born in Walcott Avenue. It was not quite the ultimate accolade. In 1988, Sir Donald Bradman conferred on Sobers the title of the greatest all-round cricketer he had ever seen. Bradman's judgment in these matters is regarded as Holy Writ.

None would contest it. Across two decades Sobers brought to a cricket world as diverse as the Caribbean, the Test arena, English county cricket with Nottinghamshire, Sheffield Shield cricket with South Australia, and even North Staffs and South Cheshire League cricket with Norton, plus hundreds of charity games, a vibrancy, nobility of spirit and versatility of accomplishment that transcended all statistics.

These were remarkable enough: 8,032 runs, 235 wickets and 109 catches in 93 Test matches for West Indies. More significantly, he could turn the tide of a Test within an hour, and it was on these occasions that partisanship was suspended. You simply sat back and marvelled at the occasion. From the direst situation his only thought was to attack. He was physically fearless. He never wore a thigh-pad, never mind a helmet, and, from his boyhood days with the Barbados Police team until his retirement, he was only seriously hit twice. Such was his adaptability that he could bowl left-arm very fast, swinging it both ways, left-arm finger-spin and left-arm wrist-spin. By his own recollection, he was no-balled fewer than half a dozen times during his entire career.

Perhaps the most fundamental argument against the modern idiom of cricket is that Sobers was never coached. He mistrusted coaches. He learned the game playing all spare hours in the street with his brothers and friends and then, after the early Barbados sunset, playing on with miniature implements, much to the detriment of the furniture, in his despairing mother's house.

Teams West Indies, Barbados, South Australia, Nottinghamshire

Test career

Batting M 93 I 160 NO 21 Runs 8032 HS 365* 100s 26 Avge 57.78

Bowling O 3599.5 M 974 Runs 7999 W 235 Avge 34.03 BB 6-73 5i 6 10m 0

Ian Wooldridge is a columnist on the Daily Mail

Sir Donald Bradman

Sir Jack Hobbs

Shane Warne

Sir Vivian Richards

fields.headline: 'Archaic revivalist' Terence McKenna dies
fields.trailText: Terence McKenna, author of Archaic Revival and Food of the Gods, died yesterday aged 54
fields.body:
Author and explorer Terence McKenna died yesterday, aged 54, from a brain tumour diagnosed last May.

McKenna was best known for his controversial views on the impact of psychotropic plants on human culture and evolution, expounded through his books Archaic Revival, Food of the Gods and True Hallucinations, his website and lectures.

He argued that language, and even consciousness itself, may have been sparked off by consumption of psychoactive mushrooms in ancient cultures and that the human fascination with altered states of consciousness reveals much about our origins as human beings and our place in nature.

Travelling widely throughout the Amazon and Tropics, McKenna explored a variety of shamanic cultures and drew heavily on his experiences in his writing; his last book, True Hallucinations, published in 1999, documents his spiritual adventures in the Colombian jungle.

As a result of his fears about environmental threats to the rainforest, McKenna co-founded the 19-acre Botanical Dimensions reserve in Hawaii, dedicated to collecting and propagating medicinal and shamanic plants from the world's tropics, as well as the rapidly disappearing folk-knowledge associated with them.

Enthusiastic about the potential of multimedia for spreading ideas, he concentrated on developing web-based projects in his last few years. He also contributed to a number of music CDs, most notably collaborating with British dance band The Shamen on Re:evolution.

webTitle: London in limbo as stock markets wobble

fields.headline: London in limbo as stock markets wobble
fields.trailText: An embarrassing technical cockup may have come to the aid of London Stock Market chiefs and City traders this morning.
fields.body:
An embarrassing technical cockup may have come to the aid of London Stock Market chiefs and City traders this morning.

Just as they were braced for a rollercoaster ride, the electronic price and trading system crashed - for the second time in three days.

The Stock Exchange said there was a fault in the electronic feed that sends prices to dealers but could not say when the fault would be corrected. The all-important FTSE market-tracking indices were also unavailable.

A dealer on the Liffe futures exchange summed up the frustration of the morning: "We're just stuffed. We can't do anything."

Some City dealers were no doubt relieved by the sudden paralysis of the system. After the wild gyrations of the main New York markets on Tuesday, observers in London were expecting a white-knuckle ride today.

Investors and financiers alike are seemingly baffled by the sudden frenzy which has gripped the markets. Many analysts put it down to Monday's US court judgement that Microsoft had breached antitrust laws.

Shares in what was the world's most valuable company plummeted, dragging many other hi-tech stocks down too. But some insiders believe that the Microsoft judgment - which could take years to have any tangible consequences - was merely a catalyst for a long-overdue market correction.

For six months, private investors and institutions have poured cash into the dot.com sector, driving up prices stratospherically, and lifting the US Nasdaq and the UK Techmark indices to record highs. For months, financial analysts have been warning that the hi-tech bubble was about to burst.

Nobody is sure yet whether that has happened. There were some reports from European bourses today that investors are once again moving into the hi-tech sector, hoping to pick up bargains. But, as in America, there was greater interest in the so-called old economy, where long neglected blue-chip shares are on offer at bargain rates.

Both the German Dax and French CAC main indices dipped this morning, but nothing like to the panic levels witnessed in the middle of yesterday's hysteria on Wall Street. The Hong Kong and Tokyo markets also fell overnight.

But with European investors mostly holding firm, and the London market becalmed, eyes are already turning again to New York, where trading opens in a few hours.

fields.headline: Dome of dreams
fields.standfirst: A theatre complex in Beijing may or may not be under way
fields.trailText: "An ellipsoid shell - slightly ethereal," is how the French designer of Beijing's planned new national theatre project describes his vision; "a giant cone floating on a pool of water", according to its critics.
fields.body:
"An ellipsoid shell - slightly ethereal," is how the French designer of Beijing's planned new national theatre project describes his vision; "a giant cone floating on a pool of water", according to its critics.

Whatever the verdict, construction is now under way on the huge site near Tiananmen Square, or so a spokesman said on Sunday.

On Monday the official China Daily said that it had not been approved at all. The state council had not yet made its decision and work was at the stage of "early site preparation".

The official news agency said work was starting but the Communist party's newspaper did not report it. The Beijing Youth Daily also made an announcement, but the Beijing Daily remained silent.

A launch ceremony scheduled for Saturday was called off at the last moment, amid stories that President Jiang Zemin had ordered its cancellation.

But Mr Jiang is also said to have chosen the design from 44 submissions which ranged from traditional Chinese buildings to steel-and-glass constructions.

The mystery is as dramatic as any production the theatre could stage - if it is ever completed.

The confusion suggests that the leadership is still wrangling. Publicity is usually coordinated with meticulous care.

Last year all the designs submitted for the project were put on show in Tiananmen Square and visitors were invited to express their choice.

But there has been no word on which design received popular approval. Chinese architects have criticised the idea of building a massive project, arguing that while Beijing needs a national theatre this scheme is too large and tickets would be too expensive for ordinary citizens.

The winning design, by French architect Paul Andreu, will comprise a 2,500-seat opera hall and three other theatres, surrounded by a lake and approached by a glass-topped tunnel under the lake. The estimated cost is about£250m.

Mr Andreu's design is thought to appeal partly because it does not rise as high as the Great Hall of the People, where parliament meets.

He said that his concept gives the audience "time to breathe" as they approach the opera house. "Opera becomes ridiculous if you don't have time to enter a world of dreams."
