fields.headline: The Dixie Chicks
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the controversial country combo on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the controversial country combo on the net
fields.body:
1. The Dixie Chicks are in trouble. No, we're not talking about a salmonella outbreak at your local fried poultry outlet.

2. The three feisty Chicks are credited with reviving country music in the States, and lately music critics over here have begun to take notice of them.

3. Cute, irrepressible and adored by their fans, the Chicks' dark side has hitherto stayed hidden.

4. They know the pain of a broken heart, the pangs of jealousy and the sting of infidelity, but their latest single is a long way from Stand By Your Man.

5. Goodbye Earl is the story of two women who murder a violent husband and dump his body - with no regrets.

6. The Chicks claim the lyrics are ironic ("The Dixie Chicks do not advocate premeditated murder, but love getting even"). But that don't impress US radio stations much.

7. "What do we do a song about next - school shootings?" asked one Pennsylvanian radio programme director. Feminist organisations have asked stations to broadcast the number of a local domestic violence helpline.

8. The lack of airplay hasn't harmed sales of the Chicks' latest album, Fly, which has sold more than four million copies. You can play an extract from Goodbye Earl here.

9. Meanwhile, Martie Seidel, Natalie Maines and Emily Robison are preparing for their next tour of the US.

10. And it's surely a tribute to their post-feminist brand of professionalism that the Chicks are still willing to get their kit off and play in the bath.

fields.headline: Music on the internet
fields.standfirst: Musicians and songwriters could lose millions of pounds unless their industry makes it easier to buy legally over the internet, according to a government report. Mark Tran explains
fields.trailText: Musicians and songwriters could lose millions of pounds unless their industry makes it easier to buy legally over the internet, according to a government report. Mark Tran explains
fields.body:
What does the report say?
The report, Consumers Call The Tune, says users have to wait hours to download files and it notes that teenagers - among the biggest devotees of both music and the net - are excluded from legitimately buying online unless they are 18 or over. Meanwhile, adults are wary of using credit cards online because of security risks. The study says people will buy from pirate sites and foreign competitors if they cannot get quicker and easier online access to music. The report was compiled by a section of the government's music industry forum which includes Martin Mills of the Beggars Banquet label and Tony Wadsworth of EMI.

What does the report recommend?
A secure online payment system for youngsters and adults; home computers, digital TVs and mobile phones that will be able to play music; and cheaper, faster access to the internet and online music through greater competition among phone operators, digital and cable services. Culture secretary Chris Smith said: "Consumers are driving the online revolution, and they want the ability to get the music they want, when they want it and where they want it. If the UK music industry is to continue to prosper it must give consumers what they need and a safe way of paying for it."

How do I download music from the net?

MP3 was the first digital audio format that made it possible to make music downloadable from the web, but that is now being challenged by a format being developed by Liquid Audio, which has come up with its own online digital audio software. Emusic is the biggest seller of downloadable music.

If people can download for free, why do we need music companies?

True, the net offers access to all and lets bands distribute music without middle men. But click on a site like peoplesound.com, and shoppers are swamped by unknown bands. Superstardom requires promotion and marketing. The market research company Jupiter Communications said that the revolution would not be instant, forecasting that digital download would not take off until 2003 when it could have an estimated turnover of $147 million.

Can artists go it alone?

Some big names have tried to skip the middlemen without much success. The Artist's recent attempts to circumvent the record companies and distribute his own music online have not reversed his steady commercial decline. David Bowie's release of Hours stirred up more media interest than actual sales. But Roger Clyne & The Peacemakers showed what can be done. He recorded his band in a little bar club and sold it as digital downloads and Honky Tonk Union made number one on the Top Internet Sales chart in Billboard magazine. That was only 1,200 internet sales but Clyne marketed himself using the net, a physical CD and live appearances to jumpstart a career.

How are the record companies fighting back?

The record labels are countering the threat from MP3 downloads by embracing more sophisticated digitised music formats like Liquid Audio or Microsoft's Windows Media Audio. These enable files to self-destruct after a pre-set period unless customers pay the required download fee.

What about the music stores?

Physical retailers are the ones most under threat from the internet revolution. HMV and other retailers face competition from online music sellers such as Amazon.com, as well as from musicians selling their own material directly to the public. Before its deal with Warner Music, EMI entered an agreement with Liquid Audio to digitise its catalogue for potential download. This way EMI would be able to have its archive of material available on demand without having to keep manufacturing copies on CD.

webTitle: Labour has only itself to blame for Ken's new coup

fields.headline: Labour has only itself to blame for Ken's new coup
fields.standfirst: The government missed a trick over museum chargesThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The government missed a trick over museum charges
fields.body:
Tracey Emin said it all, really. She was there at Gimpel Fils on Monday night for the great art auction in support of Ken Livingstone. Of course she was. Everyone who was anyone donated works for the great cause - Damien Hirst, Antony Gormley, Sir Anthony Caro, Maggi Hambling, Mona Hatoum (in dazzling pink), Howard Hodgkin et al. Among the glamourati were Neil Pearson alongside a stunning supermodel. Amongst the bidders was David Elstein, head of Channel 5. Champagne popped, Tracey kissed Ken and over £100,000 was raised for "the cause". Thus the art world rode gallantly to the aid of underdog Ken, who is only an unstoppable 30% ahead.

So when I asked her why, this is what Tracey Emin said. "I've been waiting all my life for a Labour government and now I've got one, it's shit." Why, exactly? "It's done nothing for people like me". (No, don't boggle). Such as? "There's no money for the health service and people like me don't dare use it and have to go private, so what about the people who can't afford to? Same with education." Anything else? "It's just an incredibly conservative, boring government. Ken's interesting, sexy and dynamic. We need a charismatic, stylish mayor and one who dresses good." Yes, it's cool to support Ken. Don't stop to think, just jerk your knee and Ken is where it's at. So of course the art world is there, it's the place to be.

As for Tony Blair, he is definitely, definitely not cool, not any more, though he was once. Were any of the radical chic at Gimpel Fils dancing the night away at New Labour's triumph on May 1 1997? Maybe some were in the Festival Hall itself, the glam place to be at the time. But that was then and this is now. Politics-as-fun only offers rare moments of synergy with the glam world, for they are planets best kept well apart. It's a mistake to invite Oasis to Downing Street. What did politics do for Billy Bragg's cred? And of course he dumped on Labour in the end - bound to. They all will, these butterflies from elsewhere. Getting political sense from artists is as likely as getting Tony Blair to resurrect Ugly Rumours and cut a number one hit. Keep these worlds well apart or risk cross-contamination and mutual foolishness.

Ken is good at cool, you have to give him that and his hip shelf life may last longer than most. If he keeps needling the boring old government like a teenager taunting his parents he can keep the adolescent tendency happy indefinitely: it's what he does best. How is the uncool grown-up government to handle him? They need to keep one step ahead, give him no easy goals, take away his best lines, but there's scant sign yet of that agility. Like angry parents they rant on, with no damage-limitation strategy. Despairing of Dobson, they sulk in their tent for nothing can stop Livingstone now (even fat cat tax-avoidance seems to charm his fans). And so on Monday Labour needlessly handed Ken yet another quick hit with the chatterati at Gimpel Fils. This is the kind of thing a quick-witted government should see coming.

It concerns the vexed question of museum charges. Labour's other heartland - the liberal intelligentsia - care more about this than almost anything. It is a totemic issue, alongside proper funding of the BBC. This Chris Smith well understood: he won the BBC enough money and he promised to fight for free museum admissions. (Charges nearly halved admission numbers).

It should have been an easy win and this week he nearly succeeded - but you wouldn't think so. Where are the big headlines? Where the celebrations? For the £30m spent the government has earned precious little credit. For lack of one vital ingredient they have thrown away all the glory - handing Ken a neat anti-government line on the arts. Yet again Labour snatches defeat from the jaws of victory.

The good news is that next year all national collections that currently charge will be free to pensioners, children and those on benefits. The rest pay just £1 - victory, you might think. But instead it has left the museum world angry and edgy. Those cutting their charges to £1 cannot guarantee not to raise fees again in future if the government doesn't index-link their grants in perpetuity. But Chris Smith, like any minister, can't guarantee a budget in, say, five years' time, so uncertainty remains. As for a £1 fee, it will cost 70p to collect while another 17.5p goes in VAT, leaving just 12.5p per admission. Why bother? Museums expect to rake in far more from their shops and cafes with so many extra visitors.

The reason for the remaining £1 is a governmental absurdity. That token £1 qualifies the charging museums for VAT rebates worth a lot of money. The non-charging museums still get no such rebates which is grossly unfair and a strong incentive for them to charge £1 against their will, to qualify. All those who have stayed free for all these years at great cost now find they are still penalised: those who turned themselves into businesses are rewarded. No, says the government, if any of the free museums try charging that £1 to get the VAT refund, they'll have their grants clawed back accordingly.

The villain is customs and excise and Chris Smith lost the crucial battle with them. Perversely, they only let businesses collect VAT rebates. Until now they only deemed museums to be businesses if they charged at least £3, (now reduced to £1). The British Museum has a huge building project on which they can't reclaim most VAT because they don't charge. But it's not even that simple. Behind the scenes the BM and others each negotiate private deals with customs so they don't actually pay full VAT, but a sum secretly agreed. This is arbitrary tax law, giving extraordinary power to customs officers. The National Art Collections Fund (NACF) drew up a plan agreed with the Department for Culture to remove VAT from all museums. Smith promised to do or die with the Treasury over it - and lost. It wasn't the estimated £10m cost. It was customs's claim that it would open the VAT floodgates to all arts and charities. Not so, say the NACF, a water-tight definition ring-fencing the national collections exists which opens no floodgate to anyone else.

Joined-up government this is not. Departmental pig-headedness and lack of strategy has left the government spending a lot on doing almost the right thing, but getting no kudos. Who's in charge here? Where was the clever news plan for a happy headline "Labour frees museums for all"? What a missed moment. As for all those political butterflies in the art world, why don't they use their energy in their own sphere and campaign for free, no-VAT museums for the next budget? In the meantime, Ken Livingstone will go on having fun with the issue to their applause. Is this a lesson learned? How sadly often Labour drops the ball.

Keep these worlds well apart or risk cross-contamination and mutual foolishness. Ken is good at cool, you have to give him that and his hip shelf life may last longer than most. If he keeps needling the boring old government like a teenager taunting his parents he can keep the adolescent tendency happy indefinitely: it's what he does best. How is the uncool grown-up government to handle him? They need to keep one step ahead, give him no easy goals, take away his best lines, but there's scant sign yet of that agility. Like angry parents they rant on, with no damage-limitation strategy. Despairing of Dobson, they sulk in their tent for nothing can stop Livingstone now (even fat cat tax-avoidance seems to charm his fans). And so on Monday Labour needlessly handed Ken yet another quick hit with the chatterati at Gimpel Fils. This is the kind of thing a quick-witted government should see coming. It concerns the vexed question of museum charges. Labour's other heartland - the liberal intelligentsia - care more about this than almost anything. It is a totemic issue, alongside proper funding of the BBC. This Chris Smith well understood: he won the BBC enough money and he promised to fight for free museum admissions. (Charges nearly halved admission numbers). It should have been an easy win and this week he nearly succeeded - but you wouldn't think so. Where are the big headlines? Where the celebrations? For the £30m spent the government has earned precious little credit. For lack of one vital ingredient they have thrown away all the glory - handing Ken a neat anti-government line on the arts. Yet again Labour snatches defeat from the jaws of victory. The good news is that next year all national collections that currently charge will be free to pensioners, children and those on benefits. The rest pay just £1 - victory, you might think. But instead it has left the museum world angry and edgy. Those cutting their charges to £1 cannot guarantee not to raise fees again in future if the government doesn't index-link their grants in perpetuity. But Chris Smith, like any minister, can't guarantee a budget in, say, five years' time, so uncertainty remains. As for a £1 fee, it will cost 70p to collect while another 17.5p goes in VAT, leaving just 12.5p per admission. Why bother? Museums expect to rake in far more from their shops and cafes with so many extra visitors. The reason for the remaining £1 is a governmental absurdity. That token £1 qualifies the charging museums for VAT rebates worth a lot of money. The non-charging museums still get no such rebates which is grossly unfair and a strong incentive for them to charge £1 against their will, to qualify. All those who have stayed free for all these years at great cost now find they are still penalised: those who turned themselves into businesses are rewarded. No, says the government, if any of the free museums try charging that £1 to get the VAT refund, they'll have their grants clawed back accordingly. The villain is customs and excise and Chris Smith lost the crucial battle with them. Perversely, they only let businesses collect VAT rebates. Until now they only deemed museums to be businesses if they charged at least £3, (now reduced to £1). The British Museum has a huge building project on which they can't reclaim most VAT because they don't charge. But it's not even that simple. Behind the scenes the BM and others each negotiate private deals with customs so they don't actually pay full VAT, but a sum secretly agreed. This is arbitrary tax law, giving extraordinary power to customs officers. The National Art Collections Fund (NACF) drew up a plan agreed with the Department for Culture to remove VAT from all museums. Smith promised to do or die with the Treasury over it - and lost. It wasn't the estimated £10m cost. It was customs's claim that it would open the VAT floodgates to all arts and charities. Not so, say the NACF, a water-tight definition ring-fencing the national collections exists which opens no floodgate to anyone else. Joined-up government this is not. Departmental pig-headedness and lack of strategy has left the government spending a lot on doing almost the right thing, but getting no kudos. Who's in charge here? Where was the clever news plan for a happy headline "Labour frees museums for all"? What a missed moment. As for all those political butterflies in the art world, why don't they use their energy in their own sphere and campaign for free, no-VAT museums for the next budget? In the meantime, Ken Livingstone will go on having fun with the issue to their applause. Is this a lesson learned? How sadly often Labour drops the ball.

webTitle: Byers did not pose crucial question

fields.headline: Byers did not pose crucial question
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The trade secretary Stephen Byers spoke to the head of BMW, Professor Joachim Milberg, last December but there was no discussion of the sale of Rover, according to documents handed to MPs today.
fields.body:
The trade secretary Stephen Byers spoke to the head of BMW, Professor Joachim Milberg, last December but there was no discussion of the sale of Rover, according to documents handed to MPs today.

The documents, passed on to members of the Commons all-party trade and industry select committee, included minutes of a phone conversation between Mr Byers and Prof Milberg on December 22, 1999. The note of the conversation makes no specific reference to the Rover R30 development, held by some to be the key to Longbridge's future.

Mr Byers, who has been fiercely attacked by Conservatives in the Rover crisis, told the committee this was because the whole conversation was about grant aid specifically tied to the new car, and being held up by the European commission. The EC had announced a formal investigation into whether the £152 million grant was justified under EU competition rules.

The civil service note says: "The secretary of state said that he had pressed [EU Commissioner Mario] Monti on the timing and had been told that conclusion of the procedure before the end of January was impossible. While Monti had accepted the need for a quick decision, he was talking in terms of four to five months. Prof Milberg said that this was disappointing. He would have to discuss this with his board in January. He thanked the secretary of state for his efforts."

But Mr Byers told the committee that no supervisory BMW board meeting was held in January, nor in February. Pressed as to why the note made no reference to the R30, Mr Byers told MPs: "It's because it's almost taken as read that the conversation was about the grant aid in respect of the R30. If there had been a new element introduced into the conversation that went beyond the R30, the likelihood is it would have been noted."

Describing today's release of the record of private conversations as extremely rare, officials insisted that it will not become a precedent. The trade secretary had been summoned to appear before the committee to discuss whether he or his department had prior knowledge of the sell-off, amid Tory claims that BMW gave the UK government warning of its intentions.

MPs were also expected to ask why the British embassy in Berlin did not identify the possibility early on that BMW could pull out of car making in the UK.

fields.headline: Revealed: Wisden's famous five
fields.trailText: After weeks of speculation, Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century can now be revealed. They are Sir Donald Bradman (Australia), Sir Garfield Sobers (West Indies), Sir Jack Hobbs (England), Sir Vivian Richards (West Indies), and Shane Warne (Australia).
fields.body:
After weeks of speculation, Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century can now be revealed. They are Sir Donald Bradman (Australia), Sir Garfield Sobers (West Indies), Sir Jack Hobbs (England), Sir Vivian Richards (West Indies), and Shane Warne (Australia).

Bradman's supremacy was dramatically underlined by the fact that every single member of the panel voted for him. Sobers did almost as well, receiving 90 votes and leaving no room for any doubt as to who is the all-rounder of the century.

Warne, shortly to join Hampshire, is the only current player in the quintet, the only specialist bowler, and the only man without a knighthood. This is the latest in a series of honours for him which began with his being named in Australia's Team of the Century and continued when he broke Dennis Lillee's Australian Test-wickets record.

The choice was made for Wisden by a special panel of 100 players and observers of the game, from Alf Gover (aged 92) to Steve Waugh (34). The panel included voters from every Test nation, but their final choice of five came from only three teams - two Australians, two West Indians and an Englishman.

If Bradman and Sobers were shoo-ins, the final three places were hotly contested, with 47 other players receiving at least one vote, but in the end, there was a clear verdict. Hobbs received 30 votes, Warne 27, and Viv Richards 25, six more than the best of the rest, Dennis Lillee and Sir Frank Worrell (19 each).

Warne was far and away the greatest of today's players in the eyes of the panel, winning twice as many votes as the other four current players on the list put together - Sachin Tendulkar of India (6), Wasim Akram of Pakistan (3), Curtly Ambrose of West Indies and Allan Donald of South Africa (1 each).

England had 17 players on the list, but not many recent ones. After Hobbs, England's top 12 of the century were reckoned to be Wally Hammond (18 votes), Denis Compton (14), SF Barnes and Sir Len Hutton (both 11), Ian Botham (only 9), Harold Larwood (6), Wilfred Rhodes (4), Godfrey Evans (3), and Sir Alec Bedser, Fred Trueman and Frank Woolley (2 each). In other words, the second most recent Englishman to get a vote was Trueman, whose last Test came in 1965. No Gower, no Gooch, no d'Oliveira, no Cowdrey, Knott or Boycott.

Other notable omissions included Brian Lara, Steve Waugh, Jim Laker, Keith Miller, Hanif Mohammad, Rod Marsh, Greg Chappell, Neil Harvey, Mark Taylor, Barry Richards, Peter May, CB Fry, Sir Clyde Walcott and Sir Everton Weekes.

Nobody voted for himself, but Walter Hadlee of New Zealand, after some soul-searching, voted for his son Sir Richard. "This has to be embarrassing for me," he wrote, "but there's a job to be done. I will cite the bare facts ..." It came down to Hadlee versus Lillee. Hadlee had more Test wickets, 431 to 355, many more runs, and a greater impact on the game - a factor that the panel had been asked to take into account. "I consider him to be marginally ahead of Dennis Lillee," Dad concluded, and thus ensured that Richard ended up in 10th place, level with his contemporary Imran Khan.

webTitle: Wacky Balkan western in the making

fields.headline: Wacky Balkan western in the making
fields.trailText: Milcho Manchevski is back behind the camera, five years after winning the Golden Lion at Venice for his first film, Before the Rain. Starring Joseph Fiennes (Shakespeare in Love), Dust sounds like an ambitious and intriguing undertaking.
fields.body:
Milcho Manchevski is back behind the camera, five years after winning the Golden Lion at Venice for his first film, Before the Rain. Starring Joseph Fiennes (Shakespeare in Love), Dust sounds like an ambitious and intriguing undertaking.

Described as a Balkan western, it is set across three different time periods and locations: the American midwest at the turn of the 20th century; the dying days of the Ottoman empire in 1913; and contemporary New York. It also stars David Wenham (The Boys), Adrian Lester (Love's Labour's Lost) and Anne Brochet (Cyrano de Bergerac).

The story, penned by Manchevski, follows two brothers who fall in love with, and fall out over, the same girl. Their dispute takes them to the Balkans just before the first world war. Meanwhile, in the modern time frame, a would-be mugger is about to discover the secret of a hoard of Balkan gold.

Dust has the makings of either a masterpiece or a dog's breakfast. And financing mirrors the complexity of the plot. The project is backed by the Film Consortium, one of Britain's three lotto franchises, in a complex European structure involving the Euro Co-Production Fund, BSkyB, NRW Filmstiftung, Medusa Films, Highlight Communications, the Macedonian Ministry of Culture, Shadow Dooel and Southfork Pictures.

Shooting started Tuesday in New York for two weeks, to be followed by location filming in Macedonia. There will be a studio shoot in Cologne, Germany, in late July, with post-production in London.

fields.headline: Into the unknown
fields.standfirst: Opinion is divided over primary care trusts, reports David Brindle, as the government proceeds with its plans for provision of community services
fields.trailText: Opinion is divided over primary care trusts, reports David Brindle, as the government proceeds with its plans for provision of community services
fields.body:
Amid great excitement over the government's multi-billion cash transfusion for the health service, barely any attention has been paid to a potentially momentous NHS change that took effect this week. When the money is all gone and the begging bowl is out again, though, creation of the first 17 primary care trusts (PCTs) is likely to be seen as the more lasting initiative.

The trusts, the second stage of Labour's two-part reform of the internal market inherited from the Conservatives, enable the primary care groups (PCGs) established a year ago to develop further to take over provision of community health services, as well as their commissioning. Typically, they will each be spending some £70m a year - with the larger ones responsible for as much as £150m. Truly, as the ministerial rhetoric has described it, GPs and community nurses seem to be assuming the driving seat.

Yet all is not well. There are widely held reservations about the pace of change and, in at least one case, a trust has been launched against the apparent opposition of a majority of local doctors. Moreover, the carving up of service provision is not only sounding the death knell for many good community trusts, founded less than a decade ago, but raising profound concerns about the future of mental health care.

Matt Muijen, director of the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health, is warning that care could be set back decades. "It rides roughshod through the whole joint commissioning and joint provider system which is starting to work around the country," he says. "Just when we are finding solutions, we seem to be creating new problems."

The 17 pioneer PCTs are: south Manchester, Daventry in Northamptonshire, Southampton east, Fenland, north Peterborough, south Peterborough, Tendring in Essex, Epping Forest, Southend, central Derby, Mansfield, north-east Lincolnshire, Newark and Sherwood in Nottinghamshire, Poole bay, Poole central and north, Hillingdon in west London and Nelson in south-west London.

A further 40 of the 481 English PCGs have said they wish to become trusts in October, with possibly another 100 or more following next year.

Each of the first 17 has set out its health care priorities: south Manchester is to focus on local problems such as heart disease and asthma; Mansfield's early initiatives will include a sheltered housing project and new services for young people recovering from a stroke; and Hillingdon will increase levels of community nursing, tailored to local needs. John Denham, the health minister, has said: "It will be for local communities to decide the pace of change that is right for them."

His words have come back to haunt him in Southend, however, where the PCT has been given the green light despite a 58% vote against the plan by local GPs. The postal ballot, organised by the local medical committee, attracted an 87% response and prompted the four national bodies representing family doctors to issue an unprecedented joint declaration that "no primary care group should proceed to primary care trust status until the majority of GPs are in favour of it".

Following the ballot, Denham said the Southend trust should proceed only if "significant progress" was made before April 1 to meet local doctors' concerns. A Department of Health spokeswoman said last week that the regional NHS office was satisfied that such progress had been achieved. But local opinion remains sharply divided.

Brian Balmer, secretary of Southend medical committee, says he is unaware of any progress. "What people have been asking for is the chance to evaluate the PCG. We are constantly told to practise evidence based medicine, but here we are moving from the unproven to the totally unknown. Why the rush?"

Some support for this view comes in a new, interim report of a national evaluation of PCGs by the health services management centre at Birmingham University. To date, says the report, the groups have been largely preoccupied with getting themselves up and running: service commissioning has been slow to develop and "tangible service changes are taking time to appear". In essence, the groups remain in development.

A sense of unseemly haste in pushing ahead with PCTs is felt particularly by many in the mental health field. Ministers initially signalled a preference for creating specialist mental health trusts, but then changed tack and announced that PCTs could opt to provide community mental health services.

Muijen is enthusiastic about the flexibility and responsiveness of the PCT idea in relation to health care as a whole. It is even possible, he acknowledges, that some effective approaches to mental health could emerge within a few years. But meanwhile he is alarmed at the prospect of an increasingly confused structure, with some PCTs running services and some not, and with gulfs reopening between hospital and community care and between health and social services provision.

Paraphrasing the famous dictum of the late Sir Roy Griffiths, architect of the 1993 community care system, Muijen warns that this week's watershed could lead to mental health being treated as "everyone's distant relative but no one's child".

fields.headline: Patients need danger money
fields.standfirst: It's time to be frank about the risks in health care and give compensation in good grace, argues legal correspondent Clare Dyer
fields.trailText: The billions of pounds spent by the NHS on settling negligence claims provoked huge headlines today. According to a highly critical National Audit Office report, the cost ran to £1bn in 1998-99 while another £2.4bn has been earmarked for likely payouts in outstanding cases. But buried deeper in the papers was a story thought worthy of just a few paragraphs: Britain has won a grace period of up to 12 years on junior doctors' working hours.
fields.body:
The billions of pounds spent by the NHS on settling negligence claims provoked huge headlines today. According to a highly critical National Audit Office report, the cost ran to £1bn in 1998-99 while another £2.4bn has been earmarked for likely payouts in outstanding cases. But buried deeper in the papers was a story thought worthy of just a few paragraphs: Britain has won a grace period of up to 12 years on junior doctors' working hours.

The government will have four years to bring in legislation reducing working hours to 48 a week. It will then have another five years to implement it, with a possible extension of another three. In the meantime, junior doctors will carry on working dangerously long hours.

The uncomfortable fact is that the health service is a dangerous industry. Up to 40,000 patients a year are thought to die as a result of hospital accidents. There would be a massive public outcry if another industry which engages in inherently dangerous activity - say the airline industry - produced such horrendous death statistics. But air crash deaths are obvious. The health services' victims - as the Bristol heart surgery scandal exposed - are often hidden.

Research presented to the Bristol inquiry shows that, as in the airline industry, there are many near misses in the health service. These are not only due to doctors' errors, but flaws throughout the system. In Bristol, poor diagnosis, poor aftercare and poor logistics within the surgical and intensive care set-up probably contributed as much to the deaths of the babies as surgical error. Near misses are inevitable because humans will always make mistakes. What the airline industry has done is to accept this and set up systems which will compensate for human error and avoid disaster. The health service, much to taxpayers' and patients' cost, has not yet managed to do that.

It should set to work on that task and stop demonising both the patients, who rightly seek compensation when their health is damaged by avoidable error, and the lawyers who help them.

Near misses are inevitable because humans will always make mistakes. What the airline industry has done is to accept this and set up systems which will compensate for human error and avoid disaster. The health service, much to taxpayers' and patients' cost, has not yet managed to do that. It should set to work on that task and stop demonising both the patients, who rightly seek compensation when their health is damaged by avoidable error, and the lawyers who help them.

fields.headline: Prisoner finds producer
fields.trailText: In his first major assignment at Universal since leaving Disney last September, Barry Mendel (The Sixth Sense) has committed to producing The Prisoner, with Oscar-winning screenwriter Chris McQuarrie (The Usual Suspects) set to pen the screenplay.
fields.body:
In his first major assignment at Universal since leaving Disney last September, Barry Mendel (The Sixth Sense) has committed to producing The Prisoner, with Oscar-winning screenwriter Chris McQuarrie (The Usual Suspects) set to pen the screenplay.

Director Simon West (The General's Daughter) is still slated to direct. Based on the 60s cult series The Prisoner, the contemporary version will have original creator and star Patrick McGoohan as the project's executive producer along with West.

The Kafkaesque TV programme was about a man who found himself trapped in a village where everyone has a number, but no name. It addressed such themes as the individual and society, the philosophical nature of freedom, the concentration and abuse of power, and the destructive worship of progress.

Although McGoohan wrote a script in 1996, Mendel, McQuarrie and West have elected to return to the source material rather than the earlier screenplay.

"For me, this project is a huge responsibility because there is such a cult following for the show,'' said Mendel. ''But with Simon West and Chris McQuarrie, it's going to be a cool and commercial movie. When I came to Universal, this was exactly the kind of movie I wanted to do.''

Perks for pets

Rene Castro, an instrument sterilisation supervisor from New York, was devastated when his cat Mitsu developed a nasty downstairs infection, requiring a $1,700 hysterectomy. It was a particular blow since Princess, his Maltese dog, needed $750 worth of attention last year after slipping a disc falling off the sofa. So he and his co-workers at Lenox Hill hospital were thrilled when the company added pet insurance to the list of optional benefits offered to favoured workers. "Everyone went crazy," said an emotional Castro.

As the US economy powers onwards and upwards, firms are having to offer ever more imaginative benefits to attract and keep top talent, hence the booming pet insurance. Specialist pooch pamperers Veterinary Pet Insurance Inc has been offering pet policies since 1982, but says the benefit has taken off only in the past year. "The role of the pet has truly evolved," said a spokeswoman.

Bring down the economy

If you are reading this on the way to work, you have just missed your chance to bring down the corrupt capitalist world order. As the anarchists among you will already know, today is World Phone in Sick Day, a chance to sock one in the eye to Big Brother, while supping soup in front of Richard and Judy.

Decadent Action, the "consumer terrorist organisation" behind the campaign, wants "to damage the economy by costing employers millions and contributing to inflation" on the first day of the financial year. But all is not lost if you are on the Tube: if you must go into work, suggests a US website, "do something pesky". Their suggestions include subscribing your employer to a dozen munitions or white supremacy mags, sending bogus messages that viruses have destroyed your computer system, and dressing your pet in a tie for the day. Now that's decadent.

webTitle: Too late for Mark to make his mark

fields.headline: Too late for Mark to make his mark
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle on why Mark Bosnich is not good enough for Fergie
fields.trailText: Christian Abbiati, Sebastien Frey, Gianliugi Buffon, Ruud Hesp, Tony Prats - even ageing AC Milan reserve Sebastiano Rossi. Just some of the keepers linked with Manchester United during the past few months.
fields.body:
Christian Abbiati, Sebastien Frey, Gianliugi Buffon, Ruud Hesp, Tony Prats - even ageing AC Milan reserve Sebastiano Rossi. Just some of the keepers linked with Manchester United during the past few months.

Which is why Mark Bosnich should be stirring uneasily this morning, despite his sterling heroics last night. Despite all the plaudits in the papers. And despite Sir Alex Ferguson's suggestion afterwards that it was perhaps the Australian's finest hour at the club.

Because the fact remains that Fergie has decided that Bosnich is not good enough to be the Old Trafford number one. He'll placate him for now, even single him out for praise after a big performance - but come the summer he will be ruthlessly dumped.

None of this should come as a surprise when it happens. Ferguson never wanted to sign Bosnich - his real target last summer was Edwin van der Saar. But when the Dutch keeper signed a £10m deal with Juventus he needed a reasonable big name to fill the imposing gloves of Peter Schmeichel. Bosnich was the only one left.

And so Ferguson - like the boy at the high-school prom who sees that everyone else is taken and so moves for the gawky girl in oversized spectacles - signed up the Australian international. The only consolation was that he came on a free transfer.

But Bosnich's flaws were apparent from the start. No-one doubts he's a great shot-stopper, one of the world's best on his day. But he struggles to impose himself in the area, and is woefully indecisive on crosses. He also has a dreadful kicking game, despite all his self-assured protestations after last night's match.

Throw in his weight problems, his unwillingness to toe the Fergie line and the fact that he's not Peter Schmeichel and you can see why his days at Old Trafford are numbered.

Even against Real Madrid, when Bosnich produced a display that Ferguson reckoned was as good as his performance in Tokyo in the World Championship, there were clear signs of his fallibility. For most of the second half he tentatively pawed at Balic's crosses like a young cub recently released into the wild, and froze whenever a corner kick came anywhere near his six-yard box.

With Massimo Taibi on loan at Reggina, and Raymond van der Gouw's blunder against Bordeaux still fresh in Ferguson's mind, Bosnich will probably stay number one at United until the end of the season.

But come the summer, someone bigger, more imposing, more like Schmeichel will move to Old Trafford. And Bosnich will face a choice: relegation to the reserves or move away from Manchester United.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Email your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll try our best to answer them.
fields.trailText: Q "How many Premiership teams will qualify for the Champions League should an English club win the competition this year. Can you confirm whether it will be three or four?" asks Michelle Dickson.
fields.body:
Q "How many Premiership teams will qualify for the Champions League should an English club win the competition this year. Can you confirm whether it will be three or four?" asks Michelle Dickson.

A The number of teams a country has in the Champions League is based on its Uefa coefficient - basically a measure of how well its club sides have performed in Europe over the past six years.

At the moment England are entitled to three places, made up of two automatic places (taken this season by Manchester United and Arsenal) and one place in the final knock-out stage (taken by Chelsea).

That won't change next season - unless Chelsea or Manchester United win the Champions League and finish lower than third. If that happens, England will get four teams in next season's competition.

That's because although Uefa gives the holders an automatic place in the Champions League, this only kicks in if they don't qualify automatically. So even if Manchester United win the Premiership and the Champions League, England will only get three teams in next season's competition.

Q "I am told that there are six current Premiership players who have scored for four different current Premiership clubs. I can think of Paul Ince, Dean Saunders and Mark Hughes. Who are the other three?" asks Matthew Shaddick.

A You may or may not be surprised to hear that the first of this illustrious trio is Carlton Palmer. Palmer, currently playing for Coventry (for whom he scored against Newcastle last October), has also played and scored for Southampton, Leeds and Sheffield Wednesday.

The second name on the list is not quite as unlikely, as Neil Ruddock has 37 career goals to his credit. Razor has scored whilst playing for Southampton, Spurs, Liverpool and West Ham. The last name is that of a striker, West Ham's Paul Kitson (currently on loan at Charlton). He's scored for the Hammers, Newcastle, Derby and Leicester.

Q "I don't suppose you know the name of the music played during Match of the Day's 'Goal of the Month competition?" asks James.

A The title of the music is 'Sequence 3' by Italian brotherly beat combo GF and GP Reverbi. It's taken from an album entitled 'Erotica Italia' which is available on Bistro records.

You might also be interested to know that the original Match of the Day music is by Barry Stoller and the Musicians, and was especially commissioned for the programme in 1964. Unfortunately it's not commercially available.

Finally, the music used at the top of the programme during Gary Lineker's introduction is called 'You Must Know' by Bernard Butler, and is available on Creation Records.

Q "Please could you name the England U-21 team that played in the Toulon tournament in 1990?" asks Richard Glover

A In 1990 England's U-21 squad won the eight-nation tournament in Toulon for the first time with the following squad:

Crossley, Muggleton, Lee, Sharpe, Le Saux, Barrett, Tiler, Sherwood, James, Ebbrell (capt.), Blake, Matthew, Thomas, Stuart, Slater, Olney, Robins.

Shortly afterwards the full England side reached the semi-finals of the World Cup, and many thought this U-21 team would make up the nucleus of England's 1994 World Cup side.

Things didn't quite turn out as forecast, although some players did go on to become full England internationals (notably Le Saux, Sharpe and Sherwood), and one (Crossley) bizarrely played for Wales. Sadly, most of the exalted class of 1990 have become journeyman club players, plying their trade in the lower leagues.

fields.headline: Blue skies for British films
fields.trailText: Sky Pictures, the film arm of British satellite broadcaster BSkyB and one of the partners behind the Sundance hit Saving Grace, has started production on two new star-packed movies. The first, a comedy titled On the Nose, stars Dan Aykroyd, Grace actress and Mike Leigh regular Brenda Blethyn and Robbie (Cracker) Coltrane and begins shooting on March 20 in Dublin. The Canadian-Irish co-production is being directed by David Caffrey from a script by Tony Philpott.
fields.body:
Sky Pictures, the film arm of British satellite broadcaster BSkyB and one of the partners behind the Sundance hit Saving Grace, has started production on two new star-packed movies. The first, a comedy titled On the Nose, stars Dan Aykroyd, Grace actress and Mike Leigh regular Brenda Blethyn and Robbie (Cracker) Coltrane and begins shooting on March 20 in Dublin. The Canadian-Irish co-production is being directed by David Caffrey from a script by Tony Philpott.

The second project, Kiss Kiss (Bang Bang), starring Danish actor Stellan Skarsgard (Good Will Hunting), Chris Penn (Reservoir Dogs) and Paul Bettany (the upcoming Gangster No 1), started production in London last week. Written and directed by Stewart Sugg and produced by James Richardson of Norma Heyman's London-based banner Pagoda Film, the film follows a washed-up hit man forced to come out of retirement - doesn't it sound just like The Limey?

The two films are part of Sky's goal of producing up to 12 original movies for the Rupert Murdoch-controlled satellite broadcaster. All films will be funnelled through Sky Pictures and will run on the Sky Premier channel. They will also have a shot at a theatrical release via Sky's deal with sister company 20th Century Fox.

As Britain's broadcasters face dwindling film budgets and the nation's new film council busies itself with restructuring the disbursement of state and lottery funds, British producers see the fledgling Sky outfit as a welcome addition to the traditional film financing mix.

"Sky Pictures was signed onto our film right from the start,'' said Kiss Kiss producer James Richardson. "They're a young, dynamic team, and the films that they are going for are very commercial and seem to cross the US-European divide.'' Among the other films on Sky's slate is John Duigan's thriller Paranoid, starring Jeanne Tripplehorn, Jessica Alba, Iain Glen and Ewan Bremner.

webTitle: Ethiopia: the famine that everyone saw coming

fields.headline: Ethiopia: the famine that everyone saw coming
fields.standfirst:
The west has no excuses if it fails to prevent a new disaster in Ethiopia, says Audrey Gillan, who reported from the troubled country last year

Map
fields.trailText: The west has no excuses if it fails to prevent a new disaster in Ethiopia, says Audrey Gillan, who reported from the troubled country last year
fields.body:
More than 2,000 people were lining up for food when I arrived in the village of Miramer, on the road to the Ethiopian highland village of Dese. The people had waited days for a food ration that would last no time at all.

The local council secretary, Abebe Workineh, showed me into a large shed where the food he applied to the government for had just arrived. The people of the village had waited a very long time. "This is just 12.5kg (27.5lb) of wheat per family for one month. It is just enough to prevent life from going out. It is really only about one or two days' ration and we have no hope of any more."

One boy emerged from the crowds of people sheltering from the fierce sun under torn umbrellas and old blankets. His name was name was Asalafew and he began pleading in English. "I am miserable. I am hungry. I have had to stop school because of the drought. I want to go back to school. I have worn out my clothes."

This was last July. Eight months ago, the UN warned that the Ethiopian Highlands faced a famine on a scale not seen since 1984. Then, it appealed for £32m in aid to alleviate the effect of serious drought.

The story was one that had been heard before, for Ethiopia suffers a drought roughly every 10 years. First there was so much rain it flattened the crops; then the rain failed completely. People were coming down from the mountains in search of food that could not be found.

At that time Ben Foot, director of Save the Children's operation in Ethiopia, was incredulous and angry at the west's lack of action. He told me: "These people are in really terrible shape. It's impossible to believe that just before the millennium we still have the possibility of a biblical famine in Ethiopia. We have now got almost double the population of 1984. If the harvest fails there will be complete disaster. I spent my first month here trying to keep kids alive, then burying them in the morning - and I will never forget that."

But the alerts have been going unheeded. The Ethiopian ambassador to Britain said his country had been asking for increased aid two years. Yesterday, Bob Geldof warned that the world has four weeks to avert a new famine disaster in Ethiopia. He said: "You've got four weeks. Everyone has been alerted as to what is going on, everyone feels a natural state of repugnance, and you've got four weeks before this becomes a disaster, and if it is, blame will be laid squarely at the doors of those responsible."

Geldof is right. We cannot wait to be stirred into action by reports like those made by Michael Buerk in 1984. We don't need to see images of dead children to give aid; we just need to know that they are hungry.

fields.headline: Stars' money manager accused of stealing $6m from clients
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The man who saw himself as the money manager of Hollywood's young stars has been charged with stealing millions from his clients. Among those who invested with Dana Giacchetto, who is accused of stealing at least $6m (£3.75m), are the actors Leonardo DiCaprio, Ben Affleck and Matt Damon.
fields.body:
The man who saw himself as the money manager of Hollywood's young stars has been charged with stealing millions from his clients. Among those who invested with Dana Giacchetto, who is accused of stealing at least $6m (£3.75m), are the actors Leonardo DiCaprio, Ben Affleck and Matt Damon.

In an operation described by investigators as "wholesale looting", Giacchetto, 37, is alleged to have shuffled $20m into his own account, which he then used to fund a lavish New York lifestyle.

If convicted, the money manager, who is president of the Cassandra Investment group, could face up to 20 years in jail and $1.5m in fines. He is accused of securities fraud and investment advisory fraud. His funds have been frozen and a receiver appointed to administer his affairs.

The investigating authorities are not disclosing which individuals have lost money. Last year, 17 of his most high profile clients dispensed with his services as rumours of his activities started to percolate.

Giacchetto's clients also included Courtney Cox Arquette, Cameron Diaz, Heather Graham, Tobey Maguire and Ben Stiller, the rock band Phish and the Hollywood agent Michael Ovitz.

According to papers at Manhattan federal court, Giacchetto is alleged to have taken money from one group of clients to pay off other groups when he was put under pressure. As long ago as 1997, he was in deep financial trouble and by the end of last year was insolvent.

There is also an investigation into an allegation that Giacchetto made a $12,000 down-payment on a Mercedes-Benz for a law enforcement officer.

Giacchetto, who was out of the country at the time the charges were lodged, was due to turn himself in to authorities in New York in time for the next hearing on April 12.

A spokesman for his company said Giacchetto had no comment on the charges.

webTitle: Hague attacks Byers for 'cover-up' on Rover

fields.headline: Hague attacks Byers for 'cover-up' on Rover
fields.trailText: The prime minister clashed angrily with William Hague in the Commons today after the Conservative leader accused the government of engaging in "doctoring and denial" over BMW's sale of the Rover plant at Longbridge.
fields.body:
The prime minister clashed angrily with William Hague in the Commons today after the Conservative leader accused the government of engaging in "doctoring and denial" over BMW's sale of the Rover plant at Longbridge.

Private conversations between trade secretary Stephen Byers and Rover chairman Walter Samann before the sell-off revealed that Rover was losing £2m a day and gave a clear indication that the car maker was in crisis, said Mr Hague. He then accused Mr Byers of altering crucial papers.

"Last week, BMW issued an account in Munich of precisely what their chairman said to Mr Byers in December," he said. "It says: 'If the structural aid is not approved the BMW Group has to reconsider its investment plans for Longbridge', [but] when the DTI issued the same statement in London, on behalf of BMW, the words of the BMW chairman had been carefully changed to make it seem less dramatic."

"The words 'for the R30' [a Rover model] had been inserted to make it seem that the statement could not have applied to the investment in Rover as a whole," he added.

In a bitter exchange that followed, Mr Hague said that Mr Byers, who faced two hours of questions by the trade and industry select committee over the crisis today, should be replaced by a new secretary of state who "focuses on the future instead of covering up his recent failures".

The prime minister insisted that the government had been aware of the severity of Rover's situation and told the Commons that Mr Byers had his backing.

"The secretary of state has given the fullest possible account. What you are saying is absolute nonsense," he said.

As the row escalated, the prime minister accused the Tory leader of trying to make political capital out of the crisis rather than join with the government to save as many jobs as possible.

"I am only sorry that because you have nothing serious to say on this issue, you have to carry on in the way that you have," he said. "What I find both petty and ridiculous is his [Mr Hague's] determination to back the claims of the BMW chairman."

The government, Mr Blair said, would also make sure that it puts money in place to help not just the Longbridge workers but those in the supply chain as well.

fields.headline: How the cricket world reacted
fields.trailText: The immediate reaction of the cricketing world to this morning's announcement of Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century was largely favourable - with one or two caveats.
fields.body:
The immediate reaction of the cricketing world to this morning's announcement of Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century was largely favourable - with one or two caveats.

Myles Hodgson, the PA cricket correspondent, reacted quickest to the news, which was broken at 10am on www.wisden.com, and led with the omission of Ian Botham, saying he had been "surprisingly overlooked". Hodgson went on to mention that Botham, "widely regarded as one of the great players of the modern era, finished a disappointing 16th". Only at the beginning of the third paragraph was mention made of the five who actually did get chosen. The selection of Shane Warne, the only contemporary cricketer among the five, was hailed as "a tribute to the incredible interest he has developed in the game throughout the world".

Reuters were quick off the mark too, and headed their report by drawing attention to Don Bradman's "perfect century" - a reference to the fact that every member of the 100-strong selection panel voted for him - before running down the top five and even mentioning the nearly men, Dennis Lillee and Frank Worrell, who finished joint sixth with 19 votes.

England batsman, Alec Stewart, in an interview with sportonair.com, spoke like a true player: "It's just like any selection: you're never going to get it right in everyone's eyes. They're five tremendous cricketers, but umpteen other cricketers came very close to getting in."

On the other side of the world, the Australian Associated Press were most excited by the inclusion of one of their own (alongside the national icon Bradman):"Warne is significantly ahead of the man previously regarded as the greatest leg-spinner of all time, Bill O'Reilly, who was 15th with 10 votes." AAP went on to quote Crawford White, former cricket writer for the Daily Express: "'O'Reilly didn't quite rip through the ball like Warne does and I don't think he caught the imagination quite as much as this lad.'"

London's Evening Standard also went big on Warne, but cricket correspondent David Lloyd reckoned debate would "focus on who didn't make it," tossing the names of Wally Hammond (8th) and Denis Compton (9th) into the equation. Lloyd continued: "But perhaps the strength of the competition can best be gauged by the fact that allconquering ex-West Indian captain Clive Lloyd received just one vote while Brian Lara - holder of two world batting records - failed to gain a single nomination."

There were stronger views from wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly editor Tim de Lisle in his wisden.com verdict. He called Warne's legspin bowling "the best thing to happen to the game in the modern era", but wasn't so enthusiastic about the selection of Jack Hobbs. "I wonder if the panel aren't showing a little too much Englishness here," said de Lisle. "His special significance seems to have been that he was the first professional to 'bat as well as the amateur', in the words of Gideon Haigh." Cricketing criteria, he argued, should have been more important than class considerations. de Lisle settles on Imran Khan as his hypothetical fifth man, "the first great fast bowler to come out of Pakistan, and the only one from anywhere who managed to turn himself, when his pace faded, into a front-line batsman".

Indian cricket writer, Harsha Bhogle, agreed, arguing that Imran won more with a less talented group of players than many of his predecessors. Bhogle goes on: "to stay as captain in the atmosphere that exists in Pakistan cricket was an achievement in itself. He was also a forward-thinking man. Long before the ICC could think of neutral umpries, he invited two Indian umpires to stand in a home series because he did not want the possibility of a series win to be tainted by the usual allegations of home umpiring".

The most amusing piece of punditry came this morning on Radio 4's highbrow Today programme, before the results had been announced. Former England fast bowler and professional grump Fred Trueman was busy singing the praises of ex-Yorkshire allrounder Wilfred Rhodes when his dog started barking in the background. Not a man to be shouted down, Trueman promptly left the interview to silence his canine. The resultant delay meant the news headlines were read two minutes late, "thanks to Fred Trueman", as presenter James Naughtie put it.

The final word goes to the editor of the Almanack, Matthew Engel: "Not one of our hundred voted for all the final five," he said. "Yet I don't believe anyone will argue that we have got it terribly wrong. At least one of the five played in every decade of the century. We have two Australians, two West Indians and an Englishman, which seems geographically right, though one suspects an Asian or three will be up there for the 21st century."

Wisden may not have got it terribly wrong, but the disagreements will continue (one wisden.com reader, outraged by the absence of Botham, called for a re-count). But then, as Tim de Lisle put it, that's "half the point of the exercise."

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Byers reveals details of crucial Rover talks

fields.headline: Byers reveals details of crucial Rover talks
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Government transcripts released today to MPs are expected to reveal that the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, never asked BMW the crucial question of whether it intended to sell off its Rover subsidiary - but also that the German company did not volunteer its plans.
fields.body:
Government transcripts released today to MPs are expected to reveal that the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, never asked BMW the crucial question of whether it intended to sell off its Rover subsidiary - but also that the German company did not volunteer its plans.

In an extremely rare move which officials insist will not become a precedent, records of private conversations between Mr Byers and BMW officials in the run-up to last month's surprise announcement that the firm will shed its loss-making Longbridge plant are being made available to the Commons trade and industry select committee.

The trade secretary, summoned to appear before the committee today, will face a grilling over whether he or his department had prior knowledge of the sell-off, amid Tory claims that BMW gave the UK government warning of its in tentions. MPs will also raise questions over why the British embassy in Berlin did not identify the possibility early on that BMW could pull out of car making in the UK.

The select committee will hear that the head of Rover in the UK, Professor Werner Sämann, told the trade secretary about escalating losses at the company during a meeting on March 10, just six days before the supervisory board meeting that took the sell-off decision.

Transcripts will show that Mr Byers asked Prof Sämann what steps would be taken to remedy the increase in losses to £2m a day, but that he did not specifically ask whether the entire future of Longbridge was at stake.

"I asked him: 'what steps will you take to remedy this?'," Mr Byers told BBC Radio 4's Today programme yesterday. "He put forward a four-point plan. And none of those points included the breakup of Rover." The records are also expected to show that Prof Sämann did not state that Longbridge could be sold off. MPs are expected to seek answers on what information was passed back to the DTI by the British embassy in Berlin, suggesting that officials there were still in "cold war mode", focusing on diplomacy and security, when in fact commercial sensitivity was needed.

Yesterday Mr Byers insisted that the bleak picture of UK car making painted by recent press reports was "misleading." The trade secretary said Honda's decision to cut output at its Swindon plant was not due to a downturn in the industry but was because the company wanted to invest in another production line.

But another Japanese car firm warned of job losses yesterday unless an eagerly awaited report on new car pricing is published soon. The head of Mitsubishi Motors, Denis Murphy, said it was "irresponsible" of the government to delay publication of the report any longer and that it was causing confusion for customers. "Speculation of what is contained in the report has been damaging the industry for the last 12 months without any real evidence that prices can be reduced," said Mr Murphy.

The embattled trade secretary also received a cool welcome from business leaders yesterday despite offering them an £180m olive branch in the form of reduced red tape. Mr Byers promised the annual conference of the British Chambers of Commerce that companies with an annual turnover of less than £4.8m would be exempt from audit requirements.

But the BCC said that what was needed was a bonfire of red tape and regulation which they estimate costs British business £10bn a year. Ian Peters, deputy director-general of the BCC, described the decision to raise the audit threshold as a step in the right direction. "But it will do nothing to tackle the raft of burdens this government has imposed since it came to power," he warned.

fields.headline: Country of the Month: Oman
fields.trailText: Country of the Month: Oman
fields.body:
Country of the Month: Oman

Mike Ramsden

Living | Teaching | Key points to remember | Useful contacts

Introduction - The Land
Oman is about the size of the UK with a population of 2.2 million situated at the south-eastern tip of the Arabian peninsula. Yemen lies to the south and Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are the northern borders. The peoples and culture reflect Oman's long maritime history, when dhows sailed to East Africa, Pakistan and Persia.

Stable for the thirty years of Sultan Qaboos' reign, Oman is diversifying away from total dependence on oil to light industry and tourism. The GDP is 2.5% and inflation is 1%.

The winter months are very pleasant with temperatures of 28C by day and 19C by night. This is the time to explore Oman's stunning mountains and deserts. Air conditioning in houses and classrooms mitigate the worst of the summer temperatures of 40C or above.

Living
How you live depends on where you are. Muscat is a fine modern city, exceptionally clean and gleaming white, with the turquoise sea rarely out of sight. Catherine Lonie, who left for a period of time and then returned, comments: 'When I came to Oman I was astounded by the natural beauty and the friendliness and tolerance of the Omani people towards Westerners.' Meryl Farrar 'was amazed at the rapid development and the enthusiasm of the youthful population'.

Oman invites superlatives and extends a welcome. No one need feel culture shock. The list of things to do, thanks to the exceptional climate, extends from fishing, scuba diving and boating to the whole range of land-based sports. Oman has its own Royal Symphony Orchestra, all Omanis, with a full repertoire of the classics; it has choral singing, fine arts, photography, a flourishing Historical Society. All the major hotels in Muscat have live bands and you can choose between jazz, African soukous, the blues and pop. There is a full international range of restaurants and only the fussiest of shoppers would find the supermarkets and the shopping malls lacking.

Gill Bush, a colleague who has worked in both Muscat and Sur, an ancient town 320 km south of Muscat where dhows are still handbuilt, comments, 'It has been a privilege to have worked in both places because the contrast brings out the qualities in both. Sur had a gentler pace and was a nature lover's paradise. Seeing the green turtles nesting at Ras Al Hadd, a few hours from Sur, is an unforgettable experience.'

Robert Fisk has worked in Nizwa, 160 km away from Muscat in the interior. 'Lots to do if you like the great outdoors - camping trips, wadis to swim in. Then there's the beautifully restored fort and souk but my wife, Elaine, found it a lonely spot for a European woman. The handful of expats made their own fun.'

Another colleague moved from Muscat to Salalah (1000 km south) where summer brings mist and rain and tropical growth. She loves every minute of her time in this culturally unique region.

How you'd make out financially would depend on your family circumstances, whether you eat local produce or imported food, and who you work for. The Language Centre, Sultan Qaboos University, pays 700 rials a month (£1,129 with an exchange rate of .63 rials to the £) to instructors with an RSA DipTEFL or equivalent and 800 rials to lecturers with a master's. This is tax free, as is the accommodation - usually a three bedroom house on campus or villa or flat off campus. Your utilities would average out at 10 - 15 rials a month for water, electricity and internet connection; that is, if you use bottled gas and have water connected to the mains. Petrol is .180 rial per litre, while a fresh chicken is .800, so you can live quite cheaply.

English is widely spoken and understood but courtesy would demand you speak some Arabic and this is widely appreciated, especially by the people in the interior.

Teaching
ELT is a growth industry. Thirty years ago, Oman had three schools, now there are almost a thousand state schools, with 20 university-level colleges as well as many private schools and an internationally renowned university.

The Language Centre, Sultan Qaboos University conducts an intensive programme of general and academic English to prepare an intake of over a thousand students to study for their degree subjects in English. The 120-plus staff teach on average 20 hours a week. Juliet Arden-Close, a lecturer at the Centre, is not unusual in enjoying teaching at the Centre: 'The students are keen, highly motivated and fun to teach.'

The British School, Muscat, provides a programme based on the British National Curriculum with English as the medium of instruction. Experience of the British school system would be an important asset for prospective applicants rather than years of overseas EFL teaching.

Sarah Joseph teaches EFL to learners ranging from 11 - 15 at the Royal Guard of Oman College of Technology in Muscat: "The boys are generally excellent and very polite and a joy to teach." Salaries start from 950 rials per month, with free accommodation and 'good holidays'. Recruitment is either local or through the UK TEFL press.

The British Council offers a range of opportunities including teaching young learners and young adults and general and job-related English to adults. CELTA and an add-on CELTYL module are also delivered. Recruitment is either local or through the BC in UK or, if you are already at post, through the Council's bulletins.

The colleges of Education at Sohar, Salalah, Sur, Ibri, Rustaq and Nizwa provide opportunities for teaching general and ESP but the trainee teachers are not going to teach English, and problems of motivation might have to be addressed by a resourceful teacher. At the time of writing, recruitment for these posts is shifting from private agencies to the Ministry of Education, though CfBT Reading might be able to advise.

Oman is a rewarding place to teach and has all the advantages of a vibrant and fascinating culture and dignified, friendly people.

Class size is rarely more than twenty and this is consistent with the EFL methods preferred, whether students are interacting with a text, the teacher or each other, an approach which means lively classes. As school curricula are constantly being upgraded, most students have not up to now been used to this type of interactive learning at secondary school, and a degree of tact and patience is required to break down shyness and a reluctance to speak in class; this could be due to male students being unaccustomed to a woman teacher or vice versa, or from the fact that male and female students are together - though sitting apart - in the same classroom.

Autonomous learning and independent thinking are stressed in Oman today and students at SQU first research a project utilising their freshly acquired library skills and later in the year present a topic to the class, complete with OHTs.

Key points to remember
 Check your terms and conditions

 Check when your first paycheque will arrive

 SQU insists on attested certificates of service from former employers - check which they want as this can be costly and time-consuming. You will also need attested degree certificates.

Useful contacts

SQU Language Centre

Fax 968 513411 Attn: Lamis Al-Kiyomi

British School, Muscat: Fax 968 601062

Educational Services Overseas, Oman office: Fax 968 565573

British Council UK

Centre for British Teachers (CfBT) Reading

Mike Ramsden teaches at the Language Centre, Sultan Qaboos University. He has taught in East Africa, Brunei, and the Middle East. He can be contacted at: annie@omantel.net.om
