Meryl Farrar 'was amazed at the rapid development and the enthusiasm of the youthful population'. Oman invites superlatives and extends a welcome. No one need feel culture shock. The list of things to do, thanks to the exceptional climate, extends from fishing, scuba diving and boating to the whole range of land-based sports. Oman has its own Royal Symphony Orchestra, all Omanis, with a full repertoire of the classics; it has choral singing, fine arts, photography, a flourishing Historical Society. All the major hotels in Muscat have live bands and you can choose between jazz, African soukous, the blues and pop. There is a full international range of restaurants and only the fussiest of shoppers would find the supermarkets and the shopping malls lacking. Gill Bush, a colleague who has worked in both Muscat and Sur, an ancient town 320 km south of Muscat where dhows are still handbuilt, comments, 'It has been a privilege to have worked in both places because the contrast brings out the qualities in both. Sur had a gentler pace and was a nature lover's paradise. Seeing the green turtles nesting at Ras Al Hadd, a few hours from Sur, is an unforgettable experience.' Robert Fisk has worked in Nizwa, 160 km away from Muscat in the interior. 'Lots to do if you like the great outdoors - camping trips, wadis to swim in. Then there's the beautifully restored fort and souk but my wife, Elaine, found it a lonely spot for a European woman. The handful of expats made their own fun.' Another colleague moved from Muscat to Salalah (1000 km south) where summer brings mist and rain and tropical growth. She loves every minute of her time in this culturally unique region. How you'd make out financially would depend on your family circumstances, whether you eat local produce or imported food, and who you work for. The Language Centre, Sultan Qaboos University, pays 700 rials a month (£1,129 with an exchange rate of .63 rials to the £) to instructors with an RSA DipTEFL or equivalent and 800 rials to lecturers with a master's. This is tax free, as is the accommodation - usually a three bedroom house on campus or villa or flat off campus. Your utilities would average out at 10 - 15 rials a month for water, electricity and internet connection; that is, if you use bottled gas and have water connected to the mains. Petrol is .180 rial per litre, while a fresh chicken is .800, so you can live quite cheaply. English is widely spoken and understood but courtesy would demand you speak some Arabic and this is widely appreciated, especially by the people in the interior. Teaching ELT is a growth industry. Thirty years ago, Oman had three schools, now there are almost a thousand state schools, with 20 university-level colleges as well as many private schools and an internationally renowned university. The Language Centre, Sultan Qaboos University conducts an intensive programme of general and academic English to prepare an intake of over a thousand students to study for their degree subjects in English. The 120-plus staff teach on average 20 hours a week. Juliet Arden-Close, a lecturer at the Centre, is not unusual in enjoying teaching at the Centre: 'The students are keen, highly motivated and fun to teach.' The British School, Muscat, provides a programme based on the British National Curriculum with English as the medium of instruction. Experience of the British school system would be an important asset for prospective applicants rather than years of overseas EFL teaching. Sarah Joseph teaches EFL to learners ranging from 11 - 15 at the Royal Guard of Oman College of Technology in Muscat: "The boys are generally excellent and very polite and a joy to teach." Salaries start from 950 rials per month, with free accommodation and 'good holidays'. Recruitment is either local or through the UK TEFL press. The British Council offers a range of opportunities including teaching young learners and young adults and general and job-related English to adults. CELTA and an add-on CELTYL module are also delivered. Recruitment is either local or through the BC in UK or, if you are already at post, through the Council's bulletins. The colleges of Education at Sohar, Salalah, Sur, Ibri, Rustaq and Nizwa provide opportunities for teaching general and ESP but the trainee teachers are not going to teach English, and problems of motivation might have to be addressed by a resourceful teacher. At the time of writing, recruitment for these posts is shifting from private agencies to the Ministry of Education, though CfBT Reading might be able to advise. Oman is a rewarding place to teach and has all the advantages of a vibrant and fascinating culture and dignified, friendly people. Class size is rarely more than twenty and this is consistent with the EFL methods preferred, whether students are interacting with a text, the teacher or each other, an approach which means lively classes. As school curricula are constantly being upgraded, most students have not up to now been used to this type of interactive learning at secondary school, and a degree of tact and patience is required to break down shyness and a reluctance to speak in class; this could be due to male students being unaccustomed to a woman teacher or vice versa, or from the fact that male and female students are together - though sitting apart - in the same classroom. Autonomous learning and independent thinking are stressed in Oman today and students at SQU first research a project utilising their freshly acquired library skills and later in the year present a topic to the class, complete with OHTs. Key points to remember  Check your terms and conditions  Check when your first paycheque will arrive  SQU insists on attested certificates of service from former employers - check which they want as this can be costly and time-consuming. You will also need attested degree certificates. Useful contacts SQU Language Centre Fax 968 513411 Attn: Lamis Al-Kiyomi British School, Muscat: Fax 968 601062 Educational Services Overseas, Oman office: Fax 968 565573 British Council UK Centre for British Teachers (CfBT) Reading Mike Ramsden teaches at the Language Centre, Sultan Qaboos University. He has taught in East Africa, Brunei, and the Middle East. He can be contacted at: annie@omantel.net.om

fields.headline: Barclays: banks for the memory
fields.standfirst: Negotiation could be producing a positive legacy when Barclays pulls out of one rural centre. Guardian northern editor Martin Wainwright explains
fields.trailText: All sides in the Barclays Bank controversy might benefit from an away-day to Reeth, the 'capital' of Upper Swaledale in North Yorkshire and one of the most isolated of Britain's market towns.
fields.body:
All sides in the Barclays Bank controversy might benefit from an away-day to Reeth, the 'capital' of Upper Swaledale in North Yorkshire and one of the most isolated of Britain's market towns.

Along with 169 other rural centres, the huddle of gritstone houses is shortly to lose its branch of Barclays. But its reaction to news of the closure bore little resemblance to the calls for boycotts or manure-dumping on Barclays doorsteps that characterised the other rural bank protests.

The reaction in Reeth was entirely pragmatic. Attempts to persuade the bank to change its mind were unsuccessful, and so the local councillors looked for the next best bet. It probably helped that one of them, John Blackie, who leads the local Richmondshire district council, is a former London cabbie and a holiday cottage businessman. He acknowledged that the bottom line ultimately matters; that the lack of NatWests or HSBCs queuing up to buy the bank was significant; and that running Barclays is not a charitable affair.

There was room, though, Reeth reasoned, for a little pressure on the bank along the lines of 'social responsibility'; it hadn't escaped the town's notice that Barclays now allows time off for re-training of staff who may face redundancy at short notice in challenging financial times. With the stick of the PR disaster of the rural closures, and the carrot of various tax benefits for a little in the way of good works, there was scope for a little arm-twisting.

The result is that Barclays has agreed to delay the sale (though not the closure) of its building in Reeth and to talk to Richmondshire and local people about converting it into a community office for the council and the town. The building would have a range of Richmondshire services but possibly banking facilities as well. Even if only at limited times, that would be better than the ten-mile trek to Richmond, which will be the nearest proper branch.

The office would be considerably bigger than Richmondshire's current plan for a Reeth base squashed into a little spare space at a sheltered housing complex; so the council wins in that way. Blackie is also talking up the possibility of computer and video-conferencing facilities and internet access on the lines of the Dalesnet system which is beginning to link businesses and services in the Yorkshire Dales.

Who - hint, hint - might provide some of this gear? Barclays is adamant about pulling out, but its national community affairs manager is going to talk to the council. The proposal looks set to be a model for other Barclays-losing villages; more positive than exchanging insults and in keeping with Reeth's endless adaptation of its economic survival, from the days in the mid-18th century when there were two schools, a weekly market, four annual fairs and a busy mineral industry based on Old Gang Mines.

fields.headline: An almost perfect five
fields.standfirst: Tim de Lisle gives the wisden.com verdict on the Five Cricketers of the Century
fields.trailText: Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century were trailed so widely and so long that they were in danger of ending up as a bit of a let-down. In the event, we needn't have worried. The 100-strong panel have come up with a list that is not far short of perfection.
fields.body:
Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century were trailed so widely and so long that they were in danger of ending up as a bit of a let-down. In the event, we needn't have worried. The 100-strong panel have come up with a list that is not far short of perfection.

Bradman and Sobers were always likely to be automatic choices. The striking thing about the voting is how true this turned out to be. Every single panellist voted for Bradman. The round figure of a hundred, which famously eluded him in the career-average department, is his at last.

In the list of highest Test batting averages, no-one has ever got close to Bradman. In this game, Garry Sobers did, polling 90 out of a possible 100 votes. Any arguments about who is the allrounder of the century may have to end here. The four great allrounders of the 1980s, Ian Botham, Imran Khan, Kapil Dev and Richard Hadlee, got fewer than half as many votes between them.

The three places in the pantheon that couldn't safely have been predicted went to Jack Hobbs, Shane Warne and Viv Richards. For Warne, it is yet another phenomenal achievement in a winter that has been full of them. He was delighted enough to be named in Australia's Team of the Century a couple of months ago, and probably even an Aussie can see that being included in the first XI from your own country pales next to being in the top five from all around the cricket world. The panel, whose composition showed a bias towards both the elders of the game (only one current player, Steve Waugh) and also towards England, should be congratulated on swallowing their possible distaste for peroxide, outspokenness and triumphal stump-waving, and recognising that Warne's legspin bowling is the best thing to happen to the game in the modern era.

The other undoubted colossus of the past 25 years is Viv Richards. The most murderous batsman of all time, and also, almost on the side, unbeaten in a series as a Test captain, he was beautifully characterised the other day by Matthew Engel, the Almanack's editor, as 'a one-man rebuttal of colonial history'.

For some, the surprise among the five will be Warne, because he is still playing (as if that should be held against him). For me, the surprise, and the one imperfection, is Hobbs. He was clearly a great batsman, with his Test average of 56 and his monumental collection of 197 hundreds, and he seems to have been an admirable man too. But I wonder if the panel aren't showing a little too much Englishness here. His special significance seems to have been that he was the first professional to 'bat as well as the thoroughbred amateur', in the words of the anglophile Australian writer (and Wisden panellist) Gideon Haigh. The dreaded C-word rears its head.

Of course, class plays its part in cricket. But this is a list of the greatest exponents of an international sport over a whole century. Surely, just this once, we could have left everybody's socio-economic position out of the picture, and stuck to the question of how well they played cricket. Batting was easier in Hobbs's day. He even said so himself, graciously citing changes in the LBW law; he could have added that all the great Australian fast bowlers came along after he had finally retired.

It's good to have Hobbs's period (1905-34) represented here, but there are at least 10 others who deserve a place in this super-select company ahead of him. If you want a pre-war batsman, have George Headley of the West Indies: it seems wrong that the Black Bradman should have received only five votes, when the white one got 20 times that. If you want an Englishman, have Ian Botham, whose impact in 1981 was greater than any cricketer before or since.

Better still, the panel could have used Hobbs's place to make good the two blazing injustices of their list. It contains no player who was primarily a fast bowler, even though, as a breed, they more or less ruled the century. Nor does it contain a player from the subcontinent.

Killing these two birds with one man isn't easy: the only contenders are Wasim Akram (great but not that great), Waqar Younis (ditto), Kapil (a great entertainer, and a great survivor, but surely fourth out of four among the allrounders of his time), and Imran.

Imran was the first great fast bowler ever to come out of Pakistan, and the only one from anywhere who managed to turn himself, when his pace faded, into a front-line batsman. He was also an outstanding captain who won the World Cup with a superhuman recovery from a desperate position. He came 10th equal in this poll; in my book, he would have come fifth. But it's lucky he didn't, because then there would have been nothing to argue with, which is half the point of the exercise.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly. He was not a member of the voting panel.

webTitle: Father allowed into US to bring Elian home

fields.headline: Father allowed into US to bring Elian home
fields.standfirst:
Tension builds in Miami's Cuban-American community as relatives hint they may not hand over boy

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The denouement of the Elian Gonzalez custody saga appeared to be approaching yesterday, as US and Cuban officials held negotiations over the expected arrival in the US of Elian's father, who intends to take the boy home.
fields.body:
The denouement of the Elian Gonzalez custody saga appeared to be approaching yesterday, as US and Cuban officials held negotiations over the expected arrival in the US of Elian's father, who intends to take the boy home.

The US state department issued six visas for the father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, relatives, a paediatrician and the boy's school teacher, but Cuban officials were asking for 22 more visas for the boy's classmates and a government delegation.

As the prospect of Mr Gonzalez's arrival loomed, tension intensified around the Miami home of Elian's US-based relatives who have been striving in the courts to prevent his return to Cuba. They have hinted they might not hand him over - as the US Justice Department is demanding - even if his father appeared on their doorstep.

Their lawyers are requesting that Elian undergo a psychological examination before his return to Cuba is considered.

Elian's American cousin, Marisleysis Gonzalez, was taken to hospital after fainting at the family home in Miami's Little Havana. Marisleysis, 21, who has become to close to Elian since he was found floating in the Florida Straits, said she had not yet told him that his father was on the way.

The boy's mother and 12 other Cubans were drowned on their disastrous migrant voyage to the US in November.

"As a precaution, I will not tell him until everything is certain," she told journalists before she fell ill. She claimed that whenever the possibility of the father's arrival was mentioned, "all he asks me is 'please don't let them take me'."

Juan Miguel Gonzalez and Cuban officials have accused Elian's Miami relatives of manipulating the boy to suit the rightwing exile groups backing them, for whom his fate has become a symbolic struggle with Fidel Castro's regime.

Meanwhile, the Cuban government has taken over negotiations on behalf of Juan Miguel Gonzalez. Luis Fernandez, spokesman at the Cuban Interests Office in Washington, said yesterday: "Juan Miguel is coming as soon as he receives the guarantee from the justice department and the INS [Immigration and Naturalisation Service] that he is going to receive the custody of his boy."

Al Gore, the vice-president and Democratic contender for the presidency, intervened once more in the family tussle yesterday. In an apparent bid to win Cuban-American votes in Florida, Mr Gore stunned the White House last week by breaking ranks with the Clinton administration and backing measures to grant Elian and his father permanent residence and to hand the matter of custody to a family court.

Yesterday, after criticism from senior Democrats, Mr Gore argued that the boy should be allowed to return to Cuba with his father "if the father says on free soil that he believes that the son should go back to Cuba with him."

An opinion poll published yesterday found that 56% of US citizens questioned believed Elian should be allowed to return to his father and to Cuba while 31% opposed his return.

However, more than 80% of Cuban-Americans in Florida are backing the Miami relatives' battle to gain custody of Elian, and they are expected to be a big factor in determining who wins Florida in this year's presidential elections.

The state's governor, Jeb Bush - brother of the Republican presidential contender George W Bush - met public safety officials to discuss how to respond to civil unrest if Elian was returned to Cuba.

Papers take up the fight:

Boston Herald

While sad and unfortunate that his mother died in the process of her kidnapping, all appropriate considerations compel a swift return of Elian to his father's home in Cuba.

And, without a Cuban circus intertwined with an American presidential election campaign, that is what should have happened!

Seattle Times

The US means well, but we are rapidly losing our ability to do anything that makes sense regarding little Elian.

However well-motivated Elian's Florida relatives might have been at the beginning, there seems no doubt that at least some of them have come to regard Elian not as their spunky little cousin, but as a political trophy.

San Francisco Chronicle

The plight of Elian has been trapped behind the iron barricades for too long, drowned out by the rabble rousers and buried in speechmaking by officials. Elian, the desperate castaway child has given way to Elian the street crusade.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body: In a spectacularly late attempt to seduce the youth vote, Frank Dobson now models himself on a cult hero. Announcing a "crusade against drugs", Dobbo urges people to shop to the police anyone driving a flashy car with "no visible means of support". At first sight it looks like the rantings of a maniac. On reflection, it is genius. With these few words Dobbo instantly establishes himself as London mayoral politics' very own Ali G. Consider Ali's interview with the ex-circus court judge and professional buffoon Judge James Pickles: "You've got a guy there, 19-years-old, drivin' around, in the top of the range Saab. All da lights an' everythin', leather seats, bitches in the front, bitches in the back, gold tooth, UV lighting underneath, drum and bass coming out, the guy never done any work in his life. Is he a rapper or is he a dealer, considering he never touched any decks or held a mic in his life? Are you going to send him down?" It's quite uncanny. How long can it be now before Ali G looks at a victim and utters the words: "Oooh, you amaze I!"?  In the media pages of the Independent, Tina Brown and the mag's publisher repeatedly insist how well Talk is doing. "I feel, as they say, in a very good place now," Tina concludes. "Because we have adjusted very quickly and this is a very good magazine." Oh dear. We've all heard the rumours, but who knew things were quite so bad?  Yesterday's item about Amazon.co.uk selling the infamous anti-semitic tract The Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion, with no proper warning that the text is a forgery, provokes a speedy response. Geoffrey Shisler, an orthodox rabbi in Bournemouth, has begun an email chain letter campaign inviting people to boycott Amazon. One understands the emotion (the book can be held responsible for causing much virulent anti-Jewish sentiment, and continues to do so). No doubt covering the book's entry with warnings, putting it in the history section, offering an apology and making a vast donation to Jewish charities may get Amazon off the hook before things turn really nasty. Or is it already too late? We shall see.  Treating Daily Mail readers to money-saving tips, Michael Winner relates how once he went into a branch of Marks & Spencer. "I pointed to my star. 'This is Anthony Hopkins, not chopped liver'." Michael is quick to recant when I call. "I would like to apologise to all chopped liver eaters and makers, particularly your mother, whose liver I had, of course, not eaten at the time. With the liver, your mother is as much an artist in her way as Anthony is at acting." Mmm, not quite good enough. In penance, Michael has agreed to be the second celebrity to model an Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirt. Please God we can get him into a Frank (XL) size shirt.  It is not always the Diary's way to praise the Sun or its alopecian editor David Yelland, but hats off for a campaign to increase numbers of those carrying organ donor cards. In first world countries such as Holland, where the system is one of presumed assent, cards aren't necessary at all, but here in Blighty things are different and the Sun's printing of 10m cards for readers is such a inspired idea that the Mirror will claim it as an exclusive by the end of the week.  While browsing the web, little grabs the eye like a notice saying "Not for publication", especially from the Associated Press news wire feed on Lycos. webTitle: Diana award for girl carer determined on schooling

fields.headline: Diana award for girl carer determined on schooling
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Natalie Peirce, 15, who dropped out of school to care for three brothers when her father died and her mother turned to drugs, was yesterday praised by David Blunkett for her pioneering work in persuading pupils to return to the classroom.
fields.body:
Natalie Peirce, 15, who dropped out of school to care for three brothers when her father died and her mother turned to drugs, was yesterday praised by David Blunkett for her pioneering work in persuading pupils to return to the classroom.

Natalie, described by the education secretary as his "own little Spice Girl", was one of 237 pupils between 11 and 18 receiving a new award to recognise and celebrate children's achievement, set up in memory of the late Princess of Wales.

Papers inviting all schools to nominate pupils to enter for the award will be sent out later this week. The first recipients were chosen for the benefit they had given their communities and schools - raising funds for hospitals, mentoring younger pupils, campaigning for safer roads, devising ways to make school life easier for fellow pupils with disabilities, and battling to pass exams while suffering serious illness.

At yesterday's London presentation Natalie, who attends Stewards school in Essex, told how she gave up school at 13 to look after her younger brothers - one still a baby - after her father's death, when it became clear that her addict mother could not cope. "I left for a year, because they needed someone to keep them clean, get them to school, and make sure they were safe. But it became harder and harder for me to stay away from school, as I realised the importance of my own education."

Since her return, she has acted as a role model for other children, joining a project in Essex to reduce non-attendance and truancy. Among its recommendations, schools are encouraged to issue parents with pagers so they can be informed immediately if their children fail to turn up.

Natalie, who takes GCSEs this year, has sought to raise awareness of the problems some young people face by speaking publicly and on TV. Paying tribute to her achievements, Mr Blunkett said: "If the project Natalie has been involved in can help kids who would be written off otherwise, then it is worth learning from.

"Her experience also shows that there is a real issue about young carers who act in lieu of their mum and dad. Teachers should not be social workers, and there is probably a case for a clearer role for social services - it is not just about getting kids out of a difficult situation, but about helping them through it."

Among the other award-winners was Omar Anayat, 15, of Beardwood high school in Blackburn, who raised £1,300 in two weeks for the Royal Manchester children's hospital in memory of a fellow pupil who was treated there, and Stephen Green, 17, of Warrington in Cheshire, who set up a bullying awareness programme.

fields.headline: Official: red tape hinders schools
fields.standfirst:
Heads 'need protection from Stalinist Whitehall' control
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A taskforce appointed by Tony Blair to get rid of unnecessary red tape will tomorrow demand protection for headteachers against over-zealous officials at the department for education and employment and meddlers on school governing bodies.
fields.body:
A taskforce appointed by Tony Blair to get rid of unnecessary red tape will tomorrow demand protection for headteachers against over-zealous officials at the department for education and employment and meddlers on school governing bodies.

Lord Haskins, chairman of the better regulation taskforce, is expected to say that the drive to raise educational standards is being hindered by excessive instruction from Whitehall, overcomplicated funding arrangements and lack of clear lines of accountability.

After a three-month inquiry, the team concluded that heads supported the policies introduced by David Blunkett, education and employment secretary, but criticised the speed of implementation and extent of central government intervention in the way services were delivered at school level.

Heads said they were victims of initiative overload and spent too much time bidding for up to 12 separate streams of funding, earmarked by ministers for particular projects.

Lord Haskins, chairman of Northern Foods, is understood to have told colleagues that the DfEE was "the most Stalinist department I have ever come across".

Although the DfEE will be criticised, it is expected to sup port the taskforce's conclusions and say it is already moving in the right direction.

Mr Blunkett will argue that the incoming government was bound to make lots of changes in 1997 to implement its manifesto. For example, the strategy to raise standards of literacy and numeracy in primary schools could not have been introduced without strong central direction.

He will also say that as the reforms bed down a better balance can be struck between national control and appropriate discretion for heads to manage their schools as they see fit.

Increases in public spending on education should allow money for specific projects to be distributed to all schools, instead of being limited to those able to bid successfully for small earmarked funds.

The taskforce report is expected to highlight the particular burden of regulation on schools with fewer than 500 pupils. It recommends that schools identified by inspectors as struggling need a lot more financial freedom to generate improvement.

In turn, Mr Blunkett is expected to respond with proposals for using the internet to reduce unnecessary paperwork. Heads will get "electronic intrays" to access relevant material from Whitehall. The DfEE is working towards targeted emailing to provide heads with information they ought to read and indicate what other material is available.

Other initiatives will include a "small school support fund" to allow groups of heads to club together to employ a shared bursar or administrative assistant.

The taskforce will call for a redefined relationship between heads and governing bodies to prevent governors from meddling in day-to-day administration. Heads should be like company chief executives, taking guidance from the board on strategy but personally accountable for performance. The report is expected to recommend smaller boards of governors.

It will be published tomorrow at the same time as a survey by the National Association of Head Teachers which will show increasing concern about workload pressures, including demands from the school inspectorate, government agencies, funding bodies and governors.

 The government will today announce a network of up to 100 sports academies to improve England's performance in international competition. They will form part of a programme to encourage state secondary schools to specialise in particular subjects and share their expertise with neighbouring comprehensives.

fields.headline: Race to save 16m from starvation
fields.standfirst:
EU faces obstacles of war as it steps up aid to Africa war

The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Europe is preparing to spearhead large aid deliveries to the Horn of Africa in an attempt to avoid a repeat of the famine that claimed close to a million lives in Ethiopia 15 years ago.
fields.body:
Europe is preparing to spearhead large aid deliveries to the Horn of Africa in an attempt to avoid a repeat of the famine that claimed close to a million lives in Ethiopia 15 years ago.

The United Nations warned that up to 16m people could face starvation within weeks after repeated crop failures caused by prolonged drought and years of conflict in the region. It appealed for $200m (£122m) to address the crisis.

The EU commissioner for development, Poul Nielson, yesterday said donors plan to ship 800,000 tonnes of food to Ethiopia, where the bulk of people are at risk.

"We are getting organised and we see this [famine] as a big threat coming," he said. "Everybody is following this situation with very great concern. If we now can plan in a reasonably professional way actually to move 800,000 tonnes, that's a good start.

"We have people from the European commission on site in the Horn of Africa today trying to assess the situation. It is indeed a major operation," he added.

The World Food Programme director, Catherine Bertini, is scheduled to fly to the region next week to assess the extent of the crisis.

The Ethiopian government says 8m of its people face starvation. Millions more in Eritrea, Kenya, Somalia, Uganda and Djibouti are at risk.

Among the hardest hit areas is the Ogaden region of eastern Ethiopia, where it has not rained in three years. Aid workers say dozens, if not hundreds, of children are dying each day from malnutrition and diseases such as measles and tuberculosis. Thousands of people have left their homes in search of water and food.

Earlier this week, the UN children's agency, Unicef, complained that there had not been any response to earlier appeals for urgent famine relief. But EU officials say that enough food aid for the region has been committed by Europe, the US and international aid agencies. Britain says £2.4m of UK food aid is already being distributed.

The problem now is to find efficient ways of delivering it. Continued fighting in Somalia makes distribution very difficult, as does the civil war in Sudan. The conflict between Ethiopia and Eritrea has closed the port of Massawa in Eritrea and left Djibouti as the only port in the region open to handle food distribution.It is not large enough to cope with the amounts needed.

"If we had peace and normal relations between Ethiopia and Eritrea, then the harbour of Massawa would also be available and the problem more manageable," Mr Nielson said.

As it is, a large proportion of food will probably have to be airdropped, considerably increasing costs.

Britain's international development secretary, Clare Short, said: "The failure of the last three years' rains is the root cause of Ethiopia's current crisis, but there is little doubt that the continuing conflict with Eritrea is hampering the response to the relief effort and valuable resources are being diverted to perpetuating the conflict."

She urged all sides to "intensify their efforts" to end the conflict "so that all efforts can be focused on providing relief and on the longer-term struggle against deep-seated poverty in Ethiopia".

But Oxfam yesterday blamed the looming crisis in part on the EU for delivering little more than half the food it promised last year. It said that food donations are still not coming fast enough.

"The world can't wait for that to happen. It must act now: get the food in and make serious preparations for healthcare and water provision," a spokesman for Oxfam said.

"Ethiopia estimates that 1.2m tonnes of food aid will be required this year; only 15,000 tonnes have arrived so far. There is a severe shortage of high-energy food needed by people, particularly children, who are already malnourished."

The UN's food and agriculture organisation has warned that the food crisis could spread south to central Africa's great lakes region where wars, large movements of refugees and erratic rains have created another food shortage.

Burundi in particular is facing a poor harvest because about 800,000 Hutu peasant farmers were herded into what the government calls "relocation camps" and others have denounced as concentration camps.

In the Democratic Republic of Congo, severe food shortages and malnutrition are reported among large numbers of refugees in the north and east of the country, which has been the focus of the civil war.

The World Food Programme is already committed to months of food deliveries to nearly 1m people hit by floods and cyclones in Mozambique and Madagascar.

fields.headline: Slaves to the mobile
fields.standfirst: So what if hands-free is no safer than holding the phone to your ear? Mobiles aren't just a risk to our health, says  Julie Burchill, who refuses to own one. They are also a threat to our personal freedom
fields.trailText: So what if hands-free is no safer than holding the phone to your ear? Mobiles aren't just a risk to our health, says  Julie Burchill, who refuses to own one. They are also a threat to our personal freedom.
fields.body:
This has been a great few weeks in which to be a technophobe; first all those dot.com fortunes going down the chute, then Bill Gates getting the benefit of a good, newly opened can of whup-ass from the US government. And now, apparently, the mobile phones which - sometimes it feels uniquely, in the media - I have never had any time for, have been revealed by Which? magazine to be death-traps, even when accompanied by hands-free kits and phone shields.

On the contrary, these attachments can channel three times the normal dose of radiation into your poor old brain. Such exposure causes the temperature to rise, making the heart work harder and leading to headaches, sickness and dizziness. Hang on in there and brain tumours, heart and kidney problems, multiple sclerosis and Alzheimer's could be yours. Said Which? editor, Graeme Jacobs: "If you are worried about radiation, you shouldn't rely on a hands-free set. And if you are thinking of buying a shield, don't waste your money." The phone industry, currently enjoying a boom beyond its wildest dreams 20 years ago, expressed "surprise" on Monday night and ask for more time to consider the results; adding, rather callously, that hands-free kits had been marketed as aids to convenience rather than protection from health hazards.

I've never understood why people want mobile phones; as with quiz shows and the internet, it seems that the less we actually understand, the more determined we are to trumpet it. Sometimes it seems that the only thing people are really scared of these days is the sound of silence, because only then, free of all distraction, might we begin to question exactly where are going - which, so far as I can see, is the Tower of Babel on an awayday family ticket, not transferable, no refunds. Only then, when we are all immersed in sound and fury, signifying nothing, will our politicians finally feel safe, their own hollow utterances finally indistinguishable from the rest of the clamour.

I thought it particularly appropriate last week when it was revealed that Tony "Decent Family Values" Blair has chosen to head his next election campaign the very same man who dreamed up the notorious fcuk campaign for French Connection - to the distress of many decent, decorous British people. But when all that matters is how loud you shout, not what you say, who cares if your chief cheerleader has a mouth like a sewer?

I'm lucky; I don't have a mobile phone for the same reason I'm not "online" - that is, that I like my life a great deal as it is, I am never lonely and am very keen on preserving both my privacy and the right to do what I want, when I want. I do not want to be at someone's beck and call 24 hours a day, be they employer or friend; it would be like being a child again, like not belonging fully to yourself. Get a mobile phone and your life's not your own any more; the habit of giving them to children makes even less sense, as the parent loses their freedom and the child loses the ability to fend for itself. My friend recently bought a mobile phone for her very bright 12-year-old son, and I can't recall the number of times I've hear her speak to him crossly for interrupting our lunches and shopping trips. He's never called her in trouble, usually it's to say that he's been at his friend's house, but now he's bored, so will she come and collect him? As I say, he's very clever; if the mobile phone call was not an option, he'd get on and make himself unbored. But mobile phones make chauffeurs and clients out of all of us.

Unless you're a doctor, a taxi driver or a mountaineer, you simply don't need a mobile phone. All you're doing is, in most cases, buoying up a fragile sense of self-esteem, and trying to feel indispensable. But frankly, we are none of us irreplaceable, and that's one of the great and cheerful things about life. Only someone with severe self-worth issues would find anything frightening about this. I have never had a Filofax, either, even when I was living la vida 80s; I was always very struck that the ultimate boy-about-town of the time, Robert Elms, made a point of not having one either, but wrote things down in a little dinky Letts diary. Robert always said that the bigger the Filofax, the more not quite the thing the person wielding it was; people with very little tangible in the way of real talent or ability, with only the house of cards that make up a full deck of "contacts" to boast about.

Some 24m Britons, including 300,000 children, now have mobiles. Imminent technological advances about to bring email, internet access, video screens and computer games to them have led analysts to believe that a full half of the population will be touting them around before the year is through, while British and multi-national companies are currently fighting a multi-billion bidding war over the next round of franchises.

Many scientists are now beginning to feel that the Government has once again sidelined health issues in a bid to shake every last piece of spare change out of the pockets of business. But frightening as these new claims are, there seems to be a perfect poetic justice in them; so many of the things which we have been told by New Labour "empower" us actually weaken and enslave us.

I'm not surprised Tony Blair wants every household to be on the internet; what better way to spread your black-hearted propaganda to the weak and vulnerable? What better way to turn workers into 24-hour consumers, buying goods they neither want nor need to fill up the yawning hole in their soul where socialism used to be? And now mobile phones will turn your brain to mush and rob you of your memory; all the better to become one of Mr Tony's castrated creatures. Once again, it looks like the medium really was the message.

Get a mobile phone and your life's not your own any more; the habit of giving them to children makes even less sense, as the parent loses their freedom and the child loses the ability to fend for itself. My friend recently bought a mobile phone for her very bright 12-year-old son, and I can't recall the number of times I've hear her speak to him crossly for interrupting our lunches and shopping trips. He's never called her in trouble, usually it's to say that he's been at his friend's house, but now he's bored, so will she come and collect him? As I say, he's very clever; if the mobile phone call was not an option, he'd get on and make himself unbored. But mobile phones make chauffeurs and clients out of all of us. Unless you're a doctor, a taxi driver or a mountaineer, you simply don't need a mobile phone. All you're doing is, in most cases, buoying up a fragile sense of self-esteem, and trying to feel indispensable. But frankly, we are none of us irreplaceable, and that's one of the great and cheerful things about life. Only someone with severe self-worth issues would find anything frightening about this. I have never had a Filofax, either, even when I was living la vida 80s; I was always very struck that the ultimate boy-about-town of the time, Robert Elms, made a point of not having one either, but wrote things down in a little dinky Letts diary. Robert always said that the bigger the Filofax, the more not quite the thing the person wielding it was; people with very little tangible in the way of real talent or ability, with only the house of cards that make up a full deck of "contacts" to boast about. Some 24m Britons, including 300,000 children, now have mobiles. Imminent technological advances about to bring email, internet access, video screens and computer games to them have led analysts to believe that a full half of the population will be touting them around before the year is through, while British and multi-national companies are currently fighting a multi-billion bidding war over the next round of franchises. Many scientists are now beginning to feel that the Government has once again sidelined health issues in a bid to shake every last piece of spare change out of the pockets of business. But frightening as these new claims are, there seems to be a perfect poetic justice in them; so many of the things which we have been told by New Labour "empower" us actually weaken and enslave us. I'm not surprised Tony Blair wants every household to be on the internet; what better way to spread your black-hearted propaganda to the weak and vulnerable? What better way to turn workers into 24-hour consumers, buying goods they neither want nor need to fill up the yawning hole in their soul where socialism used to be? And now mobile phones will turn your brain to mush and rob you of your memory; all the better to become one of Mr Tony's castrated creatures. Once again, it looks like the medium really was the message.

webTitle: Cyclone hurtles towards flood hit Mozambique

fields.headline: Cyclone hurtles towards flood hit Mozambique
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: A new cyclone is expected to hit flood-stricken Mozambique today after killing at least 14 people and driving 100,000 from their homes when it flattened a town in Madagascar two days ago.
fields.body:
A new cyclone is expected to hit flood-stricken Mozambique today after killing at least 14 people and driving 100,000 from their homes when it flattened a town in Madagascar two days ago.

Cyclone Hudah is expected to strike provinces north of the areas worst affected by two months of flooding in Mozambique - a disaster which has killed at least 700 people and forced hundreds of thousands of people from their homes.

But a spokeswoman for the World Food Programme, Aya Shneerson, said that more heavy rains anywhere in Mozambique were deeply worrying. "We're not expecting this cyclone to be as devastating as the previous one, but any other cyclone in this area has the potential to be catastrophic," she said.

"We're buying food from the north of the country to feed the south. If you have a situation where both the north and the south are hit then it could be another step in destabilising this country's ability to recover from the floods."

Cyclone Hudah, with winds gusting up to 200 mph, wrecked the coastal town of Antalaha in north-eastern Madagascar, which was caught in the eye of the storm.

"Cyclone Hudah has caused tremendous damage in Antalaha. We have all seen that the town is totally destroyed," said Horace Constant, a government minister.

Authorities fear that the scale of the destruction may prove far worse once rescuers are able to reach remote areas of the Indian Ocean island. Hudah is the third cyclone to hit Madagascar in the past two months.

The United Nations said that about 200 people were killed and 130,000 badly affected by the previous storm.

State radio in Mozambique has warned about 400,000 people living near the coast and in river valleys in Zambezia and Nampula provinces to move to higher ground.

Thomas Harrer, an adviser with Mozambique's national disaster management institute, said the most immediate risk was from flash floods of the kind which ripped through towns in the south and trapped tens of thousands of people in trees and on roofs.

"The highest risk will probably be as the cyclone moves inland towards the Zambezia escarpment. It will produce heavy rains and create flash floods in the Lucungo, Moniga and Mololiwe rivers.

"These rivers have a tendency for flash floods, with very fast water rising very rapidly," he said.

Aid agencies say they are preparing for the worst eventuality, but that it is almost impossible to predict the impact of the cyclone.

webTitle: Policeman shot dead as tension rises in Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Policeman shot dead as tension rises in Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Tensions have risen further in Zimbabwe with the news that a policeman was shot dead yesterday, apparently by squatters resisting arrest for beating a white farmer.
fields.body:
Tensions have risen further in Zimbabwe with the news that a policeman was shot dead yesterday, apparently by squatters resisting arrest for beating a white farmer.

Police were arresting several squatters for allegedly assaulting farmer Ian Kay when a fracas broke out and shots were fired. A police spokesman, Bothwell Mugariri, confirmed that a constable died, but gave no other details.

Mr Kay was severely assaulted on Monday by about 25 squatters on his farm near Marondera, 75 miles east of Harare. The squatters bound Mr Kay's wrists with wire, whipped him across the back and beat his head. He was hospitalised in Marondera and was expected to be released late yesterday.

The squatters are led by veterans of Zimbabwe's war against Rhodesian rule. Since February thousands of squatters have invaded 800 white-owned farms, claiming that they are taking back land that was stolen from their ancestors by Rhodesian colonialists. There is considerable evidence that President Robert Mu gabe's government organised the farm invasions. Mr Mugabe himself enthusiastically supports the squatters and has disobeyed a court order to have the illegal squatters evicted. It appears that Mr Mugabe is attempting to win the votes of rural blacks.

The uneasy standoff between the white farmers and squatters has become more heated as Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections approach. Support is growing throughout the country for the new opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC). In response Mr Mugabe and his Zanu-PF party have threatened the country with violence.

Mr Kay was reportedly attacked by the squatters because he supports the MDC and has held rallies on his farm. On other farms in Zimbabwe, squatters have become more aggressive, smashing into houses, seizing guns and threatening farmers and their workers.

Last week the head of the Commercial Farmers Union, which represents the white landowners, was warned by top government officials that farmers would meet with violence unless they stopped all support for the MDC. But many farmers have rejected the government pressure.

In the wake of the beating of Mr Kay, many white farmers warn that they must protect themselves, with arms if necessary. Violent incidents between the white farmers and the black squatters could quickly spill out of control.

Support for the MDC has grown, among blacks as well as whites, as people blame Mr Mugabe for economic mismanagement, corruption, fuel shortages, human rights abuses and the illegal farm invasions. Faced with rising support for the MDC, Mr Mugabe's government has responded with violence. Two MDC members have been killed in the past week in clashes with supporters of Zanu-PF.

Over the weekend a multiracial peace march by 4,000 opposition supporters in Harare was attacked by 150 supporters of Mr Mugabe. Armed with clubs, iron bars, bricks and rocks, the Zanu-PF supporters beat the peaceful marchers, injuring 15. One man was beaten unconscious and remains in intensive care.

The shooting yesterday of the police constable is expected to further inflame racial and political tensions. Mr Mugabe has not yet announced the date for the parliamentary elections, but on Monday he told the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, in Cairo that the polls would be held in mid-May.

Confronted by a rapidly declining economy, falling living standards and waning support, Mr Mugabe has pushed Zimbabwe towards political confrontation. Some analysts suggest that Mr Mugabe will use the chaos he is creating as an excuse to declare a state of emergency. He would then be able to assume sweeping powers and avoid holding elections.

fields.headline: It's home
fields.standfirst: A Zimbabwean explains why Mugabe will not succeed in driving whites out of their countryZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: A Zimbabwean explains why Mugabe will not succeed in driving whites out of their country.
fields.body:
As a white Zimbabwean, I watched the xenophobia and government-directed lawlessness in my home country with some despair. For the first time in nearly 40 years my relatives there voiced a fearful uncertainty about what tomorrow, next week and the period running up to the country's general election will hold. They know better than I that Robert Mugabe will hang on to power for as long as he possibly can, not least because he fears being brought to book for his systematic human rights abuses.

My elderly mother speaks carefully, circumspectly, (sometimes in her native Gaelic) on the telephone; the mail that I receive from Zimbabwe has invariably been tampered with. And yet, I know that neither my relatives, nor most white Zimbabweans of my acquaintance, have any doubt that their future remains in Africa.

For one thing, they represent the hardened rump, at 75,000, of a white population that stood at 300,000 when Ian Smith's gerontocracy still smirked at the possibility of black majority rule in the next thousand years. Those who loudest sang the chorus to "Rhodesians never die" have retired to other climes, Perth in western Australia, the Cape in South Africa, or even the outer reaches of the United Kingdom from Tunbridge Wells to the Monday Club. The whites still in Zimbabwe represent a group who have adjusted remarkably well from the rule of the rebarbative Rhodesia Front to the blessings of democracy under Zanu - Patriotic Front.

Some whites, of course, could not leave if they wanted to, simply because the ruination of the Zimbabwe dollar means they could not afford it. Some are too old to go. But many others stay because they regard Zimbabwe as their land and are tied to it by that whole fine web of memories and dreams and associations that give a country to a people. Not every white is a farmer. Whites serve on Aids charities, the Anglican cathedral's lay commission, human rights organisations and conservation groups.

Not every white owns a tennis court and a swimming pool. My parents, teachers from the idealistic days of the federation to the ominous days of Robert Mugabe's ascent to power, had neither. My father's ashes are scattered in a dry Matabeleland churchyard; my mother makes a daily visit there. My brother, a young conscript in Ian Smith's war, works for a company owned by a black businessman; his children learn SiNdebele at school, in preference to French, and they speak it well.

The farmers, particularly those in Matabeleland, have stayed tenaciously on the land, through both Smith's war and the vicious post independence "dissident" campaign that saw 61 of their number killed in a short period by guerrillas who were trained and armed in part by a white, Christian, South African government. Some farming families have lost fathers and sons, paying a biblical price for their farms and ranches. They are good farmers and, yes, their employment practises probably are feudal. They provide the only economic security their workers are likely to find in a cruelly impoverished country. There are precious few stellar social structures or relationships in Zimbabwe at present. And it is certainly the case that farmers are now investing considerably in money, in land and in expertise both to improve their workers' lot and in private land redistribution projects that answer the suicidal rapacity of the ruling party's land grab.

Which brings me to my best hope for the future of white Zimbabweans: Robert Mugabe. He has created the spectacle of stuffy whites marching and dancing, and being beaten by Zanu (PF) stalwarts, in the streets of Harare, shoulder to shoulder with black Zimbabweans. He has played the race card for all it is worth and has still been humiliated in a referendum defeat where his supporters, who ran the referendum, were ultimately unable to rig the result. He has created a determined national consensus against "white bashing" - and, indeed, the demonisation of Zimbabwe's tiny Asian community.

Whites are active as human rights campaigners and lawyers. They have helped to bring forensic experts from Argentina to Zimbabwe to identify the remains of their fellow citizens who were this government's first victims. Ironically, in the 80s, when the Fifth Brigade killed anywhere between 8,000 and 30,000 rural Ndebele people, and made a blood-chilling attempt to starve to death 400,000 more, Robert Mugabe was still being feted across the "civilised" world.

So it is likely, in the coming weeks and months before the election, that things in Zimbabwe will become pretty hellish. But the country has been to hell before, and emerged (a quarter of a million people were displaced in the civil war; over 30,000 died). If his party wins the election, Morgan Tsvangtral may prove to be capable enough to reverse the country's decline. He may be an unknown quantity, but as an Ndebele priest I know put it, "Sometimes, better the devil you don't know than the devil you do!"

I hope that there will be whites in Zimbabwe one hundred years from now. I pray that they will include my descendants - who will perhaps remember the epic sojourn of their ancestral spirit in exotic Walthamstow.

webTitle: 'I just feel they have let us down'

fields.headline: 'I just feel they have let us down'
fields.standfirst:
'Betrayed' village customers count the cost of losing their branch
Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Coral Temple is not, she readily admits, a political animal - but the news that Barclays is to close its branch in her Norfolk village has stirred the latent activist in her.
fields.body:
Coral Temple is not, she readily admits, a political animal - but the news that Barclays is to close its branch in her Norfolk village has stirred the latent activist in her.

First there was her "spur-of-the-moment" decision to join four other pensioners and their vicar in a sit-in three weeks ago at the tiny branch of the only remaining bank in Terrington St Clement. And yesterday it led her to back the call by environment minister Chris Mullin for customers to boycott the company.

For Mrs Temple, 79, a great-grandmother born in Terrington St Clement, such militancy seems incredible. But it is a pointer to the depth to which she, and many of her elderly neighbours in the sprawling fenland village, feel betrayed.

The farm manager's widow confesses: "I just feel they've let us down. I've lost my trust in them. We've been loyal to them but they haven't returned that loyalty.

"I'm not a big business person and I haven't got an enormous amount of money, but I thought they would care for all their customers. They're a big bank so surely they can care for the small person? But that doesn't seem to be the case."

For Mrs Temple, Barclays' decision to close her local branch, which at the moment opens three mornings a week, leaves her with three options: use the local Co-op's £50 cashback facility, take the 15-mile round trip by bus to King's Lynn, or rely on her daughter to fetch her money.

Mrs Temple is disabled with arthritis and the bank's move has taken away something she is desperate to cling to: her independence. "That's something that cuts hard as you get older," she said. "You lose your husband, you lose your car and now I can't even get my money out. I feel so betrayed that it upsets me more than makes me feel angry. But, if I think about it, then sometimes I just sit down and weep."

Her determination to change banks is shared by her neighbour, Valerie Collison, 64, a wheelchair user for whom the branch's closure will mean paying a carer an extra one-and-a-half-hour's wages to travel to King's Lynn.

For many of the 60-odd small businesses struggling to survive in the sprawling village of 3,750, however, switching allegiance to another bank is not a viable option.

"Even though the bank's closure will cause us huge problems, we wouldn't boycott it because I've got a very good relationship with the bank manager in King's Lynn," said Valerie Barton, 58, who has been a Barclays customer for the 30 years she has been running Hillgate Nurseries, her salad-growing company. That relationship means the bank carries her in the lean winter months while her produce is growing and before she receives her payments in the summer.

The branch's closure will lead to problems - she will have to make three trips to King's Lynn a week once the cheques appear in the summer - but she is not in a position to follow Mr Mullin's advice. "They know that I'm angry, but when you've a business you can't just change that easily."

It is a sentiment backed by the local Methodist minister, the Rev Dr Mike Bossingham - who describes the environment minister's call for a boycott as "just silly in a village where there is no alternative" - and by Bob Hornigold, 68, the retired newsagent who led the recent bank sit-in.

Pointing out that telephone banking is inadequate, not allowing for the retrieval or paying in of money, and that the closure will draw money away from the otherwise self-sufficient village, Mr Hornigold characterises Mr Mullin's call to arms as "just a load of bull".

"He's just not living in the real world, and he doesn't understand country life. He just doesn't realise the problems we have: the fact that we don't have 24-hour cashpoint machines out here, and that people don't want - and sometimes can't - make that 15-mile round trip.

"We're now going to have to leave the village to get our money - and we don't want to."

webTitle: The last bank in town takes the flak

fields.headline: The last bank in town takes the flak
fields.standfirst:
'The world needs a big bank' but not rural communities facing the closure of 172 Barclays branches
Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: 'The world needs a big bank' but not rural communities facing the closure of 172 Barclays branches
fields.body:
"The world needs a big bank", is the mantra from Barclays in a swish new advertising campaign led by film stars such as Sir Anthony Hopkins and Nick Moran.

In Britain, though, millions of Barclays customers might begin to believe that the message should be "small is beautiful", as the bank prepares to close 172 branches.

The move, which will leave many rural communities without a bank on the high street, continues the inexorable decline in the British financial sector. In the last 10 years more than 6,000 branches have disappeared as a result of takeovers, and amid pressure to reduce costs to please the banks' shareholders.

Yet Barclays has attracted more flak than its rivals - who have closed down many more branches. Its managers believe this is because it has become the "last bank in town". In some instances it might also be the last of the "great British institutions", as supermarkets and many other familiar high street names desert towns and villages for new, more cost-efficient "out of town" complexes.

"We have stayed longer than any one else," a Barclays spokesman said yesterday. Indeed, when Barclays unveiled the plans to close the branches and cut 6,000 jobs in a bid to reduce its costs, the City welcomed the move after criticising it for being slower than its rivals to take action.

Its rivals also believe that Barclays has done itself few favours. The cuts come during a turbulent period for the bank. Last year, it incensed the industry with moves to charge for withdrawals from cash machines over the Link network.

That episode followed an embarrassing search for a chief executive after a boardroom row that led to the resignation of the old Etonian, Martin Taylor. His initial replacement lasted just one day in the new job after it was discovered that he had a heart condition. Things got worse when the new chief executive, the Irish-Canadian, Matthew Barrett, was embroiled in controversies about a lucrative pay deal and over his estranged wife.

Barclays privately admits that these incidents have been damaging. A spokesman said: "The number of high-profile issues in which we are involved are inter-related and reflect rapidly changing forces in the industry brought about by the customer."

The bank argues that it has a real economic case for the branch closures, which are based on "changing customer demand". It cites a move by customers away from using branches for basic transactions and towards using the telephone, cash machines and the internet for basic banking needs. Last week alone 20,000 of its 13m customers registered for internet banking.

Tim Sweeney, director general of the British Bankers' Association, the industry's lobby group, has argued against nostalgia for a "golden age", when banks, along with churches and pubs were a "pillar of our national social life".

The banks believe that branch closures are a result of the changing nature of society in Britain driven by technological changes. The cruel realities of the financial world mean that the banks cannot afford to keep "unprofitable" branches open if they are to appease their shareholders, many of whom are ordinary men and women who invest indirectly in the shares by way of their pension schemes.

The banks argue that competition for customers means that people can now get access to their cash and financial services more easily than ever - through cash machines on filling station forecourts and "cashbacks" in supermarkets - and get advice by picking up the telephone or logging on to the internet at any time of the day or the night.

But this argument is unlikely to satisfy critics of Barclays, who insist that branch closures most hurt Britain's least well-off and elderly citizens, who may be more reluctant to pick-up the telephone or log on to the internet.

webTitle: Geo plans to spin off $1bn WebRadio

fields.headline: Geo plans to spin off $1bn WebRadio
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Israeli internet technology company Geo Interactive Media intends to spin off its Web-Radio arm, which some analysts believe could be worth more than $1bn (£625m).
fields.body:
Israeli internet technology company Geo Interactive Media intends to spin off its Web-Radio arm, which some analysts believe could be worth more than $1bn (£625m).

The news emerged as Geo revealed it had broken even in the second half, cutting its full-year loss by 57% to $7.47m. Co-founder Eli Reifman said: "We've moved from a concept and a dream to actual figures and dollars. People are actually buying and using our stuff."

Geo's WebRadio service allows internet surfers to tune into more than 200 radio stations from around the world. It uses the company's Emblaze technology, which allows clearer sound and video broadcasts over the net.

Mr Reifman said: "We started it as a demo last year but it's literally exploded. We've decided to spin it off and set it up as a subsidiary in the US."

Geo charges radio stations a monthly fee to be available on its site, WebRadio.com. Revenue also comes from advertisments. The site attracts more than 200m visitors a month, staying for an average of 51 minutes. Among the stations available is London's Kiss FM.

Earlier this year Geo struck a deal with WestWood One, one of America's largest providers of radio content, which could lead to access to 7,500 more stations.

Lehman Brothers said Web-Radio could be worth between $600m and $2.4bn, depending on how many stations sign up and which way hi-tech shares go over the coming months.

Mr Reifman said: "WebRadio is the best showcase for our technology on the face of the planet."

Geo has moved towards profitability since a strategic shift last year, when it gave up selling its internet software directly to the public. Instead, the company is signing deals to embed its technology in mobile phone and internet browsers.

Samsung, a large manufacturer of new-generation phone handsets, has already signed an agreement to use Geo's software. Trials of Geo's technology on One2One's mobile network have recently been expanded, it emerged yesterday.

Geo's shares fell 367p to £12.87, in line with other technology stocks.

webTitle: Current affairs short-circuit Vanity Fair's powerhouse list

fields.headline: Current affairs short-circuit Vanity Fair's powerhouse list
fields.standfirst:
Digital count: How the cybernauts fared
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The timing might have been better.
fields.body:
The timing might have been better.

In the week that saw one of the biggest slides in hi-tech share prices, Vanity Fair, the glossy magazine which prides itself on charting the rise of the rich and famous, is producing its list of the most powerful people in cyberspace.

This Friday the magazine proposes a "new, new establishment" alias the "eEstablishment", "the people spearheading the longest economic expansion in American history".

This famous 50 includes the obvious internet big names (Richard Belluzzo, Microsoft's group vice-president; John Chambers, head of the Cisco hardware group), as well as refugees from the "old" economy such as Stephen Riggio (head of the e-arm of traditional book chain Barnes & Noble).

Most, however, appear to share a feature that might suggest a law for success in the online economy: you have to be a bit of a card.

There is Scott Blum, founder of e-tailer Buy.Com, who "was kicked out of high school for driving the principal's golf cart into a pool". Bob Davis, head of web network Lycos, is "a practical joker who cleaned out colleagues' desks while they were absent". Halsey Minor, chairman of CNET, supplier of computer information and "a golf-playing khaki-clad young fogey".

Out-carding the lot is bookseller Amazon's financial chief, Joy Covey, who took a snowmobile to her outdoor wedding and, having left her dress shoes on a plane ahead of a meeting, "bought a pair from a woman waiting at baggage claim".

Her true significance, however, might lie elsewhere; she "was credited with selling Wall Street on ... [Amazon's] controversial plan of amassing huge losses while it races to build a huge business"

Wall Street fields Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's ace net analyst, Mary Meeker.

Miles Davis fan Jason Olim started CDNow when frustrated at his inability to track down an album by the jazz master; inevitably, in the world of the web, he started the company in his parents' basement.

Robert Young, head of software company Red Hat, is superstitious and says that he always wears red ... hats? No, socks.

fields.headline: Reality returns to the dot.coms
fields.standfirst:
Bubble bounces but does not burst

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: There is something poetic in the birth today of a company called the 451.com - a business-to-business internet resource for those interested in the way the convergence of technology adds up to a new industrial revolution.
fields.body:
There is something poetic in the birth today of a company called the 451.com - a business-to-business internet resource for those interested in the way the convergence of technology adds up to a new industrial revolution.

The name is derived from Ray Bradbury's 1953 classic, Fahrenheit 451, a peek forward into a world where books are burned by order of the special police. The company of the book, so to speak, is playing at a screen near you just as the markets have hit that temperature where paper wealth spontaneously combusts. Just before last night's close in New York, the Nasdaq composite index was showing a 27% fall from its high three weeks ago.

Our own, new-fangled Techmark 100 is down 35% across a shorter period, while in Paris and Frankfurt those hipper-than-thou indicators Le Nouveau Marché and the Neuer Markt have fallen by 40% and 32%, respectively.

It might have taken two or three weeks, but in raw (and old fashioned) stock market terms this is not a correction, it is a "crash." Huge amounts of wealth have been destroyed.

Yet yesterday's events were not being discussed in seismic terms. Instead, there were simple, matter of fact references to rockets and sticks and the inevitability that the super-thick layer of froth which had built up on a surprisingly small number of quoted companies over the past five months would be blown away at some stage.

Things had become just too silly, reality has begun to encroach once more, and lots and lots of individual speculators who have been playing the markets on borrowed money will be looking like chumps over the coming days.

Over the past five months, hundreds of thousands of ordinary Britons have been gripped by a child-like fascination with the stock market, kidding themselves they were somehow sophisticated "momentum investors", buying shares simply because they were going up. Now many will find that while it is easy to buy shares in small, illiquid companies when prices are rising, it is all but impossible to sell them when prices are falling.

So is the new economy yesterday's stuff? No. In fact, now is probably the time at least to consider laying a bet on the opposite being the case. The divergence in the real economy between those companies which apply technology to increase their productivity and those that just hope the so-called internet bubble has burst will continue to grow.

Cause to pause

On the face of it, the febrile state of the world's post-Microsoft stock markets makes life even more complicated for the Bank of England's monetary policy committee as it starts its two-day monthly meeting today. This was always going to be a tough call - perhaps the toughest decision the MPC has had in its brief life - and financial turmoil merely adds to the mass of conflicting signals.

The reality is, however, that the events of the past two days have made a rate rise in the UK slightly less probable and might just have tipped the balance in favour of no change this month. It is far too early, of course, to say that dot.com has turned into dot.bomb, but the Bank will probably want the dust to settle before it takes actions it might regret later. That would certainly be the wisest course of action.

All the signs of anxiety were there when Eddie George broke the customary pre-MPC purdah to speak to the annual meeting of the British Chambers of Commerce. Noting that the pressures on some manufacturers as a result of the strong pound were "excessive", the governor said that there was not an awful lot he and the other eight members of the MPC could do about it.

Mr George frankly admitted that were he a farmer, a steelmaker, a motor manufacturer or even a hotel owner he would be sorely tempted to be calling for lower interest rates, in the hope that the result would be a cheaper currency. However, Mr George is not an indust rialist and never has been. He is a career central banker who believes that cutting borrowing costs now would merely stoke inflationary pressure in the already over-strong domestic economy, leading to greater pain all round. House prices are rising at 15% a year, earnings growth is 5.9%, consumer demand is expanding by 4.5% a year. Mr George remembers where this all ended in 1988 and has no desire to sit through a repeat.

However, the combination of the four previous increases in interest rates and the strength of the pound means that monetary policy has already been tightened considerably since the autumn. At a time when Britain has the lowest inflation rate in Europe and BMW has just pulled the plug on Rover, the Bank may be looking for a reason to put off what would be a politically explosive decision for a month. The shenanigans on Wall Street last night suggest it need look no further.

webTitle: Nurses get £5,000 to spruce up wards

fields.headline: Nurses get £5,000 to spruce up wards
fields.standfirst:
£50m scheme aims to give sisters control of budgets

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Nursing sisters will today be promised £5,000 each to smarten up their hospital wards in the first concrete example of the government's determination to get new resources to the NHS frontline.
fields.body:
Nursing sisters will today be promised £5,000 each to smarten up their hospital wards in the first concrete example of the government's determination to get new resources to the NHS frontline.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will make the announcement to the annual congress of the Royal College of Nursing on the day of a national audit office report which lays bare the plight of the NHS before the budget announcement of an extra £2bn two weeks ago.

Mr Milburn will direct the first tranche of cash to dilapidated hospital wards. He will announce a £50m scheme, to start immediately, by which sisters or charge nurses who run wards will be able to take control of the budget for maintenance and repairs. In the first instance, each will get at least £5,000.

The minister will tell nurses that he wants to "liberate" their talents so that they can become leaders of change in the health service. He will tell them that "ward sisters are the linchpin of our hospital services, but for too long you have had responsibility without power".

Yesterday's report of the annual accounts of England's health authorities and trusts showed how dire the plight of the NHS was before Gordon Brown found substantial new money for the government's modernisation programme.

The report showed the health service sliding into debts of almost £200m for the financial year, from £18m in 1989-99. Half of the 100 health authorities in England and one in four trusts were in the red in 1988-89. One in five health authorities and one in eight NHS trusts were officially categorised as in severe financial difficulties.

The NHS confederation was optimistic about the possibilities of paying off the debts with the new money, even though Mr Milburn has made it clear much will be earmarked for specific purposes, such as cancer, heart disease and the needs of frontline troops.

Mr Milburn is by no means assured of an easy ride at the RCN conference in Bournemouth, but he is expected to fare better than William Hague, the Conservative leader, who yesterday sought to convince the nurses that his party had changed and was now firmly committed to the NHS.

He faced hostile questioning from nurses, and delegates later voted by 82% to declare no confidence in his assurances.

The health secretary yesterday announced that he planned to double the number of the new nurse consultants or "super nurses", the first 150 of whom took up post in England and Scotland this week. The nurses can earn up to £42,000 a year.
