webTitle: In the dark without a torch

fields.headline: In the dark without a torch
fields.standfirst:
Human rights investigator in Chechnya has no budget and the army will not answer him

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Vladimir Kalamanov has suddenly found himself occupying one of the least comfortable seats in the Kremlin.
fields.body:
Vladimir Kalamanov has suddenly found himself occupying one of the least comfortable seats in the Kremlin.

The lawyer, civil servant and former immigration official is Vladimir Putin's response to western criticism of atrocities perpetrated by Russian troops in Chechnya.

In a culture with scant experience of investigating or punishing human rights violations Mr Kalamanov, Russia's presidential representative for human rights in Chechnya, faces a daunting task.

"If I don't get the answers I'm looking for, I'll go to the supreme court and to the president," he asserts, determined to impress with his earnestness, honesty, and decency.

Mr Kalamanov - who will not say whether he believes the Russians have committed atrocities - insists he has a mandate to bulldoze through bureaucracy and demand answers. But the Russian military begs to differ. Asked for details of alleged war crimes, the military prosecutor's office sent Mr Kalamanov a perfunctory letter revealing nothing.

He tried again. He was told that 129 investigations had been launched. Most were about bullying and other offences within the army. Only seven concerned alleged offences against civilians in Chechnya.

"There are practically no cases for crimes against civilians. It's unsatisfactory. I just can't get the answers I'm looking for," Mr Kalamanov says.

He has asked the army for answers on three specific alleged massacres. No response.

Nor can he get the resources he needs. He was appointed on February 17, yet he still has no budget. The staff he has recruited have not been paid. Mr Kalamanov may have a large office in Moscow, but he has been unable to make contact with his people in Chechnya.

His section has one phone line and one fax in Chechnya. There's no phone link to Moscow, and no email. As we talk, word comes through that his bosses have just decided to allocate him a satellite phone.

"He faces so much obstruction and opposition. His operation is an empty shell," says a senior western diplomat. "He's decent enough and he's struggling against the system, but he's not in a position to do much."

Diederik Lohman of Human Rights Watch in Moscow says Mr Kalamanov sought to make a good impression with his organisation. "But he has a reflexive distrust of anything the displaced Chechens say. If that's your attitude before you start your investigation, you know there will be no results."

Mr Kalamanov brandishes lists of Chechen detainees obtained from the Russian military, and confidential letters from western missions or the UN. He has one detailed list of 646 Chechen detainees, an other of 49. Of those, he says, 500 have been released.

Such assertions are contested by Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, who say that thousands of Chechens have been detained by Russian troops.

In a culture with scant experience of investigating or punishing human rights violations Mr Kalamanov, Russia's presidential representative for human rights in Chechnya, faces a daunting task. "If I don't get the answers I'm looking for, I'll go to the supreme court and to the president," he asserts, determined to impress with his earnestness, honesty, and decency. Mr Kalamanov - who will not say whether he believes the Russians have committed atrocities - insists he has a mandate to bulldoze through bureaucracy and demand answers. But the Russian military begs to differ. Asked for details of alleged war crimes, the military prosecutor's office sent Mr Kalamanov a perfunctory letter revealing nothing. He tried again. He was told that 129 investigations had been launched. Most were about bullying and other offences within the army. Only seven concerned alleged offences against civilians in Chechnya. "There are practically no cases for crimes against civilians. It's unsatisfactory. I just can't get the answers I'm looking for," Mr Kalamanov says. He has asked the army for answers on three specific alleged massacres. No response. Nor can he get the resources he needs. He was appointed on February 17, yet he still has no budget. The staff he has recruited have not been paid. Mr Kalamanov may have a large office in Moscow, but he has been unable to make contact with his people in Chechnya. His section has one phone line and one fax in Chechnya. There's no phone link to Moscow, and no email. webTitle: Minister to speed applications of asylum seekers found begging

fields.headline: Minister to speed applications of asylum seekers found begging
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: New measures to speed the applications of asylum seekers caught begging were announced last night by the immigration minister, Barbara Roche.
fields.body:
New measures to speed the applications of asylum seekers caught begging were announced last night by the immigration minister, Barbara Roche.

The personal details of any foreign national arrested by the police for begging will be passed immediately to the Home Office's immigration and nationality directorate and if they are found to be asylum seekers their cases will be rapidly processed.

"It is my policy to ensure that all asylum seekers, including those convicted of begging, whose applications are unfounded, are removed from the United Kingdom as quickly as possible," she said. Although the Home Office would not put a timescale on it last night, in practice it means their cases are likely to be resolved within two to three months rather than the average wait of just over a year.

The decision to take new powers against asylum seekers found begging followed a case in which a coachload of claimants was sent back to London from Glasgow after they were allegedly caught asking for cash. Home Office ministers decided to press ahead with the crackdown even though the local authorities involved soon agreed it was a misunderstanding and the asylum seekers were sent back again to Glasgow.

The Refugee Council said last night that it wanted to see the government speed up the process for all asylum seekers. "We have repeatedly said that the answer to the current backlog of cases is for the Home Office to implement a faster as well as a fairer decision making system."

The announcement came as the police said fraud squad detectives had launched an investigation into allegations that illegal payments were received by landlords responsible for housing nearly 2,000 asylum seekers in Northamptonshire.

It is believed more than £425,000 of public money has been lost. New checks have been put into place by Northamptonshire county council to ensure asylum seekers are still at the address which the landlord claims.

fields.headline: Windows close for capitalism
fields.standfirst:
Judge Jackson proved the corporate beast can be tamed by the US statute books
Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Karl Marx always said capitalism contained the seeds of its own destruction - but perhaps it contains the seeds of its own salvation, too. Is that too optimistic a reading of Monday night's US court ruling against the computer behemoth Microsoft? Maybe. But it is a tempting one.
fields.body:
Karl Marx always said capitalism contained the seeds of its own destruction - but perhaps it contains the seeds of its own salvation, too. Is that too optimistic a reading of Monday night's US court ruling against the computer behemoth Microsoft? Maybe. But it is a tempting one.

For in the most capitalist nation in the world, a judge nominated by the most conservative president in living memory has plunged an arrow into the corporate beast. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, a free-marketeer appointed to the United States District Court by Ronald Reagan in the go-go 1980s, has achieved in an instant what leftwing activists have dreamed of for years. He has branded one of global capital's biggest players a corporate lawbreaker, a bully which abused its monopoly power to stifle creativity and innovation in an industry which relies on those qualities for its survival. He lambasted Microsoft for keeping "an oppressive thumb" on the computer software market, forcefeeding consumers Microsoft's operating system, Windows, and then its internet browser, Explorer. These were not the words of some crunchy, eco-warrior shaking his fist at the big boys of Seattle: this was the measured judgment of an American judge, administering American law.

It could not be more important - or more heartening. For what Judge Jackson has done is place a limit on corporate power. He has drawn a line and told mega-capitalism, "This far and no further." That counts as a blow not just against boardroom greed - but against the twin diseases of our globalised era, fatalism and passivity. By his ruling, the judge has reaffirmed the power of consumers and citizens. He has reminded us that, even in a world dominated by economics and market forces, politics - and the law - still matter.

It could not have come at a better time. Defeatism in the face of the market is rife just now, especially in Britain. We watch the 50,000 workers of the west Midlands facing redundancy thanks to BMW's sell-off of Rover, and we feel powerless. People want the government to do something, but few know what. Most of the current demands amount to requests to soften the blow.

We see Barclays close up to 4,000 bank branches, thereby stranding rural communities across Britain, and we feel just as impotent. Chris Mullin, a junior minister, gamely suggests a boycott. It's a good idea - but few of us are convinced it will make much difference. Whether it's Barclays or BMW, we feel the market has an iron logic and it would be quixotic, Scargillite madness to buck it.

Not now. Judge Jackson, with the help of the US statute book, has proved capitalism need not run wild: it can be tamed. He has not had to craft some new, interventionist ideal from the bench. Instead he has simply enforced America's anti-trust (or anti-monopoly) laws. These are the same rules which in 1911 took one look at John D Rockefeller's Standard Oil - which by then had gobbled up 90% of the American petroleum industry - and demanded the company break up. In 1984 it was AT&T's domination of the telephone market which fell on the wrong side of the anti-trust rules. "You're getting too big," said the law. "It's time to break up." If Judge Jackson's ruling is not overturned on appeal, he may well end up prescribing the same medicine to Bill Gates.

Is it just America that boasts this protection against excessive capitalism? Does it work like a vaccine, so that a nation where capitalism coarses through the collective bloodstream is somehow uniquely protected against its ill effects? Not necessarily. The European Union cannot claim the scalps won by America's anti-trust laws, but Articles 85 and 86 of the Treaty of Rome are darts that can be fired at corporate bullies who try to choke competition. In 1997 Brussels struck out at Boeing whose $14bn merger with McDonnell Douglas would have handed them a virtual monopoly in the world market for aircraft. The merger went ahead, but only after Europe had attached some useful strings. The continent's arsenal may not be as mighty as America's antitrust law, but it does exist.

Britain's own defence against the big boys is a work in progress. For years Britain seemed like a place where mega-business could do what it liked: witness the green light repeatedly shown to Rupert Murdoch as he gobbled up more and more of our national media. Now there is an effort to tighten the rules. Starting last month, the Office of Fair Trading has been given tougher powers to root out the Microsofts of British industry. It can now demand documents, launch dawn raids on recalcitrant firms and even slap instant fines on companies deemed to be playing with loaded dice.

We are still some way from Judge Jackson, but Labour might be heading in that direction. Last year Yvette Cooper, the impeccably modernising junior minister, published an essay on competition, wondering whether the government would "pass the Microsoft test". Would it be willing, she mused, to take on a flagship national company if such a firm were getting too big for its boots? Gordon Brown's chums say he's already passed that test: threatening last month to eat in to BT's monopoly on local calls. Monday's ruling might help him stand firm.

The logic of all this is not anti-capitalism. On the contrary, America invented this vaccine to protect enterprise, not to kill it. The authors of the antitrust laws understood that a truly free market requires competition; without it monopolies expand, before growing slow and flabby. The true capitalist is on the side of the new, cheeky Davids buzzing around the ankles of the corporate Goliaths. That, as Judge Jackson understood, is why the friend of business has occasionally to take an axe to this or that company. To promote the US software industry, Microsoft may have to tear itself apart. Eventually BT might have to shrink - not to satisfy old Labour spite, but to keep Britain a dynamic, competitive place for capitalism.

This is not exactly socialism, but for those anxious to tame the corporations who increasingly shape our world it may be the next best thing. It certainly beats giving up. The global campaign against Monsanto and its genetically-modified food had already showed that consumer action can work: in December the company bowed to pressure, spun off the GM wing of its business and quietly folded itself into another drugs firm. Now Judge Jackson has proved that the law can make a difference, too. And lest we give up on electoral politics we ought to note this: Republican George W Bush has hinted that, if he becomes president in November, he will do his best to halt the war on Microsoft. Al Gore takes the opposite view. The vice president may not want the endorsement - but you can guess who old man Marx would vote for.

webTitle: Mester William's man sends the house to sleep

fields.headline: Mester William's man sends the house to sleep
fields.standfirst: Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: What is the point of Archie Norman? One of my colleagues believes that William Hague appointed him environment spokesman to make John Prescott look good by comparison, and so help to preserve one of the Tories' best election assets.
fields.body:
What is the point of Archie Norman? One of my colleagues believes that William Hague appointed him environment spokesman to make John Prescott look good by comparison, and so help to preserve one of the Tories' best election assets.

My belief is that Mr Hague is a "sleeper", a closet Labour supporter who was recruited in his fiery, leftwing Rotherham youth to infiltrate the Tory party - and has been wildly successful.

So you can imagine him saying to his advisers: "Look, manufacturing is in a bad way, Byers is bound to be in big trouble soon. Let's put up a really heavy hitter. How about... Angela Browning!"

The advisers groan inwardly, but there is nothing they can say. Mr Hague adds: "John Prescott, old Two Jags, bit of a national joke by now. I know who'll cut him down to size: Archie Norman."

The advisers covertly roll their eyes. In Rotherham an old, wheezy man takes out the shortwave radio from his pigeon loft and taps out a message to a secret receiver in Tory central office: "Tha' done greet, lad. Kep it oop."

Yesterday Mr Prescott outlined to the Commons the housing plans in his green paper. Or rather, outlined the housing aspirations. Things, he announced, were to be "taken in action". He had "a wider ambition" to support sustainable communities. He promised "consultation" and to "seek responses".

There was a consensus that the rent system was in a mess, and he wanted to "build a new consensus" on that consensus.

And what would he do about all this? Well, the government was to "examine a range of options" and "invite proposals" for fresh "initiatives". He proposed a "stronger, more forward-looking, strategic role" for local authorities (strategic translates as "taking a long time"). "We aim for a step change," he added (step change is modern jargon for "taking even longer").

The green paper has a beguiling entry on page 34, announcing the establishment of the "cowboy builders working group". One imagines the members of this quango putting their paint-spattered radios on the table, saying, "sorry we're late, 'ad another report to finish in Purley. Now, 'oo did that last report for you? Blimey, wot a botch job."

Mr Prescott burbled to a finish, babbling about "hotlines", "best value inspections" and "pathfinder projects". It was Mr Norman's turn.

It's not his fault that he has a voice like a dying wasp, but that is no excuse. On and on he droned, his voice rising, falling, sometimes making that awful whirring noise which means the fly-killer has kicked in.

After 30 seconds he was talking about rail safety (why?), then about leaks to the press, then on to air traffic control. ("What about housing?" asked Mr Prescott, a huge grin on his huge face.)

Next Mr Norman was on to the Prescott retirement flat in Clapham, which might be a tenable political point, but not when delivered in a drone so somnolent that Tory backbenchers could be seen desperately trying to keep their eyes open.

"Now, eighteenthly..." you expected him to say. He wagged a finger at us. Mr Prescott looked happier than ever.

"In conclusion..." Mr Norman said. Labour MPs cheered wildly. Mr Norman looked furious, or at least mildly peeved. "I repeat, in conclusion!"

"Yet another impressive perfomance," Mr Prescott said, though, having watched Mr Norman dig a man-trap and fall in it himself, proceeded to follow him inside.

"I can think of a whole paucity of things to say," he began. But it didn't matter. He was safe. From Rotherham, the secret message crackled south to Mester William: "Slap tha'self on t'back, lad, tha's done a reet gradely job!"

fields.headline: United grief
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel (Mugabe regime faces meltdown, March 30) should know that Robert Mugabe founded Zanu and was not imprisoned by the British: he was jailed in 1964 under legislation passed by the Rhodesian Front.
fields.body:
Matthew Engel (Mugabe regime faces meltdown, March 30) should know that Robert Mugabe founded Zanu and was not imprisoned by the British: he was jailed in 1964 under legislation passed by the Rhodesian Front.

Until Ian Smith declared UDI in 1965, successive British governments had the power to veto any Rhodesian law. Home, Wilson, Heath, Callaghan, Thatcher - all chose to ignore the plight of nationalists detained under Smith's laws. Robin Cook is not the only British politician with his fingerprints on this tragedy.

Depicting this crisis as a black versus white; a Smith versus Mugabe choice, is precisely what the incumbent despot needs to justify violence and sustain his power. Yet this conflict pitches evil against Zimbabweans of all colours.
Patrick McKenna
Bromley, Kent
xhv05@dial.pipex.com

fields.headline: Lost in the translation
fields.trailText: Yet again, translators are fingered in mis-communication stories (Error led to bombing of Monte Cassino, April 4) when the error in fact arose from wireless and intelligence officers without translation training.
fields.body:
Yet again, translators are fingered in mis-communication stories (Error led to bombing of Monte Cassino, April 4) when the error in fact arose from wireless and intelligence officers without translation training.

The key point is that all language contains built-in "redundancy" - we hear only a proportion of any verbal information that reaches us, but under good acoustic and comprehension conditions, that is enough to convey the message.

In the broadcast in question, that redundancy (in particular, the definite articles that would have alerted the officer to his misunderstanding since "Abt" and "Abteilung" are of different genders) had been stripped out and the broadcast itself may not have been of good acoustic quality.

As your article points out, too, the context of the reference to the monastery was missing - a vital clue. A trained linguist would have recognised the dangers of jumping to conclusions from such sparse information.
Janet Fraser
Senior lecturer in translation University of Westminster
J.Fraser@westminster.ac.uk

 If the actual German message received by the allied radio operator contained as many grammatical errors as the German in your article, I'm not surprised confusion ensued.
Dr Don Mowbray
London
don_mowbray@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Skills in short supply
fields.trailText: Hooray to Madeleine Bunting (An eternal struggle, April 3) for encouraging a redressing of the balance between education and training and between work and leisure.
fields.body:
Hooray to Madeleine Bunting (An eternal struggle, April 3) for encouraging a redressing of the balance between education and training and between work and leisure.

But surely the situation is more serious than she suggests. The instrumental approach which concerns her is shortsighted, not only in undervaluing the private in favour of the public, but underestimating the dangers to society as a whole and to economic success.

The dichotomy is not that clearcut. Whilst basic skills of numeracy and literacy are crucial, an educational experience which deprives our youngsters of opportunities to develop their creative and critical skills will not only sell them short but disable employers across the spectrum, who increasingly will be dependent on people who can learn and think in the fast-moving world of the "information revolution".

This is not just a matter for the academically inclined. The need for all to be able to learn new skills and work in new cultures is already obvious.

The "lifelong learning" agenda will be doomed if the early years are dominated by a procrustean approach informed only by a narrow minded and ill-informed view of current urgent and specific skills shortages.
Prof Norman Gowar
London

fields.headline: Pensions that lag behind
fields.trailText: Millions of pensioners will take comfort from the decision by 41 Labour MPs to call for a restoration of the link between pensions and average earnings (Labour MPs stage big pensions revolt, April 4 ).
fields.body:
Millions of pensioners will take comfort from the decision by 41 Labour MPs to call for a restoration of the link between pensions and average earnings (Labour MPs stage big pensions revolt, April 4 ).

On April 10 the basic state pension for a single person will rise by a pitiful 75p a week - all because the link with earnings was broken in 1980. Such small increases, expressed as a percentage of the retail price index, are completely inadequate when faced with rises in council tax, heating bills and other services.

The basic problem is that if you apply a low percentage increase (which in this case is 1.1%) to a low base - you get a small increase. One percent of nothing is after all, still nothing.

The means-tested Minimum Income Guarantee -with its low take-up rate - is no substitute for a decent universal state pension, paid back to those who have paid NI contributions all their lives.
Jack Jones President, National Pensioners Convention
nduncanjordan@natpencon. org.uk

 What an odd argument the minister for pensions, Jeff Rooker, puts forward in defence of the decoupling of state pension from average earnings: that people for the last 17 years had voted against restoring the link!

I dare say that when "people" on modest incomes discover just how their years of occupational/private/stakeholder savings earn them just enough to be a few quid above any rights to a whole raft of state benefits, they will say contentedly: "This we voted to be so."
Graham Murphy
Liverpool

fields.headline: Dodging the column
fields.trailText:
I like Lord Hattersley. I enjoy his columns and those books I have read. I like Lord Hattersley's dog. I like Lord Hattersley's views. Well, many of them. I wish that Lord Hattersley would come to the House of Lords and express his views alongside those of us who share them. Lord Hattersley would be a valuable ally. It isn't as much fun as writing for the Guardian but Roy has accepted the title and there's a job to be done inside the tent.
Lord Bragg
House of Lords

 So, Roy Hattersley joins a cosy club noted for its "arrogant detachment from reality" (Endpiece, April 3), and when its members make "ridiculous" and "absurd" attacks on a basic human right he says nothing because he doesn't want to be... impolite. Old radicals never die, they just become impeccably mannered members of self-perpetuating oligarchies.
Richard Dunstan
London
nosleep@rdunstan.fsnet.co.uk

 It's not surprising that Julian Borger (Who is Florida Woman?, April 3) couldn't find any recidivist Tory voters in Florida; he should have been looking in Belize.
Don Keller
London

 Mouth aperture (Letters, April 4) clearly correlates with political ambition, as your London mayor mug-shots illustrate (Race for London mayor, April 4). Darren's lips gape to reveal his uvula, Steve puckers his into a rosebud, Susan's are demurely parted, Frank's grimly pursed, while Ken's are set in what can only be described as a smirk of certain victory.
Ian Short
London
i.short@bbk.ac.uk

 No doubt (Microsoft faces break-up, April 4) it will all be put right in version 2.0 of the verdict.
Tony Young
Glossop, Derbyshire

webTitle: Misgotten @ Microsoft: the court must adopt the tough option

fields.headline: Misgotten @ Microsoft: the court must adopt the tough option
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The easy bit has been done. The US district court judge, Thomas Jackson, has ruled that Microsoft abused its 90% hold on personal computer operating systems in violation of anti-trust laws. The difficulty now is deciding what to do about it.
fields.body:
The easy bit has been done. The US district court judge, Thomas Jackson, has ruled that Microsoft abused its 90% hold on personal computer operating systems in violation of anti-trust laws. The difficulty now is deciding what to do about it. Judge Jackson must have hoped that Microsoft would accept the compromise solutions offered by the independent mediator appointed to help bring about a settlement; but the Seattle colossus would have none of it. Microsoft became macro hard and decided that corporate advantage lay with hoping that the more conservative appeal judges would be lenient or that the appeal might linger on into a more congenial political atmosphere if George W Bush won the presidency. And all the time Microsoft would retain the fruits of monopoly control in the shape of its juicy 41% net return on sales, a rate of profitability that most e-commerce companies, caught up in the deflationary pressures of the internet, can only dream about.

What should be done? Some libertarian economists ask: why worry? Technological monopolies have short lives; upstart companies always undermine them (as Microsoft did with IBM). Even the revered guru Peter Drucker points out that no non-governmental monopoly in history has lasted longer than 15 years. But this ignores two points. First, why should companies be allowed to enjoy monopoly profits - ie money that should have gone to the consumer - even for 15 years? Second, companies like Microsoft, having done it themselves, are learning from the mistakes of the past. Nearly five years ago Microsoft saw a start-up called Netscape in its rear view mirror, which quickly captured an 80% share of the market for internet "browsers". It responded by bundling its own (bought-in) browser with its operating system - the main point at issue in this case - and all but snuffed Netscape out. Microsoft now has nearly 80% of the browser market.

Judge Jackson has the difficult choice of either deconstructing Microsoft into smaller competing units or insisting on good behaviour. He should go for the tougher structural solution. Microsoft can't be relied on to change its ways. It deeply believes that it has done nothing wrong (monopolists are notoriously myopic) and has such a fierce business culture that to ask it to change would be like appealing to a tiger to behave like a pussy cat. The key is to try to preserve the one positive thing that has come out of the monopoly situation - a common world standard for computers - while shedding the bad effects of stifling competition and innovation. There is no intrinsic reason why a browser or a spreadsheet has to be bundled in with an operating system. Who would dare launch a new browser now to compete with the one Microsoft gives away "free" with its operating system (on which it earns monopoly profits)? Operating systems should be constructed to take all sorts of competing software, and if they can't then they should be regulated like a utility. Microsoft often boasts of its innovation but most of its strengths (including its Excel spreadsheet and the operating system itself) originated outside the company. If Microsoft were broken up into competing units it would not only be good for consumers and Microsoft - whose huge reservoir of skilled people could be unleashed on other activities - but also for the computer industry, whose creative energies have been held back by the long shadow of Microsoft's dominance. When AT&T's telephone monopoly was broken in the 1980s, it led to the highly successful "Baby Bells". History can be repeated.

fields.headline: Bank that won't listen
fields.trailText: You quote Chris Mullin's description of Barclays as "hard-hearted" (Minister calls for boycott of bank, April 4). In the case of our local branch it goes further than this. The Barclays bank in our small market town, which serves a thriving community of small traders, met and exceeded all the targets set for it by headquarters. The reward for this is closure.
fields.body:
You quote Chris Mullin's description of Barclays as "hard-hearted" (Minister calls for boycott of bank, April 4). In the case of our local branch it goes further than this. The Barclays bank in our small market town, which serves a thriving community of small traders, met and exceeded all the targets set for it by headquarters. The reward for this is closure.

Adding insult to injury, Barclays have inserted a covenant into the lease on the building - the only one locally with vaults - which prevents its use for banking purposes by anyone else. For all the guff about the development of online banking, the real losers here will be the poor, the elderly and the isolated. I suppose one shouldn't be surprised that a bank which is prepared to pay obscene sums to its chief executive is incapable of understanding the needs of such people.
Prof Chris Husbands
Reepham, Norfolk
husbands@reepham37. freeserve.co.uk

 Barclays accuse Chris Mullin of "hysteria" over his mild suggestion that customers should vote with their feet. The best method of defence is attack, but do they ever listen to themselves?
Ray Roberts
London
roberts.ray@talk21.com

 Big changes ahead. When the big boys sit down on their big backsides in their big boardroom and look at the big protest about the big closures they have planned, perhaps it will lead to the dawning of a big new idea: that there are some people who live in rural communities who want to see a big change of heart.
Geoff Clifford
Oxford
geoffc@clara.net

fields.headline: Global lessons for Tony
fields.trailText: We welcome the fact that Tony Blair's passion for education goes beyond our national borders (We must not let our children down, April 4). But his contribution leaves unanswered an important question: will he provide the political leadership needed to translate good principles into action?
fields.body:
We welcome the fact that Tony Blair's passion for education goes beyond our national borders (We must not let our children down, April 4). But his contribution leaves unanswered an important question: will he provide the political leadership needed to translate good principles into action?

Later this month, at the World Education Forum in Dakar, Senegal, the world's governments have a real opportunity to tackle the crisis in global education. As the prime minister says, this crisis is at the heart of global poverty and inequality. Unfortunately, the opportunity provided by the Dakar conference is under threat, thanks to inept leadership. The draft plan of action now under consideration is little more than a shopping list of vague principles devoid of anything meriting the term "action". It contains no new commitments on mobilising the financial resources needed to achieve universal primary education by the target date of 2015.

Tony Blair should provide the political leadership needed to drag the Dakar conference out of the mire into which the UN and northern governments are leading it.

At present no G8 leaders are attending the event. If he were to participate and throw his weight behind calls for a decisive plan of action, it could transform Dakar from a talking shop into a springboard for action.
Kevin Watkins
Senior policy advisor, Oxfam

 Tony Blair says that education is our strongest weapon against global poverty. Your front page (Scandal of the food Britain throws away, April 4) shows how the big supermarkets are throwing away more food than poor countries can produce.

If further large-scale supermarket developments were stopped and people had more access to local shops, if vouchers were stopped and people had more income to buy healthy food, if worldwide weapons industries were stopped and poor countries had more control of their own economies ... If education started nearer to home?
John Nicholson
Chief executive, UK Public Health Association
john@ukpha.org.uk

 Tony Blair's defence of his "policies" regarding making education available to 130m children around the world fails to convince.

He says developing countries "need to give increased priority to primary and basic education". Many countries do give it a high priority but thanks to "aid" programmes and the "development" banks, they have been obliged to spend money on debt repayment, arms, dams, etc, rather than on education. Britain profits hugely from the various "aid" packages that take money away from education. Local leadership in many countries have been arguing for education spending but have been obliged to turn away, to service their debts.
Amal Chatterjee
University of Glasgow
akc@arts.gla.ac.uk

 Your section on the right to education gives a vivid picture of the acute problems around the world and some encouraging examples of what is being done about it. The footnote on "What you can do to help" is a letdown.

The whole emphasis is on applying pressure to Tony Blair and raising money. Surely the starting point must be the people of the countries concerned finding their own solutions. There is a valuable role for charities and government but they should support such people, not tell them what to do. Would that not be colonialism reborn?
George Wolfe
Calver, Derbyshire
GeoWolfe@aol.com

webTitle: Strengthen thine enemy - the bizarre logic of arms deals

fields.headline: Strengthen thine enemy - the bizarre logic of arms deals
fields.trailText: Consider the following vicious circle: the US sells advanced military technology (ie weapons) to its ally, Israel, subsidised by an annual $2bn grant; Israel, exploiting the post-Tiananmen US arms embargo, makes and sells to China weapons suspiciously like those it receives from America; China then uses those weapons to threaten Taiwan, which is armed and protected by... yes, you guessed it, the US.
fields.body:
Consider the following vicious circle: the US sells advanced military technology (ie weapons) to its ally, Israel, subsidised by an annual $2bn grant; Israel, exploiting the post-Tiananmen US arms embargo, makes and sells to China weapons suspiciously like those it receives from America; China then uses those weapons to threaten Taiwan, which is armed and protected by... yes, you guessed it, the US.

It gets worse. China, with which Israel does billions in arms business, has built a long-range nuclear missile, fetchingly dubbed East Wind, which it boasts can hit the US mainland. It has supplied missile technology to Pakistan, Iran, Libya, perhaps in the past to North Korea. Not counting China itself, these are the very "rogue states" which the US now feels it can only deter with a globally destabilising "star wars" missile shield. And some, like Iran, Libya, and Syria (to which the Chinese sold M-9 missiles) remain pledged to destroy Israel. Are the principals behind these menacing transactions aware of such contradictions? Well, William Cohen, the US defence secretary, is definitely a bit uneasy. This week he warned Ehud Barak, Israel's prime (and defence) minister, that Israel's latest sale to Beijing, $250m-worth of Awacs-like airborne radar, could alter the "regional strategic balance". What he meant, perhaps, is that the guided-missile destroyers the US may soon sell to Taiwan, and the US Pacific fleet, may as a result become more vulnerable to Chinese attack.

Israel has heard many similar US complaints before, during the more than 20 years it has been clandestinely selling arms to China. It routinely and selfishly ignores them. They will not stop Mr Barak rolling out the red carpet for Jiang Zemin who tomorrow becomes the first Chinese head of state to visit Israel. Israel says it needs the money the China trade brings in. This is short-sighted. China's military is no friend of Israel's friends. And one day, Israel may find itself on the receiving end of all these loose cannon.

webTitle: Nato troops clash with irate Serbs

fields.headline: Nato troops clash with irate Serbs
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Crowds angry at the arrest of a Serb for illegal weapons possession yesterday clashed with Nato peacekeepers, injuring 11 Americans and one Pole, the US military said.
fields.body:
Crowds angry at the arrest of a Serb for illegal weapons possession yesterday clashed with Nato peacekeepers, injuring 11 Americans and one Pole, the US military said.

The independent Yugoslav news agency, Beta, said 14 Serbs were also hurt, including 10 who were struck by rubber bullets. A Nato spokesman, Lieutenant Commander Philip Anido, said yesterday: "The situation is still ongoing," but refused to elaborate.

According to the US statement, the trouble started when American military police and Polish soldiers seized two hand grenades in the house of a Serb in the village of Sevce, about 40 miles south of Pristina, near the Macedonian border.

About 150 Serbs surrounded the house and refused to allow the troops to leave. Polish soldiers then set up a roadblock in the village of Jazince, 1 mile away, to prevent about 300 angry Serbs reaching the scene.

In Belgrade, Beta said several thousand Serbs from four villages in southern Kosovo set up the barricades after peacekeepers detained a Serb man in Sevce and took him to the main US base in Kosovo.

According to the report, Serbs from the villages of Gotovusa, Jazince, Sevce and Strpce massed near the Polish position, demanding that the man be released. US troops later brought him back to the barricade in an attempt to ease the tension, saying he would be released in 48 hours under normal procedure.

US troops later brought him back to the barricade in an attempt to ease the tension, saying he would be released in 48 hours under normal procedure.

fields.headline: Prodi rejects 'regicide' claims
fields.standfirst:
Kinnock and Patten deny plotting to oust EC president

The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, last night angrily dismissed suggestions that he was under pressure to resign after claims that he performed badly during his first six months in office.
fields.body:
Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, last night angrily dismissed suggestions that he was under pressure to resign after claims that he performed badly during his first six months in office.

Speaking during the EU-Africa summit in Cairo, the former Italian prime minister insisted there was no truth to a German newspaper report that British colleagues were trying to oust him.

"Are you stupid?" was his response to questions about the story - published in the normally respected Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung - which claimed there were signs of "regicide", with commissioners Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten aspiring to replace Mr Prodi.

Commission officials in Brussels went into overdrive to rubbish the report, which appeared to have touched a nerve.

Speaking to several hundred journalists, Jonathan Faull, the chief spokesman for the commission, said: "There is absolutely no truth whatsoever in the suggestion that commissioners are planning in some way to replace Romano Prodi.

"This commission is working and is working well. Romano Prodi is chairing and coordinating its activities effectively as well."

Referring to Mr Patten and Mr Kinnock, he added: "Both commissioners deny it and I have no idea where such an absurd story could have come from." Neither commissioner was available for comment yesterday.

But it was a lesson in poor news management, drawing attention to claims which have not even gained wide currency on the Brussels rumour mill.

In Berlin, a foreign ministry spokesman said the German government had full confidence in Mr Prodi, though recent press reports have reflected dismay that he seems closer to Tony Blair than to any other EU leader.

Mr Blair took much of the credit for setting the agenda at last month's Lisbon "dot.com" economic summit, where the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, and the French president, Jacques Chirac, were far less prominent than usual.

The Prodi story was cited by foreign exchange dealers yesterday as being one factor in a renewed bout of weakness in the euro after the currency made slight gains on Monday.

Mr Prodi's aides admit that his presentational skills are poor. He came under fire in January for his invitation to the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, whom he finally met in Cairo on Monday.

He has also been criticised over plans for aid to the Balkans, his preference for a longer timetable for the European Union's eastward expansion, and occasional bouts of tactlessness that undermine governments worried about Eurosceptic public opinion.

British officials, for example, wince when he uses phrases such as a "European army" or "European government".

"In the face of Mr Prodi's weak leadership, an open power struggle within the commission is now considered imminent," the Frankfurter Allgemeine said.

The paper also said that Mr Kinnock, commission vice-president charged with reform, was guilty of engineering appointments of top EU officials, favouring British nationals. But Mr Faull said the top positions were occupied by 11 Germans, eight Britons, seven Italians and seven French nationals.

Mr Prodi took over last September. His team succeeded a commission headed by Jacques Santer which quit in March 1999, amid allegations of cronyism and financial mismanagement.

fields.headline: Watchdog urged for care homes
fields.trailText: Elderly people get such a raw deal when it comes to care homes that the government needs urgently to appoint a watchdog, a voluntary organisation said yesterday.
fields.body:
Elderly people get such a raw deal when it comes to care homes that the government needs urgently to appoint a watchdog, a voluntary organisation said yesterday.

Counsel and Care, which offers support to older people and campaigns on their behalf, said in a report that in some homes the interests of residents "came a very poor second to economic necessity and market management".

While 20 years ago two-thirds of care places were run by the public sector, now 90% were in private hands. "Treating care homes as a financial investment means residents may be seen as a drain on resources."

Its research showed that lo cal authority funding was often provided only after a long struggle. Elderly people were squeezed between rising care home prices and attempts by authorities to avoid paying.

Counsel and Care wants a regulator to ensure that elderly people are treated "more like consumers and less like assets".

The report said big companies such as Alchemy, which is taking over Rover, have moved into the care industry.

Alchemy was involved in taking over three homes from Wandsworth council, London, it said. When it was decided to close one home, the council threatened legal action.

Hamilton Anstead, chief executive of Alchemy-backed Four Seasons Health Care, said he decided to close the home because "the standard of care was not satisfactory".

He blamed the council for not investing properly and passing on a home that was in "a mess". It was losing money and would still be closed as soon as possible, with residents being relocated somewhere better.

fields.headline: Barnardo's drug baby ad justified
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Barnardo's, the children's charity, was justified in using the "stark image" of a baby injecting heroin to drive home its role as a safe haven, the Advertising Standards Authority said yesterday.
fields.body:
Barnardo's, the children's charity, was justified in using the "stark image" of a baby injecting heroin to drive home its role as a safe haven, the Advertising Standards Authority said yesterday.

Rejecting 28 complaints attacking the newspaper campaign as shocking and offensive, the ASA said it was obvious that Barnardo's had tried to convey a "serious and important message".

When the advert appeared in January, the Committee of Advertising Practice, the industry body which writes the code administered by the ASA, asked publications not to use it. Barnardo's marketing director, Andre Nebel, called this response "ill-considered and over-hasty".

"We are a charity trying to raise awareness of our work aimed at creating better futures for children and young people threatened by disadvantage, abuse and neglect. This message is clearly reflected in our advertising."

Most newspapers, including the Guardian, ran the advert, but in the face of protest Barnardo's replaced the image with one of a happier baby. The original showed a baby holding a syringe and gripping with his teeth a cord that was wrapped around his arm.

The text read: "John Donaldson. Age 23. Battered as a child, it was always possible that John would turn to drugs. With Barnardo's help, child abuse need not lead to an empty future."

The ASA said: "Because the advertisers used the image to raise awareness of the seriousness of drug abuse and the action that could be taken to prevent it, the advertisement was unlikely to cause serious or widespread offence or undue distress."

 Virgin yesterday withdrew an advert for a video game judged by the ASA to incite violence against pedestrians. The poster for Carmageddon featured a naked bottom with the words "Pedestrians. Kiss yours goodbye", and underneath: "Puts the car into carnage" with "carnage" dripping in red.

Virgin Interactive Entertainment said the advert was humorous but apologised for any offence caused.

fields.headline: Child took ecstasy tablet
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A one-year-old boy was recovering in an Edinburgh hospital yesterday after swallowing an ecstasy tablet that he found in his mother's handbag.
fields.body:
A one-year-old boy was recovering in an Edinburgh hospital yesterday after swallowing an ecstasy tablet that he found in his mother's handbag.

The boy, who has not been named, became seriously ill on Monday after swallowing the tablet. His condition is understood to be stable.

The incident is the latest involving children who have needed medical treatment after swallowing drugs, and anti-drugs groups yesterday called on parents to be more vigilant.

It is understood the boy's mother has told police the class A drug belonged to someone else. She put the tablets in her handbag after finding them while clearing up following a party in her home at weekend.

The woman is not thought to be a drug user or dealer. It is understood that the child placed several tablets in his mouth, but his mother managed to remove all but one.

A hospital spokeswoman confirmed the child was being treated but said the parents had asked her not to give further details.

A spokesman for Lothian and Borders police confirmed an investigation was under way.

Although the incident is believed to have been an accident, it is likely that a report will be submitted to the procurator fiscal.

Alistair Ramsay, of Scotland Against Drugs, said the incident demonstrated how careful parents must be even if they were not drug users.

fields.headline: Nuclear papers found on street
fields.trailText: Papers found on a pavement near the Aldermaston nuclear weapons factory in Berkshire reveal secrets about the government's plans to develop new weapons.
fields.body:
Papers found on a pavement near the Aldermaston nuclear weapons factory in Berkshire reveal secrets about the government's plans to develop new weapons.

The papers, dated March 10, will embarrass the Ministry of Defence because they give targets for nuclear weapons research, development and production, including collaboration with the French and Americans. The government's only official announcement is that it will "maintain a capability" for nuclear weapons.

The new weapons are to replace the 100 kilotonne warheads on Trident submarines. These are five times the size of the Hiroshima bomb and enough to wipe out the centre of Moscow. They are felt to be too big for modern precision warfare.

Smaller warheads with the punch to destroy enemy hardened bunkers are thought to be needed to make Trident more efficient.

The papers also give dates for the nearby Burghfield Trident warhead assembly plant to be closed - mixed up with memos detailing safety lapses.

There was also a handwritten draft explaining how British Nuclear Fuels privatisation plans helped to get it the contract to run Aldermaston, the controversial nuclear bomb making facility. This plan was postponed by the government last Wednesday, but the contract was confirmed on the same day.

The government hoped to raise £1.5bn from the sale of BNFL, which in turn offered to put money into upgrading the A45 building at Aldermaston which purifies highly enriched uranium for Trident nuclear warheads.

Using shareholders money to make a new generation of nuclear weapons was unlikely to make BNFL any more popular, but this promise would probably have been kept secret. The government's official position, given by Helen Liddell, the trade and industry minister, is that BNFL got the contract because of its expertise in clearing up nuclear waste and decommissioning.

The scheme to develop new nuclear weapons has not been announced by the government, which is under pressure to reduce weaponry under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty.

Also among the papers is the programme "to ensure safe, secure and reliable stockpile" of nuclear weapons by next month.

The work plan details the need for new partnerships with universities and secondment and swaps of staff with French and American nuclear weapons laboratories.

The plan also involves assessing the skills of Aldermaston employees to make sure enough experts are retained who are capable of designing new nuclear weapons.

The documents make it clear that Aldermaston is still dismantling warheads from the now defunct Polaris fleet and hopes to develop a plan for dealing with them by next month.

The government's plans to save money on nuclear weapons partly involve cutting the workforce at Aldermaston and Burghfield by 1,400 from 4,500. This has included a plan for closing Burghfield, where the nuclear warheads manufactured at Aldermaston are put together with high explosive to make sure that they blow up correctly on reaching their targets.

Originally the two sites were kept nine miles apart because of the fears of what may go wrong in an accident, but now it has been decided to do the packing at Aldermaston. The work plan says this is supposed to happen in March 2001. This gives time for all the facilities, including safety devices, to be replicated at Aldermaston.

fields.headline: Ex-soccer star denies rage attack
fields.trailText: Derek Dougan, the former Wolves footballer and TV panellist, attacked his girlfriend's new partner in a jealous rage and struck him over the head with a pool cue, Wolverhampton crown court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Derek Dougan, the former Wolves footballer and TV panellist, attacked his girlfriend's new partner in a jealous rage and struck him over the head with a pool cue, Wolverhampton crown court was told yesterday.

Malcom Morse, prosecuting, said the footballer, 62, ended his relationship of 16 years with Patricia Thompson in 1998 when she went out with Eland Mason, 57, a kitchen fitter and Vietnam veteran known as "Rambo".

Dougan had gone to Ms Thompson's house in Wolverhampton on July 9, said Mr Morse, and attacked her boyfriend as he was shaving. Afterwards he allegedly shouted: "Next time you are dead - both of you."

Mr Mason, 57, was taken to hospital with head, leg, shoulder and arm injuries, while Dougan, from Codsall in Staffordshire, was picked up by police leaving a nearby pub with another woman. Dougan, who played for Wolves and Aston Villa and made 43 appearances for Northern Ireland between 1958 and 1973, denies charges of assault and aggravated burglary.

The court heard that three anonymous letters were sent to Mr Mason's former partner in April 1998. The first read: "Tell Rambo the war has just began [sic]. A well-wisher to you." Dougan's print was discovered on one letter.

Mr Mason, who completed two tours in Vietnam with the US air force, denied he had provoked Dougan. "Before I had a chance to turn round I was hit on the head," he told the court. "I remember the [pool] stick being dropped on the landing - all I could see was the American flag painted on the stick."

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Flood alert as snow melts
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Blizzards, sleet and torrential rain were seen in many areas of Britain yesterday and there were more than 60 flood warnings in force - three days before the start of the cricket season.
fields.body:
Blizzards, sleet and torrential rain were seen in many areas of Britain yesterday and there were more than 60 flood warnings in force - three days before the start of the cricket season.

Worst hit were the midlands and East Anglia where memories of the floods of Easter 1998 are still fresh. In some places it had been raining continuously for 48 hours.

Rivers were still rising last night and this, combined with high tides along the Suffolk and Essex coasts, meant that people were being asked to be prepared for the worst.

But forecasters said the picture was due to change in the next 24 hours with the heavy rain being replaced by showers, although it would remain cold.

In the south, where snow is now rare, many woke up to find blizzard conditions, and hills like the Chilterns had four inches in places. The rain soon washed it away but red alert flood warnings were posted on the Great Ouse at Newport Pagnell, Buckinghamshire, and on the River Kym at Great Staughton and Alconbury Brook, both in Cambridgeshire.

Further north, one of the worst affected areas was the Pennines with a "white-out" blocking the A57 Snake Pass from Glossop, Derbyshire, to Sheffield.

Snowdrifts across the North York Moors also forced the closure of the A169 Whitby to Pickering road. Planes had to be diverted to Birmingham and Stansted overnight after heavy snow closed Luton airport. The airport reopened at breakfast time but holidaymakers were still facing delays as the airport cleared the backlog. A spokeswoman said: "There was constant snowfall which meant every time we sent snowploughs up the runway there was more, so we couldn't operate the runway."

Peter Allen, chairman of the National Farmers Union's England and Wales hill farming committee, said lambs had been badly affected by the weather. "It takes its toll in deaths, particularly this year after having a mild three or four weeks in March.

"The biggest factor is starvation due to cold for those lambs who are newly born or in the first week of life. Farmers can expect fairly heavy losses."

The Royal Horticultural Society's senior horticultural adviser, Guy Barter, said the cold snap could spoil early flowering plants such as magnolias and camellias.

He said: "Plants from continental climates are also totally baffled, such as plum orchards. It could impinge on the amount of fruit we get."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Night sky spectacle
fields.body:
Night sky spectacle

Four of the brightest objects in the night sky come together tonight in a dramatic spectacle which will not be repeated for 20 years.

It begins 30 minutes after sunset when Mars, Jupiter, Saturn and a crescent moon can be seen within five degrees of one another.

Car clue in Enigma hunt

Police trying to find the second world war German Engima code machine stolen from Bletchley Park museum in Buckinghamshire want to speak to a woman seen in a red Peugeot parked at the back of the mansion last Saturday.

Plane crash due to uneven load

Unevenly loaded newspapers caused a plane to crash as it came in to land on Guernsey, killing both pilots, an official accident report said yesterday.

The Channel Express plane, piloted by Martin Bulgin, of Corfe Mullen, Dorset, and co-pilot Ian Rhodes, 41, of Swindon, crashed in January 1999.

Wembley attack: man for trial

Jonathan Edmonds, 31, of Slough, yesterday elected to stand trial accused of attacking Ruth Lelacheur, 30, at the Leicester City-Tottenham Hotspur Worthington Cup final at Wembley in March.

He was released on conditional bail until May 16.

fields.headline: Beginning of the line
fields.standfirst: Missing link between fish and land vertebrates
fields.trailText: Two small pieces of fossilised lower jaw found in rocks on the Baltic coast have proved to be from the "missing link" between primeval fishes and the first land vertebrates.
fields.body:
Two small pieces of fossilised lower jaw found in rocks on the Baltic coast have proved to be from the "missing link" between primeval fishes and the first land vertebrates.

The creature - perhaps a metre long and as yet unnamed - first crept out of the water 370m years ago to begin a line of descent that includes all dinosaurs, all reptiles, all amphibians, all mammals and all humans.

Its discovery, announced in London yesterday at an international conference on museums and botanic gardens, was a slow process. One fossil was excavated in Estonia two years ago. Another had been collected by an amateur, only to languish for years in Riga, Latvia, until identified by Per Ahlberg of the Natural History Museum in London as a key to a moment in history.

Both belonged to the same tetrapod; a creature with four limbs, half fish, half-amphibian, which lived in an estuarine lagoon in the Devonian era. At the time, Europe and North America were joined, and the modern Baltic was near the equator.

Palaeontologists are confident that the jawbone fragments tell a much larger story: they have similar fossils only a few million years older from fishes with gills and fins; and they have examples of younger crocodile-like fossils of the same basic design with legs and toes instead of fins. The find fits neatly between the two groups.

"There is every reason to believe it is really spending most of its time in the water," said Dr Ahlberg. "No doubt it has some terrestrial ability but we are looking at an animal that essentially lives in water and produces its crawling capacity to haul itself over mudbanks.

"Imagine a flooded forest at the edge of a lake or river. There are small fishes living in there which you want to catch. If you have the ability to crawl and slither through this stuff, you are set up to exploit this. It's not hard to see how you could get from that to more truly terrestrial animals."

webTitle: Rights court hears 'shoot to kill' claims

fields.headline: Rights court hears 'shoot to kill' claims
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Eleven men whose families took their cases to the European court of human rights yesterday were victims of a shoot to kill policy operated by the UK government in Northern Ireland, a lawyer for two of the men told the court.
fields.body:
Eleven men whose families took their cases to the European court of human rights yesterday were victims of a shoot to kill policy operated by the UK government in Northern Ireland, a lawyer for two of the men told the court.

Seamus Treacy told the 10 judges in Strasbourg that the government's policy had "resulted in the deaths of hundreds of civilians, overwhelmingly and disproportionately Catholic, by forces of the state".

He added: "The cases disclose compelling and disturbing evidence of a pattern or policy that suspects are arbitrarily killed rather than arrested."

A 12th man, Patrick Shanaghan, who was shot dead by a masked gunman, was allegedly killed as a result of collusion between loyalist paramilitaries and the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Mr Treacy said: "It is the applicants' contention that in each of these cases the UK government has violated both substantively and procedurally the most fundamental provision in the [human rights] convention, the right to life."

The case arises from four incidents between 1982 and 1992. The full facts behind the killings have never come to light. The families argue that the lack of proper investigation into the deaths violates the right to life guaranteed under the European convention.

The court decided in 1995, in a case brought by families of three IRA suspects shot dead on Gibraltar, that the convention required an effective official investigation when individuals had been killed by state force. The judges, who were holding a preliminary hearing yesterday to determine whether the case was admissible, must decide what amounts to an effective investigation.

For the government, Ronald Weatherup QC denied that the security forces had used disproportionate force in three of the incidents, or that there was collusion in the killing of Patrick Shanaghan. He argued that police investigations, inquests and criminal proceedings were capable of satisfying the convention's requirements.

webTitle: Call to regulate body piercing dangers

fields.headline: Call to regulate body piercing dangers
fields.trailText: Nurses are calling for urgent action to regulate body piercing amid mounting evidence that the trend is causing serious infections and disfigurement.
fields.body:
Nurses are calling for urgent action to regulate body piercing amid mounting evidence that the trend is causing serious infections and disfigurement.

Delegates to the annual congress of the Royal College of Nursing yesterday voted almost unanimously to press the government to act, after hearing that children as young as six were having jewellery or metal inserted in piercings in their navels, ears and noses.

The practice is regulated only in London. Elsewhere piercers can set up without registration or regular inspections.

A survey by health officials in Rochdale, Greater Manchester, found that 95% of local GPs had treated complications arising from body piercing, mainly infections.

Lesley Chivers, who chairs the Bristol RCN branch, told the congress in Bournemouth that her best friend's 13-year-old daughter had ended up in hospital after having her navel pierced, without parental consent, at a studio in Hereford.

Three weeks after the procedure the girl's navel had become inflamed and she had grown feverish and delirious. After hospital treatment she was left with an unsightly scar.

"We have seen evidence of young children, very young children, with genital piercings," Ms Chivers said.

"For whose delectation?" she asked. Certainly not the child's."

John Hill, from Scunthorpe, said people did not understand the implications of what was an invasive surgical procedure. "I have seen bleeding navels, infected tongues and ear lobes hanging off," he said.

Jeremy Bore, a prison nurse from Exeter, said he knew reputable piercers and they would welcome regulation. It was the "cowboys" who had to be driven out of business.

webTitle: Cancer drug for women may aid men

fields.headline: Cancer drug for women may aid men
fields.trailText: A drug used to treat ovarian and breast cancer could also prolong the lives of thousands of men with testicular cancer, scientists said yesterday.
fields.body:
A drug used to treat ovarian and breast cancer could also prolong the lives of thousands of men with testicular cancer, scientists said yesterday.

Researchers at Hammersmith hospital in west London discovered that Taxol can help sufferers whose illness has returned or failed to respond to chemotherapy.

They believe the treatment can improve the management of some patients with testicular cancer.

Michael Seckl, senior lecturer and medical oncologist at Hammersmith hospital, who led the study, said: "The discovery that Taxol can help in the fight against testicular cancer will hopefully mean better treatment and cure rates for patients with this common disease.

"We hope to take this finding on further to develop therapies which could increase survival rates."

Dr Seckl's team found that treating cells with Taxol combined with stem cell infusion - an advanced form of bone marrow transplant - can help overcome the 5% to 10% of testicular cancers not cured by standard chemotherapy.

Although the trial was based on 22 patients, the researchers are convinced that the results will lead to an advance in testicular cancer treatment.

The findings were presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research in San Francisco.

Lord Winston, director of research and development at Hammersmith hospital, said: "Dr Seckl's findings are really encouraging. It appears that this drug offers wider potential for the treatment of cancers than first thought."

Taxol is available on the NHS for treating ovarian and breast cancer in some regions but not in others.

The national institute of clinical excellence is investigating whether the NHS should pay for Taxol throughout Britain.

webTitle: Pennies by the million go to charity

fields.headline: Pennies by the million go to charity
fields.trailText: Fran Humphries, 84, has raised £10,000 for charity over 17 years by collecting 1m penny coins by filling thousands of Smarties sweet tubes.
fields.body:
Fran Humphries, 84, has raised £10,000 for charity over 17 years by collecting 1m penny coins by filling thousands of Smarties sweet tubes.

She had friends, family and her church congregation all filling tubes for her appeal to repaint the hall of Tewkesbury abbey in Gloucestershire.

Miss Humphries, from Tewkesbury, decided in 1983 to raise £1,000 for the abbey repairs. When donations came in, she decided it was in for a penny, in for £10,000.

She filled about two Smarties tubes each week with pennies herself but with the combined efforts of her community, managed to raise up to £12 a week.

Miss Humphries estimated she could fit 75 pennies into a tube. To collect £10,000, she would have needed about 13,333 tubes. Each tube contains 35 Smarties, so a total of 466,655 Smarties would have to be eaten to make room for the pennies.

"It is surprising how quickly a tube fills up and people are glad to get rid of their pennies," she said. "I am handing over the fund now I have reached my target. I don't take on a job unless I can do it well, but I've got to calm down now."

webTitle: Straw cuts jail term for woman who killed 'abuser'

fields.headline: Straw cuts jail term for woman who killed 'abuser'
fields.trailText: A woman who poisoned a man with arsenic after allegedly suffering repeated sexual and physical abuse could be released on parole in four years following a decision to reduce her life imprisonment tariff, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman who poisoned a man with arsenic after allegedly suffering repeated sexual and physical abuse could be released on parole in four years following a decision to reduce her life imprisonment tariff, it emerged yesterday.

Zoora Shah, who was convicted of murdering Mohammed Azam in 1993, received papers from the home secretary, Jack Straw, saying her tariff had been cut from 20 years to 12. It means she will be eligible for parole in 2004.

Shah's eldest daughter, Naseem, whose campaign for her mother's release is a cause celebre in Britain's Asian community, welcomed the decision but said a 12-year tariff was still "a farce". She added: "We expected Jack Straw to show some understanding but this shows that he is not capable of it."

Shah, an illiterate Muslim from Mirpur in Pakistan, arrived in England in the mid-1970s and had an arranged marriage which broke up in 1980.

She was convicted at Leeds crown court in December 1993 of killing Azam, a heroin-dealing Bradford businessman whom she met after her husband left.

During the trial Shah, 49, did not mention the abuse she had suffered. She said later she did not want to bring shame on her family.

But during an appeal against her conviction, which was lost, she admitted twice poisoning Azam with arsenic because he had physically and sexually abused her. Shah said she agreed to have sex with Azam in return for his finding her a home. She alleged that in 1982 he asked her to bring drugs back from Pakistan and that he was violent when she returned empty handed.

She said she was beaten, raped and "used as a bed" by him for 12 years.

When Azam was jailed for drug offences in 1984, he allegedly encouraged associates to visit her for sex.

Shah said she tried to hire a hitman to kill him but had to take matters into her own hands when he took a sexual interest in her two teenage daughters.

To begin with, she laced a samosa with arsenic in the hope it would reduce his sex drive.

Although Azam was ill for a month he continued to abuse her, so she spiked a sweet and fed it to him at a family gathering. He died the next day.

In May 1998 the court of appeal was suspicious of Shah's fresh evidence, asking why no one seemed to have noticed a single bruise other than one black eye.

Lord Justice Kennedy, sitting with Mr Justice Butterfield and Mr Justice Richards, said he was surprised Shah felt unable to inform anyone.

Naseem Shah said the appeal judges had failed to understand the cultural issues involved.

Hannana Siddiqui, of the campaign group Southall Black Sisters, said yesterday: "It is an indictment of our times that the criminal justice system still cannot distinguish between those who kill from a position of power and those who do so out of despair."

The Home Office stressed there was no guarantee Shah would be paroled in four years. "The tariff is the bare minimum she will have to serve before she is eligible for parole," a spokesman said.

fields.headline: BBC explores deal with Granada
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: BBC camera crews could soon be filming episodes of Coronation Street as part of a cost-cutting deal being discussed by the corporation and Granada television, which makes the ITV series.
fields.body:
BBC camera crews could soon be filming episodes of Coronation Street as part of a cost-cutting deal being discussed by the corporation and Granada television, which makes the ITV series.

Greg Dyke, the new BBC director general, is determined to make savings in as many areas as possible, and corporation managers have identified a link-up with Granada as a way of saving money in its Manchester division. The deal is likely to set a trend in partnerships with the commercial sector under Mr Dyke's regime.

The two broadcasters' resources departments could merge to form one company, or at least work more closely together. At present both have centres in the same city: BBC Resources Ltd employs about 150 staff such as technicians, camera crews and other support staff in Manchester, while Granada has about 350 in its resources division there.

Staff expect any merger effectively to be a takeover by Granada, and redundancies would be inevitable. As many as 100 posts may go, although the two broadcasters are far from agreeing details.

Both firms confirmed yesterday that talks were under way. A BBC spokeswoman said they had been talking for some time "about how we can develop flexible production facilities in Manchester".

The link-up could mean BBC crews working on Granada programmes such as Coronation Street, or the commmercial firm's staff working on BBC Manchester shows such as A Question of Sport.

This week, Mr Dyke announced that several hundred jobs would go in his restructuring of the BBC. It had been assumed that he had middle managers in his sights, but he is more concerned about duplication.

He is keen to encourage partnerships with the private sector as a way of saving licence fee money. He is exploring ways of financing new premises for the BBC in London with private cash.

BBC Scotland's new headquarters at Pacific Quay, Glasgow, is being financed partly with money from commercial sources and the local authority.

The Glasgow model may be drawn upon by London managers. The government has demanded that the BBC make savings of £1.2bn by 2007, in return for allowing the licence fee to rise by 1.5% above inflation each year until then.

When he launched his new structure on Monday, Mr Dyke rejected the notion that he would "preside over the decline of the BBC". On the contrary, his reforms would result in more money for programming, he said.

The BBC separated its resources division into a limited company a year ago. It markets its services to other divisions and to commercial companies. Granada and the BBC already work closely together; the ITV company makes a number of programmes for the corporation.

webTitle: Ozone layer over Europe thinner by two-thirds

fields.headline: Ozone layer over Europe thinner by two-thirds
fields.trailText: Scientists measuring the ozone layer - the planet's sunscreen - over northern Europe have found that almost two-thirds has been lost in one of the coldest stratospheric winters on record.
fields.body:
Scientists measuring the ozone layer - the planet's sunscreen - over northern Europe have found that almost two-thirds has been lost in one of the coldest stratospheric winters on record.

The losses above the Arctic mean that ozone levels over Europe will be thinner in the next few weeks. Ozone, an unusual form of oxygen, is a pollutant at ground level but blocks ultraviolet radiation in the upper atmosphere. Less ozone protection means a greater risk of skin cancers and cataracts.

The message is that, even though developed nations have stopped using the chemicals that endanger the ozone layer, the damage goes on.

The most dramatic ozone depletion occurs over the Antarctic: in 1985 British scientists identified a hole the size of the US and as deep as Everest. There were swift international steps to ban releases of the ozone-destroying chemicals chlorofluorocarbons which, in a complicated reaction with intense cold and the first sunshine of the polar spring, caused huge ozone destruction each September. Since then there has been concern about similar processes over Europe each spring.

Scientists from Europe, the US, Canada, Russia and Japan have been cooperating on detailed measurement of the chemistry of the atmosphere at high altitudes. Between January and March, they said in a report out today, there were cumulative losses of 60% at altitudes of around 18km.

The witches' brew needed to destroy the planet's sunscreen involves chlorine from CFCs, very low temperatures and clouds in the stratosphere. When conditions are right, one molecule of chlorine can destroy thousands of molecules of ozone.

In the Antarctic it happens every year. In the Arctic the conditions are less stable, and European scientists try not to talk of "holes" in the ozone layer. But there has been a pattern of continuous destruction none the less. On January 28 the area covered by temperatures low enough for clouds to form was 14.8m square kilometres. Europe covers only 10m sq km.

Georgios Amanatidis, one of the scientists in the group, said even though chlorine levels were falling the problem would continue. Global warming in the lower atmosphere, leading to a thinning and shrinking of Arctic ice, had led to greater cold in the upper atmosphere, creating more destructive conditions. The threat to public health from any episode of ozone loss was not great, he said. But the risks of exposure to ultraviolet were cumulative.

webTitle: Love triangle ends in violent deaths at hotel

fields.headline: Love triangle ends in violent deaths at hotel
fields.standfirst: Wife watches in horror as estranged husband batters her lover to death in car park before shooting himself in the head
fields.trailText: A husband bludgeoned his estranged wife's lover to death with a hammer and then shot himself after confronting the pair in the grounds of a country hotel, Sussex police said yesterday.
fields.body:
A husband bludgeoned his estranged wife's lover to death with a hammer and then shot himself after confronting the pair in the grounds of a country hotel, Sussex police said yesterday.

The double killing in the grounds of Effingham Park Hotel in Copthorne, West Susex, happened late on Monday night following what is thought to have been a row between the husband and his wife's lover.

Residents near the scene of the killing described how they were woken during the night by "the most appalling screaming" and the sound of someone being repeatedly clubbed.

The killings took place around 11pm when a 55-year-old man confronted his wife and her lover, a hotel maintenance worker, as they got out of the man's car in the hotel's staff car park.

A spokesman for Sussex police said: "We believe he [the husband] hit him on the head with a hammer, and then it looks like he did himself in."

The maintenance worker survived the intial beating and managed to stumble into the staff quarters of the hotel after the attack but collapsed despite attempts by staff to help him. He later died on his way to New East Surrey hospital in Redhill.

According to Sussex police, the wife watched in horror as her husband attacked the hotel worker, but she was uninjured in the attack.

A police spokesman was unable to say whether the woman had intervened in the struggle between the two men.

She was yesterday being interviewed by police and her children were being looked after by friends.

Her husband's body was found two hours later by police sniffer dogs 100 yeards from the main hotel building on the hotel golf course, where he had apparently shot himself in the head.

All three are from Felbridge, a village five miles from Copthorne.
