fields.headline: The auditor
fields.standfirst: Regulatory body dominated by industry
fields.trailText: When Entrust - the country's only privately owned and run regulatory body - was set up in 1996 it was given responsibility to police cash handed over to non-profit making environmental trusts for activities relating to "a tightly drawn list of approved purposes approved by government", according to the badly worded Department of Environment press release at the time.
fields.body:
When Entrust - the country's only privately owned and run regulatory body - was set up in 1996 it was given responsibility to police cash handed over to non-profit making environmental trusts for activities relating to "a tightly drawn list of approved purposes approved by government", according to the badly worded Department of Environment press release at the time.

The press release emphasised that the trusts had to be "at arm's length from the landfill operators who contribute to them". What was not expected was that the regulatory body, which is now responsible for £250m donated by the landfill operators, and approves and audits 1,900 bodies, would be so dominated by the industry.

The company is chaired by Lord Cranbook, chairman of the environment advisory board of the Shanks Group, one of the country's largest waste disposal companies. The board secretary is Roger Hewitt, former chief executive of Shanks and McEwen before it became the Shanks Group, and treasurer of the Institute of Waste Management. A third non-executive director is Peter Neill, chief executive of the Environment Services Association, which is the trade body of the waste industry, and chief executive of Lancashire Waste Services.

Marion Carter, an independent environment consultant, is a member of ESA's board and was a consultant to its environmental body, Esart. Her firm advised Esart on how to spend research money donated by landfill operators.

The other five members of the board include one council leader, an accountant, lawyer, a professor of environmental science and an independent environment consultant.

Until the Guardian began its investigation a year ago, Entrust had only audited one of the 800 environmental trusts which had received cash .

Since then it has started auditing 200 organisations. Already four have had their grant money revoked and two are under investigation by the serious fraud office.

fields.headline: Motorbike crash victim wins £1.3m damages
fields.trailText: A woman who gave birth to a healthy daughter four months after falling into a coma following a road accident was awarded £1.375m in damages yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman who gave birth to a healthy daughter four months after falling into a coma following a road accident was awarded £1.375m in damages yesterday.

Gillian Halpin was knocked from her motorcycle when a car skidded across a road at Hailsham, East Sussex, in October 1995.

Ms Halpin, then 19, suffered severe head injuries and was at first thought to be in a persistent vegetative state. At one point doctors considered switching off her life support system but then discovered she was pregnant.

In February 1996, her daughter, Carla Gillian, was born by caesarean section.

Ms Halpin, a former clerical assistant, who now lives at Bethany House, Dymchurch, Kent - a nursing home for severely disabled young people - remains in a "locked-in" state.

She sees three-year-old Carla regularly and her ability to communicate has improved. But she is unlikely ever to be able to hold her daughter, to talk to her or read to her.

Yesterday Ms Halpin's father, Andrew, paid tribute to her courage, saying she had "fought all the way". He added: "I take Carla down to see Gillian every couple of weeks and we spend the whole day there. She knows who her mum is and climbs up on to her wheelchair and puts her arms round her."

Mr Halpin, of Heathfield, East Sussex, added: "There is not going to be a miracle cure but we are working on helping Gillian to communicate better and on bringing her a better quality of life."

After making the damages award, which includes £190,000 for pain, suffering and the loss of enjoyment of life, Mr Justice Buckley said in the high court in London: "Anyone who has had any contact with this case will have enormous feeling and sympathy towards [Ms Halpin's family]. They have played their part to the full in ensuring that Gillian gets the very best treatment. I can only wish all of them the very best for the future."

Ms Halpin's counsel, Christopher Purchas QC, said Mr Halpin had given his daughter devoted attention. "Gillian has a lot to be very grateful to her father for the very close attention he has paid to her position."

After the accident, Ms Halpin was transferred to the Royal Home for Neuro-Disability at Putney, south-west London, in September 1996. There staff first noticed a flicker of movement in her fingers which led to her using a sensitive buzzer to indicate yes or no.

"It is a very laborious process and very tiring for Gillian," said Mr Purchas. "But, apart from that, she has no way of communicating at all. She can't move any part of her body, she is unable to speak, she is in a wholly locked-in situation."

He said Ms Halpin's communication abilities had continued to improve and she now used a switch mechanism below her jaw which she could operate by breathing. It was hoped that she would eventually be able to operate a television and other equipment.

"Gillian is much happier now, she is usually to be found smiling. She likes going down to see the horses in the stables and going to the cinema. She is always going to remain desperately disabled for the rest of her life," he said. "She's got a mind, she hasn't got a body."

The damages were awarded by consent against the insurers of motorist Keir Williams, of Hartpury, Gloucestershire.

webTitle: Melchett tells court of his fear of GM crops

fields.headline: Melchett tells court of his fear of GM crops
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Melchett, executive director of Greenpeace, told Norwich crown court yesterday that genetic modification of crops was one the most frightening things he had come across, and he was convinced the government was keen to pursue the technology.
fields.body:
Lord Melchett, executive director of Greenpeace, told Norwich crown court yesterday that genetic modification of crops was one the most frightening things he had come across, and he was convinced the government was keen to pursue the technology.

Melchett criticised chemical company scientists for "not living in the real world". He is accused with 27 other supporters of the environmental campaign group of criminal damage and theft after a trial GM crop of maize in Lyng, Norfolk, was destroyed last July.

The former Labour minister said that meetings with Tony Blair in late 1998 and early 1999 had left him feeling that the prime minister was determined that GM crops would be grown.

All 28 defendants deny the charges and argue that they had a lawful excuse to destroy the crop because they genuinely believed that neighbouring organic crops were in immediate need of protection.

"GM is one of the most serious issues Greenpeace has ever tried to tackle," said Melchett, 52, a farmer of Hunstanton, Norfolk. "GM means putting things into the environment which are alive. You cannot recall it."

The case continues.

fields.headline: Woman who killed boyfriend freed
fields.trailText: A young woman who stabbed her sleeping boyfriend to death and kept his body hidden in a cupboard before it was chopped up and the parts scattered across the countryside was put on probation yesterday after a judge heard she had suffered abuse and had been in a "psychotic state".
fields.body:
A young woman who stabbed her sleeping boyfriend to death and kept his body hidden in a cupboard before it was chopped up and the parts scattered across the countryside was put on probation yesterday after a judge heard she had suffered abuse and had been in a "psychotic state".

Julie Adamson, 18, from Hove, East Sussex, had pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. She was given three years probation with a condition that she be assessed at a psychiatric hospital. She killed 31-year-old Robert Kavanagh with a seven-inch carving knife as he lay on her sofa. The teenager - who was 17 at the time of the killing and had regularly been abused - had feared that he would awake and murder her.

Sitting at Lewes crown court, Judge Richard Brown heard that Mr Kavanagh was a violent man with a criminal record and a history of drug and alcohol problems. He was told that Mr Kavanagh once tried to throw Adamson under a bus in a rage, held her face against an electric fire and attacked her while she slept and kicked her in the jaw.

After the killing Adamson kept the victim's body in a cupboard before it was clothed and cut up. A postmortem said the body must have been stored in a freezer and a mechanical saw had been used with "some skill" to dismember the corpse. The court heard that it was still unclear how the body had been disposed of. A £2,000 award for information is still on offer.

A neighbour alerted police when she saw two men remove a bloody mattress from Adamson's home. Three weeks later a murder hunt began when a hand was found near a pig farm. The court heard that Adamson had tried to get friends to help her dispose of the body. One tipped off police.

Camden Pratt QC, defending, said his client - "a highly vulnerable person" who attempted to hang herself in prison and had already served 18 months in custody on remand - had become besotted with Mr Kavanagh after they met in 1997 when she was 15.

fields.headline: Royalist revenge
fields.standfirst: Scholar claims Cromwell was poisoned in high-level plot
fields.trailText: On June 1 1663 the mischievous Oxford diarist Anthony Wood wrote in his journal: "Dr Bate died at London of the French pox and confessed on his death bed that he poisoned Oliver Cromwell".
fields.body:
On June 1 1663 the mischievous Oxford diarist Anthony Wood wrote in his journal: "Dr Bate died at London of the French pox and confessed on his death bed that he poisoned Oliver Cromwell".

Wood's claim was dismissed or ridiculed for centuries by the few who noticed it. One of its problems was that George Bate - physician not only to Cromwell but to Charles l and Charles II - had not died until five years later, although he is known to have been very ill in 1663.

But the diarist and the doctor were telling the truth, according to a study of evidence in a new book. This finds that Cromwell died from three poisons administered by Bate in a high-level plot to restore the throne.

Yesterday the author, Howard McMains, a US scholar, said that without this conspiracy "the history of England could have been immeasurably different".

The American war of independence might never have happened. Britain could have remained a republic or developed into a constitutional monarchy far earlier.

Cromwell, who created the country's only, short-lived, republic after winning the English civil war and executing Charles l, died on September 3 1658 following 33 days of illness.

The cause of his death was given as malaria. But Dr McMains' book - based on the first medical study of Cromwell's illness as chronicled in family letters - concludes that his symptoms indicate poisoning by antimony, mercury and arsenic.

The letters show that the 59-year-old Lord Protector was as strong as a horse, Dr McMains says. He recovered three times, becoming well enough to ride a horse and hold a dinner party. One of these recoveries occurred while Bate was away treating another patient. But the last poison, arsenic, killed him.

The author says he has shown the family letters to an eminent US toxicologist and to a doctor. After studying the pattern of symptoms, both endorse his theory.

Wood's diary said two bishops "and his majesty" knew of the plot. One of Charles ll's first actions after the Stuart dynasty was restored to the throne was to appoint Bate as his physician.

Doubt was cast on the theory yesterday by a British scholar, John Morrill, professor of British and Irish history at Cambridge.

"He has done tremendous work and it's a very interesting book," Prof Morrill said, "But I don't think the evidence adds up to what he wants to find."

Anthony Wood was an unreliable witness, and "Cromwell's health had in fact been deteriorating for the last two or three years."

The Death of Oliver Cromwell, by Howard McMains, University Press of Kentucky (£21.50)

fields.headline: Briton jailed in Venezuela
fields.trailText: A British social worker has been jailed for nearly seven years in Venezuela after admitting attempting to smuggle £500,000 of cocaine, it was reported last night.
fields.body:
A British social worker has been jailed for nearly seven years in Venezuela after admitting attempting to smuggle £500,000 of cocaine, it was reported last night.

Irene Campbell, 53, from Glasgow, was reported to have pleaded guilty at a court in the South American country after being found with cocaine worth £500,000 in her bags.

Foreign Office sources last night confirmed newspaper reports and said that she had been sentenced to six years nine months in prison.

Police detained Mrs Campbell as she made her way through the island's airport last Wednesday.

The sources said that the information had been given to the British embassy in the Venezuelan capital Caracas by the country's authorities.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said that Mrs Campbell had been due to appear in court yesterday but official confirmation of the outcome of the hearing would not come until today.

An official from the embassy is to travel to see Mrs Campbell, who is in a prison on the island of Margarita, to discover what happened at the court hearing. Her family, from the Pollok area of Glasgow, was last night unavailable for comment.

The Venezualan judicial system has come in for criticism from Stephen Jakobi, of the campaign group Fair Trials Abroad. "We have seen 200 judges dismissed for corruption, it is a system that does not work properly. The situation on a judicial level is desperately bleak," he said.

fields.headline: Heroin: abusers start at 15
fields.standfirst:
Survey warns of new outbreak among tens of thousands of teenagers in smaller towns and cities

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The average age at which teenagers begin experimenting with heroin has fallen to only 15, two years younger than in the late 1980s, according to new research for a leading drugs charity published last night.
fields.body:
The average age at which teenagers begin experimenting with heroin has fallen to only 15, two years younger than in the late 1980s, according to new research for a leading drugs charity published last night.

The Department of Health - funded study warns that smaller cities and towns, which have escaped in the past, now find themselves facing a new "heroin outbreak" involving tens of thousands of teenagers who are also beginning to use crack cocaine in significant numbers.

The study, Hidden Heroin Users, by Manchester University researchers for DrugScope, says that the increasingly early age of onset of heroin abuse at around 15 is unprecedented and has fallen significantly from the 17 to 18 average in the late 1980s when the inner cities of Glasgow, London, Manchester and Liverpool were experiencing a boom in heroin abuse.

The survey by Roy Egginton and Professor Howard Parker involved in-depth interviews with 86 young people between 15 and 20 at four undisclosed locations in England. It reveals that hard-drug addiction is spreading rapidly in towns and cities left untouched by previous heroin epidemics. Now it is hitting places such as Bradford, Bristol and Hull where there are fewer older heroin addicts as a reminder to teenagers not to get involved.

The study found that in the smaller cities and towns between 5% and 20% of 15-year-olds had been offered heroin, while a quarter said they could easily get the drug. Only a minority of those tempted to experiment came from damaged family backgrounds, and many were from comfortable, middle-class families.

"Those involved were routinely out and about unsupervised from the age of 13. Their parents did not know where they were. They were early smokers and drinkers and moved into a phase of florid drugs experimentation. At 15 they initiated on heroin, two years younger than in the 1980s heroin epidemic," the study says.

Alarmingly young teenagers no longer regard heroin as the kind of stigma that prevented previous generations experimenting on a large scale. Most try heroin for the first time at a friend's house and begin by smoking it. Most abusers move rapidly to weekly and then daily use.

"These heroin users were initially very naive and ill-informed about heroin. They did not understand its subtle potency and addictiveness and had little idea where a heroin career might take them. As habits grow, injecting becomes routine, health and self-esteem suffer and [multiple] drug use looms involving cannabis, tranquillisers, methadone and crack cocaine," the report says.

It quotes the regrets of one user who had been smoking heroin for three years: "Knowing the consequences. Making the connection between browns and heroin. I was told it was like powdered cannabis."

But what worried the researchers even more was that three-quarters of those interviewed said they had tried crack cocaine and one-third said they had used it in the past month. To fund their "poly drug" habit - on average with a cost of more than £160 a week - these teenagers are turning to shoplifting, theft and in some cases prostitution.

The researchers say the fact that heroin is finding its way into smaller cities and towns left untouched by previous outbreaks, the broader social profile of those involved, and their unprecedented youth means that government treatment and drug services do not reach them. Many such teenagers are unlikely to go anywhere near treatment services, and their special drug language, with its talk of "gauching, rattling, clucking, digging and pins", finds no reflection in any published outlet.

Many distrust adult authority and are too insecure and immature to see the benefit of seeking help.

The combination of mobile phones and fast roads has made it much easier for dealers to supply even remote areas, and this has made it impossible to determine accurately the number of teenage users across Britain.

Roger Howard, chief executive of DrugScope, said the study provided a crucial insight into the world of teenage heroin users, many of whom were shockingly young. "It is particularly worrying that many of the youngsters interviewed had no idea of the potency of heroin before they tried it, and that three-quarters of them have already used crack cocaine. We surely have a duty as a society to find new ways of communicating with such youngsters at an early stage - be that through mentoring schemes, more targeted schools drug education, or much more outreach work in local communities."

The Department of Health - funded study warns that smaller cities and towns, which have escaped in the past, now find themselves facing a new "heroin outbreak" involving tens of thousands of teenagers who are also beginning to use crack cocaine in significant numbers. The study, Hidden Heroin Users, by Manchester University researchers for DrugScope, says that the increasingly early age of onset of heroin abuse at around 15 is unprecedented and has fallen significantly from the 17 to 18 average in the late 1980s when the inner cities of Glasgow, London, Manchester and Liverpool were experiencing a boom in heroin abuse. The survey by Roy Egginton and Professor Howard Parker involved in-depth interviews with 86 young people between 15 and 20 at four undisclosed locations in England. It reveals that hard-drug addiction is spreading rapidly in towns and cities left untouched by previous heroin epidemics. Now it is hitting places such as Bradford, Bristol and Hull where there are fewer older heroin addicts as a reminder to teenagers not to get involved. The study found that in the smaller cities and towns between 5% and 20% of 15-year-olds had been offered heroin, while a quarter said they could easily get the drug. Only a minority of those tempted to experiment came from damaged family backgrounds, and many were from comfortable, middle-class families. "Those involved were routinely out and about unsupervised from the age of 13. Their parents did not know where they were. They were early smokers and drinkers and moved into a phase of florid drugs experimentation. At 15 they initiated on heroin, two years younger than in the 1980s heroin epidemic," the study says. Alarmingly young teenagers no longer regard heroin as the kind of stigma that prevented previous generations experimenting on a large scale. Most try heroin for the first time at a friend's house and begin by smoking it. Most abusers move rapidly to weekly and then daily use. "These heroin users were initially very naive and ill-informed about heroin. They did not understand its subtle potency and addictiveness and had little idea where a heroin career might take them. As habits grow, injecting becomes routine, health and self-esteem suffer and [multiple] drug use looms involving cannabis, tranquillisers, methadone and crack cocaine," the report says. It quotes the regrets of one user who had been smoking heroin for three years: "Knowing the consequences. Making the connection between browns and heroin. I was told it was like powdered cannabis." But what worried the researchers even more was that three-quarters of those interviewed said they had tried crack cocaine and one-third said they had used it in the past month. To fund their "poly drug" habit - on average with a cost of more than £160 a week - these teenagers are turning to shoplifting, theft and in some cases prostitution. The researchers say the fact that heroin is finding its way into smaller cities and towns left untouched by previous outbreaks, the broader social profile of those involved, and their unprecedented youth means that government treatment and drug services do not reach them. Many such teenagers are unlikely to go anywhere near treatment services, and their special drug language, with its talk of "gauching, rattling, clucking, digging and pins", finds no reflection in any published outlet. Many distrust adult authority and are too insecure and immature to see the benefit of seeking help. The combination of mobile phones and fast roads has made it much easier for dealers to supply even remote areas, and this has made it impossible to determine accurately the number of teenage users across Britain. Roger Howard, chief executive of DrugScope, said the study provided a crucial insight into the world of teenage heroin users, many of whom were shockingly young. "It is particularly worrying that many of the youngsters interviewed had no idea of the potency of heroin before they tried it, and that three-quarters of them have already used crack cocaine. We surely have a duty as a society to find new ways of communicating with such youngsters at an early stage - be that through mentoring schemes, more targeted schools drug education, or much more outreach work in local communities."

webTitle: Charlie Kray dies in hospital aged 73

fields.headline: Charlie Kray dies in hospital aged 73
fields.trailText: Charlie Kray, the elder brother of Ronnie and Reggie Kray, who earned notoriety as the brains of the family's criminal empire, died last night.
fields.body:
Charlie Kray, the elder brother of Ronnie and Reggie Kray, who earned notoriety as the brains of the family's criminal empire, died last night.

Kray, 73, who had been serving a 12 year sentence at Parkhurst prison on the Isle of Wight after he was convicted in 1997 of attempting to smuggle cocaine valued at £39m into Britain, died in St Mary's hospital, Newport, where he had been suffering from a heart condition.

A hospital spokeswoman said Kray, who was moved to the hospital last month after collapsing in prison, died in the presence of his girlfriend, Diane Buffini, and two other friends.

Although he did not have the violent reputation of his younger brothers, Charlie Kray was still an important component of the family's gangland history.

When Reggie Kray, 66, moved to Parkhurst from Wayland prison, Norfolk, last month, it fuelled speculation that his brother was close to death.

Ronnie Kray, who died of a heart attack aged 62, received a life sentence at the Old Bailey for the murders of George Cornell and Jack "the hat" McVitie in 1969. Reggie Kray was jailed for life for the murder of McVitie and for being an accessory after the murder of Cornell. Charlie Kray was given a 10-year sentence for being an accessory to the Cornell killing. After his release from prison in 1975, Charlie Kray made money from promoting the family's legend.

Reggie's wife, Roberta, said last night: "Obviously I had heard what has happened. I am still waiting for a call to come through to tell me more. It's not a good time for me to speak about how I am feeling at the moment as you can imagine."

Tony Lambrianou, a friend who was sentenced to 15 years for his part in the murder of Jack "the hat" McVitie last night said: "Charlie was a gentleman, even the law who knew him would tell you the same."

fields.headline: Marine 'killed by instructor's bullet'
fields.trailText: Police investigating the death of a teenage Royal Marine recruit during a training exercise believe that he was shot dead when an instructor opened fire with live ammunition, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Police investigating the death of a teenage Royal Marine recruit during a training exercise believe that he was shot dead when an instructor opened fire with live ammunition, it emerged last night.

Wayne Richards, 17, was killed last Friday morning on Woodbury Common, Devon.

An investigation into the shooting is being led by Devon and Cornwall police, in conjunction with the Ministry of Defence.

A Devon and Cornwall police source said last night that the shooting happened when the recruits were sitting in a depression on the common.

"The instructors attacked them and threw a couple of thunder flashes into the hole.

"One of the instructors had a magazine loaded with live rounds and opened fire," the police source added.

Mr Richards was hit in the sternum, and the bullet ricocheted under his chin, and through his jaw and head, said the police source.

When asked about the claim that an instructor had live rounds, a Ministry of Defence spokesman said: "The investigation into the incident is still continuing. It would be inappropriate to comment further at this stage."

The marines, who have given no details of the weapon involved, described the incident as a "tragic accident".

It is understood the police investigation is focusing on how live and blank rounds were mixed up during the training exercise.

Richards, from Cwm Avon in the Swansea valley, was in the ninth week of a 30-week course to qualify for the coveted green beret.

He was exercising with the 780 troop from the Commando Training Centre at Lympstone, a riverside base a few miles from Woodbury Common which is regularly used by the marines for training exercises.

On the day of the shooting, Chief Superintendent Liam McGrath said that live ammunition was carried by the marines against the threat of terrorism. "Clearly any further detail as to why live ammunition was involved in this incident is the subject of our inquiry," he added.

fields.headline: Minister admits targets blunder
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair faced embarrassment yesterday when a cabinet colleague admitted that the prime minister's flagship initiative to modernise the government had proved a flop.
fields.body:
Tony Blair faced embarrassment yesterday when a cabinet colleague admitted that the prime minister's flagship initiative to modernise the government had proved a flop.

In a rare admission of failure by Labour, the treasury chief secretary Andrew Smith said that hundreds of targets imposed on every Whitehall department had created "shortcomings" that had hindered the government's performance. The system is to be radically overhauled in the coming months.

Mr Smith's remarks were the most candid admission by the government that Mr Blair's much vaunted "public service agreements" had proved cumbersome and inoperable.

Unveiled amid fanfare in 1998 at the same time as the first spending round, the agreements were designed to improve the performance of departments through targets; Gordon Brown threatened to cut departmental budgets if they did not meet them.

With negotiations intensifying in the run-up to the chancellor's second spending round in July, Mr Brown's deputy admitted yesterday that the first set had proved over-ambitious.

"The radical nature of [the agreements] and their immediate impact on departments inevitably led to shortcomings," Mr Smith said in a speech to the Blairite think tank, the Institute of Public Policy Research. "Some of our targets are simply not very good, because we were new to the business."

He acknowledged ministers had been high-handed in forcing each department to reduce sickness levels among staff. "Our emphasis on the serious issue of sickness absence in the public sector looks unabalanced when we didn't have comparable measures in other areas of people management," said an astonishingly frank Mr Smith.

The government also had been mistaken in attempting to set an example to business by paying all invoices on time. "Setting targets to achieve 100% prompt payment of invoices looks good but will often be unachievable for very sound reasons, if an invoice needs to be investigated," he said.

In a clear sign of ministerial alarm at the targets' failure, Mr Smith said that the system would be radically changed in July: instead of an average of 30 targets per department, the Mr Brown would set an average of 10: "The current spending review is a big opportunity to improve the [system] and learn from experience, both positive and negative, as we take them forward."

Mr Smith's admission was seized on by Labour's opponents. Only last month, in the Budget, the chancellor had said that billions of extra money to be pumped into health and education would be linked to "modernisation targets".

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, said last night: "The targets are political, and the money is drip-fed according to ministers' judgments on who is behaving well. No wonder people cannot plan and manage on that basis.

"It is the height of hypocrisy for Labour leaders to lecture hard working men and women in the public and private sectors about improving their performance when minister cannot even set coherent, workable targets."

John Garrett, a former Labour MP, rounded on the targets in a Guardian article last year that was praised by Mr Smith. Mr Garrett welcomed the admission and said: "Public service agreements aim to confuse by swamping people with information. I would like to see them simplified and made more meaningful."

fields.headline: Why Wardle is wrong
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Confucius once pointed out that there was nothing quite so pleasurable as watching an old friend slip gently from a rooftop. Although I cannot claim the conservative MP Charles Wardle as a friend, I had exactly that sensation while reading his baffling apologia for Mohamed Fayed in these pages yesterday.
fields.body:
Confucius once pointed out that there was nothing quite so pleasurable as watching an old friend slip gently from a rooftop. Although I cannot claim the conservative MP Charles Wardle as a friend, I had exactly that sensation while reading his baffling apologia for Mohamed Fayed in these pages yesterday.

Mr Wardle, a minor luminary from the Conservative years and still a serving MP, popped out of the blue to announce that he had done the unthinkable and signed a contract with Harrods. Moreover he wanted us to know that he had been wrong to refuse Mohamed Fayed a British passport while serving under Michael Howard at the Home Office. He says he came to realise that his judgments were based on what he now regards as the fallible procedure of DTI investigations, especially relating to Fayed's acquisition of Harrods.

To sign up for the man who has caused so much trouble for the Tories and who happily confesses that he attempted to distort the democratic process by bribery is a startling career move, and one which dramatically elevates Wardle from his status as blameless and faceless drudge. He is clearly in awe of his own decision and one sensed in the insistent falsetto of yesterday's piece someone desperately trying to convince himself - and not wholly succeeding - but also a suspicion in the author's mind that he may now be regarded as his party's chief nincompoop, a role for which there is much competition.

The most obvious point to make to Wardle, who went on about the DTI report, is that it is considered rather out of date as a record of Fayed's villainy. This is why the current home secretary, Jack Straw, set it aside when he was considering Fayed's passport application last year and yet still managed to find grounds enough for refusal.

The charge sheet, compiled subsequent to the DTI report, includes the racist treatment of employees and harassment of women at Harrods, the bugging of union negotiations and of private conversations between members of Harrods staff, the illegal break-in to a safety deposit box at the Harrods bank and, finally, the operation to distance himself from all the blame for the car crash that killed Diana, including the lie about having spoken to the Princess before she died in hospital.

It is a wonder that he is not languishing in jail: in many countries he would be breaking stones by now. It is even more amazing that Wardle has fallen for the dubious charm and aura of money. How can he be so oblivious to the dangers of associating with Fayed? How can he not see that he has been bought, not for his business experience - which nobody doubts - but for his ability to sound off as a public figure in a newspaper?

Wardle begins his defence of Fayed by alluding to a recent inquiry by the police complaints authority into allegations that the police arrested employees that had fallen out with Fayed. He says the investigators found no evidence for this. Perhaps he should talk to someone like Hermina da Silva, a maid who worked for Fayed and who was arrested after she claimed that Fayed had tried to assault her. The Harrods chief of security Bob Macnamara subsequently told Bob Loftus, then also a security officer, that she was going "to be nicked". Later, after she was released without charge, she was paid £12,000 by Fayed. There are many examples of his sexual harassment. During the Vanity Fair libel case against Fayed, I saw the evidence, heard young women speak about their experiences at Harrods. Most of it is on the record now and it is a simple matter for a man like Wardle to find it.

The MP for Bexhill and Battle is in the grip of the old Tory disease of selling his authority as a public figure for money. It's telling how much he goes on about Fayed's hugely underestimated wealth and then within a few beats is rehearsing the conspiracy theory about the crash at the Place de l'Alma. He doubts the blood tests performed on the dead driver, Henri Paul, although the French authorities concluded without hesitation that he was drunk. He wonders why the ambulance took 45 minutes to get the Princess to the hospital, although anyone with the slightest knowledge of this crash could tell him that Diana suffered a massive heart attack and had to be stabilised at the scene.

Why has he not familiarised himself with all the facts laid in the books by Tom Bower, Martyn Gregory and Trevor Rees Jones which answer the points that he flourished yesterday as if he had happened upon a new body of evidence that proved Fayed's saintliness. Clearly he has not the smallest understanding of Fayed's role in this society over the last decade, which says something about his judgment. It should make the voters of Bexhill and Battle reassess Wardle's fitness to represent them next time round. I would suggest that his reason has already been impaired during his brief spell at Harrods. But at least we know where he stands.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge.
fields.body:
We've had a soft spot for Halle Berry ever since she managed to keep a straight face while reassuring Warren Beatty that "you're my nigga" at the end of Bulworth. A woman who can do that can do anything. It's almost worth forgiving her for films as abysmal as B*A*P*S and The Flintstones. So it was no surprise when - this Saturday - Berry did the decent thing and turned herself in to the authorities having been charged on Friday with the misdemeanour of leaving an accident scene (maximum sentence: 1 year).

Berry's contribution to the fine Hollywood tradition of abysmal driving involved ignoring a red light - on Sunset Boulevard, poetically enough - smashing into another car and then getting out of there as fast as she could. The DA has accepted that since she reported the accident as soon as she got to hospital, she isn't guilty of the felony of hit-and-run (maximum sentence: 3 years). Nevertheless, she still faces time when she comes to court on May 4 and, of course, is being sued by Hetal Raythatha, the woman injured in the accident. Once again, the moral of the story is never go near a movie star at the wheel. There's a well-sourced story doing the rounds about four well-established young stars - comprehensively loaded - driving their car right across a historic square in one of the US's older colonial towns. With no reaction from the law. If only the film industry had stayed in the private-car no-go area that is Manhattan, none of this madness would have occurred.

Meanwhile, a big bo selecta! to the Virginia judge who last Tuesday flew in the face of conventional wisdom and cleared reggae superstar Beenie Man of possessing marijuana. The judge accepted that Beenie and his band knew nothing about the joint the cops found at their hotel, nor the seeds and stems in the bin. Just goes to show that justice isn't always blind inna Babylon.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: 50 Not Out | Letters From The Morning Of The World
fields.body:
Around two million of this country's over-50s have now been made redundant. In the wake of last week's official projection that in eight years' time we shall have more pensioners than school children, Jenny Cuffe (pictured) discovers how this ageing majority is reshaping its life. In 50 Not Out (11.0am, Radio 4) she meets William Billing, a discarded estate agent who has managed to reincarnate himself both as a hypnotherapist and a Mr Oddjob, willing to tackle almost any domestic chore.

Some years ago the composer Robert Walker emigrated to Indonesia; he now lives in one of its many small villages. In Letters From The Morning Of The World (8.45pm, Radio 4) he spells out the everyday realities of Third World life. As always where poverty rules, you get nowhere until you've bribed one or more local officials. When Walker needed his visa renewed he found the price worked out about the same as a return flight to London.

fields.headline: They've killed Freddie!
fields.standfirst: Rock legends don't die - they just end up in bad-taste cartoons. At least that's the fate of Freddie Mercury, Marc Bolan and friends in a new animated series, The House Of Rock.  Meg Carter  looks at Britain's answer to South Park
fields.trailText: Rock legends don't die - they just end up in bad-taste cartoons. At least that's the fate of Freddie Mercury, Marc Bolan and friends in a new animated series, The House Of Rock. Meg Carter looks at Britain's answer to South Park.
fields.body:
If you've ever wondered what happens to rock stars when they die, Channel 4 has the answer. In a new late-night animated series which starts on Wednesday, five late popsters - Marc Bolan, Freddie Mercury, Kurt Cobain, John Denver and Biggie Smalls (aka Notorious BIG) - are condemned to an afterlife in limbo as unlikely housemates, while each awaits his turn to finally rest in peace.

The new show - The House Of Rock - echoes South Park, Beavis And Butthead and Stella Street. But its setting and storylines go far further - they're more sophisticated, and more surreal - on just a fraction of its predecessors' budget. And thanks to its late-night slot, the humour can cut even closer to the bone.

In episode one we are introduced to the five dead stars. Each has been condemned to the House Of Rock for their various abuses - drink, women, drugs... in Bolan's case: lip gloss. The exception is Denver, of course, whose presence is the result of an administrative mistake. The focus of the five's sitting room-bound afterlife is their TV. Upset by coverage of the Mercury Music Awards, Freddie laments being dead means he is no longer eligible to win. So the others cheer him up with the first Dead Rock Star Awards.

This, however, is only the entrée. Subsequent episodes include Kurt Cobain's discovery of the meaning of true happinesss (although his "revelation" turns out to be the result of an amateur lobotomy performed by Bolan), Notorious BIG's sexual obsession with a fridge... and the discovery of Michael Hutchence behind the bathroom door. Tasteless? Undoubtedly. But, the show's creators insist, they've not set out to offend.

"You can certainly go far further with animated sketches than you can with live action - because of context, and because of cost", House Of Rock producer Gavin Claxton admits. "But like anything in comedy, you only go with it if it's funny. Which this is. If we thought we'd really upset someone we wouldn't have gone with it at all." Besides, he adds, in the world of House Of Rock, deceased favourites can live again. "We don't just show Marc Bolan crashing into a tree: anyone could do that", he says.

Channel 4 has commissioned House Of Rock as part of its on-going campaign to champion and develop new, home-grown, grown-up animation. The show, animated by cartoonist Andy Watt, has been produced by independent production company Fireside Favourites, which was set up last year to make a one-off comedy pilot for the channel called All Aboard The Cat Bus.

Cat Bus's story gives a flavour both of where Fireside are coming from and the direction in which Channel 4 would like to see its adult animation go. The one-off featured Gwyneth Paltrow, who loses her English accent and attempts to get it restored by the Queen. The magic cat bus helps her on her journey - but not before she meets Shaun and Bez from The Happy Mondays, who are on their way to play a game at a pitch-and-putt centre run by the author JD Salinger.

Theirs is a brand of animated humour people either instantly love or loathe, Claxton admits. But the success of The Simpsons, South Park and Futurama have made commissioning editors interested in stretching the genre in new directions. And Claxton and his writing partners Richard Preddy and Gary Howe - whose extensive comedy writing credits include work for Harry Enfield, Mel and Griff and Smack The Pony - are eager to cash in.

For House Of Rock, Channel 4 wanted an animated series of short sequences to link the live action shows in its late-night 4Music strand. Fireside came up with the idea of Colonel Tom Parker's pickled brain interviewing contemporary rock acts like Beck. Channel 4, however, encouraged the team to pursue other ideas along the dead rock-star theme. Having seen Watt's cartoon work published in SFX, FHM and The Guardian, Claxton approached him to develop the "look". "My style fits the mood, humour and sense of ridiculous in the scripts", Watt says. "It appealed because the dialogue and storylines are far more sophisticated than things like Beavis And Butthead."

The resulting House Of Rock concept persuaded Channel 4 to commission Fireside to make 14 five-minute shorts - each will be split to run around 4Music programmes then repeated in full at each night's end - and a half-hour special due to air in the summer. Budget limitations have restricted the amount of movement seen on screen (another echo of South Park). "It's been made for pennies rather than the £1 million per episode the makers of The Simpsons enjoy", Claxton concedes. But necessity has had its benefits - honing the focus of the writers who, between them, also do the show's voices and have written and performed the music.

"Usually, broadcasters say to us: 'Isn't that just a little too strange?'" adds Claxton. "With this, though, we were simply told: 'Make it darker.'" Fireside's efforts so far, however, have paid off. Soon to complete production on House Of Rock, they are also developing Dominion, an animated sci-fi soap about Roger, a man abducted by aliens, due to air on Channel 4 this autumn and again with animation by Andy Watt.

 The House Of Rock, 2.10am, C4

fields.headline: Amateur criminals
fields.trailText: Crimewatch File | Bad Girls | Cutting Edge: Kiss And Sell
fields.body:
While the Charlie Says... series of public information broadcasts are probably the most famous of their genre, no kipper-eating orange cat speaking in a voice an octave lower than Charlie Brown's teacher could ever match the couple who featured in the Bedtime Routine film.

With perfectly coiffed hair and in silky dressing gowns, they sang their way around the house in a Cole Porter style (or perhaps it was Noel Coward, I was only six at the time) advising us to close every door and switch off every appliance at the mains lest fire break out and cook us in our slumber. They danced in the doorframes, tangoed in the hall and shimmied up the stairs in choreographed wonder. The ad climaxed, with all the finesse of a Busby Berkeley musical (or at least that's what I thought at the time), with the pair on the threshold of their boudoir chorusing about the joys of a "bed-time roooo-teeeen!" To this day, I never leave the telly on stand-by.

Alas, how I wish I had when Crimewatch File (BBC1) popped up. The Hunter And The Hunted charted the investigation into the "DJ Rapist", Richard Baker, who attacked at least 12 women in London and the south-east in late 1998.

While all very admirable - much like public information broadcasts - Crimewatch File was a thoroughly shambolic affair. From out-of-focus lights signifying The City At Night and clunky dialogue like "I'll contact Crimewatch and see if they'll do us a reconstruction on their programme", it was a study in cheap amateurism. Actors who obviously thought they were in Prime Suspect but hadn't got further than an am-dram production of An Inspector Calls emoted for all they were worth (about £40 all in) as interviews with Baker's victims punctuated their woeful efforts. And all of it shot on no-expense-expended video. Were that not travesty enough, an interview with Baker's brother Kevin, who shopped him, was wasted with only a few meaningless soundbites inserted haphazardly. With a little extra dosh and some more foresight, this could have been an exemplary documentary, like Indelible Evidence, or a probing account of Kevin Baker's actions and their repercussions. Instead, it turned out more like Chris Langham's People Like Us.

The producers of Bad Girls (ITV) make much of the fact that they built the biggest free-standing set in Europe, as if that's some indicator of its quality. Actually, all it means is that the characters are more cardboard than the walls which surround them. But within those walls there's an oddly popular mix of high camp, high drama and high-rise tension.

Zandra, a heroin-addicted prisoner made out of the leftover bits from Patsy Palmer, gave birth but was about to have her baby taken away. Obviously this meant taking to the prison roof and wobbling a lot in protest. Helen, the prison governess who is surely heading for a bit of girl-on-girl action with a prisoner, followed her up and talked her down. Linda Henry, so clearly missing in the first series, popped up as a gangster's missus, and Kim Tate from Emmerdale arrived, doing that thing she always does of tilting her head ever so slightly, raising an eyebrow and sucking her cheeks in. This attempt to look enigmatic certainly beats what the rest of the cast must be doing - planting their tongues firmly in their cheeks. Especially when they have to utter lines like "I want to have a look inside that nappy." Stinky stuff.

Cutting Edge: Kiss And Sell (C4) was also pretty stinky, and about as cutting- edge as a plastic spatula. With a distinct Channel 5 flavour to the proceedings, Emma Padfield, a professional "serial soccer shagger" and a woman with a bizarre penchant for Tippex-coloured lipstick, explained the economics of doing it with premier league footballers, while another Emma talked about "how she always wanted to be famous". Tabloid journalists with their eyes too close together meanwhile explained just why they wanted to know about Ruud Gullit's penis (because it's bigger and better than theirs and it gives them a cheap, illicit thrill to think about naked men?)

Once again and oh-so-predictably, it all came back to fame and our unquenchable obsession with celebrity. And their penises. Still, there was a moment when expectations were confounded: when Emma #1 told us she would be targeting Glenn Hoddle with her charms and her Tippex lipstick. Blimey, who would have thought it possible to feel sorry for Hoddle?

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: BASEketball | Piranha | Klute | Silent Movie
fields.body:
BASEketball

(David Zucker, 1998)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

David "Naked Gun" Zucker's goofy sports industry satire is full of slapstick and farts, vomit and kicks in the goolies. But even if bodily fluids aren't enough to make the toughest-stomached viewers go "Awww!", the sight of Ernest Borgnine feeling himself up should. The two dudes play friends who invent a basketball/ baseball hybrid, which, at a time when players get traded more often than their own trading cards, needs the team spirit their game has to offer. A ridiculous movie.

Piranha

(Joe Dante, 1978)

10pm, FilmFour

Snappy horror spoof bearing the bloody-funny hallmarks of executive producer Roger Corman. John Sayles's sharp script chews over the Jaws story in a tale of people-eating piranhas accidentally released into a holiday resort's waterways. Heather Menzies and Bradford Dillman try to hook the little brutes - after they've gleefully dispatched a camp of schoolkids and a lakeful of bathers.

Klute

(Alan J Pakula, 1971)

10.05pm, Sky Cinema

With The Parallax View and all The President's Men, part of Pakula's trilogy of darkly paranoid 70s thrillers. Donald Sutherland's smalltown detective may have the title role, but the film belongs to Oscar-winning Jane Fonda as the assured but needy hooker, Bree, who is being stalked by a violent client, and unwittingly holds the key to the murder case Klute is investigating. Shadowy, taut and intelligent, all the way to the clenching climax.

Silent Movie

(Mel Brooks, 1976)

11pm, Carlton Cinema

Not a classic Brooks, although you have to admire the nerve of the man, his embattled film director reinventing the silent movie in a desperate attempt to save the studio from the mighty Engulf and Devour corporation. There's hardly a word to be heard as he sets to work with zany henchmen Marty Feldman and Dom DeLuise: and if the sight-gags aren't in the Buster Keaton class, it's always fun, with cameos from James Caan, Liza Minnelli, Paul Newman and, most famously, Marcel Marceau.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What clubbers watch on television
fields.trailText: What clubbers watch on television.
fields.body:
Henry B: "I watch Ali G, he's got that new show out but I haven't seen it yet. All my friends are like him, I think, and they watch it, and they never clock. They think he's taking the piss out of their friends. I come from Epsom, and it's just like an Epsom Massive, like the Staines Massive. Totally confused white teenagers who think they're black, really. I live in Tottenham now, so I feel that it's not me he's pretending to be anymore. I like all the gardening programmes - honest, I do. I'm a gardener myself and I like to watch the completely unrealistic plans they have."

Sarah Fortner: "I like Greece Uncovered and all that sort of thing. Puts you off going on holiday, though. I've been to Ibiza and all you meet are tarty girls and these slimy blokes. They don't even like the music. I watched that programme recently on that woman who hated herself... what was it she had? BDD, that's it. She thought she was ugly and didn't like going out."

Gavin H: "I think TV's a waste of time. I never watch it. Last thing I watched? Probably Countdown."

Kicksy: "I have to say I'm addicted to the news. I've been following the Mayor of London thing. I think it should go to someone like Malcolm McLaren - he'd know what to do with this city, more than Red Ken. Do I know his policies? Er, no, but I don't think that matters. Actually, I had the misfortune of watching Sunday morning TV when I should have been asleep, the other week. I saw that awful pop show with that woman, what's she called. Lauren something. Lauren Laverne, that's it."

Laurence Feltz: "Yeah, I've got the same surname as Vanessa. I've lost a lot of weight recently too, hahaha. Have I ever seen her on TV? No. The thing I like on telly... hum... [Thinks for about ten minutes]. Hih! I saw a porn programme on Channel Five about gay Europeans. Actually, it was quite boring, but it's the last thing I watched."

 Sian Pattenden talked to clubbers at Fabric, London

webTitle: Mission to stop Mir sinking to earth

fields.headline: Mission to stop Mir sinking to earth
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Russia sent two cosmonauts on its first manned space flight for almost a year yesterday in an attempt to salvage the ageing and accident-prone Mir space station from the extra-terrestrial scrapheap.
fields.body:
Russia sent two cosmonauts on its first manned space flight for almost a year yesterday in an attempt to salvage the ageing and accident-prone Mir space station from the extra-terrestrial scrapheap.

Flight commander Sergei Zalyotin, on his first space mission, and flight engineer Alexander Kaleri, on his third, blasted off from the launch site at Baikonur in Kazakhstan on the two-day flight to dock with Mir.

A spokesman at mission control said: "The launch was perfect."

Russia's president-elect Vladimir Putin, keen to stress his commitment to prestige projects, recently reversed plans to scrap the 14-year-old orbiting space laboratory while Mir's 21st century viability was further boosted by the decision in January of a group of American millionaires to invest up to $200m (£125m) in the project to exploit Mir's commercial potential.

The two-man crew boarded a Soyuz-TM-30 rocket and went into orbit early yesterday morning. The 48-hour flight to Mir means they are to rendezvous with the station tomorrow. They are to attempt to repair an air leak and prepare Mir for further manned operations.

Not on board the Soyuz craft, however, was Vladimir Steklov, a Russian actor being trained to fly to Mir to star in a proposed Anglo-Russian feature film set in space. "Expect to see me in the next change of crew," Mr Steklov quipped yesterday at the Baikonur cosmodrome, adding that the film's backers had so far failed to raise the necessary finance for the project.

The American businessmen who revitalised the space station's prospects in January by offering to invest $20m and trying to raise up to $200m for future missions announced yesterday that they were looking for business partners around the world to make Mir fit for space tourism, advertising in space, and for the development of hi-tech products.

"It will be a purely commercial project," said Jack Manber, the president of Mir-Corp, the firm set up by the American businessmen to rent the space station from the Russians.

Mr Manber suggested that he would be unveiling further ideas for the use of Mir later this week after the Soyuz vessel has docked. Possible investors in the Mir venture in cluded the son of an unnamed American astronaut and a celebrity from the world of entertainment.

Mr Manber's associate, the US millionaire Walt Anderson, has talked of Mir becoming a "space hotel." Last summer the Russians put Mir on autopilot as a prelude to its abandonment. The plan was to allow the station to burn up in space before falling to earth.

In addition to the multi-million dollar investment, the election of Mr Putin as president has helped to boost the space station's longevity.

"The reasons for maintaining Mir are convincing, and we will work to put them into action," Mr Putin said last month.

Yury Semenov, the head of RKK Energiya, the company which built Mir and with which Mir-Corp has signed contracts, described yesterday's launch as "a second breath of life for Mir", and said he also expected the Putin administration to put its money where its mouth is and invest almost £17m in Mir.

"We are already preparing a second crew of cosmonauts, but whether there will be a future mission will depend on Mir-Corp," Mr Semenov said.

The prospects for further missions looked rosy, to judge by Mr Manber's declaration that Mir is "an unprecedented space home in perfect technical condition. It simply shouldn't be sunk".

The mission launched yesterday is scheduled to last 45 days but it could be extended if more funding is forthcoming. Otherwise, the station will be returned to autopilot status.

The American businessmen who revitalised the space station's prospects in January by offering to invest $20m and trying to raise up to $200m for future missions announced yesterday that they were looking for business partners around the world to make Mir fit for space tourism, advertising in space, and for the development of hi-tech products. "It will be a purely commercial project," said Jack Manber, the president of Mir-Corp, the firm set up by the American businessmen to rent the space station from the Russians. Mr Manber suggested that he would be unveiling further ideas for the use of Mir later this week after the Soyuz vessel has docked. Possible investors in the Mir venture in cluded the son of an unnamed American astronaut and a celebrity from the world of entertainment. Mr Manber's associate, the US millionaire Walt Anderson, has talked of Mir becoming a "space hotel." Last summer the Russians put Mir on autopilot as a prelude to its abandonment. The plan was to allow the station to burn up in space before falling to earth. In addition to the multi-million dollar investment, the election of Mr Putin as president has helped to boost the space station's longevity. "The reasons for maintaining Mir are convincing, and we will work to put them into action," Mr Putin said last month. Yury Semenov, the head of RKK Energiya, the company which built Mir and with which Mir-Corp has signed contracts, described yesterday's launch as "a second breath of life for Mir", and said he also expected the Putin administration to put its money where its mouth is and invest almost £17m in Mir. "We are already preparing a second crew of cosmonauts, but whether there will be a future mission will depend on Mir-Corp," Mr Semenov said. The prospects for further missions looked rosy, to judge by Mr Manber's declaration that Mir is "an unprecedented space home in perfect technical condition. It simply shouldn't be sunk". The mission launched yesterday is scheduled to last 45 days but it could be extended if more funding is forthcoming. Otherwise, the station will be returned to autopilot status.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.trailText: Farewell of day
fields.body:
Farewell of day

Former defence secretary Tom King, the "quiet man" of the Commons, became the latest Tory to announce he will not contest the next election. The 66-year-old MP for Bridgwater said: "I have been an MP for 30 years and I think that is long enough."

Prediction of day

John Prescott revealed that Tony Blair is likely to take paternity leave, albeit only briefly. Interviewed by Railway Magazine the deputy prime minister said: "I think the prime minister will probably take paternity leave because he's a strong family man. He's not the sort of man who'd knock off work for a month, though, and neither could any prime minister - even if his wife wanted him to."

Today

Commons: PM's questions. Freedom of information bill, report stage. Lords: Debates on potholes, tourism and the rural economy, and conflict in central Africa.

fields.headline: Straw in new secrecy retreat
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw last night offered fresh concessions to critics of his freedom of information bill in the latest government attempt to head off rebellion among disappointed Labour MPs.
fields.body:
Jack Straw last night offered fresh concessions to critics of his freedom of information bill in the latest government attempt to head off rebellion among disappointed Labour MPs.

After backbenchers from all parties campaigning for greater public openness had again lambasted the home secretary for his retreat from Labour's 1998 white paper, Mr Straw told them that he plans to amend the bill - to modify amendments he tabled only 10 days ago.

It did not prevent a series of votes against the bill, as up to 60 Labour MPs pressed for amendments that would help restore the bill to its original "meaningful and significant" model. But the government easily won the night's first test of strength by 339 to 167 votes.

As MPs began a marathon session on the report stage of the troubled bill, rebel MPs pleaded with Mr Straw and his deputy, Mike O'Brien, to "be persuaded by some of the arguments" against what one Tory, Richard Shepherd, called "our extraordinary culture of secrecy".

Mr Straw now says that he has been influenced by the more open plans for freedom of information being devised by the Scottish executive in Edinburgh.

His latest concessions cover the 23 categories of information exempt from disclosure under the bill - where the information commissioner can order public bodies to release documents in the public interest, unless she is overridden.

Ten days ago Mr Straw said the commissioner, currently Elizabeth France, could only be overruled by an elected minister or local councillors. Last night he offered to exclude junior ministers such as Mr O'Brien from exercising that power and confine it to cabinet ministers or the attorney general.

The new amendment, to be inserted when the bill goes to the Lords, would put Britain's freedom of information machinery more in line with that in New Zealand.

Mr Straw refused to drop plans to let local councillors override the commissioner about sensitive local data, on the grounds that such a move would be seen as centralising. He did promise to review the plans later.

fields.headline: Millbank accused over loan claim
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's Millbank headquarters yesterday faced accusations of orchestrating a smear campaign against London mayoral frontrunner Ken Livingstone after Labour-inspired allegations over his financial dealings appeared to have backfired.
fields.body:
Labour's Millbank headquarters yesterday faced accusations of orchestrating a smear campaign against London mayoral frontrunner Ken Livingstone after Labour-inspired allegations over his financial dealings appeared to have backfired.

London Labour MP Brian Sedgemore wrote to the Trade and Industry department permanent secretary, Sir Michael Scholar yesterday, demanding a full inquiry into claims that Mr Livingstone had broken criminal law by using a £40,000 loan from his company to buy a holiday home.

But DTI sources privately downplayed the prospect of an inquiry into the allegations while accountants and company lawyers said it was unclear that there had been any offence, let alone a criminal one.

The loan, made by Mr Livingstone's company Localaction on the advice of his accountant, turned out to be £23,076 rather than £40,000 and was repaid well before the Brent East bought a £168,000 house in Brighton with his partner Kate Allen last summer.

After launching his purple double decker campaign bus yesterday, the former Greater London council leader insisted there had been no breach of company law and said Labour officials had "deliberately or accidentally got the legal position wrong, given it to their closest cronies in the media and now it's blown up in their faces. This must be becoming seriously counter-productive".

A Labour spokesman denied any dirty tricks campaign against Mr Livingstone, while a spokesman for Frank Dobson, the party's official London mayoral candidate, said: "Londoners need to know they have a mayor they can trust to fight for Londoners and not for themselves. How many more revelations are there about Ken Livingstone's outside earnings?"

Meanwhile, Tory candidate Steve Norris yesterday predicted that the mayoral election on May 4 would be a two-horse race between him and Ken Livingstone, with Mr Dobson heading for a humiliating defeat in third place.

webTitle: Treasury may thwart plan for more starter homes plan

fields.headline: Treasury may thwart plan for more starter homes plan
fields.standfirst: More about house prices
fields.trailText: John Prescott is battling to win Treasury backing for a multi-billion pound package to help low-cost home ownership and build thousands of public sector houses.
fields.body:
John Prescott is battling to win Treasury backing for a multi-billion pound package to help low-cost home ownership and build thousands of public sector houses.

Unveiling plans yesterday for sweeping changes in housing in England, the deputy prime minister held out the vison of a social revolution to give more choice when choosing a home to rent or to buy.

His initiative, including other measures to deal with unscrupulous landlords and with homelessness and to give councils a new strategic role, was described by the Tories as "all mouth and no money".

Pride of place in the housing green paper, billed as the most important review in 25 years, is a "starter home initiative" under which key workers in the booming south east, such as nurses and teachers, would be given state aid to buy houses. Mr Prescott told the Commons he was asking housing associations and councils to refine a plan (apparently yet to be costed) "which could involve interest free loans, development grants and other innovative approaches".

Though the scheme has been trailed, it seems clear the Treasury has yet to give a concrete commitment - a point driven home by the shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman. He said a 132-page document merely represented a shopping list for consultation. "How much has been costed, who is going to pay, when is he going to deliver?"

Mr Prescott rounded on the Tories for leaving England with a £19bn repairs backlog for council housing after selling 1.3m homes altogether, but it is clear that he is pitching everything on a cash boost from Gordon Brown in July's three-year comprehensive spending review, which takes effect next year.

This means that the starter homes initiative, along with other ideas floated yesterday, is in effect a commitment for after the general election, a point tacitly acknowledged when Mr Prescott said firm details would be announced "in the light of responses" to the paper and after the chancellor's spending review.

Although it was widely expected that the government would signal the end of council housing, Mr Prescott was more cautious yesterday.

Eight "pathfinder" schemes would be piloted under which the best-performing councils can set up arms-length housing companies and use rental income to borrow on the open market. At present Treasury rules prevent authorities, though not housing associations, borrowing in such a way.

webTitle: Smith to impose windfall levy on TV sports deals

fields.headline: Smith to impose windfall levy on TV sports deals
fields.trailText: Chris Smith, the culture secretary, will today announce a 5% windfall levy on the TV income of all major national sports - not just the football Premiership - as a means of injecting more money into the sports' impoverished grassroots.
fields.body:
Chris Smith, the culture secretary, will today announce a 5% windfall levy on the TV income of all major national sports - not just the football Premiership - as a means of injecting more money into the sports' impoverished grassroots.

The prospect of the top Premiership clubs parting with even 5% of the 2001 bidding round for TV rights, expected to reach close to £2bn over four years, will delight some grassroots sports activists, but will not satisfy MPs and fans who want 10%.

Mr Smith's is to offer such bodies as the Amateur Swimming Association, the Rugby Football Union, the Lawn Tennis Association, and English Cricket Board more powers over how their sports are run and Lottery funds are spent, in return for what critics are calling a "tax" on their fast-expanding TV revenues. He will appeal for between 5% and 10% to be handed over to modernise notoriously amateur sports administrations and to nourish the grassroots and school games, as was proposed by an influential think tank report last summer.

The leading football bodies are poised to create a football foundation in partnership with the government, which will inject matching funds. But Mr Smith is unlikely to be given more than the 5% minimum from what will be the most lucrative auction yet of TV football rights.

A mere 5% will infuriate up to 100 Labour and Liberal Democrat MPs who want radical action to support struggling clubs (some in marginal constituencies) and a football regulator to curb excesses in both wages and marketing of the Premiership. The clubs are offering self-regulation.

Today's move comes as part of the culture secretary's long-promised national sports strategy.

It will also see the creation of Sport Direct - a phone and internet service on availability of sports facilities - and the launch of a sporting audit to establish in detail where facilities are, both public and private, in towns and villages.

Key themes in the much-revised strategy are modernising sports administration, improving school facilities and participitation (two hours sport a week is the government's "aspiration"), and involving more adults in sports of choice. One fifth of sport lottery funding, £50m a year for a decade, will be ringfenced for school sports.

Today's statement is unlikely to address regulation of the Premiership, whose huge commercial power has offended many fans and last December split the members of David Mellor's task force.

fields.headline: 'Slogger' Williams
fields.trailText: Captain Arthur Williams, who has died aged 90, was one of the leading tacticians in anti-submarine warfare during the battle of the Atlantic, where he won three distinguished service crosses.
fields.body:
Captain Arthur Williams, who has died aged 90, was one of the leading tacticians in anti-submarine warfare during the battle of the Atlantic, where he won three distinguished service crosses.

Nicknamed "Slogger" for his unremitting hard work and persistence, Williams was the son of a Welsh merchant navy captain. He decided to follow his father to sea and joined the training ship, Worcester, as a cadet. At 18, he became an apprentice with a shipping line and ultimately served as a watch officer.

As a probationary full lieutenant, he was a late entrant into the Royal Navy, joining in August 1938, a time of mounting international tension. The same year he married Jessie Christine Hart, and then applied for anti-submarine warfare (ASW) training at HMS Osprey, Portland, in 1940.

His timing was impeccable. The Admiralty was just waking up to the renewal of the U-boat threat, which naval commanders fondly imagined had been checked by the invention of active underwater detection in 1918. But the German capture of French Atlantic naval bases in 1940 had enormously enhanced enemy submarine activity, and U-boats were soon making serious inroads into British merchant shipping.

Meanwhile, Williams proved such an adept pupil that, on completion of his training, he was immediately posted as an instructor at HMS Nimrod, the ASW school at Campbeltown, Argyll, for a year. He proved just as effective in practice as he had in theory. Appointed first lieutenant on the destroyer, Wanderer, in 1941, his duties included acting as ASW officer for the 3rd escort group, led by Captain St George Orpen.

On August 2 that year, the group was escorting a homeward-bound convoy, SL 81, from Sierra Leone, when it was detected by German intelligence. Ten U-boats converged on the shipping, which was protected by three destroyers and eight corvettes from the 3rd and 7th escort groups. In a four-day battle involving aircraft on both sides, seven freighters were sunk, but Williams oversaw the destruction of the German submarine U401 south-west of Ireland by Wanderer, another destroyer and a corvette. When St George Orpen was transferred to the destroyer Hesperus, he asked that Williams accompany him.

Slated for a DSC in the 1943 new year honours, Williams managed to win a bar to the decoration before the original award became official. Two destroyers and six corvettes, under the command of Captain Donald Macintyre, were covering fast-convoy HX219 en route from Nova Scotia to Britain, when it was sighted by U357 north-west of Ireland.

The submarine's radio report to U-boat headquarters was detected by the escorts, and Hesperus, with another destroyer, hunted the boat for five hours. Eventually, depth charges forced it to the surface, whereupon both escorts rammed and sank it. 'Slogger' Williams was decorated a second time for his key role in the hunt. Two other U-boats turned away without attacking.

Soon afterwards, Williams took charge of ASW training ashore at Londonderry, before taking up his first command, on the destroyer HMS Bulldog, which helped to escort convoys across the Atlantic and on the Arctic route to Russia.

Covering the Normandy landings in June 1944, Bulldog single-handedly sank U719, a coup which won Williams his third DSC. By the end of the war, he was commanding the 20th escort group on the Russian route.

Postwar, he remained in the navy, serving as executive officer on a cruiser for two years until posted to the ASW division at the Admiralty. One more seagoing command, of a frigate in the Mediterranean, ensued before he was given a senior administrative post at Chatham naval dockyard. In 1956, he was seconded to the Royal New Zealand Navy as captain superintendent at Auckland naval dockyard.

Retiring in 1959 at the age of 50, Williams remained in New Zealand, working for 15 years in the engineering industry. He left in 1974 and, at 86, returned to live in Tenby, in his native Wales.

He is survived by his wife and two sons. Arthur 'Slogger' Williams, sailor, born December 28 1909; died December 26 2000
