fields.headline: Robert Hart
fields.standfirst: Gardener with a vision of sustainable forests in the city
fields.trailText: Robert Hart, who has died aged 86, spent a lifetime pursuing his own vision of sustainability - a nation of back gardens filled not with grass, decking, or landscaped water features, but with small, verdant, productive forest gardens, which, taken together in towns and cities, would make up great urban forests.
fields.body:
Robert Hart, who has died aged 86, spent a lifetime pursuing his own vision of sustainability - a nation of back gardens filled not with grass, decking, or landscaped water features, but with small, verdant, productive forest gardens, which, taken together in towns and cities, would make up great urban forests. His legacy is a methodical approach to devising gardens that provide pleasure, health, home-grown food and spiritual solace.

Hart intended the forest garden - so called because it replicated the plant layers of a forest - to be a "comprehensive answer to two closely related problems: large-scale degradation of the natural environment and the colossal toll of avoidable ill-health". The idea was born out of a quest to relieve his suffering from childhood pain, and that of his mentally handicapped brother, for whom he cared for many years.

Born with difficulty - both he and his mother nearly died - in London, he was the son of an international lawyer and a talented soprano, who rejected her career for motherhood. She was a strong influence on him, as was his grandmother, from whom he acquired a love of the Bible and a belief in miracles through spiritual faith.

Hart was educated at Westminster school, before going to work for Reuters news agency. There he was put in charge of the special Indian mail service, for which he made digests of weekly articles by Mahatma Gandhi. This early discovery of Gandhian philosophy, with its emphasis on a search for truth, stayed with Hart throughout his life. He believed in what he called the science of love, and always tried to overcome adversity through positive thinking.

At the outbreak of the second world war, he and his best friend, Michael Asquith (grandson of the Liberal prime minister), intended to register as conscientious objectors, but after the retreat from Dunkirk in 1940 it seemed disloyal to do so. Thus Hart left Reuters to work as a military policeman, and then in the intelligence service, breaking codes.

Postwar, he became a dairy farmer in Norfolk and Somerset, before making his final home on a smallholding at Wenlock Edge, Shropshire. He worked out his distinctive approach to horticulture in his own garden, and published the results in Forest Gardening (1996) and Beyond The Forest Garden (1998).

In Hart's words: "Forest gardening offers the potential for all gardeners to grow an important element of their health-creating food; it combines positive gardening and positive health . . . The wealth, abundance and diversity of the forest garden provides for all human needs - physical needs through foods, materials and exercise, as well as medicines and spiritual needs through beauty and the connection with the whole."

The model for this practice was the British deciduous woodland, analysed into seven layers - from tall trees, via climbers and shrubs, to ground-cover plants and roots. But the range of suggested plants also encompassed the exotic - such as the Nepalese raspberry and kiwi fruit - and, in fact, anything which would grow productively without disturbing the balance. Hart's system combined fruits, nuts, herbs, salad plants and vegetables in a self-sustaining perennial system without external fertilisers, either man-made or of animal origin, in line with the vegan principles he ultimately adopted.

Following the death of his mother and brother, Hart lived alone in Gandhian simplicity, surviving without many modern conveniences. When I first visited him, fresh from the city, I was shocked to see him washing our dinner pots in the stream that ran by the side of his garden. It was cold and damp, but his obvious frailty did not prevent him from taking me on a long and energetic tour. I saw the winter bones of his cherished garden, and left humbled by its gentle plea for sanity. Robert Hart, forest gardener, born April 1 1913; died March 7 2000

The idea was born out of a quest to relieve his suffering from childhood pain, and that of his mentally handicapped brother, for whom he cared for many years. Born with difficulty - both he and his mother nearly died - in London, he was the son of an international lawyer and a talented soprano, who rejected her career for motherhood. She was a strong influence on him, as was his grandmother, from whom he acquired a love of the Bible and a belief in miracles through spiritual faith. Hart was educated at Westminster school, before going to work for Reuters news agency. There he was put in charge of the special Indian mail service, for which he made digests of weekly articles by Mahatma Gandhi. This early discovery of Gandhian philosophy, with its emphasis on a search for truth, stayed with Hart throughout his life. He believed in what he called the science of love, and always tried to overcome adversity through positive thinking. At the outbreak of the second world war, he and his best friend, Michael Asquith (grandson of the Liberal prime minister), intended to register as conscientious objectors, but after the retreat from Dunkirk in 1940 it seemed disloyal to do so. Thus Hart left Reuters to work as a military policeman, and then in the intelligence service, breaking codes. Postwar, he became a dairy farmer in Norfolk and Somerset, before making his final home on a smallholding at Wenlock Edge, Shropshire. He worked out his distinctive approach to horticulture in his own garden, and published the results in Forest Gardening (1996) and Beyond The Forest Garden (1998). In Hart's words: "Forest gardening offers the potential for all gardeners to grow an important element of their health-creating food; it combines positive gardening and positive health . . . The wealth, abundance and diversity of the forest garden provides for all human needs - physical needs through foods, materials and exercise, as well as medicines and spiritual needs through beauty and the connection with the whole." The model for this practice was the British deciduous woodland, analysed into seven layers - from tall trees, via climbers and shrubs, to ground-cover plants and roots. But the range of suggested plants also encompassed the exotic - such as the Nepalese raspberry and kiwi fruit - and, in fact, anything which would grow productively without disturbing the balance. Hart's system combined fruits, nuts, herbs, salad plants and vegetables in a self-sustaining perennial system without external fertilisers, either man-made or of animal origin, in line with the vegan principles he ultimately adopted. Following the death of his mother and brother, Hart lived alone in Gandhian simplicity, surviving without many modern conveniences. When I first visited him, fresh from the city, I was shocked to see him washing our dinner pots in the stream that ran by the side of his garden. It was cold and damp, but his obvious frailty did not prevent him from taking me on a long and energetic tour. I saw the winter bones of his cherished garden, and left humbled by its gentle plea for sanity. Robert Hart, forest gardener, born April 1 1913; died March 7 2000

fields.headline: Ian Anderson
fields.standfirst: Journalist who exposed Britain's dirty nuclear deeds in Australia
fields.trailText: In June 1993, more than 30 years after the British nuclear tests at Maralinga, in the South Australian desert, the science journalist Ian Anderson, who has died aged 53 of mesothelioma, wrote an article in the New Scientist magazine headlined "Britain's dirty deeds at Maralinga".The article was timed to appear days before meetings between the respective foreign ministers. His evidence played a crucial role in the successful conclusion of the talks.
fields.body:
In June 1993, more than 30 years after the British nuclear tests at Maralinga, in the South Australian desert, the science journalist Ian Anderson, who has died aged 53 of mesothelioma, wrote an article in the New Scientist magazine headlined "Britain's dirty deeds at Maralinga". It was a trenchant, detailed report of the Australian government's protracted negotiations with Britain on sharing the cost of "safe-sealing" waste plutonium.

Hitherto, much of this highly toxic nuclear material had been lightly bulldozed into the soil rather than buried in deep, secure concrete pits. The question became even more urgent when the Trajrutja people of this central Australian aboriginal nation, some 600 miles north- west of Adelaide, demanded - and were promised - the return of their tribal lands.

Anderson's article, backed by an editorial supporting the Australian claim, was timed to appear days before meetings between the respective foreign ministers. His evidence, and the media attention engendered by the material in such a prestigious science journal, played a crucial role in the successful conclusion of the talks.

Anderson was born and raised in the Melbourne suburb of Elwood, and began his career as a reporter on Rupert Murdoch's morning tabloid, the Sun News- Pictorial. In 1972, he became deputy information officer at Monash University, while reading for an arts degree.

He and his wife Robin, a cancer researcher, had married when he was 21. It was a partnership in which Robin would play a key role in Ian's vocation. In 1979, the couple moved to London, where Robin worked for the Medical Research Council. By chance, they found an advertisement in the New Scientist seeking freelance contributions, through which Robin was able to link her scientific expertise to her husband's journalististic skills. Thus was Ian launched on a new career.

In 1982, the couple went to California, where Ian covered Silicon valley for the magazine and freelanced for papers worldwide - including the Guardian - while Robin researched at Stanford University.

In 1990, Ian returned to Melbourne to set up an Australasian edition of the New Scientist; he was appalled at the low standard of science journalism in Australia, and was determined to establish a benchmark of excellence - which he did.

In 1993, he won two Michael Daley awards for his Maralinga articles. Five years later, in 1998, he won the public communication award from the American Society for Microbiology - his subject was the escape of the rabbit calcivirus - and the New Zealand government awarded him two fellowships, one of which took him to the Antarctic.

Ian maintained a lifelong passion for spectator sports, particularly Australian rules football.

He is survived by his wife and two sons.

Ian Anderson, science journalist, born March 8 1947; died March 30 2000

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Philip Hobsbaum writes: Your obituary of the distinguished art historian Mark Roskill (March 30) mentioned his skill with light verse. In fact, he was once regarded as a more than ordinarily promising poet.
fields.body:
Philip Hobsbaum writes: Your obituary of the distinguished art historian Mark Roskill (March 30) mentioned his skill with light verse. In fact, he was once regarded as a more than ordinarily promising poet. His poems appeared in various Cambridge periodicals while he was an undergraduate and, in the 1950s, he was a member of that London group of writers that included Peter Redgrove, Peter Porter and George MacBeth. At that time, he was at work on a sequence of poems, The Passing Of An Era, concerned with an upper-class family living in the early years of the last century.

He produced verse of notable elegance and power, as this stanza may suggest: "My father rode me over the downs in rain/ To pay his tax. I watched that tight-strained wrist,/ Those eyes that rain made damp. Such strains persist;/ I still feel proud of his long fields of grain."

Roskill never collected his verse. It is to be hoped that there is a sufficient quantity to make a posthumous collection possible.

fields.headline: Make Windows transparent
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: With Microsoft pronounced guilty and its share price falling fast, US analysts were looking fairly desperately for the good side of the story. If the judgment was bad for Microsoft, surely it must be good for somebody.
fields.body:
With Microsoft pronounced guilty and its share price falling fast, US analysts were looking fairly desperately for the good side of the story. If the judgment was bad for Microsoft, surely it must be good for somebody.

Surely there must be companies whose shares would rise. Candidates were hard to find. Ultimately, some thought that Red Hat, VA Linux and other suppliers of Linux operating systems would benefit, but in stock market terms these tiny companies are already more overvalued than the dot.coms.

Even Linus Torvalds, the Finn who wrote Linux's small core, thinks the system is three years away from being competitive on desktop and, he reminds us, that is what he said three years ago.

So if there is no realistic competition - as Judge Jackson found - why is Microsoft running scared? Why have some analysts and journalists been suggesting Microsoft is doomed, the PC industry is doomed, and that the tech world is going to be taken over by network computers, high-powered games consoles, television set-top boxes, mobile phones or whatever else happens to be flavour of the month?

It is Microsoft's bad luck to be under attack just after it has beaten off one lot of competition and just before the next lot arrives.

Although Microsoft's Windows won the battle for the PC operating systems market, this was no foregone conclusion. There were half a dozen proprietary suppliers supplying their own hardware bundled with their own software, including the Acorn Archimedes, Apple Macintosh, Atari ST, Commodore Amiga, the NeXT cube and the Sinclair QL.

This is the sort of competition the US justice department seems to want, with lots of pointless duplication of effort and users getting locked in to single suppliers instead of being free to change between hardware brands.

There have also been many alternatives to Windows on PCs, including Digital Research's GEM (Graphical Environment Manager), Quarterdeck's DesQview and Be's BeOS.

The market had lots of choice, it made its choice and it is not the US government's job to try to roll back or rewrite history. It is especially not the US government's job to decide the course of software development by defining what belongs in an operating system, and what does not - unless it is also planning to throw out the copyright laws.

But the question remains: what can be done to control Microsoft while it has a monopoly, and while it struggles for survival against whatever the next generation of technology throws its way.

The US Department of Justice needs to think hard about that, because it seems to suppose that problems of conduct and pricing can be solved by making structural changes - to Microsoft or to the market or both.

From the consumer's point of view, it would be better advised to apply the existing laws that would increase competition.

For example, PC manufacturers and consumers would benefit from published standard prices for Windows, and Microsoft might even make more money out of it.

What is more, if people resort to blackmail and other threats, why not throw them into jail?

fields.headline: Rivals welcome decision
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft's drubbing at the hands of a federal judge was applauded by many of the Seattle company's rivals.
fields.body:
Microsoft's drubbing at the hands of a federal judge was applauded by many of the Seattle company's rivals.

Oracle, one of the world's biggest business software companies, applauded the decision.

"We hope that the remedies ultimately imposed or agreed upon will be commensurate with the seriousness of the violation of antitrust law which have now been determined by the court," said Dan Cooperman, senior vice president, general counsel and secretary of Oracle.

Red Hat, which produces the rival Linux operating system, said the ruling would improve competition in the marketplace and would even ultimately benefit Microsoft.

"It's going to create more opportunities for competitors such as ourselves to negotiate contracts with Dell and IBM," chairman Robert Young told CNN.

"We're creating a lot of interest in the marketplace, but unless our bigger competitor is restrained from doing some of the things it has been doing in the marketplace, it's going to be difficult for us to deliver to the customer."

Mr Young stressed that he did not bear Microsoft any ill will. "The perception is somehow that we want Microsoft users to fail. We want Microsoft users to succeed better than before."

Sun Microsystems said of the court's decision that only a combination of "stringent structural and behavioural remedies" against Microsoft would ensure healthy competition.

"The decision confirms what almost everybody in the world knows - Microsoft is a monopoly that has acted illegally," said Scott McNealy, Sun's chief executive officer.

fields.headline: Japan quick to replace PM
fields.standfirst: Cabinet resigns despite constitutional doubts
fields.trailText: The Japanese cabinet resigned en masse last night, paving the way for Yoshiro Mori, a politican better known for his loyalty than his leadership, to replace the comatose Keizo Obuchi as prime minister.
fields.body:
The Japanese cabinet resigned en masse last night, paving the way for Yoshiro Mori, a politican better known for his loyalty than his leadership, to replace the comatose Keizo Obuchi as prime minister.

Despite uncertainties over the constitutionality of replacing a prime minister who is still alive, leaders of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party said they had to act swiftly to avoid a political vacuum.

"We should not allow any delay in our national policy," said Mr Mori, the party's second in command. "Thinking of prime minister Obuchi, it is a very painful decision. But we must not be ruled by emotions."

Mr Mori is expected to head a new but little changed cabinet that could be appointed as early as today. LDP insiders said it would be a caretaker administration until the next election, which is likely to be brought forward to June.

Mr Obuchi was in a critical condition yesterday, kept alive by artificial respirators in the intensive care unit of a Tokyo hospital. He was visited by his daughter Yuko, who flew back from her studies in Britain.

The condition of the prime minister has deteriorated rapidly since he suffered a massive stroke on Sunday morning. Mr Obuchi is known to be paralysed on one side, but reports that he is brain dead were denied by his spokesman.

Under the constitution, the cabinet can only resign on the orders of the prime minister or when the post is vacant. Mr Obuchi's condition - he is unable to speak but physically present - has created a dilemma.

Cabinet members decided at a meeting yesterday that the post was effectively vacant and they resigned to allow for the appointment of a successor. The LDP will convene today to formally select a replacement, but the choice of Mr Mori is a foregone conclusion.

Faction leaders have already agreed that the 62-year-old party stalwart will stand unchallenged to ensure a smooth transfer of power in the world's second largest economy.

The government is aware that any sudden shift could upset Japan's recovery from recession. Tokyo is also engaged in sensitive negotiations with North Korea, relief efforts for evacuees near the Mount Usu volcano, and preparations for the summer's G8 summit in Okinawa and Kyushu.

With Mr Mori at the helm, government policy is unlikely to change much as he is similar to Mr Obuchi in his low-key style and lack of ideological conviction. A former journalist who entered parliament in 1969, Mr Mori has made a steady progress through the ranks, taking the top posts in education, construction and trade before becoming LDP secretary general.

"This is a dull and boring choice made by a handful of senior party members," complained one LDP member of parliament. "Mr Mori is a caring and loyal man, but no one knows what he stands for."

But that may prove an asset in Japan, where the ability to build a consensus often proves more effective than the "follow-me" style of leadership preferred in the west.

This was certainly the case for Mr Obuchi. When he took power in July 1998, his bumbling speech, lack of economic expertise and reputation as a puppet of the LDP's power brokers made him one of the most unpopular prime ministers in Japanese history.

But in the past two years, his affability and earnestness have won over many critics. His administration has proved remarkably effective in pushing through controversial legislation, including the fastest-ever passage of a budget bill, the implementation of a new security framework with the US and legal recognition of the national flag and anthem.

fields.headline: Joel the giant killer
fields.standfirst:
From the outside, the battle against Microsoft's monopoly looked like a showdown between government and big business. But behind it lay a very personal crusade by a softly spoken, balding lawyer. Jane Martinson and Gary Younge chart the rise of Joel Klein, the boy from Queens who humbled the world's wealthiest man
Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: From the outside, the battle against Microsoft's monopoly looked like a showdown between government and big business. But behind it lay a very personal crusade by a softly spoken, balding lawyer. Jane Martinson and Gary Younge chart the rise of Joel Klein, the boy from Queens who humbled the world's wealthiest man.
fields.body:
Joel Klein takes no prisoners. The head of the US government's monopoly-busting anti-trust division fights hard and fights to win. But he is no bully either - he fights clean and he likes to pick on opponents who are bigger than him. And as Bill Gates is now discovering to his chagrin, he has a nasty habit of winning.

When the verdict was handed down against Microsoft on Monday he spoke not like a civil servant who has done a commendable job, but with the zeal of an activist who has just won a campaign. "This landmark opinion - and in the history of anti-trust, this is indeed a landmark opinion - will set the ground rules for enforcement in the information age," he said. "It demonstrates once again that no company, no matter how big or how powerful, can refuse to play by the rules."

The battle against Microsoft's monopoly has been portrayed as a straight showdown between government and commerce. It is a depiction that suits both sides well. Microsoft gets to play the aggrieved business struggling against an anti-entrepreneurial state. Meanwhile the government gets to look as though it is striking a populist blow against bad practice and monopoly.

But it was in the end a fight between one softly spoken, bald-headed man and big business. The 53-year-old son of a Brooklyn postman has been here before. Klein is the most successful entrepreneur in the US federal bureaucracy - the pen pusher who turned the justice department's anti-trust unit into an astonishing profit centre for the treasury by collecting more than $750m in fines over two years, mostly from European monopolists. This is the man who blocked the merger of two of the biggest names in the US defence industry, charged a group of the world's largest banks with running an illegal conspiracy to control the international credit card industry and then picked a fight with Microsoft within the space of six months. Now he has felled the wealthiest man in the world.

Klein may not have the sex appeal of Erin Brockovich. But before the year is out the film rights to the legal war he waged against Microsoft will almost certainly be on its way to the big screen.

His contribution was applauded by his boss, Janet Reno, the US attorney general, who described him as "the man who deserves so much of the credit" for bringing Microsoft to its knees. But the praise comes not just for completing the case successfully but for starting it in the first place.

George Carey, a senior anti-trust lawyer in Washington, said yesterday: "Joel deserves a lot of the credit because he had the courage to actually pursue the case."

Klein, who appeared during important parts of the 77-day court hearing against Microsoft, acted as a sort of field general in the campaign. David Boies, the chief prosecutor with a penchant for red meat and cheap suits, was his chief gladiator. Klein limited his appearances to a few post-victory salutes wearing his trademark Cheshire Cat grin and navy blue suits.

But unlike Boies, Klein made his name fighting for the impoverished, the mentally ill and people with learning difficulties. Growing up in public housing in the New York district of Queens, Klein was an unlikely candidate for the Washington in-crowd. When he was appointed chief trust-buster he was treated with the cold suspicion usually reserved for an outsider, because he was thought to be soft on big business.

Some tried to block his appointment. "The only thing Justice would use its enforcement authority on is the merger of Jupiter with Neptune," said Lloyd Constantine, a former anti-trust official. In 1997 Klein was decried as a "weak" choice by the New York Times.

Now that Judge Thomas Jackson has ruled against Microsoft, Klein's critics are concerned about his strength. They worry that he is overzealous and even an enemy of commerce. When asked whether Klein was still regarded as pro-business, Carey, who once worked with him, laughed. "I don't think there's anyone that thinks that any more," he said.

But Klein rejects any claim that his battle against the commercial big guns is driven by ideology. He said he would not kowtow to the public demands for blood at the same time as refusing to bow down to big business. "The public notion of tackling giants, that's a mistake," he says. "You have to look at the particular facts of a case. I'm not here to tackle big corporations or get in the way of economic efficiencies.

"I don't have this overarching theoretical model I'm trying to lower on the economy," he says. "I'm trying to decide each case on its merits, one at a time, not on ideological grounds." He credits mainstream economic thinkers rather than legal or political ones as his great influences. "My thinking is mainstream economic thinking," he says.

However, Klein does have a healthy mistrust of monopolies. At a gathering of computer industry leaders last October, a sensitive time in the case, Klein said simply: "Monopolies have to be held to a different standard because they have monopoly power."

While his motivations may be eclectic, the vigour with which he wages his battles is all his own. His friends, who describe him as both "scrappy" and "sophisticated", believe that his fighting methods highlight his defining characteristics: his immense intelligence and street-smart aggression. When talks broke down with Microsoft, the company's lawyers blamed the politicking local attorney generals rather than the justice department. Yet Klein is on the record as saying that he would rather go to trial than quietly negotiate financial penalties.

Klein started his career by winning a scholarship to Columbia University, where he earned a degree in economics, and then went to Harvard University law school. He was awarded magna cum laude at both. After working with people with disabilities he went on to become a corporate lawyer before breaking off to start his own company. Like many Democrats in the Clinton era, his career took a new turn when he met the president. Klein and his wife, Patsy Davis, were regulars at the "renaissance weekends" hosted by the Clintons in the 80s. In 1993, he was asked to help shepherd a Clinton nomination through the supreme court.

In the two years he worked at the White House he managed to gain a cameo role in the two greatest scandals of the Clinton presidency. During the Whitewater affair he argued that all White House documents implicated in the matter should be made public. It was this viewpoint that would earn him the wrath of the First Lady. And he was the man responsible for moving Linda Tripp, the woman who secretly taped Monica Lewinsky, from the White House, thus provoking her ire.

The fact that he would become even slightly embroiled in both scandals tells us something about the desire of the man to be where the action is. The fact that he survived them both tells us something about his ability to outsmart his detractors.

But his proximity to power, and hunger for it, has not left him without endearing human qualities. Lloyd Cutler, a friend and former colleague in the White House counsel's office, has said: "He's just about the only lawyer my wife likes. He can communicate feelings and read other people's feelings."

The government safely proved that Microsoft was such a beast by simply pointing out that its Windows software is used on more than 90% of the world's computers. fields.bodyText: Joel Klein takes no prisoners. The head of the US government's monopoly-busting anti-trust division fights hard and fights to win. But he is no bully either - he fights clean and he likes to pick on opponents who are bigger than him. And as Bill Gates is now discovering to his chagrin, he has a nasty habit of winning. When the verdict was handed down against Microsoft on Monday he spoke not like a civil servant who has done a commendable job, but with the zeal of an activist who has just won a campaign. "This landmark opinion - and in the history of anti-trust, this is indeed a landmark opinion - will set the ground rules for enforcement in the information age," he said. "It demonstrates once again that no company, no matter how big or how powerful, can refuse to play by the rules." The battle against Microsoft's monopoly has been portrayed as a straight showdown between government and commerce. It is a depiction that suits both sides well. Microsoft gets to play the aggrieved business struggling against an anti-entrepreneurial state. Meanwhile the government gets to look as though it is striking a populist blow against bad practice and monopoly. But it was in the end a fight between one softly spoken, bald-headed man and big business. The 53-year-old son of a Brooklyn postman has been here before. Klein is the most successful entrepreneur in the US federal bureaucracy - the pen pusher who turned the justice department's anti-trust unit into an astonishing profit centre for the treasury by collecting more than $750m in fines over two years, mostly from European monopolists. This is the man who blocked the merger of two of the biggest names in the US defence industry, charged a group of the world's largest banks with running an illegal conspiracy to control the international credit card industry and then picked a fight with Microsoft within the space of six months. Now he has felled the wealthiest man in the world. Klein may not have the sex appeal of Erin Brockovich. But before the year is out the film rights to the legal war he waged against Microsoft will almost certainly be on its way to the big screen. His contribution was applauded by his boss, Janet Reno, the US attorney general, who described him as "the man who deserves so much of the credit" for bringing Microsoft to its knees. But the praise comes not just for completing the case successfully but for starting it in the first place. George Carey, a senior anti-trust lawyer in Washington, said yesterday: "Joel deserves a lot of the credit because he had the courage to actually pursue the case." Klein, who appeared during important parts of the 77-day court hearing against Microsoft, acted as a sort of field general in the campaign. David Boies, the chief prosecutor with a penchant for red meat and cheap suits, was his chief gladiator. Klein limited his appearances to a few post-victory salutes wearing his trademark Cheshire Cat grin and navy blue suits. But unlike Boies, Klein made his name fighting for the impoverished, the mentally ill and people with learning difficulties. Growing up in public housing in the New York district of Queens, Klein was an unlikely candidate for the Washington in-crowd. When he was appointed chief trust-buster he was treated with the cold suspicion usually reserved for an outsider, because he was thought to be soft on big business. Some tried to block his appointment. "The only thing Justice would use its enforcement authority on is the merger of Jupiter with Neptune," said Lloyd Constantine, a former anti-trust official. They worry that he is overzealous and even an enemy of commerce. When asked whether Klein was still regarded as pro-business, Carey, who once worked with him, laughed. "I don't think there's anyone that thinks that any more," he said. But Klein rejects any claim that his battle against the commercial big guns is driven by ideology. He said he would not kowtow to the public demands for blood at the same time as refusing to bow down to big business. "The public notion of tackling giants, that's a mistake," he says. "You have to look at the particular facts of a case. I'm not here to tackle big corporations or get in the way of economic efficiencies. "I don't have this overarching theoretical model I'm trying to lower on the economy," he says. "I'm trying to decide each case on its merits, one at a time, not on ideological grounds." However, Klein does have a healthy mistrust of monopolies. His friends, who describe him as both "scrappy" and "sophisticated", believe that his fighting methods highlight his defining characteristics: his immense intelligence and street-smart aggression. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Guerrillas in Assam give up
fields.body:
Guerrillas in Assam give up

More than 530 separatist guerrillas surrendered their weapons to Indian authorities yesterday, giving up their fight for independence for the eastern state of Assam.

Most of the insurgents belonged to the United Liberation Front of Asom, a group that has fought Indian security forces for more than 20 years. AP, Gauhati

Liberian troops guard border

Liberia has placed troops on the frontier with Sierra Leone on alert after reported attempts by suspected Liberian dissidents to launch cross-border attacks, senior defence officials said yesterday.

A total of 111 alleged dissidents have been arrested in Sierra Leone and rocket-propelled grenade launchers, automatic rifles and assorted ammunition seized. AP, Monrovia

German trains defective

Thirteen high-speed trains were taken off the tracks in Germany for repairs after defective welded joints were found, an official said yesterday. Repairs will also be made to the remaining 46 early-model IntercityExpress trains, said Mark Wille of the Federal Railway Office. AP, Bonn

Signs of big Usu eruption

About 13,000 people were still barred from their homes on the Japanese island of Hokkaido yesterday as ash continued to rain down from Mount Usu.

Hokkaido University geologist Tadahide Uiand other experts warned that there were signs of a "lava dome" developing, which could be accompanied by a massive eruption. AP, Date

Boy holds his class hostage

A 15-year-old boy from Stuttgart held his history class hostage with a starter pistol for an hour yesterday, after the teacher set an impromptu test. Police said the boy took the classroom keys and locked up 18 fellow pupils. He later fled and was arrested at home. AP, Stuttgart

Toxic shock for melon thieves

Thieves who stole 15 tonnes of melons from a farm in southern Spain have been warned that they are covered in a potentially toxic pesticide. The farmer said the pesticide would dissipate as the melons, worth up to 2.3m pesetas (£8,300), ripen. AP, Almeria

webTitle: Court upholds refusal to be father

fields.headline: Court upholds refusal to be father
fields.trailText: The highest court in Massachusetts, ruling in a case that pitted a woman who wanted to implant frozen embryos in her womb against her ex-husband, who wanted no more children with her, has come down firmly on the ex-husband's side, saying that no one should be forced to become a parent.
fields.body:
The highest court in Massachusetts, ruling in a case that pitted a woman who wanted to implant frozen embryos in her womb against her ex-husband, who wanted no more children with her, has come down firmly on the ex-husband's side, saying that no one should be forced to become a parent.

The opinion is expected to influence court decisions around the country in a nascent area of the law: how to treat hi-tech baby-making, and in particular, how to decide the fates of frozen embryos when the couples who have made them separate or divorce.

Such cases have reached three state supreme courts, are pending in half a dozen other states and are likely to become more common as the number of frozen embryos, now estimated at 150,000, increases.

In the Massachusetts case, a woman identified in court as BZ wanted to try, at 44, to become pregnant using the four frozen embryos left from her years of fertility treatments. Her ex-husband, identified as AZ, objected, even though his ex-wife showed seven consent forms he had signed over the years saying that if the couple separated, the embryos would revert to her for implantation.

A family court had ruled in favour of AZ, saying that because the couple had had twins, circumstances had changed too much for him to be held to it.

But the supreme judicial court, in a ruling it made in February but has only now backed up with a detailed opinion, took a big step further. The consent forms, it said, had some problems, but "even had the husband and wife entered into an unambiguous agreement between themselves regarding the disposition of the frozen pre-embryos, we would not enforce an agreement that would compel one donor to become a parent against his or her will. As a matter of public policy, we conclude that forced procreation is not an area amenable to judicial enforcement."

The opinion, by Justice Judith Cowin, said that "respect for liberty and privacy requires that individuals be accorded the freedom to decide whether to enter into a family relationship".

In similar cases, state courts have tended to rule that whenever possible, the agreement a couple signs with a fertility clinic about what to do with their embryos in the event of a divorce or death should be considered a contract. A few legislatures have considered or passed laws requiring such agreements. But the Massachusetts ruling, experts say, indicates that such a contract is far from ironclad.

Couples "cannot assume that one or the other can use the frozen embryos in the event of a divorce in Massachusetts or any court jurisdiction that follows Massachusetts", said Susan Crockin, a lawyer specialising in reproductive technology. The New York Times

webTitle: Lassa fever kills man in Germany

fields.headline: Lassa fever kills man in Germany
fields.trailText: A 57-year-old Nigerian man with Lassa fever, evacuated to Germany for treatment eight days ago, has died of the tropical disease, officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
A 57-year-old Nigerian man with Lassa fever, evacuated to Germany for treatment eight days ago, has died of the tropical disease, officials said yesterday.

The man, who worked for a German company, was admitted to the Horst Schmidt Clinic in Wiesbaden, where his condition at first appeared to improve before he died on Saturday, a Hesse state official said.

It was not clear why his death was not announced earlier. "All possible protective measures have been taken," said the state social minister, Marlies Mosiek-Urbahn.

She said officials at the state health ministry were available to advise people who might have come in contact with the victim, although experts believe he probably did not infect anyone in Germany.

It was the second death attributed to Lassa fever in Germany this year. In January a 23-year-old German woman died of massive internal bleeding after a week-long battle with the disease.

The art student, who had been travelling in Africa, apparently contracted a new and aggressive strain of the disease, officials at the tropical medical clinic in Würzburg said at the time.

Lassa fever was discovered in 1969 when two missionary nurses died in Nigeria. It is named after the town where the first cases originated. The virus kills an estimated 5,000 people a year in west Africa.

It is transmitted through body fluids or coughing, but not by casual contact.

webTitle: Anti-drugs colonel had role in wife's smuggling

fields.headline: Anti-drugs colonel had role in wife's smuggling
fields.trailText: A US army colonel formerly in charge of running the US military's high-profile anti-drugs effort in Colombia faces up to three years in jail after an astonishing admission that he covered up his wife's illegal heroin smuggling and money laundering activities.
fields.body:
A US army colonel formerly in charge of running the US military's high-profile anti-drugs effort in Colombia faces up to three years in jail after an astonishing admission that he covered up his wife's illegal heroin smuggling and money laundering activities.

Colonel James Hiett is expected to plead guilty to the cover-up charges when he appears in a federal court in New York on April 17. He had previously claimed to be in the dark about his wife Laurie's scheme to smuggle $700,000 (£437,000) worth of heroin into the US from Bogota.

Col Hiett's confession is potentially a huge embarrassment to the Clinton administration, which has just asked the US Congress to approve a huge increase in aid to Colombia, most of which is to be spent on the programmes which the Col Hiett had been heading until he was transferred after his wife's arrest last year.

Court papers show that, far from being marginal to his wife's drug smuggling activities, Col Hiett played an important role in trying to bank the profits from the operations. The couple discussed how to transfer large amounts of cash to the US without arousing suspicion from currency regulators, and the colonel took several actions to launder his wife's proceeds.

On one occasion, as army investigators prepared to search the couple's flat, Col Hiett removed around $45,000 in cash and transferred it to his office safe in the US embassy in Bogota. After his wife's arrest, Col Hiett took the money to the US where he divided it and deposited it in several banks.

At a court appearance in January, Laurie Hiett pleaded guilty to the smuggling plans but denied that her husband knew about her activities. "I never told him what I was doing," she said. Mrs Hiett faces up to nine years in jail when she is sentenced on April 28.

Mrs Hiett has admitted that she posted six packages filled with heroin from Bogota in 1998 to addresses in the US before travelling to New York to collect the profits. Federal agents intercepted two of the packages, each of which contained 1.2kg of heroin.

Mrs Hiett told investigators that she sent the packages on behalf of Jorge Ayala, a Colombian driver for US military commanders in Bogota. Mr Ayala was arrested in Colombia in February and the US is seeking his extradition. Another accomplice, Hernan Ancila, has pleaded guilty to conspiracy to import the drugs.

A probe by the US army's criminal investigation division had cleared Col Hiett of any knowledge of what his wife was up to. But an investigation by customs officials implicated the colonel, and he privately acknowledged his involvement late last year.

Both Hietts insist that the colonel told his wife he did not want to know where the money came from and Col Hiett has not been charged with drug smuggling. Instead he faces charges of misprision of a felony - not telling authorities what he knew about his wife's illegal activities.

"Customs agents have suspected for some time that US Army Col James Hiett had knowledge of his wife's actions and may have even had some complicity," said the US customs commissioner, Raymond Kelly.

Colombia is the source of an estimated 80% of all cocaine imported into the US, and of a significant proportion of the heroin.

Even before this year's proposed aid package, Colombia was the third largest recipient of US aid, after Israel and Egypt. But the $1.6bn planned for this year represents a five-fold increase on 1999.

Under the package, a fifth of the funds would go on economic and human rights aid projects. The rest would be spent on military equipment and training to support anti-drugs operations and to attack the estimated 20,000 guerrillas engaged in Colombia's civil war.

fields.headline: Mandela accuses 'policeman' Britain
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela, on his first visit to Britain since he retired as president of South Africa last year, yesterday accused the government of encouraging international chaos, together with America, by ignoring other nations and playing "policeman of the world".
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela, on his first visit to Britain since he retired as president of South Africa last year, yesterday accused the government of encouraging international chaos, together with America, by ignoring other nations and playing "policeman of the world".

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Mandela said he resented the behaviour of both Britain and America in riding roughshod over the United Nations and launching military actions against Iraq and Kosovo.

"Tony Blair is a young man I like very much," Mr Mandela said. "But I am resentful about the type of thing that America and Britain are doing. They want now to be the policemen of the world and I'm sorry that Britain has joined the US in this regard.

"It's a totally wrong attitude. They must persuade those countries like China or Russia who threaten to veto their decisions at the UN. They must sit down and talk to them. They can't just ignore them and start their own actions."

Such disregard for international conventions was more dangerous to world peace than anything that was currently happening in Africa, Mr Mandela said.

"Africa hasn't got the capacity to create such destruction of innocent civilians as the western powers have. We have no bombs in the proper sense of the word, except one or two countries, and we have no lethal weapons such as the west has.

"What they are doing is far more serious than what is happening in Africa - especially the US and Britain. It is proper for me to say that."

Mr Mandela's attack follows similar charges this week from fellow African leaders angered by British attitudes. On Monday, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe accused the government of treating his country as though it were still a British colony, while the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, claimed Europeans had long regarded Africans "like gorillas".

Mr Mandela is on a private visit to Britain and Ireland to see friends and to raise funds on behalf of his charity, the Mandela Foundation. He will be speaking at the London School of Economics tomorrow.

He pointed to Britain and America's decision to bomb both Iraq and Kosovo without seeking permission from the UN Security Council. "The message they're sending is that any country which fears a veto [from the UN] can take unilateral action. That means they're introducing chaos into international affairs: that any country can take a decision which it wants."

Mr Mandela even suggested a racist motive behind America's neglect of the UN.

"The US did not do this when the secretary-general of the UN was white. They are doing it now, ignoring the UN under Kofi Annan. And there are many people who are whispering that it is because the secretary-general is black. That perception is disturbing."

Mr Mandela was was reluctant to criticise Mr Mugabe, who he suggested had been unfairly represented in the media.

"The South African press unfortunately are so hostile to Mugabe that they are prepared to say things which we know are not true about him. Simply because he lost the referendum, they think he is going to lose the election," he said.

"The fact that he has lost the referendum may be a blessing in disguise for him. Because Mugabe is a strategic thinker, he's a very capable man. If I have to express an opinion, he is likely to retain power."

He denied that something had gone wrong with the idea of African democracy.

"Clearly there are problems in Africa, but African leaders are rising to expectations. You are having democracy throughout the continent, with a few exceptions."

webTitle: Darling of Italy's left 'spied for Mussolini'

fields.headline: Darling of Italy's left 'spied for Mussolini'
fields.trailText: A betrayal too painful to be true haunted leftwing intellectuals yesterday when Ignazio Silone, the writer who inspired a generation to fight fascism, was accused of being a spy for Mussolini.
fields.body:
A betrayal too painful to be true haunted leftwing intellectuals yesterday when Ignazio Silone, the writer who inspired a generation to fight fascism, was accused of being a spy for Mussolini.

Silone allegedly infiltrated the Italian Communist party and passed its secrets to the blackshirts just before writing the novel Fontamara, which for 60 years has stood as a plea for social justice against totalitarian oppression.

Last night followers were bewildered. Silone's widow said she would sue scholars who published the claim based on intelligence documents in the central state archives in Rome.

"It is difficult for people to believe but it is true. It's there in black and white. Beyond doubt, he was a spy," said Romano Canosa, author of Mussolini's Secret Service, published this week.

Silone became a spy in 1924 and under the codename Silvestri betrayed his colleagues to the dictator's secret police, said Mr Canosa, a historian and a judge.

The motive was neither money nor love but an ideological ambiguity. "He was a complicated man, it's difficult to know what drove him."

The author, who some critics have credited with inspiring George Orwell's Animal Farm, stopped spying in 1930. In a letter to a Fascist functionary, Emilia Bellone, he confessed an existential crisis. He wanted to shed "everything in my life that is based on falsehood and duplicity".

Later that year he wrote Fontamara, a tale about a village's revolt against landlords and fascist thugs sent to enforce unjust laws. The novel's power and beauty made it an instant classic. Mr Canosa suggested the work was motivated by guilt.

Silone's treachery remained a secret after he moved to Switzerland and, with George Orwell and Arthur Koestler, galvanised opponents of totalitarianism with The God that Failed, a collection of essays.

The death of Silone's brother in a fascist jail cemented his status as a favourite of the left. His novel Bread and Wine was hailed as another onslaught on intolerance. The veneration continued after his death in 1972.

Stuart Hood, who escaped an Italian prisoner-of-war camp, fought with partisans and translated Italian literature, was astonished at the revelation.

"It is an extraordinary story, shocking. Silone was an icon of humanistic communism. Fontamara was viscerally anti-fascist, it was deeply empathetic with the peasants. It had a huge impact.

"These claims raise question marks over all his work. Either the accusations are false or Fontamara is false. This will create a lot of sorrow." The case echoes claims that Orwell spied for the British secret services.

Two other scholars, Dario Biocca and Mauro Canali, have made the same claims in another new book, The Informer: Silone, the Communists and the Police.

The veteran commentator Indro Montanelli savaged the claims in the newspaper Corriere della Sera. He said that the first person to be put in charge of intelligence documents in the central state archive was Palmiro Togliatti, head of the Communist party and sworn foe of Silone. It was wrong to put the past on trial.

However Antonella Passarelli, who teaches Italian literature at the American University at Rome, said the accusations could have a profound impact.

"If this is true our interpretation of Fontamara and other works will have to change. We will have to re-read everything and think again."

webTitle: Boxing clever with Bruno and Burundi

fields.headline: Boxing clever with Bruno and Burundi
fields.standfirst: South Africa's former president takes time out from fundraising to talk of his role as a mediator, and Africa's growing independence
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela seemed leaner and fitter at 81 than he was during his time as president of South Africa, as he talked to the Guardian yesterday in Kensington, where he is staying with a wealthy supporter.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela seemed leaner and fitter at 81 than he was during his time as president of South Africa, as he talked to the Guardian yesterday in Kensington, where he is staying with a wealthy supporter.

Relaxing in his customary flowery Indonesian open shirt, he insists that he is enjoying his retirement and the opportunities to speak his mind. But he shows little sign of seeking to interfere with his successor, Thabo Mbeki, as some friends had expected.

Mr Mandela is in London on a private visit - his first since he retired as president last June - seeing old friends and making a speech about Africa at the London School of Economics tomorrow morning. He will then weekend in the country before flying to Dublin to be awarded an honorary doctorate at Trinity College.

While in London, he is raising funds for his recently launched Mandela Foundation by approaching rich businessmen, friends and British boxers, including Frank Bruno. "American boxers have been very generous," he explained, "now it is the turn of the British."

As always, he enjoys harking back to his life before he went to jail in 1962. "Tony [Sampson] and I first met in a shebeen," he told one of his colleagues. But he seemed especially pleased that Frank Bruno was waiting to see him.

He is still much concerned with trying to bring peace to Burundi, where the government of Tutsis, who make up only 14% of the population, dominates the Hutu majority. In 1994, as many as 800,000 ethnic Tutsis died at the hands of the Hutus.

Since retiring as president, he has been mediating in Burundi's six-year civil war. Recently, he has become much more outspoken in his criticism of the president of Burundi, Pierre Buyoya. "We need to be a little bit tough with them," he said yesterday. "It's unacceptable to me, having been in prison for 27 years, to be dealing with someone who has detained without trial thousands of people, some of them for three years."

He has become impatient with the negotiating process and with the number of delegates involved. "The problem there is that you've got small parties, some of them just a man and a wife, with no members. The negotiations are a means of earning a livelihood, and they're not in a hurry for a solution, because it means that all that comes to an end."

He has been in frequent touch with western leaders, including France's Jacques Chirac, Tony Blair and the Foreign Office minister Peter Hain over Burundi. He has special praise for President Bill Clinton, who "made a terrific impact".

"I'm trying to teach Europe how to help matters, how to speak with one voice, so that we would not undermine one another as the west is doing in the Middle East. So far as Burundi is concerned, they're doing very well."

He remains hopeful of a settlement. "Buyoya is a very shrewd chap. These things are sensitive. He does not want a change in the status quo. But I have now moved them, and a breakthrough is in the offing."

But Mr Mandela is much less hopeful about the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where he was closely involved as president in seeking peace. "The Congo was unfortunate. Because when Angola, Namibia and Zimbabwe decided to send in troops to help [the Congolese president, Laurent] Kabila, I made it clear that neither Kabila and his friends nor the rebels and their supporters - Uganda and Rwanda - would win.

"All that would happen was that they would destroy the infrastructure, prevent development, slaughter innocent civilians. They are going to reduce that country to ashes. And after that they will sit down and talk. I said: 'Why can't you sit down and talk now?' and the best thing to do was that the five foreign armies should withdraw."

"They are still there. Kabila's friends say: 'Let Uganda and Rwanda pull out first, because we only went there at the invitation of [the] head of state.' I say: 'It's not a question of who invited you, it's a question of getting all the foreign armies out. The best thing is that all of you should pull out at the same time.' But they did not.

"There is now a decision to send about 5,000 UN troops and South Africa, if she is asked, will contribute a force. But the situation inside the Congo is such that we can't send our army there unless they respect the existing agreement, which they don't. So they would go there to fight, and we're not prepared for that. The UN is not going to send a force as peacekeepers unless there is peace. But the government and rebels together with their allies are now resuming the fighting. It is a problem."

Mr Mandela still sees western powers as complicating Africa's problems by seeking to interfere in their interests. "Many countries are receiving financial assistance from the old mother countries and from the US, and therefore they are not confident enough to challenge them.

"That is a real problem because although some heads of state are outspoken in criticising the vestiges of colonialism, the majority do not want to offend their benefactors and tend to keep quiet.

"Nevertheless, Africa has produced very competent and experienced leaders who are rising to the challenge who feel that the time has come to handle their own affairs without interference, and they are succeeding in that. That is the overall picture, whatever criticisms you may have."

Mr Mandela hopes that, with a Burundi agreement, he will be able to enjoy his retirement fully. "Three other countries have asked me to sort out their problems, but I"m not going to do so," he says.

 Anthony Sampson is the author of Mandela: The Authorised Biography, to be published in paperback by HarperCollins next month.

webTitle: French lose faith in credit card

fields.headline: French lose faith in credit card
fields.trailText: An emergency government meeting was called yesterday to deal with a crisis of confidence in France's management of international bank cards in which foreign-issued plastic is considered particularly vulnerable to fraud.
fields.body:
An emergency government meeting was called yesterday to deal with a crisis of confidence in France's management of international bank cards in which foreign-issued plastic is considered particularly vulnerable to fraud.

Insurance firms have threatened to cancel cover against losses for both French cards, which incorporate a microchip, and foreign issues protected by a magnetic strip.

The move follows accusations by an independent consumer inquiry that fraud was at least 17 times higher than reported by the 175 French institutions that jointly manage Visa, Mastercard and other popular systems in France.

The consumer minister, Marylise Lebranchu, summoned charge card managers, user groups and traders to her office over the alleged mismanagement of the 34m cards issued in France and the failure to protect plastic used by foreign visitors.

An investigation by the consumer wing of the trade union Force Ouvrière, which is strongly represented in banks, claimed that at least £300m a year was creamed off through charge card fraud - 17 times more than admitted by the big banks joint management group, GIE.

Although bankers said the estimate was "a fantasy" and that France had "the safest system in the world", they lost public trust after hackers issued internet instructions on how to make microchip cards that can fool cash machines.

This year, a programmer was given a 10-month suspended sentence for cracking a supposedly unbreakable charge card code and asking for £20m to develop a fail-safe response.

According to Force Ouvrière's spokesman, Charles Riguardati, French banks hid the extent of customer losses by failing to reveal statistics on the cost to foreign visitors using British-style plastic.

"This amounts to at least £220m a year," he said. "To diminish the size of overall criminal losses even further, banks disclose only claims repaid by insurance firms - nowhere near the real level of this type of fraud."

Insurance companies have warned that unless protection is tightened within 45 days they will withdraw cover.

fields.headline: No: 1609
fields.standfirst: Jemima Khan
fields.trailText: Jemima Khan.
fields.body:
Age: 26.

Appearance: Slightly bedraggled supermodel.

Bedraggled? Well, if the stories are true.

What stories? About Jemima's life in Pakistan. Ugh!

I'm lost. And so is she, if Vanity Fair is to be believed. It says her life with husband Imran in Lahore is a living hell. The streets are full of beggars, her husband is broke, her two young children are often sick, and her telephone is always breaking down.

Sounds grim. A change from her father's manor house in south-west London, certainly.

Her father? The late Sir James Goldsmith - millionaire, rightwinger, litigant, famed for living with his wife and mistress.

So why did Jemima leave? You must have seen photographs of Imran - cricketer, icon, sex god.

All-rounder, wasn't he? Indeed - 3,807 runs and 362 wickets in Tests.

I can see why she was smitten. There may have been other factors.

I bet she regrets it now. The tabloids say so, but they've been willing the east-meets-west union to fail since the pair married in 1995.

Why? Beautiful young socialite meets foreigner 20 years her senior who carries her off to a distant land where she has to learn Urdu and wear a veil. It's just not right, is it.

What's Imran's view of her plight? "Struggle is good for you. If people avoid struggle they decay. Life has been very easy for Jemima."

Bit harsh: Imran, who wants to be Pakistan's prime minister, takes a fairly stern view of life these days.

No more parties? Only political.

I thought Pakistan was a military dictatorship. It is, but the chiefs are quite well disposed to Imran.

So things could be worse for Jemima: Don't tempt fate. She was charged with illegally exporting antique tiles in 1998 and had to flee.

Not to be confused with: Tara Palmer-Tomkinson; Tamara Beckwith; Jemima Puddleduck.

Do say: "Let's send a taskforce!"

Don't say: "I didn't know Vanity Fair did bleak third world stories."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The third Manchester United player shown in the main photo on page 36 of yesterday's paper, along with Phil Neville and David Beckham, was Mikael Silvestre; not, as the caption claimed, Quinton Fortune. Apologies for the confusion.
fields.body:
The third Manchester United player shown in the main photo on page 36 of yesterday's paper, along with Phil Neville and David Beckham, was Mikael Silvestre; not, as the caption claimed, Quinton Fortune. Apologies for the confusion.

A photo in our arts section (G2, pages 12 and 13 yesterday) accompanying a piece about UK garage music was not of Artful Dodger, as the caption stated, but of Craig David, a featured singer with Artful Dodger. Apologies to Mark Hill and Peter Devereux (who comprise the duo, Artful Dodger) and to Craig David for the mistake.

Overnight trains from Paris to Madrid leave from the Gare d'Austerlitz, not the Gare de l'Est, as stated wrongly (and misspelt) in a column, Have one on the chancellor, page 20, Monday's paper.

Linda Nazarko, quoted in our report (page 6, yesterday) on the Royal College of Nursing's annual congress, is director of nursing at a charitable nursing home in south London; not "a nursing home proprietor" as we said.

The area of Birmingham which in the past has been flooded with racist hate mail (news story, page 3, April 1) was King's Norton; not the Falcon Lodge estate as was stated.

webTitle: Branson pulls out of phone auction

fields.headline: Branson pulls out of phone auction
fields.trailText: Richard Branson's Virgin Group is pinning its hopes on One2One in the bidding for the third generation mobile phone licences after its own consortium SpectrumCo abandoned the auction yesterday because of the rocketing prices.
fields.body:
Richard Branson's Virgin Group is pinning its hopes on One2One in the bidding for the third generation mobile phone licences after its own consortium SpectrumCo abandoned the auction yesterday because of the rocketing prices.

Virgin has an agreement with One2One to use its network if it wins a third generation licence. The safety net was revealed yesterday after SpectrumCo pulled out of the bidding, with major shareholder Sonera saying the cost was too high.

Sonera was joined by Nomura-subsidiary Epsilon, which also quit the auction. Rupert Murdoch's One.Tel may also be close to throwing in the towel. SpectrumCo's ownership comprised Sonera at 67%plus Virgin, Tesco and Marconi.Bids in the government's auction for the five licences now total £11.52bn.

Vodafone Airtouch continued its lead with a £2.46bn bid for licence B which contains the largest amount of spectrum available.

Canada's TIW offered £2.32bn for licence A, with France Telecom backed NTL Mobile bidding£2.18bn for licence C and British Telecom and One2One tied with offers of £2.23bn for licence D. Orange offered £2.33bn for licence E.

webTitle: Union urges MoD to buy British

fields.headline: Union urges MoD to buy British
fields.trailText: Sir Ken Jackson, the AEEU engineering union leader, today calls on the Ministry of Defence to buy British to protect jobs and ensure that the country has a strategic defence manufacturing capacity.
fields.body:
Sir Ken Jackson, the AEEU engineering union leader, today calls on the Ministry of Defence to buy British to protect jobs and ensure that the country has a strategic defence manufacturing capacity.

In a speech to be delivered at a defence procurement agency meeting, Sir Ken criticises the MoD for its willingness to buy from overseas companies.

"It is time for the MoD to work with British industry to meet the country's military needs," he says. "We need a clear policy of putting the UK first, of placing orders within our own shores."

He accuses the MoD of behaving as if providing the best for the armed services and building a national strategic capacity were mutually exclusive objectives.

He cites the MoD's plans to order six roll-on roll-off ferries from foreign shipyards as a perfect example. "We have the capacity to build them here," he says. "Indeed it is crucial to our own shipbuilding industry that we do. But leaks suggest that the order will be exported overseas.

"That undermines our own shipyards and places many jobs on the line. It's a disgraceful example of procurement policy at its worst. The MoD should look closely at its procurement objectives."

He stresses that the buy-British policy was not just about protecting the 150,000 jobs in Britain's defence industry. "It's about building a capacity that meets our needs," he says.

He praises the multinational Airbus venture and says it should continue. "Airbus has created many thousands of UK jobs and it is meeting both military and commercial needs around the world," he says. "It is a partnership that has been a huge success."

fields.headline: Gresham directors resign
fields.trailText: Gresham, the computer support group, was in turmoil last night as its chairman and two directors resigned, along with its merchant bank and stockbroker.
fields.body:
Gresham, the computer support group, was in turmoil last night as its chairman and two directors resigned, along with its merchant bank and stockbroker.

The crisis was triggered by rejection of the restructuring programme put forward by the troubled company's new-broom chief executive, Bill Simpson.

It was not clear last night whether Mr Simpson, who was appointed only in December, was still with the company.

Gresham's shares, which stood as high as 189p just over a year ago, yesterday lost another 2p, dropping to 36p.

The chairman, Roger Graham has resigned, as have two other non-executive directors, Peter Bickerton and Clifford Jakes.

The company's financial adviser, the Close Brothers merchant bank, and its stockbroker, SG Securities, have also resigned.

It seems that Mr Simpson's strategy of selling off some businesses and concentrating on three main areas - website testing, e-business software design and financial systems consultancy - failed to win support from two major director-shareholders, Sid Green, with 30.6%, and Steve Purchase, with 15.1%.

Mr Simpson, who joined Gresham in June last year, is thought to have planned a sale of the US data storage business and its computer personnel subsidiary. He was formerly with both British computer group ICL and America's IBM group.

Mr Jakes joined the board in September.

In February, Gresham announced losses of £864,000 for the year to October 31 1999, against profits the previous year of £3,003,000.

Mr Graham said that escalating costs and sluggish growth had helped tip the group into the red.

He described the results as "extremely disappointing", adding that fears for the millennium bug had choked off business as clients put major projects to one side until after the new year celebrations.

In December, Gresham disappointed fans of speedway motorcycle racing by announcing that it would not be renewing its sponsorship of the Oxford team, which is owned by Mr Purchase.

Gresham had previously supported the team to the tune of about £50,000 a year.

webTitle: Vodafone and Bell to spin off mobile unit

fields.headline: Vodafone and Bell to spin off mobile unit
fields.trailText: Vodafone AirTouch and Bell Atlantic announced plans yesterday to spin off their US mobile phone arm, Verizon Wireless, in a flotation that could value the division at $150bn (£94bn).
fields.body:
Vodafone AirTouch and Bell Atlantic announced plans yesterday to spin off their US mobile phone arm, Verizon Wireless, in a flotation that could value the division at $150bn (£94bn).

Neither Vodafone nor Bell Atlantic would say how much of their holdings they would sell into the flotation, expected to occur later this year.

Vodafone owns 45% of Verizon Wireless and Bell Atlantic the remainder.

Vodafone and Bell Atlantic also announced a $3bn expansion of the Verizon Wireless network, which already covers 90% of the American population. The expansion will include trials of third generation mobile phone networks this year. The company will also look at expanding its network through acquisitions.

Making Verizon Wireless independent through a public sale is expected to strengthen management decision-making, which has been splintered by joint ownership.

Merrill Lynch analyst Mark Lambert said hiving off Verizon would "crystallise part of Vodafone's portfolio that has not been easy to value."

Verizon is expected to have 24m customers - twice its nearest competitor - once the mobile assets of GTE Corp are included. It also has 4m pager customers.

Bell Atlantic's merger with GTE Corp is expected to be completed by June.

Mobile phone penetration in the US remains low compared with Europe. Analysts predict that US penetration levels of 70% will be achieved only by 2009.

Verizon Wireless has the opportunity to build on this low usage rate but faces a fierce battle against AT&T and Sprint PCS for market share.

"Combining our US wireless businesses with those of Bell Atlantic and GTE positions us to succeed in a market poised for accelerating growth," Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent said. "We also look forward to offering the public an opportunity to participate in the growth in value we believe Verizon Wireless will create for both its parents."

Verizon Wireless was created when Vodafone and Bell Atlantic announced in September plans to combine their mobile businesses.

Vodafone yesterday also reported strong growth of 52% in its global customer base in the three months to March 31.

It said that, before its acquisition of the German mobile phone group Mannesmann, the number of customers grew by 3.5m to 39.1m.

Including customers resulting from the acquisition of Mannesmann, Vodafone' customer base grew by 5.1m to more than 53m.

Vodafone said that of its 851,000 new UK customers connected in the first quarter 839,000 joined the Pay-as-you-talk service, bringing the total number of UK customers for that pre-pay scheme to 5m.

In all, 8.8m people in the UK were using its mobile services, Vodafone said.

fields.headline: Peptide defends 57% rise in losses
fields.standfirst: Bid talks continue despite vaccine specialist's claim to independence
fields.trailText: Vaccine specialist Peptide Therapeutics yesterday insisted it was strong enough to survive as an independent, despite a 57% jump in its full-year losses to £13.6m.
fields.body:
Vaccine specialist Peptide Therapeutics yesterday insisted it was strong enough to survive as an independent, despite a 57% jump in its full-year losses to £13.6m.

The company's production line includes vaccines for yellow fever, typhoid and travellers' diarrhoea. However, it has been weakened by setbacks to several products over the last year.

Peptide admitted last week that it was in preliminary bid talks. Speculation about the identity of the bidder has settled on Cantab Pharmaceuticals, and there were also suggestions yesterday of interest from the US. However, Peptide chief executive John Brown said: "We could stay on our own. We've got very strong finances, a good portfolio and technology which can lead to more products."

Mr Brown said any offer would have to be "one that makes us a more robust company". He added: "It's got to be a good fit. People don't merge to cut costs in this industry."

Cantab also specialises in vaccines, although its products aim to treat, rather than prevent, disease. Its products include therapies for genital warts, cervical cancer and nicotine addiction. Cantab's chief executive, Jurek Sikorski, has said he wants to do deals to build critical mass. Peptide's shares fell 15p to 99p, valuing the business at £78m. Another company mentioned as a possible suitor, Powderject Pharmaceuticals, is not believed to be seriously interested. Peptide's losses were higher because of its recent $20m (£12.5m) purchase of OraVax, a loss-making American vaccines firm. The group's first product, to prevent yellow fever, is to be launched next year, with potential sales of $25m.

But analysts were doubtful about its ability to survive without a deal. Max Herrmann of Charterhouse Securities said: "They're not a viable entity to go it alone. They have about two years' more cash and they'll have a hard time raising more."

 Biotechnology firm Scotia Holdings could target disorders including heart disease after a deal with American group Techniclone yesterday.

fields.headline: Clinton Cards
fields.trailText: It was a red-letter day yesterday for investors in Clinton Cards, who have seen confidence in the family-run business taking a pasting after a profits warning in January.
fields.body:
It was a red-letter day yesterday for investors in Clinton Cards, who have seen confidence in the family-run business taking a pasting after a profits warning in January.

The shares rose over 14% in early trading as the greeting card retailer announced unexpectedly good profit figures for 1999 and said that like for like sales had risen 5.3% in the first nine weeks of the new year.

Clinton also revealed a host of e-initiatives which interested the market.

Lazy customers in future will be able to send personalised cards via the net without leaving their work stations. This might help bring in more male customers, as 90% of those visiting its shops are women.

But the most important news revolved around the figures themselves. Pre-tax profits before amortisation and goodwill rose from £16.1m to January 30 to £17.6m on turnover that was up 22% to £297m.

Not great results, it must be said but reassuring nevertheless, given an extremely bumpy ride during last autumn, when the company warned that earlier optimism about 1999 may be misplaced.

It was general high street gloom that had hit sales, but Christmas brought a turnaround and the company has not looked back - with big buying seen around St Valentines day and Mother's day.

Yesterday Clinton's chairman, Don Lewin, said prospects for the future were very bright, with "plenty of opportunities to grow the business organically".

Clinton Cards has had its ups and downs since its flotation on the market in 1988, but the group has performed fairly soundly for investors over the last four years. The share price steadily climbed to a high of 315p before tumbling down to 100p following the profits warning.

Yesterday it finished the day 11p up at 123p.

Analysts are now forecasting pre-tax profits of close to £20m this year - and the shares, even after the comeback yesterday, still appear to be relatively cheap.
