fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The tussle between the old economy and the new continued in earnest yesterday but by the end of the day the sell off in the once-sexy media, telecom and technology stocks drove the the FTSE 100 to a lower close.
fields.body:
The tussle between the old economy and the new continued in earnest yesterday but by the end of the day the sell off in the once-sexy media, telecom and technology stocks drove the the FTSE 100 to a lower close.

The index ended at 6,427, down 35 points, despite stellar performances by some of the financial stocks which have been shunned of late.

Despite quiet, behind the scenes inquiries by the stock exchange, Legal & General was not required to explain yet another rise in its shares to 180p, taking its gain in just two days to almost 20p. The shares are back towards the levels they traded at when the insurer struck the ill-fated deal with NatWest, now being integrated with Royal Bank of Scotland.

It was a day on which many of the hard-hit financial firms recouped lost ground. Royal Bank put on 65p to £10.11 while Abbey National jumped 10% to close at 938p in a move sources insisted was unconnected to any takeover talks. That sentiment appeared reinforced by statements showing a director had been exercising shares.

Insurance group Prudential was also strongly firmer, gaining 86p to £10.64 while Lloyds TSB was heavily traded and gained 56p to close at 741p. Old Mutual , the South African insurer, gained 4.25p to 148p as its annual report revealed its chief executive Mike Levett took home £1m last year, double the amount he earned the previous two years. The pay deal includes a £207,000 benefits allowance which includes the cost of accommodation in London where the firms shares were listed last year.

Retailing group Boots was another of the companies rejected of late to gain ground, rising 64p, to 591p.

However it was big falls in Vodafone , down 13p to 321p and British Telecom , down 64p to 527p, that ensured the FTSE ended the day in negative territory .

The fall out in technology stocks was reflected in the plight of Psion which lost 564p to £34.16 and chip-maker ARM Holdings which was down 490p to £34.92.

Meanwhile, Reuters lost another 66p to £10.86 - the seventh straight session of losses. Dealers again pointed to the performance of its Nasdaq-listed associate, networking specialist Tibco, which has fallen almost 20%.

Sir Alan Sugar's Amstrad slumped 75p to 222p. The shares have been under pressure since the company unveiled its "e-m@iler," a telephone which promises to bring email and fax capability to the masses, but followers of the company seem to have been heavily disappointed by the new product.

webTitle: GUS hurt by credit data subsidiary

fields.headline: GUS hurt by credit data subsidiary
fields.trailText: Great Universal Stores, the owner of Argos and UK Home Shopping, failed to keep investors happy yesterday after a second half trading update revealed a mixed performance among its main subsidiaries.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores, the owner of Argos and UK Home Shopping, failed to keep investors happy yesterday after a second half trading update revealed a mixed performance among its main subsidiaries.

The share price, which opened at 380p, fluctuated before reaching a low of 358p after it was disclosed that spectacular growth at Argos - which it acquired two years ago - was offset by weaker results from UK Home Shopping and Experian, the company's credit information arm.

Argos posted a 13% increase in profits compared with the last six months of 1998, with new store openings accounting for 3% of the increase and like for like sales for 10%. The performance far outstripped most rivals. Investment in marketing, advertising and e-commerce was said to be behind the increase.

Meanwhile a general decline in the home shopping market, especially in the fourth quarter of 1999, was said to be behind a 5% profit fall for UK Home Shopping, the country's biggest mail order company. Hardest hit were hard goods and clothing, with sales in the latter down 10%. It hopes to turn the situation around and fight off increased competition from discount clothing retailers by using the Argos brand to offer clothing at discount prices.

Percentage figures for Experian were not released, but sales outside North America were reported to be strong.

The costs of integrating information service Metromail, which GUS bought in 1998, and developing Insource, an integrated marketing database, were said to have affected Experian's US profits along with high interest rates at a estate agency division.

However, GUS was keen to add that it expects to see profits from the two subsidiaries coming through.

Most analysts retained their forecasts, posting a profits before tax figure of between £420m and £440m.

GUS hit a high of nearly 800p in 1999, falling 45% over the year and being ranked the second-worst performer in the FTSE 100. The price recovered slightly in January but has continued to struggle since.

The costs of integrating information service Metromail, which GUS bought in 1998, and developing Insource, an integrated marketing database, were said to have affected Experian's US profits along with high interest rates at a estate agency division. However, GUS was keen to add that it expects to see profits from the two subsidiaries coming through. Most analysts retained their forecasts, posting a profits before tax figure of between £420m and £440m. GUS hit a high of nearly 800p in 1999, falling 45% over the year and being ranked the second-worst performer in the FTSE 100. The price recovered slightly in January but has continued to struggle since.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Call for HIPC troubleshoote
The government yesterday urged the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to appoint a debt troubleshooter to speed up the writing off of bad loans to the world's poorest countries. Chancellor Gordon Brown and the international development secretary, Clare Short, called for a new joint Bank-Fund to sharpen the focus of the global effort to give 25 countries a fresh start by the end of the year. "We place great emphasis on countries coming forward at the earliest opportunity to receive interim debt relief because this is the money they need to spend on improving primary health care, providing primary education and basic sanitation," Mr Brown said. He and Ms Short intend pressing for action on the highly indebted poor countries' initiative at the meeting of the Bank and the Fund later this month.

Chancellor Gordon Brown and the international development secretary, Clare Short, called for a new joint Bank-Fund to sharpen the focus of the global effort to give 25 countries a fresh start by the end of the year. "We place great emphasis on countries coming forward at the earliest opportunity to receive interim debt relief because this is the money they need to spend on improving primary health care, providing primary education and basic sanitation," Mr Brown said. He and Ms Short intend pressing for action on the highly indebted poor countries' initiative at the meeting of the Bank and the Fund later this month.

UK tax diverts Cisco Systems
The British tax regime has forced Cisco Systems to look at mainland Europe as an alternative for its expansion plans, says the group. It is planning to create 4,000 jobs but has been put off by the national insurance levy on share options in the UK. "It is a concern," a Cisco spokeswoman said. "But we're working with the government to resolve it." The group's plans have not changed yet, although Cisco would not rule out setting up a major operation in mainland Europe. Recent reports had speculated that Cisco will cut investment in Britain if the government does not make tax changes.

FSA chief warns on liquidity
The City's top regulator yesterday warned that a flurry of new electronic trading systems and exchanges could create a two tier market that would restrict liquidity and hurt investors. Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority, called for a greater debate on market structure while pointing out that it was not the regulator's role to set the market's shape.

Anglo-French clearing deal
The London Clearing House - which acts as a guarantor for London trades - and Clearnet, its French equivalent, plan to merge in a move which will reduce the cost of dealing in financial contracts. The LCH provides the security for most dealing on London's derviatives exchanges and, combined with its French rival, will become the largest such organisation in Europe. The move is driven by pressure from the clearing houses' users, primarily the international banks, to reduce the cost of dealing. The merger may also fuel closer co-operation between the exchanges which own the clearing houses, such as the LME.

webTitle: Art nouveau: sinuous style that swept the world

fields.headline: Art nouveau: sinuous style that swept the world
fields.standfirst: V&A hosts largest display of movement's intricate pieces
fields.trailText: The most startling among 400 objects in the largest exhibition of art nouveau ever mounted has been lent on condition that no salacious comments are made about it.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The most startling among 400 objects in the largest exhibition of art nouveau ever mounted has been lent on condition that no salacious comments are made about it.

An extraordinary armchair by Rupert Carabin, boasting a naked woman carved on the back, is one of the centrepieces of the exhibition, which opens tomorrow at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.

Paul Greenhalgh, the exhibition's curator, restrained himself yesterday, and merely remarked: "That chair should have every schoolboy in London queueing to see this exhibition."

But in addition to the Carabin chair the show brings together jewellery by Lalique, glass by Tiffany and Gallé, furniture by Charles Rennie Mackintosh, paintings, textiles and metalwork from 70 public and private collectors. Many museums have loaned national treasures which have never left their countries before to complete an exhibition of the sinuous style that swept the world in the decade after 1900.

The object that required the most effort to install was the largest and heaviest, the tonnes of wriggling ironwork of one of the famous Parisian Metro gates, designed by Hector Guimard in 1900.

It was bought by a private collector in the 1960s when the city demolished many stations, but it stayed in crates because he could never work out how to put it together.

The V&A staff spent months puzzling over it. The original gates were held upright by metres of supports buried in the ground. Failing digging up parts of the road outside the museum, the curators eventually bolted the gate and railings to a horseshoe of specially forged steel.

A much smaller, but priceless, object nearly gave Mr Greenhalgh a heart attack. The René Lalique jewel of a half-woman, half-dragon fly creature, loaned by the Gulbenkian museum in Lisbon, is the emblem of the show.

Mr Greenhalgh said it was "the icon of its time, the most accomplished piece of jewellery of the 19th century, probably the most accomplished piece of jewellery ever".

He had not realised that the wings and body were articulated until the whole thing flopped in his hand and he thought, for a breath-stopping moment, that he had smashed a piece he described as "beyond value, beyond skill".

The exhibition traces the evolution of the style spread by the new era of mass communication, and killed by it when the critics became bored.

Mr Greenhalgh believes that the violent reaction against its excesses is seen to this day in minimalist architecture and interiors. "If the exhibition has a message, this is it: there is nothing wrong with decoration."

But the Carabin chair, made in 1896 and rejected for an exhibition that year because it was not considered to be a proper sculpture - is from closer to home.

It is owned by a woman in Guildford, Surrey, who normally uses it every day, with an equally startling matching table on which she does her correspondence.

 Art Nouveau 1890-1914, Victoria and Albert Museum, London, April 6-July 30

fields.headline: £1.3bn fight for travel giant
fields.trailText: A battle for control of Britain's biggest holiday company, Thomson Travel, was under way last night after it rejected a £1.3bn bid by a German rival.
fields.body:
A battle for control of Britain's biggest holiday company, Thomson Travel, was under way last night after it rejected a £1.3bn bid by a German rival.

C&N Touristic, the No 2 travel operator in Germany, said Thomson was a failing business that would benefit from merging with a stronger and more profitable company.

Thomson has seen profits tumble during an "annus horribilis" that has disappointed thousands of shareholders. The group floated on the stock market two years ago. It offered a mixture of shares and discounted holidays to potential investors amid a fanfare of publicity. But the company is widely seen to have failed to use its size to attract customers in an intensely competitive market.

A takeover could lead to the closure of Thomson's travel agency branches, job losses and less choice for consumers.

Almost half of the British tour industry would reside in German hands if C&N won control of Thomson, which ran up losses and sacked its chief executive last year.

Thomson runs Britain's biggest holiday airline, Britannia, and owns the travel agent Lunn Poly, giving it a 24% of the UK market. Rival Thomas Cook, which is already controlled by Preussag and Westdeutsche Landesbankof Germany, holds a 22% stake. Both traditional companies are struggling against overcapacity and internet competition.

The travel sector also has been reeling from a catalogue of problems that started with a collapse in demand for late summer holidays last year, heavy price discounting, and poor sales of millennium holidays. But Thomson has been more vulnerable than most because more of its holidays are sold by third-party travel agents. Thomson plunged to a £5.1m first-half loss last year compared with a £5.7m profit for the same period of 1998.

Its shares sank below the 100p mark, bringing pain to many of its customers who had been encouraged to take part in a May 1998 stock market flotation at 170p a share.

The new investors had been offered "founders club" holiday discounts if they took shares in a company that had built up a blue-chip reputation as a private firm.

It was founded in 1965 by the Canadian media tycoon Lord Thomson, and the family still holds a 19.2% stake. Other shareholders include Legal & General, which said last night it would wait to see how things developed before deciding what move it should make.

Thomson threw overboard its chief executive Paul Brett after he insisted the company would keep its market share, whatever the competition threw at it. This triggered a ticket price war that helped consumers with cheap holidays but battered the company's profitability and savaged the share price.

Stefan Pichler, C&N's chief executive, insisted a combination of the companies would bring benefits to employees and customers.

But Thomson, led by its new chief executive, Charles Gurassa, rejected any talks. He said: "The board is unanimously of the view that such an offer, if made, would be wholly inadequate and the board would recommend shareholders reject any such offer."

Phil Davies, editor of Travel Trade Gazette, said Thomson was an obvious acquisition target after a disastrous year. He predicted Europe could consolidate into three main groups: Airtours, Preussag and C&N/Thomson.

"There would obviously be economies of scale and cost benefits but I would be surprised if there were not job losses and the closure of Lunn Poly branches. Holiday prices might not be affected immediately but the big groups will not be diversifying so there will be less choice for the consumer."

Biggest air package holiday companies

Thomson Holidays 5.3m

Airtours 4.5m

Thomas Cook 3.7m

First Choice 3.1m

Cosmos 1m

Virgin 501,000

British Airways 409,000

Kuoni 347,000

webTitle: Manuscript of Bach's last work found in Kiev

fields.headline: Manuscript of Bach's last work found in Kiev
fields.trailText: A manuscript of Johann Sebastian Bach's last work - written for his own funeral as his eyesight was failing - has come to light in Ukraine.
fields.body:
A manuscript of Johann Sebastian Bach's last work - written for his own funeral as his eyesight was failing - has come to light in Ukraine.

The discovery, by an American academic, comes in time for the 250th anniversary of the composer's death in July, an event to be marked by celebrations around the world.

The work is not entirely original. It is an arrangement for double choir, wind and strings of Lieber Herr Gott, Wecke Uns Auf (Dear Lord God, Awaken Us) composed in 1672 by Johann Christoph Bach, Johann Sebastian's uncle.

It was presumably sung at Bach's funeral and burial in the churchyard of the Johannis-Kirche in Leipzig on July 31 1750, when he was given an oak coffin and free use of a hearse. Bach had died, worn out from service to the church and his patrons, three days previously at the age of 65.

In his biography of Bach to be published by Oxford University Press this month, Christian Wolff, the William Powell Mason professor of music at Harvard, told how he found the work in a Bach family archive in Kiev.

He described the motet as extraordinarily expressive. "He is thinking back to the music of the previous generation in his own family and his own children," he said. "Feeling that his end was near and wanting to make contingency plans, he selected a work by his most distinguished ancestor that set to music a traditional prayer text whose words anticipated life after death."

The manuscript is the work of an old man who had trouble forming his letters. The writing is "uneven, stiff, and disproportionately large".

His career produced a catalogue of more than 1,100 works, including about 300 sacred canatas of which 200 survive.

webTitle: Still bolshie after all these years

fields.headline: Still bolshie after all these years
fields.standfirst: Playwright Edward Bond tells  Brian Logan  why he knows better than Sam Mendes, Trevor Nunn and the rest of theatre's A-list
fields.trailText: Playwright Edward Bond tells Brian Logan why he knows better than Sam Mendes, Trevor Nunn and the rest of theatre's A-list.
fields.body:
One approaches a visit to Edward Bond in his own home rather as one might steel oneself for a trip to Bluebeard's castle. One doesn't expect to leave intact. The playwright's "difficult" reputation, as much as the increasing difficulty of his plays, has precipitated exile from the British theatre which his lacerating dramas of moral responsibility - Saved, Lear, Early Morning - once animated. The last time I interviewed him, with the director of his 1996 play Coffee - Dan Baron Cohen - sitting in too, Bond parroted the phrase "I agree with Dan" in response to every inquiry.

This time it's different. Bond is the very soul of courtesy, reserving his ire for the "nonentities" of the theatre world he's left behind and for the injustices of global capitalism he delineates in his new radio play, Chair. Before the tape recorder is even on, he's damning British theatre - specifically the work of Oscar-winning director Sam Mendes, who once revived Bond's The Sea - as "an obscenity", and crowing about the imminent French productions of Coffee and of a new play, Crime of the 21st Century.

His success in Europe is integral to the Bond myth. "The Comédie Française says I'm the most important theoretician of drama since Brecht," he says, before adding, with an immodest shrug, "Well, it's a fact." Chair may be Bond's first radio play ("I wrote it in two and a half days, just like that," he says), but the writer doesn't doubt that our continental cousins will stage it.

About the play - an oblique dramatic poem set in a futuristic dystopia that outlaws community and busses old ladies to their execution - Bond is even more talkative, reciting at interminable length his critique of societies, such as ours, that colonise or cauterise their citizens' imaginations. He decries what he calls "social madness_ the people who went off in 1914 were socially mad; the people who dropped A-bombs on Hiroshima and named the bombs after their mothers, they were mad - there's no other way of describing it. But it's totally acceptable. Why is that so? Because our societies are unjust."

Bond talks in essays. In his grand sweep, he embroils theoretical leaps with which it's impossible to keep up ("when Galileo looked through that telescope, Auschwitz became inevitable") and lucid, if desiccated, arguments. This isn't a conversation, and it takes several interruptions to persuade him to discuss Chair rather than to orate about it. I suggest that the society he envisages in the play is too apocalyptically atomised to credit. "Whatever the economy needs to maintain itself, the government will do it," he replies, tangentially. "That means we are caught in a terrifying dilemma. The natural order says certain things are born, make love, eat and die. The economy says: consume, destroy. Those two things clash, and they disrupt society. So society has become more and more disorientated, lost and destructive."

Bond cites the fear of crime, mass incarceration in the States, erosion of trial by jury. "We're on a treadmill, and the fact that some of the bars of the treadmill are made of sugar candy, and we can lick them as they go round, doesn't make our position any securer. The world of Chair is absolutely possible if we don't learn to describe what's happening to us."

Bond's thoughts on his profession are consistent with his thoughts on the world. "It has become a product," he says of the theatre. "Humanity's become a product and when humanity is a product, you get Auschwitz and you get Chair." It should be theatre's role "to recreate what it means to be human, to redefine our relationship with the world", while the dramatist's problem is "how do you speak sanity to the insane?"

So far, so polemical - but here's the ambition. "It seems absurd in our society to say, 'Well, actually, we could be saved by our theatre.' People would say, 'How bloody ridiculous.' But who did they say was the greatest Englishman of the millennium? What Shakespeare and the Greeks were able to do was radically question what it meant to be a human being. Do you really think that what happens at the RSC or at the National Theatre or in your average television show is doing that?"

This is audaciously idealistic talk - until one remembers that Bond is complicit in his own alienation from the British stage. If he wants to re-invent our "corrupt" theatre, why not fight, or compromise, to have his work performed? If he seeks to inaugurate a new theatre for a wider audience, why write such dense, difficult plays?

Compromise is anathema to Bond, who cites as his heroes "Cézanne, who threw his pictures out of the window, and Michelangelo, who smashed his marbles because he was unhappy with them." Compromise is also unnecessary. "If you engage people on a vital, important level, they will respond. But you can't just go to factory workers and say, "Here's Hamlet." You have to learn the language of Hamlet. It would take time." Time for which the commercial imperative Bond seeks to circumvent will not allow.

In any event, he's constitutionally incapable of a rapprochement with "Americanised" British theatre. "Supposing you went to Holy Communion," says Bond, his nose wrinkling, "and the priest was so drunk he was pissing himself. You'd say, 'This can't be right.' But we do the equivalent on our stages."

The biggest sadness, he says, is that new writers are forced to homogenise. "They cannot go beyond the symptom. They're like Terence Rattigan but with obscenities." The exception is Sarah Kane, who Bond knew and admired, but who "was surrounded by really trivial people", whose work was "trivialised and made pretty" and who was "killed by our theatre".

If he regrets this rupture with the community in which he made his name, he hides it in relish of his own acerbity. At one point, describing how Trevor Nunn has turned the National into "a Technicolor sewer", Bond winks at me, "Put some of those remarks in, please." While the Royal Court considered opening their new building with a revival of Saved, Bond's new work is more likely to be performed by Theatre in Education groups, which he famously adores. "A child of 14 or 15 asks the questions Plato asked," he attests, "and if you engage the child in drama on that level the child is fascinated." The enthusiasm isn't counterfeit: non-institutional theatre meets Bond's need to see theatre having an immediate imaginative effect in a classless environment. Among the chattering classes who frequent mainstream theatre, this rarely happens.

Should we be ashamed of that, and of Bond's assertion that his brand of rigorously investigative theatre "still has a validity abroad that it doesn't have in this country"? Bond's polemics are often justified. Who that loves theatre doesn't wish it were as vital as he demands it should be? Whether his still prolific output could help bring such a theatre about is open to question - a question Chair, which is minor Bond, won't answer.

I think a writer with his uniquely epic faith in the possibilities of drama deserves a platform in his own country, and deserves, not uncritically, to be indulged. But it won't happen. "It's wonderful to be able to sit down and write a play," says Bond, "it fascinates me. The fact that I don't have to go along and watch Sam Mendes direct it," he adds, conclusively, "is a great relief."

 Chair is on Radio 4 at 9pm on Friday.

The world of Chair is absolutely possible if we don't learn to describe what's happening to us." Bond's thoughts on his profession are consistent with his thoughts on the world. "It has become a product," he says of the theatre. "Humanity's become a product and when humanity is a product, you get Auschwitz and you get Chair." It should be theatre's role "to recreate what it means to be human, to redefine our relationship with the world", while the dramatist's problem is "how do you speak sanity to the insane?" So far, so polemical - but here's the ambition. "It seems absurd in our society to say, 'Well, actually, we could be saved by our theatre.' People would say, 'How bloody ridiculous.' But who did they say was the greatest Englishman of the millennium? What Shakespeare and the Greeks were able to do was radically question what it meant to be a human being. Do you really think that what happens at the RSC or at the National Theatre or in your average television show is doing that?" This is audaciously idealistic talk - until one remembers that Bond is complicit in his own alienation from the British stage. If he wants to re-invent our "corrupt" theatre, why not fight, or compromise, to have his work performed? If he seeks to inaugurate a new theatre for a wider audience, why write such dense, difficult plays? Compromise is anathema to Bond, who cites as his heroes "Cézanne, who threw his pictures out of the window, and Michelangelo, who smashed his marbles because he was unhappy with them." Compromise is also unnecessary. "If you engage people on a vital, important level, they will respond. But you can't just go to factory workers and say, "Here's Hamlet." You have to learn the language of Hamlet. It would take time." Time for which the commercial imperative Bond seeks to circumvent will not allow. In any event, he's constitutionally incapable of a rapprochement with "Americanised" British theatre. "Supposing you went to Holy Communion," says Bond, his nose wrinkling, "and the priest was so drunk he was pissing himself. You'd say, 'This can't be right.' But we do the equivalent on our stages." The biggest sadness, he says, is that new writers are forced to homogenise. "They cannot go beyond the symptom. They're like Terence Rattigan but with obscenities." The exception is Sarah Kane, who Bond knew and admired, but who "was surrounded by really trivial people", whose work was "trivialised and made pretty" and who was "killed by our theatre". If he regrets this rupture with the community in which he made his name, he hides it in relish of his own acerbity. At one point, describing how Trevor Nunn has turned the National into "a Technicolor sewer", Bond winks at me, "Put some of those remarks in, please." While the Royal Court considered opening their new building with a revival of Saved, Bond's new work is more likely to be performed by Theatre in Education groups, which he famously adores. "A child of 14 or 15 asks the questions Plato asked," he attests, "and if you engage the child in drama on that level the child is fascinated." The enthusiasm isn't counterfeit: non-institutional theatre meets Bond's need to see theatre having an immediate imaginative effect in a classless environment. Among the chattering classes who frequent mainstream theatre, this rarely happens. Should we be ashamed of that, and of Bond's assertion that his brand of rigorously investigative theatre "still has a validity abroad that it doesn't have in this country"? Bond's polemics are often justified. Who that loves theatre doesn't wish it were as vital as he demands it should be? Whether his still prolific output could help bring such a theatre about is open to question - a question Chair, which is minor Bond, won't answer. I think a writer with his uniquely epic faith in the possibilities of drama deserves a platform in his own country, and deserves, not uncritically, to be indulged. But it won't happen. "It's wonderful to be able to sit down and write a play," says Bond, "it fascinates me. The fact that I don't have to go along and watch Sam Mendes direct it," he adds, conclusively, "is a great relief."  Chair is on Radio 4 at 9pm on Friday.

fields.headline: A lad insane
fields.standfirst: How a spell in mental hospital produced a remarkable new play.
fields.trailText: How a spell in mental hospital produced a remarkable new play.
fields.body:
In 1982 Jon Hough was a happy 21-year-old student with everything to look forward to. Within a year, following the death of his mother and the onset of depression, he had been sectioned and put in a mental hospital. His weight dropped below four stone and he fell into a coma.

He was transferred to the Maudsley hospital, south London, where he stayed for over a year before being discharged with a handshake and the offer of a year's psychotherapy. He might have gone mad; instead he discovered the stage.

With his theatre company Ridiculusmus, Hough produced one of the few high points of last year's Edinburgh festival, an extraordinary two-hander about madness. Now that play, Yes, Yes, Yes, is about to open at London's BAC.

Yes, Yes, Yes is an upbeat title for a piece that while very funny is touched by the sadness of madness. But then, Hough and Ridiculusmus's co-founder, David Woods, want us to embrace the idea of insanity. Madness, they argue, is a social construct. Some cultures and societies revere the wise fool.

This approach may sound simplistic, even flip, but Hough and Woods have earned the right to be funny about madness. While Hough was experiencing his breakdown, the teenage Woods was coming to terms with the fact that at least three generations of his family had experienced mental illness: "It took me a long time to realise that it wasn't normal for members of your family just to collapse upon you in states of severe anxiety."

Five years ago Woods's elder brother, a computer engineer, flew off to China on business. He came back in an ambulance. Nobody knows exactly what happened. But Woods says the family has tried to piece together the story and it seems exhaustion, a dinner involving raw chicken's feet and perhaps a genetic predisposition, pushed his brother over the edge. He now spends most of his time in bed.

Like his grandfather before him, Woods's brother suffers from a condition called florid psychosis, a mental illness that makes the patient believe he has gained unique insights into life. There is evidence that some religious leaders also suffer from the condition.

Hough and Woods play cleverly with the idea of florid psychosis in Yes, Yes, Yes, in which Mr H, an excitable bundle of confused identity, and his manic-depressive friend Chatterjee try to explain the meaning of life through an evening of philosophical discussion peppered with autobiographical touches.

This brief description hardly begins to do justice to 70 minutes that is endearingly funny and combines first-rate physical skill with such superb comic timing that the descent into mayhem seems quite logical, even as everything that could go wrong does. The hapless Mr H loses his money, job, wife and status but remains unfailingly optimistic. His optimism is a complete madness in the face of reality.

The stroke of brilliance is never mentioning the word madness and never setting out to be funny. Back in the early 90s, Hough and Woods's rejection of the gag or punchline was so intense that they ran an anti-comedy club that invited people to do very unfunny routines. "You don't have to try to be funny," says Woods. "The truth is generally hilarious." But he adds that audience response to Yes, Yes, Yes is extremely varied. One performance in Northern Ireland raised not a single laugh; in Dorset almost everyone was crying by the end. When I saw the show in Edinburgh last summer, playing in a room in a VD clinic, the small audience was in fits of laughter.

But the creation of Yes, Yes, Yes has been long and painful, and performing takes its toll too. "I love doing The Exhibitionists [Ridiculusmus's award-winning play about what gallery attendants get up to when nobody is looking], but doing Yes, Yes, Yes is like having to be coaxed out of a dark room," says Woods. Hough argues that the process the company uses to create its shows is akin to having a breakdown: "We go into a room with an idea and ourselves, and for 10 hours a day you delve into yourself. There is chaos and a search for order preceded by depression and boredom."

The pair first began working on the idea in 1994, but Yes, Yes, Yes was really shaped by a trip to India in 1996. They met a swami, who invited them to come to his mission, where they found a community of "ranting men" and other mentally ill patients. The pair stayed for some weeks working with these men, playing ring-a-ring a roses and other games. Some of that strange innocence informs Yes, Yes, Yes.

Later, in Bangalore, they came across a man called MM Murthy, who runs the International Humour Society and believes that laughing brings you closer to God. "It is like a sect and his speeches go on for hours and are full of terrible jokes and puns." Mr M in Yes, Yes, Yes is a close cousin of MM Murthy.

Pitched somewhere between meta-theatre, philosophical treatise and frivolous stupidity, Yes, Yes, Yes suggests the mad are truly sane and that anyone who doesn't recognise that we're all in a mess must be utterly insane. Perhaps it should be no surprise that the company's next show, Say Nothing, is about the Northern Ireland peace process and includes a scene in which two characters face off, each menacingly wielding a chair and trying to determine who will decommission their chair first.

 Yes, Yes, Yes is at BAC, London SW11 (0171-223 2223) till April 16.

webTitle: An Eton boy in the East End

fields.headline: An Eton boy in the East End
fields.standfirst: How Jay Jopling became Britart's most successful dealer. By  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: 'I never knew it could be so... professional," said Steve Martin after having sex with Kathleen Turner in The Man With Two Brains. And that's how you feel after meeting Jay Jopling, the "happening" British art dealer whose central London gallery White Cube is shortly to open a new branch, White Cube 2, in the East End.
fields.body:
'I never knew it could be so... professional," said Steve Martin after having sex with Kathleen Turner in The Man With Two Brains. And that's how you feel after meeting Jay Jopling, the "happening" British art dealer whose central London gallery White Cube is shortly to open a new branch, White Cube 2, in the East End. Jopling sits behind the biggest, barest desk I have ever seen - it has absolutely nothing on it but a phone - exuding a calm discipline that couldn't be further from the out-of-control behaviour of some of the artists he represents, including Tracey Emin and Damien Hirst.

Jopling is an übercelebrity of Britart, a face photographed at every party, the Eton-educated son of a Tory minister, married to Turner-nominated artist Sam Taylor-Wood. If you came straight off the plane from Dallas looking for art to buy, he'd make you feel at ease and give you the pop-history spiel on how the Young British Artists emerged at the end of the 80s: "They had nothing to lose. It was an extremely difficult period, towards the end of the Thatcher years..."

The myth of contemporary British art is one of geniuses plucked from romantic East End squalor. The reason the myth is so powerful is that, as Jopling explains, we are talking about an export market. "Seventy per cent of our sales are outside this country, and America is a big part of that." Getting their knowledge of Britain from TV adaptations of Dickens, American art buyers clearly have no problem seeing London as a place of rat-infested railway arches beneath which gin-sodden street urchins spend their time devising in-your-face conceptual art.

Which is why major art dealers are now moving into east London. The capital is shortly to lure more international art visitors than flies around a rotting cow's head. "Tate Modern's going to draw a lot of people to London," says Jopling.

As Jopling describes his business, it becomes clear that transgressive art is being marketed in a super-organised way. White Cube is, he proudly explains, fearsomely efficient: "We have 18 people working here. We have departments to set up museum shows and liaise with curators, a department to work directly with the artists, a whole archival department. We have a publications department..."

Jopling is the most successful dealer in Britart because he looks after his artists in this systematic way. White Cube even has its own "fabrication" department to help artists realise their ideas. Jopling is the Bill Gates of art dealers, exploiting art as intellectual property. The art market is a virtual one, and Jopling's gallery is, he says, also an "agency" dealing not just in objects but in the slippery stuff of ideas. "Obviously you've got to be able to sell as well, and we've been fortunate in that I've worked with artists who art collectors and museums want to buy. I'm sure it's not always going to be like that."

And there's the rub. You can't doubt Jopling's enthusiasm for what his publicity material calls "the Damien Hirst generation of artists", but when it comes to business, he is already thinking about them as history. "The avant-garde is always shifting. What is the vanguard today inevitably is an acceptable aesthetic tomorrow, or a forgotten aesthetic tomorrow. It's up to history to determine what lasts and what stays. Galleries are generational things, and however much one might want to be permanently at the cutting edge, it doesn't work."

By opening White Cube 2, Jopling has "made a commitment to the generation of artists that I work with". It's the one that emerged in the early 90s, not the one emerging now. So his new space - which opens with a group show of that generation - is a kind of museum where Jopling can showcase this art in the scenic atmosphere of the East End and conveniently close to Bankside, while his West End space continues to show work by new artists.

This is amazing - and ruthless. Recognising that YBA art is history, Jopling is finding a new way to market it. This is what art collectors want to buy, work that has a place in history. Now visitors to Bankside from around the world can take a trip across the river to Ye Museum of Ye Younge British Artists in picturesque Hoxton Square.

 White Cube 2 opens on April 15 at 48 Hoxton Square, London N1 (0171-930 5373).

fields.headline: To be continued...
fields.standfirst: Too many intervals
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney discusses the pros and cons of the interval.
fields.body:
The Dutchman currently in flight at the Royal Opera House doesn't wing it in one straight burst but in three stages, with pauses for refuelling. Wagnerians are used to the opera being performed in a single act, but the ROH does it in three for "safety reasons", according to the management. Michael Varcoe-Cocks of London W6, in a letter to the Times this week, detects a more sinister agenda: for "safety reasons", he suggests, read "financial reasons". The ROH, he complains, has been transformed into "an expensive restaurant providing bites of opera or dance between the courses". He fears the three-interval La Bohème will end up with five ("aperitif, first course, main course, cheese, pudding, coffee").

I'm not much of an opera-goer, but I can sympathise. In fact, one reason I prefer cinema-going to opera or theatre is that I can't stand intervals. I still haven't got over the notoriously short first act of David Mamet's The Cryptogram - you'd only just stuffed your coat under your seat when you were back in the bar arguing about Eddie Izzard's American accent. But it's not so much that intervals shatter the dramatic illusion or break the concentration, I just feel uncomfortable standing around at a loss for intelligent comments about what I've not yet digested.

I know I'm a weak-willed spectator: it just seems reckless for theatres to put temptation in the way of punters like me and provide a break where we can slip out. So I welcome the implicit understanding in cinema that no matter how long or how bad a film is, you'll sit tight to the bitter end.

On the whole, intermissions are alien to cinema-going. The Rio cinema in London is currently showing the three-hour Magnolia in two halves, breaking after reel five of a 10-reeler. It's not done to sell more orange-juice: it's just that the cinema has an old-fashioned "tower" projection system that can only show up to 156 minutes at one go.

Three-hour mainstream films are now so common (The Green Mile; Meet Joe Black) that the studios seem to have developed a touching faith in the capacity of audiences' attentions and bladders. There isn't a natural narrative break in Magnolia, and in a sense, its rather fatiguing relentlessness is part of the appeal. Maybe I could have used that breather, but the film is more effective without it.

The last film I saw with a scheduled break was the 222-minute Lawrence of Arabia, re-released some 10 years ago. The intermission was an integral part of the film's his tory: on its release in 1962, audiences who'd been staring at sand dunes for two hours caused an unprecedented boom in ice-cream sales. But in many countries, cinemas routinely interrupt standard-length films, and in Britain, some cinemas even quite recently used to do it for the confectionery revenue, at the risk of being caught out by the Society of Film Distributors.

The hardcore art-house crowd might recoil at such interruptions, but concessions are often made to the standard rhythms of human attention. Even among legendarily long films, few demand unbroken viewing: Peter Greenaway's 185-minute mock-documentary The Falls used to be billed with the proviso that people could walk in and out. You wouldn't sit watching Andy Warhol's film of the Empire State for eight hours straight, any more than you'd stare at the actual building for that time. Even the notoriously gruelling seven-hour Hungarian film Satantango was shown in New York with two intervals (presumably with gall-and-wormwood liqueurs available in the bar).

Given that we're increasingly attuned to the fragmentary rhythms of video and DVD viewing, it can't be long before Hollywood starts to make films with ad breaks pro-grammed in, or ever more formless epics you can wander in and out of when you get the munchies, or when a car chase goes on too long.

Perhaps the uninterrupted session will soon be for aesthetes only. After all, you don't sit and read a novel without a break (although the late American comedian Andy Kaufman used to drive audiences to despair with uninterrupted recitals of The Great Gatsby). Come to think of it, a non-stop Proust marathon has potential. You'd need the odd break, but think how many madeleines they could shift in the café.

fields.headline: England players given deal ultimatum
fields.standfirst: Hussain upbeat but board tries to twist arms as contract talks reach deadline
fields.trailText: The 12 England players who have been offered central contracts by the England and Wales Cricket Board face the prospect of losing them if they fail to sign by tomorrow night.
fields.body:
The 12 England players who have been offered central contracts by the England and Wales Cricket Board face the prospect of losing them if they fail to sign by tomorrow night.

A source close to the negotiations is adamant that, although all but a few clauses in the contract's commercial appendix have been agreed for some time, a month or more of talks between the Board and legal representatives of the players have brought little shift on some sticking points. It was also made clear that tomorrow is the final cut-off for signatures and that offers could be withdrawn from those who do not agree.

But another source, on the players' side, believes such threats , veiled as they may be, are unhelpful to the process and are designed to do little more than force the hand of the players.

This source added that the players had cooperated fully with the board in the negotiations. In Cheshire yesterday, where the squad have been based for four days of fitness assessment, the England captain Nasser Hussain insisted no problem existed between the parties and he was optimistic the players would meet the deadline.

"This has just been people making sure that everything is done right," he said. "Our advisors have done a lot of work on this, as has the board. But this is a new contract with a lot of things in it and we do not want to sign without digesting it properly. We realise the importance of the stakes at the moment. We are not just going to sign things that players of the future might regret.

"It is them we are thinking of and we want to make sure that they do not suffer because we have signed away without thinking about it. However, although no one wants to be rushed, with an important year ahead, we want to get it sorted and get on with playing."

A clue to the board's thinking came in a terse statement from the ECB's international teams director Simon Pack. "Following discussions with the players and their representatives over the weekend we have issued final contracts to all 12 players and are expecting them to agree to them by Thursday.

"Since discussions first began the ECB has sought to accommodate the players wishes in a number of areas and believes the contract contains substantial benefits over the past and compares very favourably with contracts in other countries."

At issue is the principle of personal image rights, specifically the relatively new and uncharted waters of on-line broadcasting. Presently the ECB owns its TV rights and players take no cut.

However, it is thought that the 12 players are arguing for a percentage of any future online deals, a point that the board is not willing to concede, believing it would set precedents for other areas, including television.

The players, though, have clearly been advised that it is not possible at present to anticipate the impact of online broadcasting and that it would be foolish to sign away rights now and so stymie negotiations in the future, when the implications are more fully understood.

"When you sign something, even if it is only for six months as these contracts are, it is very difficult, we are told, for people in the future to get it taken out," Hussain said.

"So we have to get it right. Really that is all it is. We will get it sorted.

"If there are those who want to dig in, then it could drag on but I don't see that. Certainly it has not got to the stage where there is a stand-off, although I can't speak for individuals and I am not prepared to prejudge that issue. Basically though we just want to get on and play."
